abstract: The savage and bloodthirsty manner in which the traitors have begun this war, and the fiendish resorts which their organs already threaten in its prosecution, demands the closest watchfulness on the part of the Government as to the novel methods of destruction which modern engineering has put into the hands of any one who knows enough to use them.
lead_paragraph: The savage and bloodthirsty manner in which the traitors have begun this war, and the fiendish resorts which their organs already threaten in its prosecution, demands the closest watchfulness on the part of the Government as to the novel methods of destruction which modern engineering has put into the hands of any one who knows enough to use them. Of the loyalty of the engineers of locomotives and steamers it should be particularly certain. While it may be in the power of one loyal man to hopelessly disable an enemy's steamer, without running any unusual personal risk, or to utterly paralyze a locomotive at any moment, without a chance of de tection, prevention or remedy, and thus disconcert all plans of attack and retreat; or to sink a steam vessel or blow up its boilers; or to throw a troop train off an embankment, and still have a tolerable chance of personal safety -- while all this is more feasible in the hands of one or two wise and daring engineers, than the unprofessional public can credit or imagine, we do not counsel this method of offensive warfare, however richly the enemy may deserve any irregular manner of destruction. But we earnestly beg of the officers of regiments that they make sure of their defence against it. Already we hear of the weakening of a bridge in Ohio, a little too late, fortunately, to let the intended train through. But guarded bridges and a track police by no means insure safety. It is a very simple matter for an engine-driver to withdraw some part absolutely essential to locomotion, which cannot be replaced, pitch this vital part into a river while the train is running, and bring a reinforcing regiment, upon whose promptness a victory may depend, to an ignominious halt in the wilderness at midnight -- all without much fear of detection, and with ample chance for escape. Nothing is more easily done by a daring engineer, than to dispose of his fireman, by a pistol-shot or otherwise, arrange an infernal machine to pitch the train over an embankment. reach the rear car with the fatal line, alight without much risk, at a twenty-five mile speed, in a well-known soft spot, and send the doomed train reeling to death and destruction. A locomotive, in good order, may be deserted by the driver, after ten minutes' opportunity to tamper with it, under pretence of repairing or readjusting a part, and left in such a state that the first attempt to start it will be the violent and irreparable rupture of some of the machinery. A locomotive may be backed out of a yard where there are facilities, and half an hour's time for getting it in trim, attached to its train, and started again by its own power, without a drop of water or a coal of fire in its boiler, and with such adjustment that no steam can be generated in it. There are plenty of ways known to engineers to delay -- hopelessly delay -- trains upon which the issue of a battle may depend. We do not propose to publish them for the benefit of any one who can read a newspaper, but they are none the less absolute for all that, and any one whose business it is to guard against them can readily find them out.

abstract: The first letter of Mr. RUSSELL, the correspondent of the London Times, has been received in this country, and as it has been looked for with considerable interest, it will be very generally read.
lead_paragraph: The first letter of Mr. RUSSELL, the correspondent of the London Times, has been received in this country, and as it has been looked for with considerable interest, it will be very generally read. We have little time to bestow on criticism in these stirring times, and no desire to treat Mr. RUSSELL unfairly by judging of his ability to comprehend the grand problem of the American Republic in its present crisis, from the first and sole letter that has reached us.

abstract: REPUBLICAN CENTRAL CAMPAIGN CLUB. At the regular weekly meeting of this Club, last evening, Ex Gov. NOBLE, of Wisconsin, made a stirring speech upon the present crisis, which fully compensated for the absence of Vice-President HAMLIN, who was advertised to address the Club.
lead_paragraph: REPUBLICAN CENTRAL CAMPAIGN CLUB. -- At the regular weekly meeting of this Club, last evening, Ex Gov. NOBLE, of Wisconsin, made a stirring speech upon the present crisis, which fully compensated for the absence of Vice-President HAMLIN, who was advertised to address the Club. He said he was opposed to all reconstruction, and for maintaining the Government as it is, with all its guarantees to all sections of the country. The conspirators at the South were trying the experiment of founding a Republican Government, with a nigger for a corner-stone. This Government was made for white men, and while the result of this struggle might incidentally operate to the weakening of Slavery, and ultimately to its extinction, in a manner which would be safe to both races, yet he objected to the idea, frequently advanced in the excitement of the present hour, that we should enter the contest with a view to exterminate Slavery at whatever cost and sacrifice to innocent persons. He had been frequently asked what the Western people were going to do with the Mississippi River. Now he would inform them that the free navigation of the Mississippi River was of far less consequence to the West than to the South. It was a matter of little importance to the West whether this river was open or not, but to the South it was a matter of life and death. Nineteen-twentieths of the produce of the West now found its way to New-York and Boston Harbors by other routes than the Mississippi River, and it could all come by other routes, with very little detriment to Western interests.

abstract: The schooner S.B. Bailey, Capt. ROBINS, and several other vessels arrived yesterday from Wilmington, N.C., which port they left on the 25th. The Secessionists had entire control of the place, and were carrying things with a high hand. Nineteen vessels
lead_paragraph: The schooner S.B. Bailey, Capt. ROBINS, and several other vessels arrived yesterday from Wilmington, N.C., which port they left on the 25th. The Secessionists had entire control of the place, and were carrying things with a high hand. Nineteen vessels lay at anchor at Smithville, all loaded and outward bound, except two which had cargoes of rice, and were towed back to be discharged: the rice was retained on account of scarcity of provisions. There was not over 20 days' provisions in the town for the regular inhabitants, yet troops wore hourly arriving from the South and the interior.

abstract: All through the loyal States our able-bodied men between the ages of twenty and fifty are springing to arms. The turtle is silent, and the voice of the drill-sergeant is heard in the land.
lead_paragraph: All through the loyal States our able-bodied men between the ages of twenty and fifty are springing to arms. The turtle is silent, and the voice of the drill-sergeant is heard in the land. Of the volunteers who are flocking to the support of the Constitution and the laws, and to the defence of our national existence, a part only will be absorbed by the organized and uniformed regiments which are already subject to the orders of the Governor of each State. There remains a vast, enthusiastic, determined multitude of men, in the prime and vigor of life, eager to be converted by drill, discipline, organization, and uniform into a great army. To these we propose to say a timely word.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches and correspondence this morning give the most complete and comprehensible accounts of events transpiring there which has reached us for some time.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington dispatches and correspondence this morning give the most complete and comprehensible accounts of events transpiring there which has reached us for some time. A feeling of security has now taken the place of the continued depression under which loyal citizens labored a week ago, and as an expression of that feeling the City Councils yesterday passed a series of resolutions, expressing the strongest devotion to the Union, and thanking the citizen soldiery of the North now there, for coining forward so promptly at the call of the Government. Gen. SCOTT, it is understood, is about to proclaim partial martial-law in the District of Columbia and along these lines of railroad which it is necessary for the Government to keep open.

abstract: The steamship Jamestown left New-York on Wednesday morning, the 16th ult., for Norfolk, Va., and arrived at Hampton Roads on Thursday morning. Two light-ships were sunk in the channel.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jamestown left New-York on Wednesday morning, the 16th ult., for Norfolk, Va., and arrived at Hampton Roads on Thursday morning. Two light-ships were sunk in the channel. These, however, did not prevent the Jamestown from going up to the city of Norfolk. There the crew heard that the steamer Yorktown was detained at Richmond on account of the freshet in the river. This report satisfied Capt. SKINNER that there was no obstruction to the harbor, except the light-ships, till the Jamestown arrived at City Point, at 12 1/2 P.M., when the crew and passengers were informed that the ship Argo was seized by the city authorities. As soon as the ship was made fast to the dock, an officer, representing himself to be a Marshal of Petersburgh, ordered Capt. SKINKER, of the Jamestown, to haul down the American flag, which he did. The Marshall then produced a revolver and pointed it at the Captain's breast, saying that he was his prisoner, and that he must go in custody to Petersburgh, the ship to be held, in the meantime, under the control of the authorities. To this Capt. SKINNER objected, and pledged his word that he would take the ship to Richmond. He did this, with the Marshal's consent, the Marshal himself remaining on board. The Captain's object, as he stated, for taking the ship to Richmond, was his desire to visit his wife and family, who resided there.

abstract: The steamer Mount Vernon, recently seized by the Government, and fitted up for special service, has, during the past two or three days, been cruising up and down the Potomac for the purpose of preventing the erection of batteries along the shores and making observations. On Wednesday evening, when about fifty miles down the river, a small boat, containing some fifteen or twenty men, was descried, just as it was leaving the Virginia shore, some distance below. She was signaled; upon refusing to notice which, three shots were fired. This having the effect only to cause the men in the boat to work with renewed energy, one of the large guns was opened upon her. The men, upon this, instantly leaped from the boat into the water, and made for the shore as best they could, on reaching which they made their escape through the woods. The steamer springing a leak just at this point, by coming in contact with some obstruction in the river, was compelled to return to Washington for repairs.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Mount Vernon, recently seized by the Government, and fitted up for special service, has, during the past two or three days, been cruising up and down the Potomac for the purpose of preventing the erection of batteries along the shores and making observations. The men, upon this, instantly leaped from the boat into the water, and made for the shore as best they could, on reaching which they made their escape through the woods. The steamer springing a leak just at this point, by coming in contact with some obstruction in the river, was compelled to return to Washington for repairs.

abstract: To-day the new flag-ship of the Home fleet, the steam-frigate Minnesota, will be put formally in commission at the Navy-yard, Charlestown. She is about to commence one of the most important cruises ever made by an American man-of-war.
lead_paragraph: To-day the new flag-ship of the Home fleet, the steam-frigate Minnesota, will be put formally in commission at the Navy-yard, Charlestown. She is about to commence one of the most important cruises ever made by an American man-of-war. The Commander-in-Chief of the squadron, Flag-officer STRINGHAM, is at present in Boston, waiting orders to sail. He is a native of New-York, and entered the Navy in 1809. He is credited with thirty-six years' active service, of which over twenty-one were spent at sea. The other officers of the ship have also been selected on account of their efficiency.

abstract: Virginia has placed herself in a position that calls for the immediate and very decided action of the Federal Government.
lead_paragraph: Virginia has placed herself in a position that calls for the immediate and very decided action of the Federal Government. During the last week two officers of the United States Navy were arrested by the mob at Norfolk, carried to Richmond, kept in durance three days by Gov. LETCHER, and then dismissed by him with great politeness, and, no doubt, with assurances of his most distinguished consideration. Within the same period a high officer of the Army of the United States, Gen. HARNEY, was taken prisoner from a railroad car in Virginia and detained several days, till he was released, we are told, by the orders of Gen. LEE, of the Virginia army. In the same manner, Lieut. WATERS, of the United States Navy, while escorting a party of ladies from Norfolk to Washington, was arrested in Petersburgh, and carried before an examining magistrate, but discharged. He was again arrested in Richmond by a file of military under command of Capt. WISE. While in their custody, he was threatened with death by an infuriated mob, but on an appeal to Governor LETCHER, he received a permit that relieved him from further molestation during his journey. Now, if Virginia is at war with the United States, it may be very well for her to indulge in these practices, subject, of course, always to the law of retaliation, and to all the other laws of war. Conduct of this description, in times like the present, is, in fast, a declaration of war, and should be so recognized and so punished.

abstract: Though the courtesy of the gentleman to whom they were addressed we lay before our readers extracts from some private letters, written by a NewYorker now traveling in the South.
lead_paragraph: Through the courtesy of the gentleman to whom they were addressed we lay before our readers extracts from some private letters, written by a NewYorker now traveling in the South. For obvious reasons we suppress name, and the more personal portions of the anecdotes We can see from those portions that we print that down to the 20th the highest and most intelligent class in Charleston, among whom the writer moved whilst there, had no conception of what had and was occurring here and throughout the North. How unprepared their minds have been for the reception of the news of the holy, high enthusiasm such as animates us here, can be gathered from that sad exclamation about the enlistment of thirteen soldiers at Chatham street depot on the 16th.

lead_paragraph: The Bridgeport Bank vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company. -- The plaintiff in this case holds about $9,000 of the spurious stock issued by Schuyler, and brought this action against the Company for a refusal to transfer the same. abstract: The steamship Chesapeake, Capt. CROWELL, from Fort Monroe, Old Point Comfort, arrived last night at this port. At 4 A.M. she passed the steamship Baltic off the Capes of the Delaware. She brings home, per escort, Sergeant DELANY and ten men of the United States Army; also, seventeen disabled seamen from the frigate Pennsylvania, who were transferred to the Harriet Lane last night. Among her passengers are Rev. M.L. CHEEVERS, wife and two daughters, late Chaplain in Fort Monroe. He left New-York in 1812, and has resided in the South since then. Mrs. RESSLER, Mrs. Capt. VOGLE, with seven, children. The above are all from Old-Point Comfort. Capt. VOGLE is second in command at Fort Pickens. There are also two men from the Seventh Regiment of Massachusetts. The Chesapeake landed 3,800 bbls. provisions at the fort.

abstract: The guage of war having been offered by the Confederate States, and promptly accepted by the United States Government, it only remains to end the contest by the most desperate and fatal agencies of destruction that the respective parties can command.
lead_paragraph: The guage of war having been offered by the Confederate States, and promptly accepted by the United States Government, it only remains to end the contest by the most desperate and fatal agencies of destruction that the respective parties can command. It is one of the triumphs of art and civilization, that, while they have not the power to change the nature of man and eradicate his passions, they give to his passions such formidable instruments of destruction that wars cannot be lingering.

abstract: The Secretary of War has given authority to WIDDER DWIGHT and GEORGE L. ANDREWS, who have just left Washington, to raise a regiment in Boston for the war. This regiment is to be one of the 25 just called for. It will be under the command of Major GORDON, a West Point officer, who served during the Mexican war. abstract: The first reply to a call to arms brings patriotism and enthusiasm to the service; but not experience and not skill.
lead_paragraph: The first reply to a call to arms brings patriotism and enthusiasm to the service; but not experience and not skill. Our young men eagerly take the field, with some knowledge of military taties and evolutions, but none of active duty in actual warefare, none of the startling terrors of battle; very little practice in marksmanship and in the use of the bayonet. In the hands of the officer the sword is often of no more value than a rattan in a conflict with the expert swordsman -- it would simply invite a speedy death. Nor in such sudden demands for troops is attention apt to be paid to the composition of a perfect army. To such an organization go various departments of service, each auxiliary to the other, and each rendering the other doubly effective. A force which includes no artillery, or omits sappers and miners, for rendering streams and roads passible, or throwing up entrenchments, or which possessed no cavalry for scouting or skirmishing parties, is entirely at the mercy of an enemy employing those indispensable aids. So with regard to a defective commissiariat or quartermaster's department. A defect in either is fatal to all.

abstract: Much dissatisfaction has been caused in the several Militia Regiments by the delay and uncertainty on the part of Gen. SANFORD and the other State authorities. The Seventy-ninth have passed a series of vigorous resolutions last evening denouncing the demolalizing influence of such a course, and declared their intention of applying for orders direct to the President, expressing their desire to be called into immediate service without further procrastination. It having been stated that they were not in a fit condition to leave, they beg to deny this, as they have been properly armed and equipped for some time past.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge INGRAHAM, Andrew J. Hackley pleaded guilty on an indictment for criminal contempt of Court. This plea was put in in accordance with a stipulation between the prisoner and the District-Attorney that judgment should not be pronounced upon the plea until the Court of Appeals shall decide upon the constitutionality of the question propounded by the Grand Jury, for refusing to answer which the indictment had been found. If the question shall be pronounced constitutional the defendant stipulates to answer it, and the prosecution on the indictment will be withheld. If the question is pronounced unconstitutional, of course no sentence will be imposed. The matter is to be tested on an appeal from Judge Barnard's decision on a habeas corpus, in which an application is made for the discharge of Mr. Hackley from his second commitment for contempt.

abstract: The Tribune of yesterday made a very energetic protest against the election of Mr. JAMES LAWTON, of New-Rochelle, to a vacant post in the in the American Institute, on the ground that he is a Secessionist. We are requested to state that this is entirely untrue. Mr. L. was, and is, a Democrat, and while this was a political question, he acted with those who believed the demands of the South to be just. But when the rebels put themselves in open hostility against the Government, Mr. LAWTON, with the great body of his party, come promptly to the support of the Government, and has done everything in his power to make that support effective.

abstract: It will be seen by our Washington dispatches that the Secretary of the Treasury has decided to call for proposals, to be received until the 30th inst., unless the whole should, be sooner taken at par, for about $14,000,000 United States Stock.
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by our Washington dispatches that the Secretary of the Treasury has decided to call for proposals, to be received until the 30th inst., unless the whole should, be sooner taken at par, for about $14,000,000 United States Stock. This call is made under the act of June, 1860, authorizing a loan and providing for the redemption of Treasury notes. There is not the slightest doubt that this stock will be taken up immediately. Matters in and about Washington continue much the same as reported yesterday. The Government now feels itself entirely secure, and no more troops beside those now actually on their way, will probably be required there. This will account for the turning back of some of the Pennsylvania regiments. whose services can be rendered more effective in some other direction. Reports continue to reach the Capital that large bodies of Secessionists are gathering in Virginia preparatory to an attack, but military men express the opinion that there is very little danger of one being made immediately.

abstract: The United States transport Bienville, Capt. GIFFORD, arrived yesterday afternoon from Washington City, D.C., which place she left on the 29th ult., makes the following report. She left New-York April 25, having on board 532 officers and men of the Rhode Island Regiment, with 22 horses. She had smooth weather to the mouth of the Chesapeake, where she arrived on the 26th, at 9 P.M., and lay off all night, and then proceeded up to the Washington Arsenal yard, at which place she arrived on Sunday, at 10 1/2 A.M. She was convoyed up the River Potomac by the gun-boat Pocahontas, and landed the troops, all in good, order. She left on Monday, the 29th, at 6 P.M., and passed, in the Chesapeake, going up, the steamers Coatzacoalcos, Baltic, Keystone State and British propeller Kedar -- all having troops on board, and all the troops in good health and spirits. There were no fortifications on either side of the Chesapeake or Potomac in the hands of the Secessionists. Five thousand troops were to be thrown into Alexandria on Tuesday, April 30, by order of the Secretary of War. The secession flag was flying in Alexandria when the Bienville left Washington. Mr. J.L. MACDONOUGH. Express messenger, brings the mails from the troops in Washington.

abstract: Mr. JOHN SCOTT, a German, who has been employed on board of the steamer Jamestown, recently seized at Richmond, left that place last Friday, He was discharged the same day, and was paid off in Virginia money, which he paid 20 per cent. to get exchanged for New-York bills.
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN SCOTT, a German, who has been employed on board of the steamer Jamestown, recently seized at Richmond, left that place last Friday, He was discharged the same day, and was paid off in Virginia money, which he paid 20 per cent. to get exchanged for New-York bills. The Jamestown lay at Rocketts, alongside the Yorktown. On Sunday week a party came down with eight 12-pounder brass pieces to put them on board the Yorktown, to fit her for a privateer. The movement was countermanded by Gov. LETCHER, on the ground that specific orders had not been received from JEFF DAVIS. Nothing has been done with the steamers, but soldiers are kept on board. A rumor prevailed in Richmond that the Pawnee was coming up with 4,000 troops (!) to demand the release of the stolen steamers, and there was immense excitement in the town. The Richmond troops went down the river fifteen miles to reconnoiter, but they returned again the next day at 5 o'clock P.M., much chagrined at their bootless march. The German Hussars, a military company about three hundred strong, who are strongly Union in sentiment, paraded on Tuesday week, all under arms, but they did not dare to carry the Stars and Stripes, which are only displayed in their head-quarters on Main-street. The Commander-in-Chief visited the quarters of the Hussars, and in order to prevent disturbance the American flag was quietly taken down, but no secession flag was substituted.

abstract: Not an instant should he lost in repeating upon the soil of Virginia the experiment so successfully tried upon Maryland--the presence of an armed force sufficient to put down the mob, now as rampant in the former State as it was a few days ago in the latter.
lead_paragraph: Not an instant should he lost in repeating upon the soil of Virginia the experiment so successfully tried upon Maryland -- the presence of an armed force sufficient to put down the mob, now as rampant in the former State as it was a few days ago in the latter. Reason is returning to Maryland, simply by a demonstration of force, without ready menacing her metropolis, or without firing a gun. The recent election there showed how contemptible, in point of numbers, was the mob that seized upon Baltimore -- not one-quarter of its male population. Yet this miserable minority would have held the city indefinitely had not the strong arm of Government been seen coming to the aid of the law-and order loving citizens. In a week more reason will assume her sway in Maryland. Her public highways will be opened and safe for the unarmed traveler. Commerce and trade will resume their wanted operations. The mechanic and farmer will return to their avocations, while to all the experience of the past ten days will be a horrible dream never again to be repeated.
headline: {'main': 'How to Hold Virginia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How to Hold Virginia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A private letter from Chesapeake City, Cecil County, Maryland, dated April 29, says: " We are for the Union here. We might have had a few Secessionists here some time back, but, I think, the sight of those troops has changed their sentiments. It is thought here that in case Maryland secedes, Cecil County will annex herself to Pennsylvania. P.W.M."
lead_paragraph: A private letter from Chesapeake City, Cecil County, Maryland, dated April 29, says: " We are for the Union here. abstract: To that point, where forbearance ceased to be possible, the great body of the loyal population of the country disbelieved in the approach of war.
lead_paragraph: To that point, where forbearance ceased to be possible, the great body of the loyal population of the country disbelieved in the approach of war. This disbelief was founded upon a just appreciation of the superior resources at the command of the Government, and its ability, by the easiest exercise of its powers, to repress insurrection and restore order, and a doubt whether the madness of the South had proceeded so far as to impel it to challenge the corrective faculties of the supreme authority. But the moment these grounds of doubt and hesitation were shown to be baseless, and war became plainly inevitable, public opinion with a unanimity unparalleled in history, swept to another conclusion, namely, that this war should be as short as the comparative resources of the loyal and rebel powers might authorize. Peace was primarily sought because it rendered practicable an early restoration of commerce, industry and enterprise to their customary channels. But when the hope of peace vanished, universal sense pointed to a short war as the most available path to the recovery of social order and prosperity.

abstract: JEFF. DAVIS, the arch-rebel of the South, is as wary as he is wicked. Let us be well assured of this. There is, for the moment, a lull in his war-notes.
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS, the arch-rebel of the South, is as wary as he is wicked. Let us be well assured of this. There is, for the moment, a lull in his war-notes. His poor tool, the Executive of Virginia, through whose territory alone the United States Government can be assailed in any vital point, ostentatiously declares that he "will not allow Washington City to be attacked from the soil of Virginia!" A mean, false varlet, this LETCHER! He and his adhering portion of Virginia belong to JEFF. DAVIS as completely as Faust belonged to the Devil. And JEFF. DAVIS has drawn the sword, and thrown away the scabbard.
headline: {'main': 'Jeff. Davis and How to Fight Him.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Jeff. Davis and How to Fight Him.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Fourteenth Regiment did not go into the Marine Barracks yesterday morning to quarter, as was anticipated, because the contractor has not yet turned the building over to Government, and there was no one authorized to attend to the matter.
lead_paragraph: The Fourteenth Regiment did not go into the Marine Barracks yesterday morning to quarter, as was anticipated, because the contractor has not yet turned the building over to Government, and there was no one authorized to attend to the matter. The Regiment is now full and ready to march, and the officers and men are anxious to be sent off. To urge the matter forward, Adjutant GILL proceeded to Albany, last night, to see the Governor and obtain, if possible, immediate orders for marching.

abstract: The Massachusetts and other regiments that are reported to have garrisoned Fort Monroe will be at once initiated into the mysteries of regular artillery practice.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts and other regiments that are reported to have garrisoned Fort Monroe will be at once initiated into the mysteries of regular artillery practice. The only school for artillerists in the United States, and one of the best in the world, is at Old Point. The officers who superintend it have traveled all over Europe to complete their military education. On Wednesday of last week there was a grand turn out of all the ordnance in the fort, and a general "heavy metal drill." With such teachers the Massachusetts soldiers, and the present garrison of the Point, may defy all Virginia.

abstract: The Mississippi River is now at its annual flood, and is threatening the low lands of the South. We learn from the St. Louis papers that the Mississippi at that point is very high and rising.
lead_paragraph: The Mississippi River is now at its annual flood, and is threatening the low lands of the South. We learn from the St. Louis papers that the Mississippi at that point is very high and rising. Boats that have just reached St. Louis from New-Orleans report the Lower Mississippi very fall, and a great many plantations below Cairo under water. The Lower Ohio is very high. The Illinois River is out of its banks. The Upper Mississippi is rising rapidly at Keokuk, and swelling slowly from St. Paul down. The "June rise" of the Missouri River has not commenced pouring out its mighty flood, but as the snows on the Great Plains were deep during the past Winter, the torrent will be great when it comes, and the danger of general overflow, when it is added to the already swollen Mississippi, will be imminent.

abstract: We shall be glad indeed when we hear that the Administration has concluded that hostilities exist, and that it has begun to originate measures of national defence.
lead_paragraph: We shall be glad indeed when we hear that the Administration has concluded that hostilities exist, and that it has begun to originate measures of national defence. So far, everything has been done on the suggestion or compulsion of the enemy, or in appeasement of the constant clamor of the people. The Administration has been kept in the midst of surprises, by demands of the country that it move forward. Now let the Administration take its true place, and keep the people surprised by the rapidity and vigor of its actions.

abstract: We hope to hear very soon that Fort Pickens has dispersed the rebels who have been erecting fortifications in its vicinity, and retaken Fort Barrancas and the Pensacola Navy-yard.
lead_paragraph: We hope to hear very soon that Fort Pickens has dispersed the rebels who have been erecting fortifications in its vicinity, and retaken Fort Barrancas and the Pensacola Navy-yard. The Atlantic yesterday brought us news that forces have been thrown into the fort quite sufficient for the accomplishment of this object; and the recent reports of the condition of the besieging force encourage the belief that the Government property at that point might be retaken without any serious difficulty.

abstract: THE SUPPOSED MURDER AT HOBOKEN. The body of the man found in the water near the Elysian Fields, who had been shot and stabbed was identified. yesterday, by a man who boarded in the same house with deceased in New-York. His name was R. GATTI, a native of Germany.
lead_paragraph: THE SUPPOSED MURDER AT HOBOKEN. -- The body of the man found in the water, near the Elysian Fields, who had been shot and stabbed was identified. yesterday, by a man who boarded in the same house with deceased in New-York. His name was R. GATTI, a native of Germany. Who deceased went out on Sunday last, he had with him a valuable gold watch and about $20 in money Coroner BOHNSTEDT adjourned the inquest todays (Friday) afternoon, at 11 o'clock, in order to procure further evidence.

On this continent, we are now marshaling a host greater, perhaps, than he brought into the field, to fight, like France, for an idea -- the paramount authority of the Federal Government; the seceding States denying this authority -- the loyal States affirming it.

lead_paragraph: The Union Defence Committee has just held an interesting correspondence with Gen. WOOL, in consequence of the reception of orders from Gen. SCOTT for Gen. WOOL to return to the discharge of his routine duties at Troy. The Committee has received important aid in the discharge of their duties, from Gen. WOOL, and they believe that it has been mainly through his energetic efforts that the Committee has been enabled to carry out its plans in forwarding troops and keeping them well supplied.

abstract: Yesterday, at 2 P.M., a Convention of Clergymen from various churches in New-York, Connecticut, Massachusetis, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Maine, New Jersey, Ohio and Illinois, met in the..
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at 2 P.M., a Convention of Clergymen from various churches in New-York, Connecticut, Massachusetis, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Maine, New-Jersey, Ohio and Illinois, met in the rooms of the Geographical Society, Clinton Hall, in response to a call by the minority party of the Church of the Puritans, who were aggrieved by the action of the majority, and felt the need of counsel in the adjustment of the difficulties which had thereupon arisen. About fifty ministers were present. Rev. J.M. STURTEVANT, D.D., of Jacksonville, ill, was chosen Moderator, and Rev. S.W.S. DUTTON, of New-Haven, and Rev. H. ELLIOTT, of Bedford, Mass., were appointed Secretaries. The list of churches and delegates having been called, prayer was offered by the Moderator, and the business commenced. It will probably occupy some days. The complaints submitted to the Council by the Committee of seven members are:

abstract: We have strong sympathies with our oppressed fellow-men, as all good citizens ought to have.
lead_paragraph: We have strong sympathies with our oppressed fellow-men, as all good citizens ought to have. It is therefore with immense indignation that we have read the account of an outrage lately perpetrated by one of the United States old "war-dogs" down near Fort Monroe. The wrong-doer is no other than the United States man-of-war Cumberland, not long since feloniously towed out of Gosport Navy-yard.

abstract: Whereas, existing exigencies demand immediate and adequate measures for the protection of the National Constitution and the preservation of the National Union, by the suppression of the insurrectionary...
lead_paragraph: Whereas, existing exigencies demand immediate and adequate measures for the protection of the National Constitution and the preservation of the National Union, by the suppression of the insurrectionary combinations now existing in seven States for opposing the laws of the Union, and obstructing the execution thereof, to which end a military force in addition to that called forth by my proclamation of the 15th day of April, in the present year, appears to be indispensably necessary. Now, therefore, I ABRAHAN LINCOLN, President of the United States and Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy thereof, and of the Militia of the several States, when called into actual service, do hereby call into the service of the United States, forty-two thousand and ninety-four volunteers, to serve for a period of three years unless sooner discharged, and to be mustered into service as infantry and cavalry. The proportions of each arm, and the details of enrollment and organization will be made known through the Department of War; and I also direct that the regular army of the United States be increased by the addition of eight regiments of infantry, one regiment of cavalry, and one regiment of artillery, making altogether a maximum aggregate increase of twenty-two thousand seven hundred and fifty officers and enlisted men, the details of which increase will also be made known through the Department of War. And I further direct the enlistment for not less than one nor more than three years of eight-teen thousand seamen in addition to the present force, for the naval service of the United States. The details of the enlistment and organization will be made known through the Department of the Navy. The call for volunteers hereby made, and the direction for the increase of the regular army and for the enlistment of seamen hereby given, together with the plan of organization adopted for the volunteers and for the regular forces hereby authorized, will be submitted to Congress as soon as assembled. In the meantime, I earnestly invoke the cooperation of all good citizens in the measures hereby adopted for the effectual suppression of unlawful violence, for the impartial enforcement of constitutional laws, and for the speediest possible restoration of peace and order, and with those of happiness and prosperity throughout our country.

abstract: The Union Defence Committee has just held an interesting correspondence with Gen. WOOL, in consequence of the reception of orders from Gen. SCOTT for Gen. WOOL to return to the discharge of his routine duties at Troy.
lead_paragraph: The Union Defence Committee has just held an interesting correspondence with Gen. WOOL, in consequence of the reception of orders from Gen. SCOTT for Gen. WOOL to return to the discharge of his routine duties at Troy. The Committee has received important aid in the discharge of their duties, from Gen. WOOL, and they believe that it has been mainly through his energetic efforts that the Committee has been enabled to carry out its plane in forwarding troops and keeping them well supplied.

abstract: -- It is gratifying to know that during the exciting scenes of the past two weeks the great highway of Pennsylvania maintains its deserved reputation for speed and safety. Although its enormous business has been greatly increased by the transportation of troops and munitions of war, its through connections have been uninterrupted. It affords this day the best and most expeditious route for trade and travel that can be found between the East and West.

abstract: DESPERATE ENCOUNTER WITH ROWDIES -- A POLICE OFFICER SHOT -- PROVIDENTIAL ESCAPE. -- Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, as Officers ROBB and FAYEN, of the Fourth Ward, were patrolling [???] beat in Roosevelt-street, they came suddenly upon a man named DAVID STARLING, keeper of a sailors' boarding house in Batavia-street, who was quarrelling with several sailors. The officers requested the party to disperse, which, after some hesitation, they did, except STARLING, who refused to go home, but was finally compelled to do so. After reaching his house, it appears, he loaded a pistol, and, taking with him one CHARLES TUCKER, proceeded to a groggery on the corner of Roosevelt-street, to await the return of the officers. The latter soon appeared, and STARLING began abusing them, but was directed by them to go home, or take the chances of an arrest for disorderly conduct. He and his companion then started, apparently with the intention of going to his house, but suddenly ruined upon the officers and discharged his pistol at officer ROFF. The ball struck the shield of the officer, which was upon his breast, passed through it, and then struck a large brass button upon his under-coat, from which it glanced and [???] in the wadding of the coat entirely flattened. A desperate conflict then [???], STARLING and TUCKER both drawing bowle[???] and attempting to murder the officers. The [???] defended themselves with their clues, and final[???] sucked down the desperadoes and took them [???]. They were locked up in the Station-house [???] of the night and in the morning brought before Justice OSBORN, who committed them for trial. Both prisoners as well as officers, exhibited in their [???] and on their persons evidences of hard finding. STARLING has long been considered a [???] and the terror of the neighborhood in which he render and has repeatedly been arrested for felonious assault and larcenies.

abstract: Thank God! we have caused to talk about defences. The might [???] of the loyal States have render [???] language unnecessary, and the people [???] no language brook it. While there was a prospect of peace, the North, the East and the West were quiet. They deprecated war They clung to the hope that secession was a madness of the hour, from which the Cotton States would recover after a brief experience of the evils which they were bringing upon themselves. From this delusion they were aroused by the thunder of hostile cannon and the tramp of armed men. The tide of rebellion came rolling up from the Gulf, seducing the integrity and corrupting the patriotism of the Border States. For a time the Capital itself was almost at the mercy of the traitors. DAVIS and BEAUREGARD promised it to their followers as a spoil, and the rebel States counted upon it as already their own. They saw in imagination their flag waving above the National halls, and their rebel chief installed in the Executive mansion. When Virginia cast her fortunes with secession, they were sure of their prey, and the slaughter of the volunteers in Baltimore removed the last doubt of its acquisition. They looked for hosts of armed men from the North and West to swell their invading legions, whose hatred to the Administration would hurry them into treason as black and damning as their own. The great City of New-York was, to their deluded senses, a second Charleston, waiting only the proper time to seize the National armories and fortifications, or a New-Orleans, to plunder the Treasury and the Mint, and, by a union of forces, establish the new Confederacy from the Canadas to the Gulf.

abstract: About 1 1/2 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, the express train which left Albany about 11 o'clock, was thrown from the track by the breakage of the front axle of the engine. The engine was thrown down an embankment nearly twenty feet in height, but the fender fortunately took the opposite direction, thus blocking the train and saving the passengers from Injury. The engineer went down the embankment with the locomotive, and received very serious wounds. The fireman escaped with comparatively slight injuries, and the brakerman on the baggage. It was very badly, and it is feared; fatally bruised. The injured men, whose names we could not learn, were conveyed to their respective homes in this City.
lead_paragraph: About 1 1/2 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, the express train which left Albany about 11 o'clock, was thrown from the track by the breakage of the front axle of the engine. abstract: Well-informed Southern loyalists, now in this City, who have recently fled from their native section, estimate that not less than twenty thousand loyal American citizens have fled or been driven from the revolutionary States during the last month, because they...
lead_paragraph: Well-informed Southern loyalists, now in this City, who have recently fled from their native section, estimate that not less than twenty thousand loyal American citizens have fled or been driven from the revolutionary States during the last month, because they would not renounce their allegiance to the American Government and flag. From Virginia and North Carolina, as well as from the seven Confederate despotisms, there are daily-arrivals here of companies, families and individuals, fleeing from the wrath of white savages more desperate and inhuman than the red savages they have superseded -- many of whom have been subjected to barbarities that make us blush to believe they could be perpetrated by our country men. On only one day of last week five car-loads of white fugitives were reported as having arrived at a single, point in Pennsylvania; on the succeeding day a Presbyterian clergyman from Mississippi arrives with a hundred and fifty other refugees fleeing for life; on another, three hundred mechanics escape from Richmond, twice as many from Memphis and other towns in Tennessee, and so on; in fact, from almost every village of the far South come the reports of flights, or hangings, or floggings, or imprisonment or banishment of those who dare remain faithful to the Constitution, while of course of more than half the assassinations and persecutions that actually do occur, no report is over published and no account ever reaches the civilized world. A gentleman who has just escaped the clutches of the half-Cannibal chivalry of South Carolina avers that in Columbia, (from which he hails,) Charleston, and other towns of that perfidious little despotism, the chronic reign of terror which has prevailed for the last dozen years has been intensified, till now it is more relentless than that which under Bomba and Bonibaline has so lately called down the execration and the vengeance of mankind. Age is not regarded; sex is not spared; character or honorable repute are of no avail -- whoever will not bow down before the black and infernal deities which they worship, is thrown into the den of wild beasts to be destroyed.
headline: {'main': 'Southern Exites and American Citizenship.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Southern Exites and American Citizenship.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Maryland is said now to "keep step to the music of the Union." Her sudden return to the Union column is a marvelous conversion. We have seen so sudden a change but once before, and that occurred in a cognate case in our own City. But with a similar moving cause, how wondrously different the effect! For whereas a lively street crowd in New-York converted a hardened Secessionist into an emphatic Union man, in Baltimore the street rabble turned a Union people into rampant Secessionism.
lead_paragraph: Maryland is said now to "keep step to the music of the Union." Her sudden return to the Union column is a marvelous conversion. abstract: New-UTRECHT. A large and enthusiastic meeting was held in New-Utrecht on Thursday evening, for the purpose of raising a fund for the aid and support of volunteers and their families, and to organize a Home Guard.
lead_paragraph: New-UTRECHT. -- A large and enthusiastic meeting was held in New-Utrecht on Thursday evening, for the purpose of raising a fund for the aid and support of volunteers and their families, and to organize a Home Guard. A considerable sum was subscribed on the spot, and several young men volunteered for the war, Speeches were made by Col. T.B. THORPE, W.J.A. FULLER, T.G. BERGEN and ARCH. YOUNG.

abstract: A large number of the conservative citizens of Arkansas, among them some of the Union Delegates to the State Convention, publish a card in the Little Rock Gazette, declaring it to be their purpose to resist to the last the coercion policy of Mr. LINCOLN, and to "embark their lives, their fortunes and their sacred honors" in the rebellion or revolution, as the result of the conflict, already begun, shall determine its character to be. The Gazette has been hitherto a firm Union paper. In its last issue it says: "We fairly and deliberately, in the light of day, and in the exercise of our calm and cool judgment, take upon ourself the position of resistance to, and rebellion against, the present Government of the United States; and if there be any who wish to denounce us for this treason against LINCOLN'S Government, or war against LINCOLN, we are willing and ready to furnish them the testimony, by the commission of an overt act whenever an opportunity offers."

abstract: About a hundred representative citizens gathered at the head-quarters of the Home Guard, Room No. 41 Astor House, yesterday morning, in expectation of the welcome of Vice Precident HAMLIN by the Committee of the Guard.
lead_paragraph: About a hundred representative citizens gathered at the head-quarters of the Home Guard, Room No. 41 Astor House, yesterday morning, in expectation of the welcome of Vice Precident HAMLIN by the Committee of the Guard. Mr. HAMLIN was, however, called away on important business connected with the Maine regiments, and could not be present. The Committee, however, succeeded in capturing Gov. C.B. STANTON, of Kansas, who was formally welcomed by Mr. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER, on behalf of the Committee.

abstract: Gen. HOUSTON spoke in Galveston, Texas, on April 19. The Civilian sketches his remarks. He denied all intention of trying to regain the seat from which he had been ousted, counseled coolness, union, and courage among all classes of people. He gave a humorous account of the manner in which he had been superseded in the office of Governor, and said that his relief from the labors, cares and responsibilities of the office was rather a favor than a matter of regret to himself.

abstract: A gentleman who has just returned from an extended tour through the South reports the result of his observations to the Louisville Journal. He says that in all his journey he did not see a solitary railroad train going in the direction of Richmond that was not loaded with troops and munitions. From Charleston alone, during the two days he was there, 4,000 armed men started for the Virginia rendezvous. He states that these general and rapid movements are not reported in the papers of the Confederate States, but he has no doubt that the army at Richmond will prove tremendous in its strength of numbers. He tells us that all the men he met with, military officers and others, spoke of the conquest of Washington as a settled thing, just as well settled as if already accomplished, and that the avowed determination is not to preserve the public buildings of the Capital for the uses of the Southern Confederacy, but to demolish them utterly, not leaving one stone upon another.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman who has just returned from an extended tour through the South reports the result of his observations to the Louisville Journal. abstract: JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his Message to the Rebel Congress, says: "All we ask is to be let alone." Nobody will doubt the truth of this assertion.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his Message to the Rebel Congress, says: "All we ask is to be let alone." Nobody will doubt the truth of this assertion. The robber dislikes nothing so much as being disturbed in the possession of his plunder. He deprecates interference on the part of the police, and would gladly be relieved from the meddling propensities of the officers of the law. The thief wants to be quiet. What he desires most is to be "let alone" to enjoy the fruits of his larceny. He does not fancy the intrusion of the tipstaff nor the presence of the town constable. The misfortune, however, is that the world will meddle with the crimes of men, and justice will hunt the guilty to punishment. The further misfortune is, that that hunt will be energetic in proportion to the magnitude of the offence committed.
headline: {'main': 'He Wants to be Let Alone.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'He Wants to be Let Alone.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: AN OLD KNICKERBOCKER GONE. -- The funeral of PETER ERBEN, aged 91, a native of this City, and the last but sixteen of the veritable Knickerbockers surviving, took place at Trinity Church yesterday, and was numerously attended by citizens, as well as by the officers and ministers of the Church, Rev. Dr. VINTON officiating. The venerable deceased was organist of Trinity Church for fifty years, and was succedcd in 1850 by Dr. HODGES. He dined on Christmas last with his descendants of five generations, viz.: children, grandchildren, great grand and great great grandchildren, and only a few days since was walking the streets with the apparent vigor of a hale man of 70. His son, HENRR ERBEN, is the well-known builder of the largest organs in the country. His grandson, H. ERREN, Jr., U.S.N., is now doing his duty to his country at Fort Pickens.

abstract: Maryland, after all the assurances recently given that she would remain loyal to the Union, appears likely to drift into the hands of the Secessionists, unless the Union men within her borders shall bestir themselves.
lead_paragraph: Maryland, after all the assurances recently given that she would remain loyal to the Union, appears likely to drift into the hands of the Secessionists, unless the Union men within her borders shall bestir themselves. The action of her Legislature in passing to a third reading what is called a bill to provide for the public safety, proposes to place the destinies of the State in the keeping of a rank Secession Committee, and to remove every restriction and safeguard which has heretofore existed against a rash employment of military force. It now appears that while the Union element in the State has been deluded with the idea that no further apprehension need be felt that the State would occupy a position hostile to the Federal Government, the Legislature has been engaged in perfecting arrangements which, at any appointed time, may precipitate the State into the arms of JEFF. DAVIS. We are glad to learn, however, that this action on the part of the Legislature is not likely to meet with the favor they desire. The Union feeling has gained such headway in the State, and especially in Baltimore, that a tremendous pressure has been brought to bear against the measure, which happily did not become a law, as at first announced. Our latest dispatch indicates a likelihood that the attempt to spring secession upon the State will be a failure.

abstract: A few evenings since FRED DOUGLAS spoke at Rochester on the crisis. He concluded his address by showing that the only settlement which can be made of our troubles will be by the destruction of the cause which has produced the difficulty -- Slavery. True, the Government seems not to be doing anything to bring about this result directly; but things are working. If the Government is not yet on the side of the oppressed, events mightier than the Government are bringing about that result.

abstract: We have never had entire faith in the conversion alleged to have been wrought almost by miracle among the Secessionists of Maryland.
lead_paragraph: We have never had entire faith in the conversion alleged to have been wrought -- almost by miracle -- among the Secessionists of Maryland. We attribute, justly, no doubt, very great efficacy to the presence of a superior force on her borders, and to the moral influence of the general uprising in the North, in restoring the reign of reason and moderation. All this strengthened, the hands of the Unionists, and enabled them to make themselves heard and felt; but, though it might repress and stifle the outward demonstration of treason, it could not extinguish the rankling discontents and animosities which led to it. We have never believed that the men who shot down Federal soldiers yesterday, were prepared to look with complacency on the flaunting of the Federal flag in the breeze to-day.

abstract: It is pleasant to observe the amiable and tender treatment extended by a portion of our newspaper Press to the military and naval deserters of the day.
lead_paragraph: It is pleasant to observe the amiable and tender treatment extended by a portion of our newspaper Press to the military and naval deserters of the day. If an officer of the army, who has been educated, sustained and furnished with opportunities of honor and distinction by the Federal Government, desert his Flag in her hour of trial, and in the face of impending or rather flagrant hostilities, goes over to the enemy, he is sure to receive nothing but a "first-rate notice" from an habitually indulgent and eulogistic Press. We are assured that the delinquent and deserter, attained very great distinction at West Point, and was a very meritorious and deserving and able officer; and that Gen. SCOTT shed tears on parting with him, and remarked that he had rather lose a battle or his right hand than lose such a marvelous good soldier at such a time. So with our naval deserters. Not a Captain, Commander or Lieutenant has disgraced himself forever by the surrender of his commission, but some tender-hearted scribe is at hand to record his innumerable merits, and to tell how great a favorite he was with Commodore BAINBRIDGE or Commodore MORRIS.
headline: {'main': 'The Deserters of our Flag.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Deserters of our Flag.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To understand thoroughly the position of Kentucky, and to form a probable conjecture of her ultimate action and destiny in this turmoil of States, one needs not only to, understand how the present revolution affects her interests and feelings, but, he should know, also, the political traditions of the State.
lead_paragraph: To understand thoroughly the position of Kentucky, and to form a probable conjecture of her ultimate action and destiny in this turmoil of States, one needs not only to, understand how the present revolution affects her interests and feelings, but, he should know, also, the political traditions of the State. Kentucky has had a peculiar experience in domestic discord, resulting, at one time, almost in civil war; and her people have, therefore, clearly marked precedents of action by which to direct their course in this revolutionary phrensy. They steer by well-known landmarks, which no other State now tempted to rebellion, possesses; and hence it is that her Union men yet hold the helm firmly, and make-steadily for the haven which safety and honor present, while the best and wisest of their kind in other States -- such as JOHN BELL and the EWINGS, of Tennessee, have dropped their arms in reckless despair, and are drifting onward to destruction. We shall prepare the readers of the TIMES for a thrilling drama, to be enacted are long on the "dark and bloody ground" of Kentucky, if they will attend a brief historical reminiscence of that State.

abstract: The St. Louis Democrat of April 27 details the circumstances of the seizure of the powder magazines near that city, by order of the State authorities. These magazines, it says, three in number, are situated on the river bank, about three aides above the city, in an open field, half a mile east of the village of Lowell.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Democrat of April 27 details the circumstances of the seizure of the powder magazines near that city, by order of the State authorities. These magazines, it says, three in number, are situated on the river bank, about three aides above the city, in an open field, half a mile east of the village of Lowell. They are compact, close structures, capable of containing about eighteen thousand kegs of powder. One of them belongs to Messrs. LAFLIN & SMITH, who obtain their powder at Saugerties, New-York. The others are the property of the Hazard Powder Company. The method of sale has been to convey the article to the city each morning, in spring wagons, and distribute to the retailers. Larger quantities are frequently received by boats. The amount of powder in the buildings Thursday night is stated at not less than twelve thousand kegs. This was yesterday in process of removal to a steamboat lying near. A vigilant guard of six soldiers was posted at the bridge, on the road from the village to the magazines, and no passage was allowed, except to those having passes from Capt. KELLEY. We understand that the combustible property is destined for Jefferson City.

abstract: To-day an election is held in the State of Kentucky for delegates to a Border Slave State Convention. This election is held in response to an invitation that Virginia gave, by her Legislature, about two months ago; but Virginia will not be present at the entertainment to which she invited others. Arkansas responded to the Virginia call, and her Convention appointed delegates. Missouri, by her State Convention, did the same. We are not aware whether Maryland and Delaware responded; but apprehend they may do so, if they have not.

abstract: The United States steam transport Chesapeake, VAIL, left last evening direct for Washington City, with 600 barrels provisions and 120 head live cattle. The steamship Columbia has now on board 32 men of the Seventy-first Regiment, who will go as escort to the uniforms for the volunteers that sailed in the R.R. Cuyler. She has also 12 men of the Twelfth Regiment as escort to 600 stand of arms. The Columbia is awaiting the Maine Regiment, which was expected yesterday, and should they arrive, will sail early this morning.

abstract: On April 26, in the Canadian Parliament, Hon. T.S. MACDONALD called upon Attorney-General CARTER for information regarding the statement that the United States Government had applied to the Canadian authorities for muskets, either on loan or purchase. After an animated colloquy the Attorney-General refused to give any information, unless due notice were given that the question would be asked. So the matter dropped.

abstract: The Directors of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad of Virginia, at a meeting on the 28th, resolved that "owing to the disturbed condition of the country, provision could not be made to pay, in New-York, the coupons of its bonds, due May 1st." They add: "If circumstances should permit (!) and the arrangement can be effected satisfactorily, (!!) said coupons will be paid in Virginia currency, at the office of the company, "at a time to be named" hereafter! Let bondholders be encouraged. Perhaps they'll go down to draw their interest.

abstract: The total cessation of clearances for vessels to Southern ports has changed the whole current of the coasting trade; but such is the enthusiasm in favor of sustaining the Government in the present crisis, that owners and captains of vessels, with a ready versatility, are finding other employments, which, if not so profitable, are at least equally satisfactory, until trade resumes its wonted channels. Mr. BARNEY is keeping a sharp look-out for all vessels clearing from this port, to guard against the shipment of "aid and comfort," in any form, to the Seceded States.
lead_paragraph: The total cessation of clearances for vessels to Southern ports has changed the whole current of the coasting trade; but such is the enthusiasm in favor of sustaining the Government in the present crisis, that owners and captains of vessels, with a ready versatility, are finding other employments, which, if not so profitable, are at least equally satisfactory, until trade resumes its wonted channels. abstract: On Tuesday evening last the ladies of the city of Bridgeport, Conn., presented a sword and epaulettes to the captain and lieutenants of Co. D., Third Regiment Connecticut Volunteers. Capt. FRYE, who has, by his individual exertions, succeeded in organizing this company, deserves, for his gallant ancestors and himself, more than a passing notice. In 1698 Capt. JAMES FRYE served with the Massachusetts troops against the Indians; in 1744, his son, Lieut. JAMES FRYE (afterward colonel in the "old French wars,") was present at the capture of Louisburg; in 1775, his son, JAMES FRYE, was colonel at the battle of Bunker Hill, and with him there was his son, FREDERICK FRYE (then 18 years old,) subsequently lieutenant in the revolutionary army, and in command at Governor's Island, New York, during 1812; and his son, DANIEL M. FRYE, father of the present Capt. FREDERICK FRYE, served as captain in that war. Capt. FREDERICK FRYE is a member of the Cincinnati, and carries the original badge and certificate of that order, received by Lieut. FRYE in 1784. He has also the original commissions issued to his (forefathers) ancestors above mentioned, bearing the autographs of SHIRLEY, HANCOCK, WARREN and WASHINGTON. He is a native of New York city, a graduate of old Columbia, and his numerous friends will be gratified to know that he is early in the field in which his fathers served so well.

abstract: The case of Mr. TRACY, who was maltreated, and, with his wife and six children, forcibly expelled from Columbia, S.C., was briefly referred to a few days since in the TIMES.
lead_paragraph: The case of Mr. TRACY, who was maltreated, and, with his wife and six children, forcibly expelled from Columbia, S.C., was briefly referred to a few days since in the TIMES. It is worthy of further notice. Mr. TRACY was for nearly eight years the sole trustee and custodian of the large property of Bishop LYNCH, of Charleston. It consisted of some 1,600 acres of land. It was cultivated exclusively by free labor. Bishop LYNCH had other plantations, and owned some five hundred slaves. Mr. TRACY was a favorite with the Bishop, and was intrusted with the most important business. He was also employed by the city in various contracts.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning contain important and startling intelligence. The twenty days allowed to the Southern rebels in which to disperse have now expired, and indications are abundant that the Government intends now to assert its supremacy in the most emphatic manner.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington this morning contain important and startling intelligence. The twenty days allowed to the Southern rebels in which to disperse have now expired, and indications are abundant that the Government intends now to assert its supremacy in the most emphatic manner. Of course, exactly what is to be done is known only to the proper author-thorities; but among the rumors at the Capital which seem to have some foundation, is one to the effect that early this morning the Seventh, Seventy-First and Twelfth New-York regiments, and the Rhode-Island men, were to march upon Alexandria, dislodge the Secession forces there, and take possession. Another rumor says that the Sixth Massachusetts regiment will this morning proceed to the Relay House, seven miles from Baltimore. They were under orders last night for some point. It seems to be the general impression in Washington that some effective demonstration is to be made in Virginia. Meantime, the blockade is already perfect in Chesapeake Bay; it will be so at Charleston and all other points on the Atlantic coast soon. By next Saturday, it is believed, every port in the seceded States will be shut up; and this will be done with the full consent of the representative of the European Powers; the stories to the effect that they had protested against the blockade having been entirely without foundation.

abstract: We understand that a graceless scamp who was expelled from the Twenty-Eighth Regiment because of treasonable, conduct, is now going from house to house in Williamsburg, where the majority of the members of the Regiment reside, making most exaggerated statements regarding the hardships which the force was compelled to undergo on its way from this city to Annapolis. The fact that the fellow can descend to such a method of revenging himself, is the best proofthat his expulsion was deserved. We can assure those having friends in the Twenty Eighth, on official authority, that the entire Regiment is in good health, and that all its wants are faithfully attended to.

abstract: Of all the States, in the Southern Confederacy, there is but one which can pretend to have been revolutionized by the authority of her people. South Carolina was never much attached to the Union. Since 1832, a large majority of her inhabitants have been avowedly disloyal.
lead_paragraph: Of all the States, in the Southern Confederacy, there is but one which can pretend to have been revolutionized by the authority of her people. South Carolina was never much attached to the Union. Since 1832, a large majority of her inhabitants have been avowedly disloyal. They have been educated by Mr. CALHOUN and Mr. MCDUFFIE to believe that their rights and interests are antagonistic to the rights and interests of the North, and that the Union, instead of being a beneficent protector, has been to them an oppressor and a scourge. In 1850 there were Statelights associations formed in every neighborhood, the object of which was to foment and combine discontents, and to devise ways and means for safe secession. There have been hardly a score of Union, men in the State, at any time for the last ten years, who have dared to avow their sentiments. It is said that the action by which South Carolina finally sought to accomplish her object was illegal and unconstitutional under her own laws -- but it must be admitted, we apprehend, that the voters of the State, by an overwhelming majority, were disposed for Revolution under any circumstances and at all hazards.
headline: {'main': 'Conspiracy not Revolution.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Conspiracy not Revolution.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In this Court on Saturday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Mr. Sedgwick moved for the discharge upon bail, of Redman McManus, indicted for murder. Prisoner's counsel argued that the evidence on which the indictment had been found made out at most a case of man-slaughter in the fourth degree. The District Attorney opposed the motion, and moved to send the case to the Oyer and Terminer. Decision on both motions was reserved.

abstract: The total cessation of clearances for vessels to Southern ports has changed the whole current of the coasting trade; but such is the enthusiasm in favor of sustaining the Government in the present crisis, that owners and captains of vessels, with a ready versatility, are finding other employments, which, if not so profitable, are at least equally satisfactory, until trade resumes its wonted channels. Mr. BARNEY is keeping a sharp look-out for all vessels clearing from this port, to guard against the shipment of "aid and comfort," in any form, to the Seceded States.

abstract: Two of our principal places of amusement have brought their regular seasons to a close Wallack's and Niblo's Garden. The farmer establishment, however, promises a supplemental season of six nights, and has provided for the same the now appropriate drama of "Jessie Brown."
lead_paragraph: Two of our principal places of amusement have brought their regular seasons to a close -- Wallack's and Niblo's Garden. The farmer establishment, however, promises a supplemental season of six nights, and has provided for the same the now appropriate drama of "Jessie Brown." With the drums rolling around us, and a quick public ear for the tread of armed hosts, it will be strange, indeed, if the story of the heroine of Lucknow does not prove interesting at this moment. Mr. WALLACK devoted his last two nights (Friday and Saturday) to patriotic purposes; but beyond affording a couple of evenings' amusement to a number of volunteers, who availed themselves of the courtesy of the doorkeepers to obtain free admission to the house, the result was not what might have reasonably been expected. Patriotic entertainments, in truth, are seldom successful. If people are disposed to give -- as they are at present -- they prefer doing it in a direct way. An amalgam of patriotism and amusement does not pass current.

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS AND FRIENDS: The great assemblage that I see around me, the simple but interesting ceremonial with which the flag of our country has been thrown to the breeze, the strain of inspiring music, the sweet concert of these youthful voices, the solemn supplication of the Reverend clergy, which still fills our ears, -- all these proclaim the deep patriotic sentiment, of which that flag is the symbol and expression. Nay more, it speaks for itself. Its mute eloquence needs no aid from my lips, to interpret its significance. Fidelity to the Union blazes from its stars; allegiance to the Government, beneath which we live, is wrapped within its folds.
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS AND FRIENDS: The great assemblage that I see around me, the simple but interesting ceremonial with which the flag of our country has been thrown to the breeze, the strain of inspiring music, the sweet concert of these youthful voices, the solemn supplication of the Reverend clergy, which still fills our ears, -- all these proclaim the deep patriotic sentiment, of which that flag is the symbol and expression. abstract: The correspondent of the Nashville (Tenn.) Gazette, writing from Warrenton, on April 25, talks very warlike. He says that May 6 is the day fixed by the Confederates for making the assault. A paragraph which we find in the New-Orleans Picayune, of April 29, however, would seem to indicate that a retrograde movement had been commenced despite BRAGG's call for 2,000 more men. Letters received on that day announce the departure from Pensacola, for Virginia, of the Orleans Cadets, Capt. CHARLES DREUX; the Louisiana Guards, Major TODD, and the Chasseurs a Pied, Capt. ST. PAUL. These companies expect to meet, at Grand Junction, the other corps from this city.

abstract: We give the following statistics of the failures and suspensions reported during January, February, March and April, in our list of business changes, which will be found of general interest to the mercantile community. Our list includes all concerns of importance; of course, there are various retail establishments that are of little or no account, which pass out of sight, from time to time, without perceptibly affecting the current of trade; such we have not deemed it worth our while to report. The following table shows the number of failures the past four months, and also the States in which they occurred. The numbers given in the States of Massachusetts, New-York, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Ohio, are exclusive of those which occurred in their capital cities, the numbers in those cities being given by themselves.

lead_paragraph: We gave a few days since some deductions from the Census of 1860, as to the relative increase or decrease of the sections in representative influence; and we now propose to make a brief analysis of the progress in population. The remarks upon this branch of the subject, made some four or five weeks ago, were based upon unauthorized and imperfect newspaper statements as to the results of the Census, but we now have the official summary of population for the whole Union, and can speak with certainty.

abstract: Several days since, one GREENE was arrested in Philadelphia, charged with having been engaged in the capture of Fort Pulaski, near Savannah, Ga. Judge CADWALLADER, on Friday, rendered an opinion in the case, the substance of which was, that a probable case of treason has been made out; that the occupation of Fort Pulaski was an act of treason on the part of every one concerned. The jurisdiction of the United States over the fort was, under the Constitution, as exclusive and as independent of State control as if the land on which the fort was erected had not been within the limits of Georgia. It was no excuse that the defendant acted under the orders of a superior officer, unless it was proven that force was used to compel his obedience and that he escaped as soon as he possibly could. His duty of allegiance to the United States was paramount to that which he owed to the State of Georgia. The Judge therefore decided to hold the accused in $10,000 to keep the peace. Subsequently, Judge CADWALLADER consented to reopen the case to hear argument on the question, whether the Court was not bound to presume that the Government would reassert its power, and reopen the United States Courts in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Several days since, one GREENE was arrested in Philadelphia, charged with having been engaged in the capture of Fort Pulaski, near Savannah, Ga. It was no excuse that the defendant acted under the orders of a superior officer, unless it was proven that force was used to compel his obedience and that he escaped as soon as he possibly could. His duty of allegiance to the United States was paramount to that which he owed to the State of Georgia. The Judge therefore decided to hold the accused in $10,000 to keep the peace. Subsequently, Judge CADWALLADER consented to reopen the case to hear argument on the question, whether the Court was not bound to presume that the Government would reassert its power, and reopen the United States Courts in Georgia.

abstract: PETER HART, the Ex-Metropolitan Policeman, who raised anew the Stars and Stripes which had been shot away at Fort Sumter, thereby exposing himself to the hottest of the rebels' fire, has been presented with one Of TIFFANY'S best English gold lever watches, as a tribute to his bravery.
lead_paragraph: PETER HART, the Ex-Metropolitan Policeman, who raised anew the Stars and Stripes which had been shot away at Fort Sumter, thereby exposing himself to the hottest of the rebels' fire, has been presented with one Of TIFFANY'S best English gold lever watches, as a tribute to his bravery. The watch, which may be seen at TIFFANY's, bears the following inscription: "The Officers of Fort Sumter to PETER HART, a tribute to fidelity and courage. April 12 and 13, 1861. Major Robert Anderson, First Artillery; Assistant Surgeon S.W. Crawford, Medical Department; Capt. A. Doubleday, First Artillery; Capt. T. Seymour, do.; Lieut. J.C. Davis, do.; Lieut. N.J. Hall, do.; Capt. J.G. Foster, Engineers; Lieut. G. W. Snyder, do.; Lieut. R.K. Meade, do."
