abstract: The Philadelphia Ledger states that the determination to reconstruct the bridges on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad, destroyed by a mob from Baltimore, has led to the construction of a railroad battery by the Federal Government, at the locomotive works of BALDWIN & Co., in that city. One of the long platform baggage cars has been fixed with sides and top of thick sheet iron, the sides havieg port-holes and loop-holes for musketry. A turn-table has been arranged, on which a rifled cannon is to be placed. The carriage for the gun is so constructed, that it can be fired at any angle, and from any one of the port-holes in the sides or end of the car. In place of shot or shell for the cannon, pieces of iron punched from locomotive boilers will be used as loads. This car is to be placed in front of a locomotive, and with fifty men inside, armed with Minie rifles, and seamen to work the cannon, there are but few more terrible instruments of destruction.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Ledger states that the determination to reconstruct the bridges on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad, destroyed by a mob from Baltimore, has led to the construction of a railroad battery by the Federal Government, at the locomotive works of BALDWIN & Co., in that city. abstract: The Pittsburgh Dispatch is inclined to think that there is something in the stories about JOHN BROWN having collected a band of negroes to attack the South. By way of confirmation of the statement made a few days since, by a correspondent of the Cleveland Herald, the Dispatch of the 3d states that it has learned of several boat-loads of provisions having been sent from that city, to an encampment said to have been formed near New-Brighton.

abstract: Two traveling agents of a prominent mercantile house in this city arrived here yesterday, having spent the last six months in the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: Two traveling agents of a prominent mercantile house in this city arrived here yesterday, having spent the last six months in the Southern States. They confirm the accounts received from other sources with regard to the utter anarchy that exists in the Gulf States. They say that there are large numbers of intelligent, solid men, scattered all through the South, who are Union men at heart, and who deplore the state of things around them, which they see must inevitably end in ruin, but who are powerless to arrest the tide of revolution, or to counteract the mob-law that everywhere prevails.

abstract: The war in which we are engaged presents several characteristics, which it is necessary to define, in order to have a perfect understanding of its importance, and of its probable ultimate effects. It is national in this sense, that its object is to defend the Constitution and the laws; it is moral because there is in it a sentiment of revolt of the public conscience against Slavery; it is a civil war, ...
lead_paragraph: The war in which we are engaged presents several characteristics, which it is necessary to define, in order to have a perfect understanding of its importance, and of its probable ultimate effects. It is national in this sense, that its object is to defend the Constitution and the laws; it is moral because there is in it a sentiment of revolt of the public conscience against Slavery; it is a civil war, because it divides into two hostile camps a people who, not long since lived under the same Constitution, acknowledged the same Government, and believed themselves happy in forming one and the same nation, strong by union, great by its strength.

abstract: James Clark vs. The Steamboat Plymouth Rock. -- This was a libel filed by the owner of the schooner Charter Oak to recover the damage occasioned to her by a collision with the steamboat in the East River, on April 12, 1860. The steamer had left her berth in the North River about 5 P. M., and came round the Battery, near the middle of the river, in her usual course under a speed of 10 or 11 knots an hour. At about opposite the South Perry she slowed to let a Wall-street Ferry-boat pass into her slip and then went on at speed to get out of the way of a vessel beating across the river from the starboard side of the steamer. She then perceived the Charter Oak coming on the larboard side against the wind. In the judgment of the master and pilot of the steamer, if she had stopped and backed she would have fallen across the track of the vessel coming upon her starboard side. She therefore blew her whistle to warn the Charter Oak of her embarrassment, and sheared as far to starboard as she could. The schooner, which was coming close-hauled on the wind from about Wall-street Ferry, on the New-York side, did not change her course, but held on, and the two vessels came in collision.
lead_paragraph: James Clark vs. The Steamboat Plymouth Rock. -- This was a libel filed by the owner of the schooner Charter Oak to recover the damage occasioned to her by a collision with the steamboat in the East River, on April 12, 1860. The steamer had left her berth in the North River about 5 P. M., and came round the Battery, near the middle of the river, in her usual course under a speed of 10 or 11 knots an hour. At about opposite the South Perry she slowed to let a Wall-street Ferry-boat pass into her slip and then went on at speed to get out of the way of a vessel beating across the river from the starboard side of the steamer. She then perceived the Charter Oak coming on the larboard side against the wind. In the judgment of the master and pilot of the steamer, if she had stopped and backed she would have fallen across the track of the vessel coming upon her starboard side. She therefore blew her whistle to warn the Charter Oak of her embarrassment, and sheared as far to starboard as she could. The schooner, which was coming close-hauled on the wind from about Wall-street Ferry, on the New-York side, did not change her course, but held on, and the two vessels came in collision.

abstract: Several days since, one GREENE was arrested in Philadelphia, charged with having been engaged in the capture of Fort Pulaski, near Savannah, Ga. Judge CADWALLADER, on Friday, rendered an opinion in the care, the substance of which was, that a probable case of treason had been made out; that the occupation of Fort Pulaski was an act of treason on the part of every one concerned. The jurisdiction of the United States over the fort was, under the Constitution, as exclusive and as independent of State control as if the land on which the fort was erected had'not been within the limits of Georgia. It was no excuse that the defendant acted under the orders of a superior officer, unless it was proven that force was used to compel his obedience and that he escaped as soon as he possibly could. His duty of allegiance to the United States was paramount to that which he owed to the State of Georgia. The Judge therefore decided to hold the accused in $10,000 to keep the peace. Subsequently, Judge CADWALLADER consented to reopen the case to hear argument on the question, whether the Court was not bound to presume that the Government would reassert its power, and reopen the United States Courts in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Several days since, one GREENE was arrested in Philadelphia, charged with having been engaged in the capture of Fort Pulaski, near Savannah, Ga. Judge CADWALLADER, on Friday, rendered an opinion in the care, the substance of which was, that a probable case of treason had been made out; that the occupation of Fort Pulaski was an act of treason on the part of every one concerned. It was no excuse that the defendant acted under the orders of a superior officer, unless it was proven that force was used to compel his obedience and that he escaped as soon as he possibly could. His duty of allegiance to the United States was paramount to that which he owed to the State of Georgia. The Judge therefore decided to hold the accused in $10,000 to keep the peace. abstract: Henry Best, a porter in the store of Townsend & Gale, dry goods merchants in Warren-st., was arrested on Friday, charged with having at various times embezzled goods to the aggregate value of about $2,000, which he sold to noted receivers of stolen goods. One of the receivers was also arrested, and some of the goods were found on his premises. The two prisoners were committed to await examination.

abstract: Great results have followed the experiments of our own and European Governments in the range and accuracy of both small arms and rifled cannon. For the clumsy musket and rough ordnance of Revolutionary times, we have the rifle of 1,000 yards to a mile range, and the Armstrong and Whitworth artillery hurling their steel bolts, true to the mark, five miles away.
lead_paragraph: Great results have followed the experiments of our own and European Governments in the range and accuracy of both small arms and rifled cannon. For the clumsy musket and rough ordnance of Revolutionary times, we have the rifle of 1,000 yards to a mile range, and the Armstrong and Whitworth artillery hurling their steel bolts, true to the mark, five miles away. But while this has magnifiedthe plan of field operations, it has not intrinsically changed their nature. The same essential difference in the transport and fighting of cannon and small arms still obtains; as far as powder is concerned, its two distinct uses are in the heavy horse-propelled artillery and the mountain howitzer on the one hand, and the light infantry-carried rifle musket on the other. There is no standard intermediate arm to outreach the range of the hand arm, without impeding the operations of light infantry, -- a revolving rifled gun on wheels, terrible in rapidity, accuracy and execution, but light enough to be jerked by three or four men through swamps and over stone walls, without impeding the regular order of march and manoeuvre. A long rifled barrel, with an inch or a 3/4-inch bore, carrying a 3/4-pound to a pound projectile, and fed by a series of revolving chambers so that an incessant fire of a mile and a half to two miles range might be maintained -- an exaggerated revolving pistol, mounted on a modification of the light, but superlatively strong running gear of our best steam fire-engines, and capable of flying to new positions at a moment's notice -- a battery of such metal in skilled hands would indeed break up the plans of present field operation, and in many circumstances, well known to military men, create have among an enemy not within the range of the rifle-musket, and quite too quick in its movements to be cut up by the present artillery. A half a mile advantage in range would give it every advantage over infantry arms, and its lightness and celerity would enable it, many times, to pick off artillerists before their heavy metal could be trained and served.

abstract: The Philadelphia North American says that about two weeks ago it was publicly announced that the Friends would hold a meeting at Goode Creek, in Loudon County, Va. The horses driven to these assemblages are proverbial for their excellence, and tempted by the expected advent of these noble animals, about thirty of the rebels went there, expecting to obtain possession of a number. But fortunately, owing to some unforeseen circumstance, as well as to the inclemency of the weather, the meeting was unavoidably postponed. Consequently the rebels failed of their purpose. One gentleman, however, had his horse taken from him, and in consequence of hints that he might lose other portions of his moveable property, he has bidden good-bye to the State.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia North American says that about two weeks ago it was publicly announced that the Friends would hold a meeting at Goode Creek, in Loudon County, Va. abstract: The deplorable condition of affairs in the United States is giving birth in the minds of European Governments to all sorts of dreams of conquest on the Western Continent. The Monroe doctrine is hereafter a dead letter. In the European view of the question, self-government has proven itself a failure.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Tuesday, April 16, 1861.

abstract: The garrison of Fort Schuyler is ready to take the field on very short notice, it was just two weeks Thursday since Col. DURYEA commenced raising his Regiment. Probably no body of raw recruits was ever brought together and advanced to such a high degree of military proficiency as this command has attained in so short a time before. Since they have been at Fort Schuyler, the men have been subjected to very rigid discipline, and any one skilled in the science of war, who shall pay them a visit, will be surprised at the precision with which they execute some of the most intricate battalion movements-Manoeuvres which we have seen performed by militia regiments of long standing with far less accuracy. The corps, in fact, has a Colonel; and that is a matter of as much importance to soldiers as the now established truth that we have a Government is to the people at large. That the Advance Guard is Col. DURYEA's Regiment, is a sufficient guarantee that it will be a highiy-trained and soldierly body of troops. Col. DURYEA has been a military man ever since he has been a man, and has risen gradually from the ranks through every gradation in the service to the position he now holds. The only fear his men have is that he will be too speedily promoted; but there is little probability that he could be induced to leave his Regiment, in whose progress he takes a great deal of pride.
lead_paragraph: The garrison of Fort Schuyler is ready to take the field on very short notice, it was just two weeks Thursday since Col. DURYEA commenced raising his Regiment. Probably no body of raw recruits was ever brought together and advanced to such a high degree of military proficiency as this command has attained in so short a time before. Since they have been at Fort Schuyler, the men have been subjected to very rigid discipline, and any one skilled in the science of war, who shall pay them a visit, will be surprised at the precision with which they execute some of the most intricate battalion movements-Manoeuvres which we have seen performed by militia regiments of long standing with far less accuracy. The corps, in fact, has a Colonel; and that is a matter of as much importance to soldiers as the now established truth that we have a Government is to the people at large. abstract: The correspondent of the Nashville (Tenn.) Gazette, writing from Warrenton, on April 25, talks very warlike. He says that May 6 is the day fixed by the Confederates for making the assault. A paragraph which we find in the New-Orleans Picayune, of April 29, however, would seen to indicate that a retrograde movement had been commenced despite BRAGG's call for 2,000 more men. Letters received on that day announce the departure from Pensacola, for Virginia, of the Orleans Cadets, Capt. CHARLES DREUX; the Louisiana Guards, Major TODD, and the Chasseurs a Pied, Capt. ST. PAUL. These companies expect to meet, at Grand Junction, the other corps from this city.

abstract: When the Cotton States swung off into secession, and Virginia refused to follow their example, the people of the North applauded what seemed to be her devotion to the Union. They leaped at once to the conclusion that the "Mother of Presidents" would be true to her former greatness, and strong in sustaining ...
lead_paragraph: When the Cotton States swung off into secession, and Virginia refused to follow their example, the people of the North applauded what seemed to be her devotion to the Union. They leaped at once to the conclusion that the "Mother of Presidents" would be true to her former greatness, and strong in sustaining the Government she aided so largely in establishing. True, her loyalty to the Constitution was qualified. She upheld the right of secession, and while she professed to love the Union, deprecated all attempts to enforce obedience to Federal law as a violation of the rights of the States. The people of the loyal States were, however, rejoiced to find even so much of patriotism in a State where Slavery was a cherished institution, and they accepted it as a sign of possible adjustment without a resort to the arbitrament of the sword. Rebellion came surging up from the far South, and no steps were taken to arrest its progress, for fear of irritating the delicate nerves of Virginia and the Border States. The Administration of Mr. BUCHANAN was charmed into inertia by the attitude of Virginia. His Cabinet plundered the Government of its arms, and the Treasury of its funds, without rebuke. The seceding States took possession of forts, and arsenals, and mints, without one effort of resistance. True, we had a "Peace Congress." We had plenty of negotiation; plenty of talk about reorganization; about the ultimate triumph of the Constitution, and the preservation of the Union, to be effected through some mysterious agency of Virginia and the Border States.

abstract: In compliance with the call of the Metropolitan and Palace Garden Home Guard Committees, a meeting was held at the Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of consolidating the various organizations of the kind under one general organization. Delegates were present from every Ward in the city, and in some cases three or four bodies were represented ...
lead_paragraph: In compliance with the call of the Metropolitan and Palace Garden Home Guard Committees, a meeting was held at the Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of consolidating the various organizations of the kind under one general organization. Delegates were present from every Ward in the city, and in some cases three or four bodies were represented from one Ward. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER Esq. presided. Among other delegates appeared Maj.-Gen. STORMS, of the Sixth Ward, who raised the first Artillery Corps in this city during the late war. He was glad that Yorkville was represented. He said he had the honor of founding Yorkville, having in 1824 attended the sale of the "Harlem Commons," bought land and built the first houses that were elected there. [Applause] He was called crazy at the time, but he was glad he had lived to see the city extend as far as that, as he had expected it would. [Applause.] He was glad that they could raise a regiment there now. When he went there the place could not muster a corporal's guard. [Applause.]

abstract: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Bible Society was held on Thursday evening, May 2, at the Bible House, Astor-place, the President, WILLIAM ALLEN BUTLER, in the chair. The Committee for the supply of the destitute resident population, reported the visitation, by the agents in their employ ...
lead_paragraph: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Bible Society was held on Thursday evening, May 2, at the Bible House, Astor-place, the President, WILLIAM ALLEN BUTLER, in the chair. The Committee for the supply of the destitute resident population, reported the visitation, by the agents in their employ, of the First, Eleventh and Twenty-second Wards, and a distribution of 880 volumes among families in those Wards during the month of April. The principal business of the meeting related to the active operations conducted during the past month by the Committee on Military Posts and Naval Stations, in supplying the soldiers and sailors of the United States service, and the volunteer regiments with Testaments. Messrs. PIERSON, SMYTHE and GARDINES, agents of the Board, have been engaged in this important work, and have supplied the soldiers in the forts, the marines in the navy yard and on the vessels of war, and also twenty one of the volunteer regiments which have left tills City or are now stationed in it. The Testament used in this supply is a neat pocket volume, easily carried in the knapsack, and having an appropriate colored design pasted on the inside of the cover, exhibiting the stars and stripes, with the inscription below -- To the defenders of their country: Presented by the New-York Bible Society;" and also with reference to appropriate texts. The details of the distribution were given at length by the Agents, and were of great interest, the officers of the several regiments having cheerfully cooperated with the Agents of the Board in carrying out the arrangements for the supply of every man in the ranks who was without a Testament and was willing to accept it. Contributions for this special work were announced, and the Board, by a unanimous vote, authorized its further prosecution, to as to include every regiment of troops and every vessel of war passing through the City or leaving the harbor. The whole number of Testaments already distributed is over 14,000.

abstract: Government, having taken possession of the railroad between Philadelphia and Baltimore, as a military thoroughfare, is about to commence the reconstruction of the bridges. The opportunity for an invaluable public improvement is not to be lost. For twenty years past the traveling public has protested indignantly against the ferry at Havre de Grace, ...
lead_paragraph: Government, having taken possession of the railroad between Philadelphia and Baltimore, as a military thoroughfare, is about to commence the reconstruction of the bridges. The opportunity for an invaluable public improvement is not to be lost. For twenty years past the traveling public has protested indignantly against the ferry at Havre de Grace, and demanded the construction of a bridge. Travel has been delayed and rendered intolerably uncomfortable by the change of cars at that point; the mails have been kept back; and immorality and profanity largely encouraged by the gratuitous annoyance the public has been obliged to suffer. The Legislature of Maryland has persistently refused to authorize a bridge. If Government will add this to the other facilities it proposes to lend traffic between New-York and Washington, it will insure one blessing at least from the war. It will not have far to seek for a precedent. The Virginia railroads have been taken possession of by the Confederate Government as military routes. At Richmond the traveler will remember with disgust the omnibus connection between the termini of the Northern and Southern roads. In a spirit similar to that of Maryland, the Common Council of Richmond has always declined to permit a connection of the two depots by rail; and it is only now when the power has passed into despotic hands, that the nuisance is to be abated. The rails to unite the two roads are now being laid by the direction of the rebel Government. Let the example do the public a service at Havre de Grace.

abstract: THE SUPPOSED MURDER IN HOBOKEN -- A MYSTERIOUS CIRCUMSTANCE. -- The inquest upon the body of R. GATTIE, found in the water near the Elysian Fields, who had been shot and stabbed, was continued yesterday afternoon, before Coroner BOHNSTEDT, at Hoboken. GUSTAVUS PIERREZ, superintendent of the Rondout Machine Works, testified that deceased had been in his employ the last six months, as a draftsman. He left Rondout on the 21st of April for New-York, with the intention of joining a German military company for the war. Deceased was a sober and industrious man. JOHN FISCHER, a clerk, residing at No. 27 Bayard street. New-York, identified GATTIE, and was with him on Saturday last. Deceased expressed a desire to visit various places, and since he has been missing, witness had ascertained that he had visited a disreputable house on two occasions. The inquest was adjourned indefinitely, and the matter will be placed in the hands of detectives. Upon further examination, it has been ascertained that the ball which entered the heart did not pass through any of the clothing. There was also a blackened spot around the wound, caused by the close proximity of the pistol. Dr. ELDER is of opinion that the man could not have committed the deed himself. His coat, vest and shirt were found buttoned. The supposition is that he had been murdered in New-York, and the body afterwards thrown into the river.
lead_paragraph: THE SUPPOSED MURDER IN HOBOKEN -- A MYSTERIOUS CIRCUMSTANCE. -- The inquest upon the body of R. abstract: We understand that a graceless scamp who was expelled from the Twenty-Eighth Regiment because of treasonable conduct, is now going from house to house in Williamsburg, where the majority of the members of the Regiment reside, making most exaggerated statements regarding the hardships which the force was compelled to undergo on its way from this city to Annapolis. The fact that the fellow can descend to such a method of revenging himself, is the best proof that his expulsion was deserved. We can assure those having friends in the Twenty Eighth, on official authority, that the entire Regiment is in good health, and that all its wants are faithfully attended to.

abstract: PETER HART, the Ex-Metropolitan Policeman, who raised anew the Stars and Stripes which had been shot away at Fort Sumter, thereby exposing himself to the hottest of the rebels' fire, has been presented with one of TIFFANY's best English gold lever watches as a tribute to his bravery. The watch, which may be seen at TIFFANY's, bears the following inscription: "The Officers of Fort Sumter to PETER HART a tribute to fidelity and courage. April 12 and 13, 1861. Major Robert Anderson, First Artillery; Assistant Surgeon S.W. Crawford, Medical Department; Capt. A. Doubleday, First Artillery; Capt. T. Seymour. do.; Lieut. J.C. Davis, do.; Lieut. N.J. Hall, do.; Capt. J.G. Foster, Engineers; Lieut. G.W. Snyder, do.; Lieut. R.K. Meade, do."

abstract: The position of affairs at the seat of Army operations, has not materially changed within the last twenty-four hours. The most important move ment seems to have been towards Baltimore the Sixth Massachusetts Regiment having proceeded
lead_paragraph: The position of affairs at the seat of Army operations, has not materially changed within the last twenty-four hours. The most important move ment seems to have been towards Baltimore -- the Sixth Massachusetts Regiment having proceeded from Washington to the Relay House yesterday morning, where they were to be joined by a Regiment from Annapolis, and another from the Annapolis Junction. A park of Artillery, from Annapolis, was also to join them, which would swell the force to about 3,000. Our dispatch from Baltimore announces the arrival of a portion of the troops at the Relay. It is not positively known what service this body of men is to be employed on, but it is conjectured at Washington that they are intended to cooperate with the Pennsylvania troops approaching Baltimore, under command of Gen. PATTERSON, to open and hold the route through that city. They will also act as a check to any movement of secession forces from Harper's Ferry, as they have possession of the road in that direction, as well as control of the telegraph line. The approach of these troops to the Relay House was very quiet, and they had possession of everything almost before the people there were aware of their presence. More New-York troops reached Washington yesterday -- the Twenty-eighth Regiment, and part of the Thirteenth of Brooklyn.

abstract: A gun manufacturer at Norwich, Conn., has manufactured a new and terrible weapon for arming vessels to cruise for pirates and Southern privateers. It is a cylindrical bomb, about twelve inches long and sharpened with a steel point, which is thrown from a heavy gun fired from the shoulder. The projectile sticks into the deck or side of a vessel and explodes in a few seconds after being discharged. Its effect is terrific, one shell being sufficient to clear a whole ship's deck. It is intended for close action.
lead_paragraph: A gun manufacturer at Norwich, Conn., has manufactured a new and terrible weapon for arming vessels to cruise for pirates and Southern privateers. abstract: It is my pleasing duty to announce to you that the Constitution framed for the establishment of a permanent Government for the Confederate States has been ratified by Conventions in each of those States to which it was referred. abstract: We publish in another part of this morning's issue the Message of JEFFERSON DAVIS to his Congress of Confederates. It deserves careful perusal. Its general tone is apologetic, as its first and most prominent purpose is to vindicate the secession movement, and its
lead_paragraph: We publish in another part of this morning's issue the Message of JEFFERSON DAVIS to his Congress of Confederates. It deserves careful perusal. Its general tone is apologetic, -- as its first and most prominent purpose is to vindicate the secession movement, -- and its next, to throw upon the Government of the United States the responsibility of the impending war. This is certainly a double task of extraordinary difficulty, -- one to which Mr. DAVIS is manifestly unequal. That he should think it necessary at this late day, after each of the seceding States has gone over the whole ground in excuse of its own secession, is somewhat singular, and indicates possibly a suspicion on his part that the case is not yet quite free from doubt.

abstract: We publish this morning some very interesting and important diplomatic documents. The first is a dispatch from Mr. FAULKNER, our late Minister in France, reporting his interview with the French Minister, in regard to a recognition of the Southern Confederacy. This report is very nearly identical with that made
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning some very interesting and important diplomatic documents. The first is a dispatch from Mr. FAULKNER, our late Minister in France, reporting his interview with the French Minister, in regard to a recognition of the Southern Confederacy. This report is very nearly identical with that made by our Paris Correspondent, in a letter published in the TIMES some days since, and confirms its accuracy in every particular. The French Minister informed Mr. FAULNER that no application for recognition had yet been made -- that it would not be acted on hastily, and that, in his opinion, the exercise of force to preserve the Union was to be deprecated.

abstract: A SOLDIER SHOT. HUGH MCNICHOL, a member of the Second Regiment of Jersey City, on the way to Washington, was accidentally shot at Bordentown on Friday evening. Two of the soldiers were sky-larking, one having a bowie-knife and the other a revolver, when the revolver was accidentally discharged, shooting MCNICHOL, who was standing near, in the bowels. It is thought the wound will prove fatal.

abstract: We regret to announce the death of Mr.E.G.P. WILKINS, a gentleman widely known and esteemed in literary and art circles. For some days past Mr. WILKINS had been laboring under a severe attack of pneumonia. It was known that his case was critical, but his demise was sudden and unexpected, inasmuch
lead_paragraph: We regret to announce the death of Mr. E.G.P. WILKINS, a gentleman widely known and esteemed in literary and art circles. For some days past Mr. WILKINS had been laboring under a severe attack of pneumonia. It was known that his case was critical, but his demise was sudden and unexpected, inasmuch as a more favorable set of symptoms had manifested themselves, and it was hoped the crisis had been passed. This, unhappily, did not prove to be the case. On Saturday night, about 12 o'clock, he sank peacefully into the arms of death.

abstract: SHOCKING ATTEMPT AT ARSON. At a late hour on Friday night a dastardly attempt was made to fire the house No. 5 Mangin-street, occupied by Mr. EDWIN FALOONER and family. The incendiary effected an entrance by breaking out the sice-light of the rear basement door, and having procured some shavings
lead_paragraph: SHOCKING ATTEMPT AT ARSON. -- At a late hour on Friday night a dastardly attempt was made to fire the house No. 5 Mangin-street, occupied by Mr. EDWIN FALOONER and family. The incendiary effected an entrance by breaking out the sice-light of the rear basement door, and having procured some shavings and kindling-wood, which had been placed near the range, saturated them with burning fluid, and then set them on fire. The smoke, fortunately, soon awoke Mr. FALCONER, who, with a few pails of water, extinguished the flames. ANDREW L. BROWER, a son-in-law of Mr. FALCONER, is the suspected incendiary, and has been arrested. It appears that for some cause his wife had abandoned him and returned with her child to her father's house. BROWER called there on Friday, and after an angry altercation with his wife, left, saying that before morning he would have his father-in-law's life. He then, as is supposed, purchased a bottle of burning-fluid, and, returning to the house, set it on fire. Justice BRENNAN, who caused his arrest, locked him up to await the production of other testimony, which will be obtained to-day.

abstract: Emil A. Chauncey et al. vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company. -- These are four actions, which were argued together. The motion was to slay the proceedings of the defendants in the actions commenced until the further order of this Court, to be made after the appeal taken from Justice Ingraham's opinion in the omnibus case, and also to extend to the several plaintiffs time to serve complaints. These actions are all brought to recover damages order Justice Ingraham's decision -- that the defendants are liable for their over-issue of stock by their agent, Schuyler.

abstract: United States stocks went up two per cent. yesterday. This was the effect mainly of Mr. SEWARD's instructions to Mr. DAYTON, and the evidence afforded by current events that the Government is determined to meet this rebellion with vigor and resolution. Mr. SEWARD gives the world to understand that this Union shall not be broken up, -- that all the power of the Government will be used to crush the rebellion which threatens it with destruction. In the face of this declaration, and of the vigorous preparations of the Administration to prosecute the war with relentless vigor, Government stocks advance. Could there be better proof of the spirit and resolution which pervades the great mass of our people?
lead_paragraph: United States stocks went up two per cent. yesterday. abstract: It is vitally important at this time that our citizens should know just how our Army is situated, and what are its greatest wants. These hundreds of thousands of men in various parts of the country, who are to light our battles, and bear exposure and cold and sickness and wounds in defending our common liberties, are the elite of our youth. On them depends the future strength and glory of the nation. They are bone of our bone and flesh of our flesh, bound by uncounted ties to every county and almost every circle in the Free States. Whatever concerns them -- whatever will help them, or shield them from suffering, or guard them from evil, or elevate or ennoble them, is the first of all interests now to the whole people. Our young men are now throughout the country to assume a new position: they are to take up camp-life.

abstract: This Regiment is now being formed under the supervision of Col. RAMSEY, late of the regular army -- an officer who served with distinction in the army of the United States during the war with Mexico. His experience in organizing, drilling, and disciplining men, as well as fitting them for the field, is invaluable at this time. He had charge of the camp of instruction at Palo Alto, for the ten additional regiments which were incorporated in the army in 1846. These regiments afterwards distinguished themselves during the war, subsequent to the battles in the Valley of Mexico. Col. RAMSEY was ordered to Vera Cruz to organize another army, consisting of regulars and volunteers, of 5,000 men. He is now in the prime of life, and quit the service after the war, having often held the important commands of brigades and divisions of the army. Many of his officers will be graduates of West Point. There will also be others of great military experience. Some of the non commissioned officers will be men who have served in the field. The Regiment will be thoroughly equipped with camp equipage, transportation, a full commissariat, medical stores, &c. The men are to be thoroughly drilled and made efficient to take the field as soon as possible. The head-quarters of the Regiment are at present at No. 86 Cedar-street, where those gentlemen who have heretofore served in the regular army, and are desirous of returning to the service, are requested to send their address; and those who desire to join as officers, who have served, may report in person, and those non-commissioned officers who have seen seen service in the field, and others who desire appointments, may also apply in person.

abstract: We have already noticed the robbery by the Virginians of Capt. PETER METSGAR, of Keyport, N.J., who fell into the hands of the pirates when trying to purchase a cargo of oysters. He lost about $500. Capt. WATTS, of the schooner Conductor, has also just returned to Keyport, having had a narrow escape from seizure, which was prevented by his being notified as he lay at anchor in the Rappahannock, by three negroes, who very carelessly rowed around his vessel for over an hour, and finally slipped up to her and said: "Massa, you hid better git outer here, base Virginny's quit" This was the first notice that Capt. WATTS had of secession. He immediately took the hint and left for the lower bay, finished loading, and caine away, forgetting to pay his inspection fee. Several other vessels have just arrived, all having had narrow escapes from seizure, and a number are due, the owners of which are very apprehensive that they have fallen into bad hands.

abstract: These enteprising gentry, undeterred by the law recently enacted, which makes the following of their vocation a felony, are still at work. On Sunday, Wm. Long, of No. 50 Cherry-street, while looking at the barracks in the Park, had his pocket picked of a valuable watch, but fortunately he secured the thief, and an accomplice to whom the watch had been passed. The prisoners are known as Thomas Maynard and James Williamson, and the watch was found on the person of Maynard. They were taken before Justice KELLY, who looked them up to answer.

abstract: THE STORM. -- The fine weather of Sunday last gave encouragement to the hope that the season for planting and gardening, so long deferred by the hitherto "cold and backward Spring," had come at last. Yesterday, however, proved one of the stormiest of the season. The rain set in early in the morning, and, with an increasing gale from the Southeast, continuedalmost without intermission through the day. All out-door business was suspended, and there was little traveling abroad. The troops on the Battery had a severe foretaste of the hardships of camp-life, the grounds being flooded with water, their tents proving only a partial protection to the descending floods. It was feared that this sudden exposure of so many persons unused to the soldier's life would produce a harvest of colds and their concomitant diseases. The booths in the Park furnished good shelter for those having the good fortune to be quartered there. The streets have been thoroughly cleaned by the falling rain, and the City thus rendered all the more healthy for citizens and the thousands of strangers who are now passing through it on the way to the seat of war.

abstract: It has been charged upon the people of the North that they entertain unjust prejudices, and indulge a hatred against the people of the South. We deny it. The converse of this has always been true. The terms "Southern chivalry" and "Southern honor" were originally used among us in sober earnestness, denoting our appreciation of what was once the Southern character, and our admiration of its high attributes. If they have come to be spoken in irony, or in a spirit of ridicule, the fault is not ours. If the progress of degeneracy at the South, the growing arrogance and presumption of its people, have forced upon us a change in the estimation in which they were once held, the blame rests not upon us.
lead_paragraph: It has been charged upon the people of the North that they entertain unjust prejudices, and indulge a hatred against the people of the South. We deny it. abstract: The Twentieth Regiment New-York State Militia, Col. BRETT, from Ulster County, consisting of seven hundred and fifty men, which has been quartered at the barracks, in the Park, during the last week, and which was yesterday morning ordered to return home, has suddenly had its order countermanded, and they are ordered to Washington. They received their arms on Saturday -- the imported rifle muskets -- in place of the clumsy arms brought here; and instead of going home to be laughed at by their neighbors, which they were all very much opposed to, they are now ordered southward, to participate in active duty in defence of the Government. They were asked to enlist for three years, but many of the men had left families at home, and were willing to serve for any time inside of a year, but not longer. A company of 100 from Rhinebeck, and another of the same number from Catskill, which arrived last evening, joined their Ulster County brethren and will go forward with them, making in all about 1,000 men. The orders for their departure arrived last evening at 7 1/4 o'clock; by quarter part eight, two days' rations had been served out to the men, everything was packed and the regiment was ready to start. Owing, however, to the inclemency of the weather, the hour for departure was postponed till 9 o'clock this morning.
lead_paragraph: The Twentieth Regiment New-York State Militia, Col. BRETT, from Ulster County, consisting of seven hundred and fifty men, which has been quartered at the barracks, in the Park, during the last week, and which was yesterday morning ordered to return home, has suddenly had its order countermanded, and they are ordered to Washington. They received their arms on Saturday -- the imported rifle muskets -- in place of the clumsy arms brought here; and instead of going home to be laughed at by their neighbors, which they were all very much opposed to, they are now ordered southward, to participate in active duty in defence of the Government. They were asked to enlist for three years, but many of the men had left families at home, and were willing to serve for any time inside of a year, but not longer. A company of 100 from Rhinebeck, and another of the same number from Catskill, which arrived last evening, joined their Ulster County brethren and will go forward with them, making in all about 1,000 men. The orders for their departure arrived last evening at 7 1/4 o'clock; by quarter part eight, two days' rations had been served out to the men, everything was packed and the regiment was ready to start. Owing, however, to the inclemency of the weather, the hour for departure was postponed till 9 o'clock this morning.

abstract: The officers at the Quartermaster's Department were last evening surprised by the arrival at this port of Lieut. DE LANIEL and his Company 01 Artillery, consisting of 52 men, from Wilmington, N.C. They arrived in a sailing vessel, the command being in good health. This vessel was one of the twenty odd which have been detained at that port by order of the secession authorities, and finally ordered away by parties holding the command of the port. The company remained on board during the night.

abstract: The election of officers of the Board of Commissioners of the Central Park took place on Saturday last, and resulted as follows: R.M. BLATCHFORD, President, reelected; HENRY G. STEBBINS, Vice-President, in place of JNO. A.C. GRAY, declined: DANIEL H. GREENE, Treasurer, reelected; Mr. FIELDS, Secretary, reelected. The work on the Park will be continued during the Summer, though the expenditures will be less than heretofore. The work of planting trees is now being prosecuted with vigor. The old arsenal in the Park has been surrendered to the use of soldiers, by whom it is now occupied.

abstract: If there is one thing that the Confederate States need more than anything else, at this perilous juncture, it is -- cash. Their credit down there is always good. Their loans are always, asked for before they are ready -- and always taken at part --and sometimes at a premium! Discrimination in favor of their own cherished citizens, is invariably made, and Bankers of distant nations (the ROTHSCHILDS, for instance) refused the smallest share of their eight per cent, coupon bonds!

abstract: There is no present interruption of trains over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and the Legislature reassembles to-day. Since the failure of the Committee of Safety bill, the Secessionists, it is said, will not attempt to call a Convention. If they do the Union men will insist that the question of Convention or no Convention shall be submitted to the people at the election for Delegates.

abstract: The condition of affairs at the Federal Capital does not appear to have changed much during the last twenty-four hours. The number of troops there has been augmented by the arrival of two regiments from New-Jersey, but no movement indicating a specific line of operations on the part of the Government has been made. The people across the river in Alexandria have been much alarmed at the recent reports that the Federal troops would soon take possession of that place, and many of them have left their homes in consequence. The Virginia militia who were quartered there have also left precipitately, and taken up a new position at Culpepper Court-house, a little further from supposed danger. The plans of the Government are kept so secret that it is impossible to tell in what direction the first movement will be made, but it is more than probable that we shall soon hear of the reoccupation of Harper's Ferry by the United States troops.

abstract: At a regular meeting of this Board, last evening, a resolution was offered to appoint a Special Committee to inquire into the manner in which the Union Defense Committee were discharging their duties, but it was met by a communication from the Committee, inviting the cooperation of one Councilman from each Ward to carry out the purposes of their organization. It was referred to a Committee of four, one from each district. The Committee Mr. BARNEY, Chairman, reported, after a brief consultation, the names of the Councilmen designated to cooperate with the Union Defence Committee, viz.: Councilmen Barney, Bickford, Hogan, Shannon, Hall, Jones, Miller, Ryan, Gross, Repper, Smith, Hazieton, Lent, Keech, Orton, Cleveland, Stevenson, Long, Curnen, Brice, Brandon, Pinckney, This list includes every member of the Board, except Mr. OTTIWELL, who is absent with his regiment (Twelfth,) and Mr. TROTTER, who is sick.

abstract: A correspondent of the Washington Sunday Chronicle, writing on board the Sabine, off Pensacola, under date of April 20, gives details of the recent unsuccessful attempt on the part of the Rebels to get possession of Fort Fickens by bribery. Lieut. SLEMMER, having had his suspicions aroused by the frequent passage of letters and papers between the Fort and Warrington, gave orders that all such communications must be stopped. The very next day a roll of papers was sent over from Warrington to a sergeant, which Lieut. SLEMMER opened and examined. He was rewarded for his trouble by finding a note inclosed, making vague offers to the man if he would betray his trust. A watch was set over the sergeant, and the next day another package came over, addressed to the same man, and having this note inclossd:

abstract: The Thirty-Third Anniversary of this Society was held at Irving Hall, Irving-place, last evening. The audience was quite large, considering the unpropitious state of the weather. The platform was occupied by many prominent gentlemen identified with the seamen's cause -- WILLIAM A. BOOTH, Esq., the President, in the chair. Rev. Dr. HUTTON offered up a prayer, after which an abstract of the annual report was read by Rev. H. LOOMIS, one of the Secretaries, from which it seems that over two hundred converted sailors have been supplied with well-selected libraries for the forecastle during the two past years.

abstract: Prof. HAMILTON's lecture, at Bellevue Hospital, last Friday, was one of unusual interest. It would seem, from the Professor's remarks, almost impossible for a man to be killed by a bullet. After speaking on the different varieties of shot and shell need in modern warfare, and exhibiting them to his audience, Dr. HAMILTON observed that it was impossible to conceive of all the variety of accidents to which the soldier is liable from such a variety of instruments. The Army and Navy surgeons had related many extraordinary cases which had occurred in their experience. A slight resistance, in many cases, would destroy the line of direction of the missile. Should a ball strike a bone, for instance, in an oblique direction, the ball would not penetrate, nor in some cases even fracture the bone, but would glance off, and either go to some other part of the body or fall to the ground. Nor is such a hard substance as bone always necessary to turn off the missile. Mr. HENNING related a case where a man received a ball full upon the neck, beneath the chin, when, instead of preserving its original direction, meeting with some resistance it glanced off, and went completely round the neck, making its exit where it first entered. Another case was mentioned where a man received a ball upon the chest, which penetrated to the rib, when it glanced off and made half the circuit of the body, coming out behind. And still another, in which the abdomen was struck, the ball making its exit behind, as in the last case. In all these cases the patients had recovered. Still more remarkable, says Dr. HAMILTON, are those cases where the bullet has entered the chest, striking upon the pleura pulmonalis, (the covering of the lungs,) has turned from its line of direction, and gone entirely round the lung, lodging itself in the back. Prof. H. mentioned a case of the kind, where the man recovered without any serious result; and also one in which the skull was penetrated, but the brain uninjured, the missile meeting with the dura mater, (the covering of the brain,) and glancing off as in the other cases. Many cases of this kind were mentioned by the Doctor, the only explanation being, as far as he could see, in the fact that the force of the ball becomes spent when it reaches the body, and thus it is easily turned from the straight line, when it meets with any resisting substance, naturally going in that direction where there is the least resistance.

Should a ball strike a bone, for instance, in an oblique direction, the ball would not penetrate, nor in some cases even fracture the bone, but would glance off, and either go to some other part of the body or fall to the ground. Nor is such a hard substance as bone always necessary to turn off the missile. Mr. HENNING related a case where a man received a ball full upon the neck, beneath the chin, when, instead of preserving its original direction, meeting with some resistance it glanced off, and went completely round the neck, making its exit where it first entered. Another case was mentioned where a man received a ball upon the chest, which penetrated to the rib, when it glanced off and made half the circuit of the body, coming out behind. Prof. H. mentioned a case of the kind, where the man recovered without any serious result; and also one in which the skull was penetrated, but the brain uninjured, the missile meeting with the dura mater, (the covering of the brain,) and glancing off as in the other cases. abstract: The Mormon General Conference convened on the 6th, in the Tabernacle, in this city, and continued two days. It was crowdingly attended, especially on the second day, Sunday. The weather was good, but keenly cold for the season, a northerly wind blowing most of the time; indeed, the chilling breezes still hail from that point, bringing the other day a slight peppering of snow and hail.

abstract: It is amusing to see the bewilderment of the merely partisan Press in the chaos of these times. When the alarm was sounded that the Union was in danger, political organizations were shivered in an hour. The Democratic Party, the Republican Party, and all the little asteroids and aerolites that went skirring through the political heavens, were dashed to pieces, and from the fragments up rose one great, solid, impregnable and overwhelming Union Party, joined together by a common spirit of patriotism, cemented by a common love of country and impelled by a common resolve for its preservation. Old prejudices and animosities were forgotten, old platforms smashed to pieces, old associations broken up. Men everywhere hailed each other as brothers in the great cause of saving the Republic from the dangers that menaced it.
lead_paragraph: It is amusing to see the bewilderment of the merely partisan Press in the chaos of these times. Old prejudices and animosities were forgotten, old platforms smashed to pieces, old associations broken up. Men everywhere hailed each other as brothers in the great cause of saving the Republic from the dangers that menaced it.

abstract: In one of his recent speeches at Chicago, Senator DOUGLAS affirmed that the plan of the conspirators for the establishment of the Montgomery Government was matured more than a twelvemonth since, and that the election of President LINCOLN had nothing to do with it. There is no doubt that the whole matter was concocted by a very few individuals, disappointed, as Mr. STEPHENS said, in their political aspirations; and that they have sought to carry it through according to a very ingenious and masterly programme, that was devised for them five-and-twenty years ago, and then published in a work of fiction, written by Prof. BEVERLEY TUCKER, of William and Mary College, a leading politician of the school of nullification and disunion. The volume to which we refer, is a novel entitled The Partisan Leader, which was intended as the pioneer of a series of similar works, composed with the view of disseminating disunion sentiments in the Southern States. Even the masterly genius of DISRAELI, however, has failed to give vitality to the political novel; and it is no reflection upon Mr. TUCKER to say that the reading public did not manifest sufficient interest in his enterprise to make it worth his while to pursue it. His disunion novel fell still-born from the Press, and its successors never saw the light -- but recent events have caused the exhumation of the Partisan Leader, and we are indebted to the National Intelligencer for the preservation of so much of its contents as is of interest in the present connection.

abstract: Barrow C. Watson et al. vs. Selaen C. Warner et als. -- This action is brought to recover damages for a breach of contract in refusing to carry freight. The defendants, it appears, are shippers in this City, and in September, 1859, entered into an agreement with the plaintiffs to carry to London 4,700 barrels of crude turpentine, on board their ship, the Margaret Evans. The defendants, it appears, took into the ship 2,728 barrels of the turpentine, and then refused to take any more. The plaintiff claims thereby that he has sustained damage to the extent of $375. The defendants deny all the allegations in the complaint, except the making of the contract; and deny further that they agreed that plaintiff should have in said agreement any part of the carrying space of the Margaret Evans. The case is still on.
lead_paragraph: Barrow C. Watson et al. vs. Selaen C. Warner et als. -- This action is brought to recover damages for a breach of contract in refusing to carry freight. abstract: Some days ago we heard that Judge ALBERT JACKSON was having trouble in some of the counties of his district on account of his strong Union position and declarations. The particulars have come to hand. The trouble in Ripley County was caused by an order of Judge JACKSON, requiring all attorneys practising before his Court to renew the oath of allegiance to the Constitution of the United States, on pain of being prohibited to appear as counsel in civil or criminal wars. At Greenville, Wayne County, the attorneys took the oath, though with much reluctance; but at Doniphan, in Ripley County, on the 22d ult., the lawyers refused the oath, and the citizens took possession of the offices of the Sheriff and Clerk, and refused to allow the Court to sit. A meeting was held denouncing the order of the Judge, and asking him to revoke it. Judge ALBERT JACKSON never revokes. He plays as clean and close a hand as ever won in the world.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The burlesque of "Hiawatha" was revived here on Monday night, for the purpose of introducing Mr. JEFFERSON in a new part. Good acting made the piece which is not brilliant a success when it was first produced, and has given it a temporary vitality. Mr. JEFFERSON contrives to
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The burlesque of "Hiawatha" was revived here on Monday night, for the purpose of introducing Mr. JEFFERSON in a new part. Good acting made the piece -- which is not brilliant -- a success when it was first produced, and has given it a temporary vitality. Mr. JEFFERSON contrives to give point to the dullest language, and in several overwhelming, tours, literally convulses the House. Mrs. JOHN WOOD has an opportunity to display herself to great advantage in a charming costume, and we need scarcely add, never loses an atom of her astonishing vivacity. The other parts are moderately well played. The piece will be repeated during the week, preceded by a farce called "Lend Me Five Shillings," in which Mr. JEFFERSON is immense.
headline: {'main': 'Amusements.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Amusements.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are some among us who cannot see how the position of the State of Kentucky, in failing to respond favorably to the Proclamation of the President of the United States, ...
lead_paragraph: There are some among us who cannot see how the position of the State of Kentucky, in failing to respond favorably to the Proclamation of the President of the United States, calling for volunteers to sustain the Constitution and laws of the country, is consistent with the just requirements of patriotism and loyalty. The hasty and insulting dispatch forwarded by the Governor of the State, MAGOFFIN, to Secretary CAMERON, might perhaps be overlooked as the passionate impulse of a weak man who did not reflect the sentiments of his constituency. But we have abundant evidence, that while the people of Kentucky in great part condemn the manner of MAGOFFIN's reply, they do, with very great unanimity, approve his abrupt refusal to call out any volunteers in response to the President's Proclamation. How is this fact compatible with the existence in Kentucky of any loyalty to the Union, or any desire to preserve it?
headline: {'main': 'Position of Kentucky Armed Neutrality Explained.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Position of Kentucky Armed Neutrality Explained.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Nothing has yet transpired at Washington tending to indicate the intentions of the Government, further than the general preparations which point to a decisive stroke in some direction--but whether it will be at Norfolk, at Alexandria, at Richmond,...
lead_paragraph: Nothing has yet transpired at Washington tending to indicate the intentions of the Government, further than the general preparations which point to a decisive stroke in some direction -- but whether it will be at Norfolk, at Alexandria, at Richmond, or at Harper's Ferry, is simply a matter of conjecture. It still remains probable, however, that Harper's Ferry will be the first scene of conflict -- unless, indeed, the rumor that Gov. LETCHER intends to withdraw the Virginia troops now in possession there should prove true, in which case the Government would quietly reoccupy the post. From across the Potomac, we hear that a considerable number of Virginia troops have again assembled at Alexandria, but this is in accordance with the proclamation of Gov. LETCHER, which designated Alexandria as the rallying point of the militia from several counties. They seem to have no specific object in view, and their stay there will probably be short, as they are already short of provisions. Troops from Montgomery, to the number of about two thousand, have reached Richmond, and constitute the first installment of the army of eighteen thousand, spoken of by JEFF. DAVIS in his recent message to the Confederate Congress.

abstract: Volunteering has had a sad effect on many poor families in the City -- their homes being, broken up and the children left adrift. Numbers of these little creatures are coming to the News Boys' Lodging House and the Children's Aid Society, while the means of these charitable institutions are exceedingly straitened by the times, and they are not able to do as much as they would desire for them. Why can not some of the funds collected for the families of the Volunteers be appropriated to the children of these brave fellows, through these existing Societies?

abstract: On the 2d inst., there were at Cairo 5,250 troops, 30 pieces of cannon, and a full supply of ammunition. The cannon were planted and well protected.
lead_paragraph: On the 2d inst., there were at Cairo 5,250 troops, 30 pieces of cannon, and a full supply of ammunition. The cannon were planted and well protected. The preparations for defence were complete, and no fears entertained of any successful assault. The excitement had very much subsided, owing to the consciousness of security. The feeling at Paducah and Columbus, Ky., the points from which in attack was threatened, was also said to be more reasonable and pacific.

abstract: The Brokers' Circular reports : The sales of the week have been 80,000 bales, including 12,000 to speculators, and 12,000 to exporters. The market is active...
lead_paragraph: The Brokers' Circular reports: The sales of the week have been 80,000 bales, including 12,000 to speculators, and 12,000 to exporters. The market is active, and all qualities have advanced partially 1/8d., chiefly on the good staples, which are scarce. The sales of Friday reached 20,000 bales, of which speculators and exporters took 10,000 bales. The advices from America, per Nova Scotian and Kangaroo, containing the news of the hostilities at Charleston, caused an unsettled and excited market, with a further advance of 1/8 d lb. on all descriptions, while holders demanded an advance of 1/4 d. abstract: The plan suggested by the Governor of Georgia for replenishing the Treasury of the C. S. A., does not seem to be very successful.
lead_paragraph: The plan suggested by the Governor of Georgia for replenishing the Treasury of the C.S.A., does not seem to be very successful. It will be recollected that he suggests to Southern debtors to repudiate their debts owing by them to Northern merchants and banks, and to invest the amount in the loan of the new Confederation, to be paid back to them when peace shall be restored. The Georgia debtor is entirely satisfied with the suggestion, so far as repudiation is concerned. He is altogether pleased with that, but the other idea of investing in C.S.A. stock is not quite so clear to him. He naturally asks what he is to gain by that. He has no objection to being dishonest for a consideration, but he is not so patriotically knavish as to play the scoundrel for the good of the State. Besides, he shrewdly asks, if he is thus invited to repudiate for the good of the State, why may not the State repudiate for its own benefit? Then again he inquires whether, when the war shall be over, and forced loans and taxation shall leave anything in his hands to be reached by execution, his creditor may not compel him to pay whether he will or not? If this question shall be answered in the affirmative, then the inquiry suggests itself, whether it is not a good deal easier to invest money in Southern stocks than to realize anything from the investment? On the whole, while there is plenty of refusal to pay on the part of the Southern debtors, we do not hear of their making any very extensive investments in C.S.A. stocks -- wherefrom we infer that repudiation is more popular, than patriotism down South.

abstract: CHANGE OF TIME AND TERMINUS ON THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD. The Long Island Railroad Com
lead_paragraph: CHANGE OF TIME AND TERMINUS ON THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD. -- The Long Island Railroad Company, having completed their extensive arrangements for their new terminus at Hunter's Point, will commence and terminate running at that point on Thursday next. The freight trains have already been changed, and the passenger trains will commence running on Thursday. On and after Friday, May 11, in accordance with the advertisement, passenger trains will take their departure from, and arrive at, the new depot at Hunter's Point. The trains will leave as follows; Leave James slip Ferry, New-York, 9 A.M. for Greenport; 12 M. for Syosset; 3:30 P.M. for Yaphank; 4:30 A. M. for Syosset; 5:30 P. M. for Farmingdale, and 4:30 for Jamaica.

abstract: A good many years ago the rebellious Governor of South Carolina, then Mr. Representative PICKENS, in the Congress of the United States, announced on the floor of the House, ...
lead_paragraph: A good many years ago the rebellious Governor of South Carolina, then Mr. Representative PICKENS, in the Congress of the United States, announced on the floor of the House, to the general amazement of his colleagues and of the country, that he was "born insensible to fear." His proclamation to the volunteers of South Carolina, which we published yesterday, is the pattern of such a manifesto as might be expected from an egotist and braggart capable of making such a public exhibition of himself. He is one of those self-sufficient, arrogant, overbearing, patronizing creatures, run in the same mold precisely with JEFFERSON DAVIS; and the way in which he takes the Old Dominion under the wing of a Palmetto regiment, must be especially gratifying to Gen. LEE and the other prominent deserters from the regular army, who are now in command of her militia.

abstract: We have intelligence from Fort Pickens to April 28. The most startling occurrence of late seems to...
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence from Fort Pickens to April 28. The most startling occurrence of late seems to have been the escape from among the Confederate forces of a man who was doubtless playing the spy for Lieut. SLEMMER's benefit. He managed to rob a room-mate of $180 in cash before he left the Confederates, then hired a negro to row him down the bay, and when well out from shore obliged the boy to take him over to Fort Pickens, threatening to take his life it he did not do so.

abstract: The solemnities attendant upon the obsequies of the late Bishop ONDERDONK were witnessed by thousands who crowded Trinity Church yesterday afternoon. The interior of the edifice was appropriately...
lead_paragraph: The solemnities attendant upon the obsequies of the late Bishop ONDERDONK were witnessed by thousands who crowded Trinity Church yesterday afternoon. The interior of the edifice was appropriately draped for the occasion -- the altar, the stalls of the choristers, the pulpit, the eagle lectern, the reredos, the credence tables, the organ and the ornaments being shrouded in mourning. The chancel and the body of the Church were filled with the clergy of this and neighboring dioceses -- no less than several hundred of that reverend body being present in full canonicals. Bishop POTTER, Bishop ODENHEIMER, of New-Jersey, Rev. Drs. VINTON, TYNG, HAWKS, HIGBEE, MORGAN, and Rev. Mr. OGILBY, were comprised in the number. So great was the anxiety to witness the impressive services that the steps of the chancel and of the pulpit, and even the seats reserved for the clergy, were occupied by spectators, the greater proportion of whom were ladies.

abstract: ARREST OF ONE OF EX-MARSHALL RYNDERS'
lead_paragraph: DEPUTIES -- THE ESCAPE OF CAPT. LATHAM. -- Marshal MURRAY, yesterday, secured the arrest of JOHN COLLIGAN, the ex-Deputy Marshal under RYNDERS, for permitting Capt. LATHAM, of the slave bark Cora, who was committed to the Tombs for trial as a slaver, to escape. It will be recollected that the Captain escaped while COLLIGAN was ostensibly trying on a suit of clothes at the BROOKS BROTHERS, on his recommendation. It was suspected at the time that the escape of the Captain was not unexpected by COLLIGAN, and his voluntary absence from the City strengthened the suspicion, and a warrant was issued for his arrest. A few days since the Marshal was informed that COLLIGAN might possibly be found around the decks of the lower part of the City, and he determined to arrest him. On examination, it was found that an ex-Deputy had the warrant in his possession, and that any attempt to get that warrant would again cause the absence of COLLIGAN. The Marshal therefore had a duplicate warrant issued, which was placed in the hands of the Harbor Police, who yesterday morning found Mr. COLLIGAN, and he was rendered up to the Marshal and justice. He was committed to the Tombs for examination.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, Judge McCUNN, who had just returned from the seat of war, came upon the Bench, and was greeted with enthusiastic applause, which the efforts of the officers were unable for a moment to check.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, Judge MCCUNN, who had just returned from the seat of war, came upon the Bench, and was greeted with enthusiastic applause, which the efforts of the officers were unable for a moment to check. His Honor's physique appeared to have been the gainer by the rough experience of camp life, and he presented an aspect quite thoroughly bronzed. After completing the present term of the Court, he will return to Washington with his Regiment, the Seventy-fifth.

abstract: Such was the import of certain telegraphic dispatches that passed, on Monday, between Messrs. DIX, WADSWORTH and DRAPER, and...
lead_paragraph: Such was the import of certain telegraphic dispatches that passed, on Monday, between Messrs. DIX, WADSWORTH and DRAPER, and Gov. MORGAN; and which have got into the papers. We cannot conceive that, there is any serious cause of alarm at Washington from a foreign force. How could any army be marched up and thrown across the Potomac, all the crossings and approaches being commanded on this side, in strength great enough to endanger Washington, and their advance not be known to so sagacious and prudent a General as WINFIELD SCOTT, until the very last month, when the telegraph has to be implored to fetch means of rescue? It does not look at all reasonable, and we await developments.

abstract: Whoever supposes that the conflict now waging in these States, is peculiar to this side of the Atlantic, or to this Continent, or that it ...
lead_paragraph: Whoever supposes that the conflict now waging in these States, is peculiar to this side of the Atlantic, or to this Continent, or that it was contingent upon, or the result of the late Presidential election, makes a very great mistake. A reference to the history of the last few decades will show that the universal drift all over the civilized world has been towards liberalism, towards the breaking up of despotisms and the advancement of human rights. The genius and spirit of the age, moving all over the face of the earth, points to the amelioration of the condition of the great masses, -- the millions who do the work and on whose shoulders rest the ultimate burthens of Government. England, the most enlightened and liberal of monarchies, has been and still is engaged in extending the privileges and promoting the interests of her working classes. She is now dealing with the great questions of universal suffrage, the reduction of her pension lists, the diffusion of education and the elevation of her masses. France, though under the dictation of a single will -- a dictation based upon the immense popularity of the man who wields it -- is still, in her theory of government and constitutional enactments, making long strides in a career of liberalism. Prussia, by the adoption of the habeas corpus, the trial by jury, and her system of free education -- all the results of a generation -- has moved a vast way forward. In Russia, the system of serfdom has fallen before the march of liberalism. Austria has been compelled to grant a Constitution, comparatively liberal in its guarantees, to her empire and her provinces. In Italy, the great world-movement has culminated in revolution and the regeneration of a people. All over Europe is sounding the note of preparation for new movements in favor of liberalism. Underlying and impelling forward this current of events, is the great fact of a constant struggle between popular rights and despotic sway, -- a struggle that has been going on for decades, kept alive and strengthened by the genius and spirit of the age in which we live. Even in Mexico, that unhappy country, given over almost to anarchy, plundered by demagogues and deluded by a bigoted and corrupt priesthood, we can trace the spirit of liberalism, striving for the emancipation of the millions, the enlightening and upbuilding of the masses who work.
headline: {'main': 'The Spirit of the Age.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Spirit of the Age.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The officers and men of the Fourteenth Regiment were in a high state of excitement last night, and rejoiced exceedingly at the prospect of a speedy departure for the seat of war. The cause of the unwanted...
lead_paragraph: The officers and men of the Fourteenth Regiment were in a high state of excitement last night, and rejoiced exceedingly at the prospect of a speedy departure for the seat of war. The cause of the unwonted excitement was the receipt of a telegraphic dispatch from Major-General DURYEA, at Albany, to the effect that he should return by the next train, and that he had orders for the Regiment. Of course it would be highly improper to state the nature of these orders, for the reason that no one here knows the purport of them. But it is generally believed that the orders are to march forthwith. The Fourteenth is now in complete order for field duty, and is under better drill and discipline than ever it was before.

abstract: was quartered with his regiment in DEVLIN's new building, in Canal-street, and on the 29th ult., late at night, proceeded to the fourth story to sleep. Towards morning the sentinel on the lower floor heard a noise in the dummy, which reaches from the top to the cellar of the building. He immediately proceeded to search for the cause, and found deceased in the dummy, insensible. He was conveyed to the Hospital, and died on Monday night. It is supposed that he mistook the door of the dummy for the door of a closet, and in the dark made the misstep which caused his death. Deceased was a native of Ireland; 27 years of age, a carpenter by trade, and a single man. He was attached to Warren Rose Company, No. 33.

abstract: The brig Gen. Boyd arrived at this port yesterday, from Savannah, bringing thirty-three passengers, of whom all but three were laborers and stevedores, belonging here and at Quebec. They had escaped...
lead_paragraph: The brig Gen. Boyd arrived at this port yesterday, from Savannah, bringing thirty-three passengers, of whom all but three were laborers and stevedores, belonging here and at Quebec. They had escaped from the place on account of its disturbed condition, and the prostration of all business. They each obtained a certificate as British subjects, but for which they would have been detained, and impressed into the Southern army.

abstract: We regret to be obliged to record the death of WM. P. CLAWSON, who has been Foreman in the Press-room of the TIMES since the day it was started. He died yesterday morning, at his residence in Fourth-street, after a severe illness of about ten days. He was a man of marked energy of character, an excellent workman, devoted to his business, and faithful and trustworthy in all the relations of life. He leaves a wife and four children to mourn his loss. His funeral will take place at his late, residence No. 6 Fourth-street, on Friday morning, at 10 o'clock.

abstract: John Matthews, James Berryman, and John Kromet, members of Col. McChesney's Regiment of National Zouaves, were arrested on Monday after-...
lead_paragraph: John Matthews, James Berryman, and John Kromet, members of Col. McChesney's Regiment of National Zouaves, were arrested on Monday afternoon, charged with having committed a felonious assault upon officer McArthur, of the Twenty-third Precinct. It appears that the officer recently arrested Matthews for disorderly conduct, thereby making him an enemy. On Monday afternoon, while McArthur was on duty in Eighty-sixth-street, Matthews commenced an assault upon him, being aided therein by Berryman and Kromet. The ruffians at length succeeded in wresting the officer's club from his grasp, and beating him terribly with it. McArthur obtained assistance eventually, and conveyed one of the ruffians to the station-house, but immediately after became insensible from the beating he had received. He remained unconscious throughout the night, and his attending pysician pronounced his condition exceedingly critical. The other rowdies were subsequently arrested by officers of the Yorkville Police Court, and Justice BROWNELL locked them up for trial in default of $1,500 bail each.

abstract: It looks not at all unlikely now that the first conflict in the field in the civil war that impends will occur in Western Virginia, and between ...
lead_paragraph: It looks not at all unlikely now that the first conflict in the field in the civil war that impends will occur in Western Virginia, and between the loyal Union citizens of Virginia and the Secessionists who are trying to revolutionize the State. The spirit of resistance to the decree of secession is spreading rapidly and widely in the West. Already have large and enthusiastic meetings been held in Morgantown, Wheeling, Wellsburgh, Cameron, Moundsville, Berwood, New-Martinsburgh, Fairmont, Grafton, and other important central towns of Northwestern Virginia, by which resolutions have been passed, declaring the purpose of determined and undying opposition to the attempted withdrawal of Virginia from the Union.
