abstract: While there is no satisfactory evidence that iron or steel-clad ships are a failure, it may be wise for our Government to avail itself of the facts elicited by costly European experiments, before undertaking the construction of a mailed fleet, if not to postpone all great expenditures in this directioon, until La Gloire, ...
lead_paragraph: While there is no satisfactory evidence that iron or steel-clad ships are a failure, it may be wise for our Government to avail itself of the facts elicited by costly European experiments, before undertaking the construction of a mailed fleet, if not to postpone all great expenditures in this directioon, until La Gloire, The Warrior, &c., have experienced some heavy weather and Armstrong projectiles. To this end, this Government should send abroad one or two competent engineers, who are familiar with the subject and the men, to make a detailed, specific and practical report, rather than to rely on foreign newspaper gossip and discussion, the best data we now have.

abstract: The weakness of the South in all the material elements of wealth and social stability is most strikingly manifested in every seceded State. There is, in the nature of things, no reason why secession should affect the regular workings of society in the Southern States more seriously than in the Northern.
lead_paragraph: The weakness of the South in all the material elements of wealth and social stability is most strikingly manifested in every seceded State. There is, in the nature of things, no reason why secession should affect the regular workings of society in the Southern States more seriously than in the Northern. The result to each section is the same. There is a loss of trade, there is a failure of confidence, there is a general derangement of business. And in each section there is accepted war, and all the exhausting preparations going on to meet it. If any difference were seen, one would expect to find the Northern communities more disturbed, and their business more shattered by the existence of hostilities; because of the notorious fact that the Southern people owe many millions of dollars to Northern merchants and manufacturers, and that payment is almost universally withheld. This fact of the practical confiscation of perhaps two hundred millions of dollars of Northern property by the people at the South, would incline us to think that comparative ease would pervade their section -- while with us of the Free States would be found the ruin and dismay resulting from a state of almost universal bankruptcy.

lead_paragraph: Brig. Gen. COCKE (we never saw Gen. COCKE. We never heard of him. We didn't know there was such a man in existence. What his birth-piece or lineage may be, we cannot tell. Whether he is of plebeian origin or an F.F.V., we have not the slightest idea. That he is a Brigadier-General, and at the present speaking hails from Virginia, seems to be a fixed fact. At all events we shall enter into no controversy on the subject, assuming the truth to be as stated. That he commands the "Military troops and defences on the Potomac border of Virginia," we shall take for granted according to his own showing.)

abstract: The Twenty-seventh Anniversary of this Society was held yesterday morning and afternoon, at the Chapel of the Home for the Friendless, in Twentyninth-street.
lead_paragraph: The Twenty-seventh Anniversary of this Society was held yesterday morning and afternoon, at the Chapel of the Home for the Friendless, in Twenty-ninth-street. There was a large attendance of the friends of the institution, and much interest was manifested in the proceedings. Mrs. M.A. HAWKINS occupied the Chair, and the exercises were conducted by Rev. Mr. CRAMER. The report for the year ending Dec. 31, 1860, shows the receipts of the institution to have been $42,295, and the expenditures $38,584 78. The number of beneficiaries received in the Home since its establishment has been 10,311, of whom 6,581 were adults and 3,730 children. The statistics of last year were as follows:

abstract: In consequence of a serious accident to our special Washington correspondent, the particulars of which will be found elsewhere, our dispatches from the Capital this morning are not so full as usual. The most important development relative to the plans of the Government is in regard to the
lead_paragraph: In consequence of a serious accident to our special Washington correspondent, the particulars of which will be found elsewhere our dispatches from the Capital this morning are not so full as usual. The most important development relative to the plans of the Government is in regard to the concentration of troops at Cairo -- special orders having gone forward from the War Department to assemble a large additional force at that point immediately. This is in consequense of the threatening reports which come from Tennessee and elsewhere down the Mississippi, to the effect that Gen. PILLOW and other desperate secession leaders contemplate a descent upon the place. At the time of going to press with our first edition it is not positively known whether troops have passed though Baltimore, though as everything was apparently in readiness for the movement, and it has been positively ordered, it is most likely that they have. SHERMAN's Battery was to precede the Pennsylvania troops, and Gen. BUTLER's command at the Relay House was to act in concert with them in case any difficulty should occur.

abstract: I regret exceedingly to announce that a very serious accident has befallen Mr. SIMONTON, special correspondent of the TIMES. He was driving this afternoon, in company with Mrs. SIMONTON, in the neighborhood of Blighwood, and on turning the corner of Seventh-street suddenly passed a picket-guard of militia, whose Captain accidentally discharged his musket, which was leveled full at SIMONTON'S back.
lead_paragraph: I regret exceedingly to announce that a very serious accident has befallen Mr. SIMONTON, special correspondent of the TIMES. He was driving this afternoon, in company with Mrs. SIMONTON, in the neighborhood of Blighwood, and on turning the corner of Seventh-street suddenly passed a picket-guard of militia, whose Captain accidentally discharged his musket, which was leveled full at SIMONTON's back. The ball penetrated the shoulder, passing through the trapesis muscle, and emerging from the front of the breast, breaking no bone, but leaving a very ragged wound; it then glanced around his neck, tearing the skin, and passing miraculously over the surface of his throat Mr. SIMONTON was so stunned as to drop the reins, and the horses, being frightened by the explosion of the musket, ran furiously, and upset the buggy, with Mr. and Mrs. SIMONTON, in a ditch. There they remained until taken out by the individual who caused the trouble, when Mrs. SIMONTON, who was greatly bruised, was found to be cut upon the forehead, while her nose was split open about an inch and a half, as though it had been done by a knife. They are doing comparatively well, and it is hoped no serious result will ensue.

abstract: "Yesterday afternoon, a telegraphic dispatch was received in this city from what was considered high official authority in New-York, that a number of cadets had left West Point, to go South to join the secession forces. They were to land in this city between 9 and 10 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: "Yesterday afternoon, a telegraphic dispatch was received in this city from what was considered high official authority in New-York, that a number of cadets had left West Point, to go South to join the secession forces. They were to land in this city between 9 and 10 o'clock. Chief RUGGLES, Dr. BLACKBURN and Detective GEORGE H. SMITH, at that time headed a posse of 23 men, and proceeded to Walnut-street wharf. About a quarter before 10 o'clock the boat arrived, and the police officers stepped on board and took the whole party, 45 in number, into custody. They were soon at the Central Police Station, where they were briefly addressed by Chief RUGGLES, who requested them to lay down their arms.

abstract: These are very precarious times, I assure you. Our Regiment is stationed at the Washington Navyyard, and yesterday Lieut. Srow came to and told me that there was a talk around the Yard about sending a parts of men to the Potomac River to reconnoire, and if they did, he warned me to go; that was, pro- vided he got the command; and I promised him that I would go,--so about 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon
lead_paragraph: These are very precarious times, I assure you. Our Regiment is stationed at the Washington Navy-yard, and yesterday Lieut. STOW came to and told me that there was a talk around the Yard about sending a parts of men to the Potomac River to reconnoire, and if they did, he warned me to go; that was, pro- vided he got the command; and I promised him that I would go, -- so about 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon we had sealed orders to go. So they detailed men from each Company, and made a guard of thirty men, and gave Lieut. STOW command, and me as Sergeant; so we packed our knapsacks and went on board the steamer Baltimore. She is one of the five that the United States Government seized from Virginia. She is commanded by Lieut. WEST, U.S.N., a perfect gentleman. We sailed under sealed orders, but it was rumored around that we were to plant a gun on Fort Washington. We got down to the fort, but did not stop, so then we did not know where we were bound. We sailed all night, and about 10 o'clock next morning we arrived at Hampton Roads; during the night we had our men at arms twice -- once passing Alexandria, about seven miles from Washington -- a hot secession place. We can see the recession flag flying from the State House, from the White House at Washington; so we had our man in readiness, but they did not attack us. The river is not as wide as the East River, so you can judge how near we were to them; and the other place is called Cedar Point. We could see that their batteries were all manned, but they did not trouble us. The only reason that keeps them from Washington is our numbers. It was a great thing for this country when the President called for troops. If he had not Washington would be the Headquarters of JEFF DAVIS. But I will go on with my letter. When we got to Hampton Roads we had to leave to, and send our boat on board the flag-ship Cumberland. She is stationed there. She lays off Old Point Comfort. There is where Fort Monroe is situated, the largest fort in the United States. They have the world-renowned Floyd gun, the largest in the service.

abstract: The Secessionists, as a means of uniting the South in favor of their rebellious enterprise, habitually speak of the struggle as if it were purely sectional--the North against the South. It is to be hoped that Northern men will not accept this definition of the state of affairs, since it only serves to emitter the contest and to promote the cause of rebellion, while it is far from being true.

abstract: When two months ago President LINCOLN, in his Inaugural, declared his purpose to "hold, occupy and possess the property and places belonging to the Government," he gave utterance to a conviction of duty rather than to a foreordained policy.
lead_paragraph: When two months ago President LINCOLN, in his Inaugural, declared his purpose to "hold, occupy and possess the property and places belonging to the Government," he gave utterance to a conviction of duty rather than to a foreordained policy. It is obvious that the means through which these ends were to be obtained were as indeterminate in his mind as they were in the popular mind. It is equally obvious now that he, like everybody else, greatly underestimated the imminency and magnitude of the National Crisis. "You have no oath registered in Heaven to destroy the Government," he said to men who, for years, had been engaged in secretly weaving a web of treason whose intricate design is only now being disclosed. He evidently thought that conciliation and compromise would suffice to win back those whom he regarded in the light of erring children, and that, in his own words, "the better angels of our nature, touching the mystic chords of memory, would again swell the chorus of the Union." All was to be settled by diplomacy and nobody hurt.

abstract: The remains of Bishop ONDERDONK, which were kept in the chancel of Trinity Church during Tuesday night, were yesterday morning removed to their last resting-place, at Trinity Cemetery. Before leaving the church, the body was again exposed to public view, and a large concourse of people assembled to take a last look at the deceased. The funeral cortege, consisting of twenty five carriages, occupied by the principal clergymen of the diocese, attended the body to the Cemetery.

abstract: As there is a probability of the "United States Volunteers" being accepted as a Regiment of Regulars, they will soon be registered as the Eleventh Regiment of Infantry in the United States Army. abstract: The recent reports relative to the concentration of the secession forces preparatory to a descent upon the Federal Capital, have had the effect of accel-...
lead_paragraph: The recent reports relative to the concentration of the secession forces preparatory to a descent upon the Federal Capital, have had the effect of accelerating the movements of the Northern troops towards that point, under orders of the authorities. Nineteen Regiments, in addition to those previously ordered, have been called for to proceed there at once, and they are already on the way, to rendezvous at the Relay - Camp and at Washington. Gen. PATTERSON, who has advanced on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore road as far as Bush River, where men, under his direction, are engaged in reconstructing the burnt bridge, is stated to have upwards of fifteen thousand men under his command, who are proceeding over from different routes, three of which converge at Baltimore. It is expected that, in anticipation of threatened movements on the part of the forces in Virginia, Federal troops will soon occupy Arlington Heights -- perhaps to-day.

abstract: The Mayor, , vs. The Exchange Fire Insurance Company. This was one of a number of suits brought by the Corporation on policies of insurance for $5,000 each, upon to old Crystal Palace. The suit was brought by Messrs. Mann Rodman instead...
lead_paragraph: The Mayor, &c., vs. The Exchange Fire Insurance Company. -- This was one of a number of suits brought by the Corporation on policies of insurance for $5,000 each, upon the old Crystal Palace. The suit was brought by Messrs. Mann & Rodman instead of the Corporation Counsel, and the question to be determined is, whether the complaint can be sustained by them, they having no personal or official interest in the result; also whether or not the Corporation Counsel has power to delegate his authority to outside parties.

abstract: The Forty-Second Anniversary of this most benevolent and interesting Institution took place yesterday afternoon, at Irving Hall, in the presence of an audi
lead_paragraph: The Forty-second Anniversary of this most benevolent and interesting Institution took place yesterday afternoon, at Irving Hall, in the presence of an audience which filled that large building to its utmost capacity, while about two hundred persons were unable to get within the doors. On the platform, the young ladies of the Institution were arranged on elevated seats, dressed in white muslin, with bright sashes and other adornments, such as Union rosettes, and scarfs. With the exception of six or eights boys, who had to take part in the exercises, the male members of the Institution were placed in the rear gallery. Most of the officers and Directors of the Institution were present. Dr. PEET introduced Rev. Dr. STONE, who, after briefly welcoming the audience, opened the proceedings with prayer. Dr. PEET then stated that there were just 300 pupils in the Institution, very nearly all of whom where present. They were divided into 16 classes, each under a distinct teacher. Representatives of only two of those classes would be presented to the meeting. Two girls and two boys, of the latest class, those who entered the Institution in September last, being at that time ignorant that ideas could be conveyed by words and the class of highest attainment, consisting of those who had been eight and nine years under instruction. The former class were first exhibited, and went through their exercises on the slate in the most creditable manner. Two young ladies and two youths of the highest class were then introduced, and manifested a proficiently that astonished and delighted the spectators. Illustration of the manual language, the sign language and the blachial alphabet for conversing at a distance were given, and some very amusing numetic interludes convulsed all the beholders. But the feature of the occasion was, as usual at these Anniversaries, the competition of impromtu themes on the slates by pupils of the higher grade, and the most noticeable of these were those in which the present condition of the country was made the theme of comment. The Deaf and Dumb read the newspars daily, and are, as they proved themselves yesterday, highly patriotic. Washington, Harper's Ferry, Baltimore, Gen. SCOTT, Major ANDERSON, Fort Sumter, are topics of as immediate and exciting interest to them as to those who listened to the reading (by Dr. PEET) of their compositions with eagerness. Miss MARY L. GOODRICH, of Brooklyn, a remarkably beautiful young lady, manipulated a poem, in the Sikh language, with considerable effect; while Miss FANNY L. FREEMAN, of Allahabad. Northern India, whose parents were killed by the Sepoys in the last Indian war, fairly "took down the house" by her admirable rendering of the poem "When Freedom from her mountain heights." The proceedings terminated with the Lord's Prayer, in the Sikh language, by Miss FANNY WALTER, and a benediction by Rev. Dr. ADAMS.

The steamer Delaware, JOHNSON, left at 4 P.M. for Philadelphia, with provisions and 15 cannon, weighing three tons each, for the Philadelphia Navy-yard. The steamer P.T. Hart also sailed with provisions for the Philadelphia Navy-yard. The Second Regiment, encamped on the Battery, will positively leave on Saturday by steamer; they are thoroughly equipped except 600 overcoats.

abstract: The Administration have evidently come to the conclusion that the three months' volunteers have about done what was desired of...
lead_paragraph: The Administration have evidently come to the conclusion that the three months' volunteers have about done what was desired of them. They have overawed Maryland, guarded Washington against traitors within and possible attacks without, and served to express to the world the intense attachment of the people to the Republic. For these things, a grateful posterity will always number the first volunteers of the War of 1861, on the country's roll of honor. They went out to unknown perils, and they led the van against an enemy whose power our imaginations had greatly exaggerated.

abstract: Brooklyn experienced another sensation yesterday, occasioned by the departure of the Thirteenth Regiment 425 men under the command of Lieut.Col. CLARK, and an order for the Fourteenth Regiment,...
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn experienced another sensation yesterday, occasioned by the departure of the Thirteenth Regiment -- 425 men -- under the command of Lieut.-Col. CLARK, and an order for the Fourteenth Regiment, Col. A.M. WOOD, to go into quarters and prepare for marching as soon as possible The members of the Thirteenth Regiment have been quartered in the State arsenal in Portland-avenue. Wednesday night they received orders to be on band at seven o'clock yesterday morning. At the hour named, nearly all were present, making final preparations for departure. At ten o'clock, having bid good-bye to the friends on the ground, the men formed and to the music of STEWART's Band, proceeded by Myrtle-avenue and Fulton-street to Fulton Ferry, where they wept on board the ferry-boat Wyandotte, and were transferred to the steamer Empire State, lying in the North River. The men were all in fine spirits, and they were heartily cheered, as they passed through the streets, by the thousands of people gathered to witness their departure. A salute of 34 guns was fired from Form Greene.

abstract: The Rochester Union publishes a statement which fully vindicates Col. GARDINER, Major ANDERSON's predecessor at Fort Moultrie, of the charges of disaffection which have been made against him. Before he was transferred from Fort Moultrie, Capt. GARDINER repeatedly called on FLOYD for more men and provisions, but could not get them. Instead, an installment of workmen were sent; ostensibly to repair Fort Sumpter, but really to weaken it. Col. GARDINER meanwhile managed to get six months' provisions thrown into the fort without FLOYD's knowledge, through the influence of Commissary-General TAYLOR, and the Secretary of War, finding now impracticable a man he had placed in charge of the fort, ordered him away, and sent ANDERSON in his place, whose sympathies with the South he considered sufficiently strong to make the surrender on demand inevitable. How FLOYD miscalculated events have shown; but for the ability to hold out so long, ANDERSON was indebted to the finesse practiced by GARDINER.
lead_paragraph: The Rochester Union publishes a statement which fully vindicates Col. GARDINER, Major ANDERSON's predecessor at Fort Moultrie, of the charges of disaffection which have been made against him. Before he was transferred from Fort Moultrie, Capt. GARDINER repeatedly called on FLOYD for more men and provisions, but could not get them. Instead, an installment of workmen were sent; ostensibly to repair Fort Sumpter, but really to weaken it. Col. GARDINER meanwhile managed to get six months' provisions thrown into the fort without FLOYD's knowledge, through the influence of Commissary-General TAYLOR, and the Secretary of War, finding now impracticable a man he had placed in charge of the fort, ordered him away, and sent ANDERSON in his place, whose sympathies with the South he considered sufficiently strong to make the surrender on demand inevitable. How FLOYD miscalculated events have shown; but for the ability to hold out so long, ANDERSON was indebted to the finesse practiced by GARDINER.

abstract: The attack on Fort Sumter may be explained by the strong interest of the seceding States in provoking a collision. Although the officer in command seems to have sustained the honor of his flag, the result of the struggle could not have been doubtful. The Government of Washington must have foreseen the...
lead_paragraph: The attack on Fort Sumter may be explained by the strong interest of the seceding States in provoking a collision. Although the officer in command seems to have sustained the honor of his flag, the result of the struggle could not have been doubtful. The Government of Washington must have foreseen the occurrence, and it bas throughout preserved the secret of its intentions with unusual firmness. The telegraphs and the newspaper correspondents have become so far aware of the change as to diversify their positive statements with occasional confessions of ignorance. A small force has been dispatched southward, but it has for some time been understood that the Cabinet had abandoned all intention of relieving Major ANDERSON in Fort Sumter. The remaining alternatives were the occupation of the posts on the Islands of the Southern coast, and the more formidable enterprise of reinforcing Gen. HOUSTON in Texas. In the absence of information, it may be safely assumed that Mr. Lincoln had never any intention of commencing hostilities, though it might be prudent to take up positions which might be serviceable in the event of a collision, while they would have a tendency to exercise a favorable influence on negotiation, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS has probably a defensive force greatly superior to any army of which the Northern States could dispose for purposes of invasion. On the other hand, he cannot hope to command the sea, and he must be well aware that Foreign Powers will not be hasty to quarrel, on the subject of blockade, with the United States.

abstract: Surgeon McDERMOTT, of the United States Army, and bearer of important dispatches, arrived here on board of the British screw-steamer Kedar yesterday forenoon from Annapolis, via Fort Monroe, where the steamer stopped on Tuesday to receive on...
lead_paragraph: Surgeon MCDERMOTT, of the United States Army, and bearer of important dispatches, arrived here on board of the British screw-steamer Kedar yesterday forenoon from Annapolis, via Fort Monroe, where the steamer stopped on Tuesday to receive on board the wives and daughters of the officers at that post and the other women heretofore connected with the garrison. Twelve prisoners, who were arrested for various crimes, belonging to the different regiments, but mostly from the Twelfth, together with thirty-nine sick, came on in his charge. One of the prisoners was sent after by a steamer after they had left the port, and he was delivered to the United States authorities. The sick have been properly cared for, and the petty thieves and rogues who have disgraced their respective commands will be dismissed. The invalids were mostly from the Eighth Regiment, now stationed at the Relay House.

abstract: We are requested to call attention to the Anniversary of this Institution, at Irving Hall, this evening, at 7 1/2 o'clock. Addresses will be delivered by Rev. Dr. TYNG, Rev. T.L. CULYER, Rev. H.D. GAUSE and R.J. THORNE, Esq. Those who love to hear children sing will be gratified. The same cause that straightens the circumstances of the wealthy cuts off the income of the house and depresses the poor almost to the point of starvation Mr. BARLOW says that every day applications for relief are made to him by those who three months ago earned a good living, and are now unemployed and in dread of the Alms-house. As the Institution has hitherto depended solely upon the voluntary gifts of the benevolent for money to carry on the enterprise, and has never been disappointed, they hope for the continued liberality of those who are able to spare a little from their stare for the benefit of the poor and needy.

abstract: We confess, that with all our confidence in the Administration and Gen. SCOTT, we are not satisfied that the Capital is out of danger. The journals have been filled with notices of...
lead_paragraph: We confess, that with all our confidence in the Administration and Gen. SCOTT, we are not satisfied that the Capital is out of danger. The journals have been filled with notices of the arrival of troops at Washington from day to day, and yet we are informed, from a perfectly reliable source, that two days ago here were less than 18,000 troops in that city. There are about 2,500 at the Relay House, and perhaps 5,000 at Annapolis and along the road. Gen. PATTERSON's force en route for Washington is estimated at 15,000, but it will probably be a week before they reach that city, if indeed that is their destination. But as things stand now, we do not see how it would be possible, within three or four days, to marshal more than 25,000 men for the defence of the Capital.

abstract: It is a great mistake to suppose that the war, which is now being initiated, is a war "against the South," or against Southern institutions. It is true that geographically the...
lead_paragraph: It is a great mistake to suppose that the war, which is now being initiated, is a war "against the South," or against Southern institutions. It is true that geographically the North occupies one side of the controversy and the South the other, but this is simply owing to the fact that the treason which renders the war inevitable, originated and prevails only at the South, while loyalty to the Union is the universal sentiment of the Northern people. On the part of the South the war was begun, and is being prosecuted, for the overthrow of the Government, to pull down and destroy this free Republic, that for more than three-quarters of a century has been the astonishment and the admiration of the world. There never was a war so utterly, causeless forced upon a peaceful people. No right of any citizen has been invaded, no priviliges withheld or interfered with. No right of any State has been invaded, no attribute of State Sovereignty interfered with. There is no pretence on the part of the seceding States that the rights of the citizen or the security of the State will be enhanced by successful revolution.
headline: {'main': 'Not a War against the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Not a War against the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Friday, the 26th, the funds were depressed by the commencement of hostilities at Charleston, but Consols finally closed at a reduction of barely 1/8 per cent., the price being 91 @ 7/8 for both money and...
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the 26th, the funds were depressed by the commencement of hostilities at Charleston, but Consols finally closed at a reduction of barely 1/8 per cent., the price being 91 3/4@7/8 for both money and account. On the 27th, afternoon, they closed at 91 3/4 @91 7/8 for money, and 91 7/8@92 for account. In the discount market, and at the Bank, there was rather an increased demand for money, and there was less disposition to take even the best bills below 4 1/2 cent. The decline in American Securities was general, but they closed with, a tendency to recover. The following were the closing prices, on the 27th, of the following securities: Illinois Central Railroad, 31 @ 30, discount; Erie Railroad stock. 23 1/2@24 1/2.

abstract: Yesterday the Fifth Regiment, Advance Guard, under Col. DURYEA, was inspected at Fort Schuyler and mustered into the service of the United States. Capt. SEYMOUR, U.S.A., who as was one of the garrison of...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the Fifth Regiment, Advance Guard, under Col. DURYEA, was inspected at Fort Schuyler and mustered into the service of the United States. Capt. SEYMOUR, U.S.A., who as was one of the garrison of Fort Sumter, was the inspecting officer, and Dr. ALEX. B. MOTT conducted the medical examination. Those set aside as unfit for duty were uncommonly few, and they were those whom it was most desirable to excoriate. The ranks of the regiment are full and a finer-looking body of men is not to be found in this part of Christendom. All are uniformed so far at the funds of the munificent Chamber of Commerce and public-spirited individuals have sufficed to pay for raiment; but the niggardly and paltry delay of the State authorities in responding to the requisitions for overcoats and fatigue pants has seriously discommoded the men during the wet season just passed. The necessary articles have not yet been furnished. It is to be hoped that they will be very speedily.

abstract: Our citizens have plainly come to the conclusion that a life-and-death struggle has begun for the very existence of the Government. They are seriously preparing themselves for...
lead_paragraph: Our citizens have plainly come to the conclusion that a life-and-death struggle has begun for the very existence of the Government. They are seriously preparing themselves for the burdens of the war. Money is afforded without stint, and more can be had when it is called for. Time, and services, and life are freely offered. This is necessary, and right. The first interest now should be this question between Law and Anarchy.

abstract: We understand that letters from Mr. WALDEN, of Savannah, to whose case we alluded yesterday, do not warrant the statement that his young son was killed because he would not enlist. On the contrary, Mr. W., writing from Montgomery, states that he learns by telegraph that his son was shot by the Accidental discharge of a pistol. We made the original statement on authority which we deemed reliable, but from the letters of Mr. WALDEN, which we have since seen, we are satisfied that the report of the manner of his death lacks confirmation.
lead_paragraph: We understand that letters from Mr. WALDEN, of Savannah, to whose case we alluded yesterday, do not warrant the statement that his young son was killed because he would not enlist. abstract: This Brigade is being armed, and equipped in the most substantial and efficient manner possible. A battery of steel-rifled field guns is being constructed for Gen. SICKLES as rapidly as possible. The British Legion, and Capt. HOGAN's Battery of Flying Artillery, will join this Brigade. Capts. DUNN and SUMMERS have tendered their companies, and it is understood they will be accepted. The last three companies are from the Sixty-ninth Auxiliary Corps. Capt. BRODERICK requests all men who have signed the rolls of this Regiment, and all those who were about to volunteer, to meet, this day, at 11 A.M., at No. 17 Centre-street.

abstract: The Union men in Kentucky continue to insist, with great energy, that the State shall remain neutral in the pending contest between the Union and Rebellion. The Louisville
lead_paragraph: The Union men in Kentucky continue to insist, with great energy, that the State shall remain neutral in the pending contest between the Union and Rebellion. The Louisville Journal, which wages fierce and effective war upon the Disunionists, presses this policy with very great force upon public favor. It insists that Kentucky shall take no part in the contest, -- that she shall repel trespass upon her soil from either party, and devote herself to the preservation of peace within her own borders.

abstract: It is evident from the tenor of our dispatches that some movement of startling importance is in contemplation, and will soon be made by the Government against the Secessionists. What direc-
lead_paragraph: It is evident from the tenor of our dispatches that some movement of startling importance is in contemplation, and will soon be made by the Government against the Secessionists. What direction this movement will take, it is of course impossible to say -- whether towards Norfolk, Richmond, or Harper's Ferry. Our Washington correspondent states that there are now in Washington and in the immediate vicinity some 30,000 troops, and more are daily arriving, both by railroad and by. transport. The regulars and volunteers which passed through Baltimore on Thursday afternoon, reached the Capital that night; and Gen. PATTERSON'S command, 15,000 strong, can be made available in a very short period. The movements of the secession forces in Virginia seem to be somewhat uncertain They evidently anticipate that the Government intends to take possession of Alexandria, and accordingly, to be out of harm's way, those who were stationed there yesterday commenced a retrograde movement to Culpepper. It is most likely, however, that instead of Alexandria, Harper's Ferry will be the point to which the Government will first direct its attention, as the rebel forces there have commenced a system of depredations upon the trade passing over the Baltimore Road which it will be necessary to put an end to immediately. They yesterday took from a train bound to Baltimore, one hundred beef cattle and ten horses.

abstract: Michael Sweeney vs. Benjamin T. Babbitt. -The plaintiff brings this action to recover damages for injuries sustained in 1859 by the explosion of a steam-boiler. It appears that the premises in which the explosion took place were Nos. 66, 68 and 70 Washington-street, in this City. The plaintiff was employed in No. 64 that street, and was at work at the time the explosion took place. He claims to have been greatly bruised and injured, and maimed for life. The complaint alleges neglect on the part of the defendant, and plaintiff claims damages to the amount of $15,000.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sweeney vs. Benjamin T. Babbitt. -The plaintiff brings this action to recover damages for injuries sustained in 1859 by the explosion of a steam-boiler. abstract: The tenth anniversary of this Institution was held last evening at Irving Hall. In spite of the rain, there was a large audience present, and the children of the Institution, to the number of three hundred and over -- in about equal proportions of boys and girls -- were there in all the glory of bran new frocks, clean faces and well kemot hair. To these juveniles was assigned a large portion of the exercises of the evening, and very appropriately, for the intense delight manifested in the beaming eyes and joyful countenances with which they entered into the performance of their parts, was more grateful to the audience than any other part of the programme, besides being the best possible argument in favor of the happy influences exerted by the Five Points House of Industry. The school exercises and the song, hymns and anthems performed by there children, were highly creditable to the officers of the institution was nave them in charge, and would rarely be excelled by children of the same age in any school in the City. Besides the performances of the children, addresses were delivered by Rev. T.L. CUYLER, Rev. HENRY D. GANSE and H.T. THORNE, Esq.

abstract: Geo. Ulrich and Rosa Bachman, keeping a den of infamy at No. 33 Park street, were arrested yesterday by the Sixth Ward Police, charged wita enticing three girls, scarcely 14 years of age, named Mary Kelly, Mary Orgett and Jane Young, into their place, for
lead_paragraph: Geo. Ulrich and Rosa Bachman, keeping a den of infamy at No. 33 Park street, were arrested yesterday by the Sixth Ward Police, charged wita enticing three girls, scarcely 14 years of age, named Mary Kelly, Mary Orgett and Jane Young, into their place, for infamous purposes. About three weeks ago they got the girls into their den, and persuaded them to come regularly every day, and to represent to their parents that they had obtained situations for which they were to receive $2 50 each per week. The girls did so, and at the end of each week the money was given them to take to their parents. A day or two since, however, one of the parents became suspicious and followed her daughter to the house in question, where the facts of the case became apparent The Police were informed of the outrage, Justice KELLY issued a warrant for the arrest of the parties keeping the place, and they were locked up for trial. The girls were sent to the House of Detention, as witnesses.

abstract: It seems, to be understood that a force of Secessionists is rapidly collecting at Harper's Ferry, with the evident design to held that position, which commands, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and thus seriously checks federal reinforcements from the West. A large body, four or five thousand at least, has been pushed forward from Virginia, and is swelled by additions from Kentucky and Maryland. We presume it numbers now 6,000 men. The position itself is a strong one, and can probably be held against a much superior force.

abstract: Late Thursday night the Fourteenth Regiment, Col. A. M. WOOD, received orders to proceed to the seat of war yesterday at 12 o'clock M., on board of the steamship Kedar. At the time the order was received
lead_paragraph: Late Thursday night the Fourteenth Regiment, Col. A.M. WOOD, received orders to proceed to the seat of war yesterday at 12 o'clock M., on board of the steamship Kedar. At the time the order was received a majority of the officers and men had left for their homes, with directions to report at 7 o'clock the following morning, but Col. WOOD immediately dispatched orders for the Regiment to meet at the Armory, and before midnight a majority of the command had assembled. All received the order to march with manifestations of satisfaction, and the work of preparation was at once commenced. The clothing and accoutrements were at the depot, No. 166 Fulton-street, in charge of Aldermen DAYTON, SCHOLES and VAN BRUNT, and these gentlemen, assisted by Judge ADAMS and others, at once set to work to equip the men. Detachments of ten men each were sent to the depot at a time, clothed and equipped and sent back to their quarters. This work was kept up without intermission until 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when 900 men were equipped ready for service, and then the uniforms gave out leaving about 50 men unprovided for. These men became very indignant when told that there were no uniforms for them and expressed a determination to go with out them. As the Regiment did not get ready to sail yesterday at the time appointed, it is not definitely known when they will leave, but they may possibly get off to-day. The following is a list of the principal officers of the Fourteenth Regiment:

abstract: The steamship Illinois, P.E. TERRY, Commander, employed in the transportation of the United States troops and stores to Fort Pickens, arrived at this port yesterday. The Illinois left Pickens on the even-
lead_paragraph: The steamship Illinois, P.E. TERRY, Commander, employed in the transportation of the United States troops and stores to Fort Pickens, arrived at this port yesterday. The Illinois left Pickens on the evening of the 2d, arrived at Key West on the night of the 4th, and left Key West on the morning of the 6th. The following vessels-of-war were off Pickens when the Illinois left: The Powhatan, Brooklyn, Sabine, storeship Supply, Wyandotte and Water Witch. The gun-boat Mohawk arrived on the 29th of April, and left on the 1st for the coast of Texas. The Ezra Atwater, of New-Haven, arrived at Pickens on the 27th of April.

abstract: Since your recent adjournment, events of the most startling character have followed in rapid succession. The comparative quiet in which the public mind was then lulled by the semi-official announcement of a pacific policy on the part of the Federal Administration, has been broken, and the patriotic hope for a peaceful solution of our political complications; in-
lead_paragraph: Since your recent adjournment, events of the most startling character have followed in rapid succession. The comparative quiet in which the public mind was then lulled by the semi-official announcement of a pacific policy on the part of the Federal Administration, has been broken, and the patriotic hope for a peaceful solution of our political complications, inspired by the proposed mediatorial interposition of the Border Slave States, has been disappointed by the sudden development of an evidently pre determined purpose of the President and his supporters, the attempted execution of which has not only sealed the separation of the States, but has involved the country in civil war, and, if not successfully resisted, will prove fatal to the liberties of the people.

abstract: The First Regiment Vermont Volunteers, Col. PHELPS, from Camp Fairfax, Rutland, arrived at Thirty-first-street yesterday morning at 8 1/2 o'clock. They are a remarkably fine body of men, and as they passed down Fifth-avenue, Seventeenth-street and Broadway, they were much admired by a large gathering of people who lined the sidewalks. They are now quartered in the Park, and will stay there till to-morrow, when they will leave for Fort Monroe, Virginia, in the Coatzacolcos. Each man wears a sprig of green hemlock in his hat to show, that he is from the Green Mountains. It is not enough for a man to volunteer to belong to this regiment, he has to be voted in by the members; by this means all weak men and those of doubtful character are rejected. The, following towns have each sent a company; Woodstock, Bradford, Cavendish, Rutland, Middlebury, Brandon, Burlington, St. Albans, Northfield and Swanton. The regiment left Rutland at 8 o'clock on Thursday morning. Annexed is a list of the Field and Staff Officers:

abstract: -- One of the finest Concerts ever given in Brooklyn, is promised for to-morrow evening, at the Academy of Music. BRIGNOLI, SUSINI, FERRI, Miss KELLOGG, and Mlle. ELENA are announced as the principal vocal performers, the last named lady being the beneficiary of the occasion. The leading instrumentalists are Mr. APPY, one of the most accomplished and popular violinists of the day, Herr KOPPITZ, a pianist of remarkable executive bribiancy, and Mr. PATTISON, a young, but skilfull pianist. The appreciation lately shown for the higher order of musical entertainment by the Brooklyn public authorizes the supposition that Mlle. ELENA will be liberally sustained in her appeal for favor.

abstract: Augustus Van Amringe and Wife vs. James Barnett. This is an appeal from a judgement rendered at a trial term of this Court, the action having
lead_paragraph: Augustus Van Amringe and Wife vs. James Barnett. -- This is an appeal from a judgement rendered at a trial term of this Court, the action having been brought by the plaintiffs to recover the undivided fifth of certain lands which are described as land lying on the eastern side of the Eastern post-road. The plaintiff claims title in right of his wife, who was a daughter and one of the heirs of George Youle, who died seized of the said tract of land in 1828. After the death of Youle, the plaintiffs and one William F. Van Amringe, in May, 1834, filed a bill in chancery for the partition of the premises in question, and a decree for the sale thereof was made in May, 1835. The description of the land as contained in the bill and decree, are the same as that contained in the deed to Youle. The decree directed a sale of all the premises. The Master in Chancery, to whom it was referred, sold the premises in lots and exhibited at the sale a map of the property to be sold at the sale, parcel No. 8, as designated on said map, was purchased by Henry A. Slepper, who afterwards sold the same plot to the defendant. The question arose upon the trial, and is one of the principal questions now before the court, whether the Masters' deed, describing the lot as lot No. 8, which, it is alleged, included one-half the post road, actually carried with it the title to one-half the post-road. The read, it appears, has long since been closed, and in order to insure title to the strip of road bordering on his premises, the defendant obtained a deed of release from the Mayor and Commonalty of this city, which was excluded. It appears that no proof was offered by the plaintiffs, nor was any given, when the eastern post-road was opened, or how long it had been used as a read, or when or how long it was closed, or ceased to be a road. The point taken by counsel for defendant and appellant on this argument is, that the deed from the corporation was improperly excluded, as,

abstract: swept over Lake Erie on Monday night, the schooner Freeman, having on board 8,983 bushels of corn, was wrecked on the Canada shore. Of the six persons on board five were lost. The names of the drowned are SYLVESTER A. NEWALL, a son of the captain, and mate of the vessel; GEORGE EVESTON, cook; ANTONIO DARZALLAN, and two others, whom the captain knew only as JOE and ALECK, the three last being deck hands. All of the crew shipped at Detroit.

abstract: The Austrian brig Istock M., Capt. PACURICH, arrived at this port 7th from London, reports April 12, lat. 42° 40', long. 35°, fell in with a large ship of about 1,200 or 1,500 tons, on fire, supposed to be lumber laden. Sent a boat to her to ascertain if assistance could be rendered, but seeing nobody on board, the boat returned; part of her name was burned; the letters F.E.O.--T.--M.-----, could only be made out; left the vessel burning.

abstract: we called the attention of the Board of Brokers to the propriety of striking from the stock list the securities of seceding and seceded States. lead_paragraph: The midshipmen of the first and second classes, on board the Constitution, have been ordered to sea. Detachments of them were yesterday dispatched from 11'ewgort to Boston, Phtladelphia and New-York About fourteen arrived here last evening,and reported for duty to Commodore BREESE. The Wabash, Mississippi, Roanoke, Jamestown, and other vessels preparing, will have a proper number of these junior officers detailed for them, the exigencies of the service necessitating the postponement of theoretical studies for a while.

abstract: It is one month to-day since Mr. CORWIN left New-York for the capital of Mexico. On the day after his departure commenced the attack upon Fort Sumter, and since that time events have occurred which, entirely altering the political situation, must give an absolutely new character to his mission, while they interpose a multitude of unforeseen difficulties in the way of its fortunate execution. War has be-
lead_paragraph: It is one month to-day since Mr. CORWIN left New-York for the capital of Mexico. On the day after his departure commenced the attack upon Fort Sumter, and since that time events have occurred which, entirely altering the political situation, must give an absolutely new character to his mission, while they interpose a multitude of unforeseen difficulties in the way of its fortunate execution. War has begun; the Federal authorities have declared some millions of the people in a state of insurrection; the blockade of all the Southern ports is announced; the nation has entered upon a domestic struggle which is to decide its downfall or its perpetuity. Successive proclamations of the President have declared the measures the Government is prepared to take for the suppression of the rebellion; counter declarations of the rebels disclose the sturdiness with which they are prepared to withstand the enforcement of the laws and the reestablishment of Constitutional power. And then that great awakening of the patriotic sentiment of the North, which is destined, sooner or later, to exercise the spirit of secession, is a phenomenon of which Mr. CORWIN had no intimation, and which nothing short of the gift of prophecy could have taught him to anticipate.

abstract: The long controversy between the City of Brooklyn and the Long Island Railroad Company, is at length ended; the company has blown its last whistle
lead_paragraph: The long controversy between the City of Brooklyn and the Long Island Railroad Company, is at length ended; the company has blown its last whistle in the ears, and puffed its last volume of smoke in the eyes of the denizens of Atlantic street, and decamped with all its paraphernalia from the City to more congenial quarters at Hunter's Point. Whether, as many believe, Brooklyn has not "bit her own nose off," by thus driving from her limits the only great avenue of communication with the interior of Lung Island, is a question for time to determine; certain is it that the Railroad Company will be a great gainer by the change, as will also the vicinity of Hunter's Point and the no-town residents of New-York, who will now be afforded easy and rapid access to the numerous beautiful resorts on the Island.

abstract: It is important that the people of this country should understand clearly the real nature and causes of the contest in which they are engaged. Every one recognizes the fact that
lead_paragraph: It is important that the people of this country should understand clearly the real nature and causes of the contest in which they are engaged. Every one recognizes the fact that the South has been plunged into rebellion against the authority of the Federal Government, and now seeks, by force of arms, its overthrow. But the causes of this fact, -- the motives which have given it birth, are less generally recognized. One class of writers ascribes it to the election of LINCOLN, and regards it as a passionate protest against the choice of a sectional President. Another class considers it the effort of an alarmed people to protect their domestic institutions against apprehended danger. Nearly all regard it as the natural growth and inevitable result of the Pro-Slavery and Anti-Slavery agitation, which has marked the history of the past twenty years, and which has aroused the passions, the prejudices, the pride and the resentment of both sections of the country.

abstract: Since your recent adjournment, events of the most startling character have followed in rapid succession. The comparative quiet in which the public mind was then lulled by the semi-official announcement of a pacific policy on the part of the Federal Administration, has been broken, and the patriotic hope for a peaceful solution of our political complications, in-
lead_paragraph: Since your recent adjournment, events of the most startling character have followed in rapid succession. The comparative quiet in which the public mind was then lulled by the semi-official announcement of a pacific policy on the part of the Federal Administration, has been broken, and the patriotic hope for a peaceful solution of our political complications, inspired by the proposed mediatorial interposition of the Border Slave States, has been disappointed by the sudden development of an evidently pre determined purpose of the President and his supporters, the attempted execution of which has not only sealed the separation of the States, but has involved the country in civil war, and, if not successfully resisted, will prove fatal to the liberties of the people.

abstract: About eighty more of the Baltimore mobites passed through here this evening on their way to join the Virginia troops at Harper's Ferry. They walked all the way from Baltimore, and are a hard-looking set of rowdies. They carry with them no baggage of any kind. Some are armed with revolvers. They say that about a thousand more will leave Baltimore within the next five days, and that they will come in this direction via Westminster.

abstract: In the confusion of these times, there is no such utter fallacy as the idea, which seems to have taken possession of Kentucky and Missouri, of the neutrality of States.
lead_paragraph: In the confusion of these times, there is no such utter fallacy as the idea, which seems to have taken possession of Kentucky and Missouri, of the neutrality of States. There is no such thing, there can be no such thing, as the neutrality of a State in the struggle now going on in this country. There can be no such thing in theory, no such thing as a practical fact. The great issue of the times involves the existence of the Constitution which comprehends all the States -- of the Union, which includes all the States. The duties and obligations, as between the people and the General Government, are the same in all the States alike, binding on the people of all the States. When Virginia attempts to subvert the Constitution or overturn the Union, she strikes at the rights of Kentucky and Missouri precisely the same as at those of New-York; and it is as much the duty of those States to aid in putting down the rebellion of Virginia, as it is of New-York. This theory of neutrality involves the idea of two rightfully existing powers struggling against each other, with which Kentucky and Missouri have nothing to do. Consider the fallacy of this. The General Government extends over all the territory of the country, embracing all the States, and while acting within its constitional sphere, paramount to all the States. Allegiance is due to it from every citizen, and it is his duty to defend and uphold it in its unity always. Kentucky and Missouri are as much a part of this Government as are New-York and Pennsylvania. A portion of the territory embraced in the States rebels. Its population determines to dissolve all connection with the rest of the Union and zet up as an independent nation. The duty of Government in regard to such rebellion no man will question. It may not have the power to overcome it, but its clear duty is to try. But who shall grapple with this rebellion? If New York says she will not, then New-York consents to dissolution, and practically sides with rebellion, -- throws her moral power on the side of treason, while she refuses to employ her physical energies for its overthrow. What would be thus true of New-York is true of Kentucky and Missouri. If all the loyal States held to this fallacy of neutrality, secession would have nothing to do but to define its boundaries, take possession of all the Government property within them and organize its government. Treason would accomplish its aims, subvert the Constitution and dissolve the Union without the expenditure of a dollar or the mustering of a regiment.

abstract: Given, a thousand men who volunteer for military service, the question is how to make them most effective against the enemy? to what discipline to subject them? what arms to put into their hands? As to drill, of late years a change of opinion and practice has taken place similar to that which we have already noticed with regard to uniform.
lead_paragraph: Given, a thousand men who volunteer for military service, the question is how to make them most effective against the enemy? to what discipline to subject them? what arms to put into their hands? As to drill, of late years a change of opinion and practice has taken place similar to that which we have already noticed with regard to uniform. Military rigidity, which had become a by-word, is yielding to the attacks of a school which seeks to unite flexibility with precision. It is found that constant constraint does not increase, but on the contrary, seriously impairs the soldier's efficiency. There is a limit to every man's power of endurance; he has only a certain supply of nervous energy to draw upon. This can be exhausted as much by fret and worry and quiet suffering as by rapid movement and by wounds. Try to hold out your arm at full length for five minutes, or to avoid the need for muscular exertion -- stand with your arms hanging down immovable for fifteen minutes, and you will "realize" this truth. Even in the latter case you will find, unless you have been accustomed to the position, that you will suffer irritating discomfort, if not pain, in both arms and hands. To endure this costs you an expenditure of your nervous energy, a waste of all your bodily tissues.

abstract: A gentleman just arrived in St. Louis from Houston, Texas, makes some interesting statements.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman just arrived in St. Louis from Houston, Texas, makes some interesting statements. He says that martial law had been declared in Houston and Galveston, and all Union men had been waited upon by a Vigilance Committee, and ordered to enlist in the Confederate Army and be ready for active service, or leave the State, and six hours was given to decide. The Union party is strong throughout the State, but is awed by the violence of the [???]. Thousands were leaving the State in consequence of the terrorism. The gulf steamers from Galveston to New-Orleans' were crammed with men fleeing for the North, and it was stated in New-Orleans that ten thousand must have left Northern Texas, leaving crop, in [???] and everything behind. There is great [???] between the Unionists and [???] [???]. [???] the former were strengthened there would unevitably be war among themselves, and there is imminent danger of it now. When SAM HOUSTON spoke in Galveston, there was almost a fight. A committee waited upon, [???] and requested him not to speak, or it [???] did, not to discuss late events in that State. He replied that he should speak, and as he pleased; no threats should intimidate him. When [???] to hear him, [???] THATONER, famous in [???] [???] animals, got up and [???] that SAM HOUSTON be not allowed to speak, and, if necessary, that [???] battery of artillery be brought out to prevent it. Thereupon, a lawyer of the city rose and declared that SAM HOUSTON was the father of Texas and swore before [???] that he should have the privileged saying whatever he pleased in Galveston. His friends rallied around him and he was permitted to go on. He is just as strongly opposed to the whole secession scheme as can be, but beats a retreat so far as to oppose coercion, but at the same time advocated a [???] republic. The Legislature had established a Committee of [???], and it was even proposed to give it the power to hang. But the [???] will do that business if their decrees are not complied with. Some Union men are still [???], [???] the traitors [???]. The fact is, Texas is [???] a [???]. Thousands are leaving New-Orleans and the country this side. The [???] gentlemen came up on had 400 passengers, and the railroad [???] the largest traits ever known thereon. The fact is, there is a [???] of terror in the Southwest, and no Northern or Union can feels safe.

abstract: "The Police Commissioners of this city have formally demanded of Capt. LYON, the officer is command at the Arsenal, the removal of United States troops from all places and buildings occupied by them outside the Arsenal grounds. The Captain, as was doubtless expected, declined compliance with the demand, and the Commissioners have referred the matter to the Governor and Legislature. The Commissioners allege that such occupancy is in derogation of the Constitution and laws of the United States, and in rejoinder Capt. LYON replies, inquiring what provisions of the Constitution and laws were thus violated. The Commissioners in support of their position say that originally 'Missouri had sovereign and exclusive jurisdiction over her whole territory,' and had delegated a portion of her sovereignty to the United States, over certain tracts of land for military purposes, such as arsenals, parks, &c., and the conclusion implied, but not stated, is, that this is the extreme limit of the right of the United States Government to occupy or touch the soil of the sovereign State of Missouri. The Democrat argues at length against this position and charges that the controversy has been broached only to bring the State and federal authorities into conflict.

abstract: Among our intelligence by the Great Eastern, we give an article from the London Times upon the affairs of this country.
lead_paragraph: Among our intelligence by the Great Eastern, we give an article from the London Times upon the affairs of this country. It differs in no essential respect from the previous commentaries of the same journal upon American questions, which appear to be an insoluble puzzle for the Thunderer, and to abate much of the dogmatism it is apt to bring to all its editorial discussions. In the present case the reader will be at no loss to discern the entire failure to appreciate the motives which have at last put the united North in action, or the energy which must inevitably result from the impulse. The Times compares the military strength of the Contending sections by the assumption that skill and experience are on the side of the South, allied with sufficient means and men; while the North lacks the skill, and has no mentionable advantage in the other particulars. We, who know better, are aware that Northern troops had a larger share of instruction in the military school of the Mexican war than those of the South; while here we have also European volunteers, practiced and thoroughly disciplined at home in martial exercises, and numerous enough to hold their own alone against the largest force procurable at the rebel States. We also know better the value of the credit displayed in the subscription to the Southern loan. Not one-half of the amount, after all means of compulsion had been exhausted, was secured; and that which the pressure of terror actually extorted was paid, not in gold or silver, but in over-issues of bank paper, unsupported by a specie basis. Such pecuniary resources are of small worth in a controversy such as the South has provoked; and in fact they could not keep an army of 20,000 men a-foot for a campaign of three months. Adding to this element of weakness the facts, that in the insurgent States food is almost exhausted, the commissariate of their army destitute, and that three millions of implacable and watchful enemies are at their firesides and shadowing their very threshholds, and we may appreciate how wide of the mark are the assumptions of the Times as to the likelihood of a long and doubtful struggle. All we require, indeed, is that the strength the people are prepared to exert shall be instantly and effectively employed. The prospect of a tedious war exists only in the chance that it may not be thus used and directed.

abstract: --The first application of the treaty between the United States and Austria for the extradition of criminals has lately taken place at Vienna, where an American, named MARSH, a clerk in a mercantile house, who had embezzled $20,000, was arrested. His employers, having learned that he had sailed for Europe, sent off a legal gentleman in pursuit; named COL, who traced MARSH to Spain, but as there is no treaty of extradition between the United States and that country, he determined to follow MARSH wherever he went, hoping that he would at last go to same country where his arrest could be effected Mr. COL thus traveled through Spain, Portugal and Italy, following MARSH, like his shadow, until he came to Vienna, where he had him arrested. As the treaty leaves the accused the option of being tried in Austria, or sent back to America, Mr. COL had taken the precaution of bringing with him proofs of the forgeries by which MARSH had long concealed, his crime, but they were not required, as the prisoner chose to return to his own country. A sum of $500 and 200 Napoleons in gold were found in his possession -- Galignani.
lead_paragraph: --The first application of the treaty between the United States and Austria for the extradition of criminals has lately taken place at Vienna, where an American, named MARSH, a clerk in a mercantile house, who had embezzled $20,000, was arrested. abstract: Mrs. LINCOLN, wife of the President of the United States, with her sister and niece, arrived in town yesterday morning, and the party are stopping at the Astor House. Col. (late Major) ANDERSON escorted the ladies from Washington, whence they came by the 10 1/2 A.M. train, Friday, as far as Philadelphia, and SIMEON DEAPER, Esq., conducted them during the remainder of the journey to this City. Mrs. LINCOLN has come North mainly to visit her son ROBERT, who is at college.

abstract: MR. CHAIRMAN, LADIES AND GENTLEMAN: The object which brings us together, even if it had not been so satisfactorily stated and so persuasively enforced by the gentleman who have proceded me, sufficiently explains itself.
lead_paragraph: MR. CHAIRMAN, LADIES AND GENTLEMAN: The object which brings us together, even if it had not been so satisfactorily stated and so persuasively enforced by the gentleman who have proceded me, sufficiently explains itself. At the call of the President, seconded with the most praiseworthy and almost unexampled energy of the Governor of Massachusetts, a numerous force of volunteers has patriotically hastened to the defence of the Capital of the United States, threatened with invasion. The war, for a long time though in profound peace secretly prepared for, has been openly commenced by the South, by the seizure of the undefended forts, arsenals, dockyards, [???] and custom-houses of the United States, and the plunder of the property contained in them, in flagrant violation of the law of the land, if the South is still in the Union, and equally flagrant violation of every principle of international law, if she is out of the Union. But even these acts of treason and rebellion (for such they are,) are thrown into the shade by the last unutterable outrage upon the flag of the Union, at Fort Sumter, (a fort which no more belongs to South Carolina than it does to New York or Massachusetts) which has carried twenty millions of freemen as one man to its defence.

abstract: "The Legislature adjourned at 10 o'clock, yesterday, after having fully completed the work for which it was called together. abstract: The officers commanding the forces on Staten Island, report that the troops are making excellent progress in drilling, and the two regiments are in good spirits, and only impatient to be called into service as early as possible.
lead_paragraph: The officers commanding the forces on Staten Island, report that the troops are making excellent progress in drilling, and the two regiments are in good spirits, and only impatient to be called into service as early as possible. Col. WILSON's command consists of eight full companies, and two which are yet incomplete. Every day improves their condition, and they are now only wanting suitable equipments to make them compare favorably with the most efficient men in the service. Many of the accounts heretofore published of this regiment have done them great injustice, and have created undeserved prejudices. They conform cheerfully to the rules of the camp, and when not under drill, amuse themselves in various athletic sports upon the green at the north side of Quarantine inclosure. With the exception of $700 donated by two or three patriotic citizens, and a gray uniform for temporary service, the officers have thus far provided everything for the men since they have been in quarters. The lack of necessary changes of raiment during the late cold and rainy weather has produced some suffering, which, however, they hear cheerfully, expecting soon to have the requisite uniforms and other equipments so necessary for service. Only some half dozen are on the sick list.

abstract: In his present number Mr. DUNBAR has brought to a close the first series of his dissertations upon the condition of Mexico, and its relation to the United States.
lead_paragraph: In his present number Mr. DUNBAR has brought to a close the first series of his dissertations upon the condition of Mexico, and its relation to the United States. Of the value of these contributions to our knowledge of a subject so ill understood, stood, we have had occasion to speak in terms of hearty appreciation as the successive issues have appeared, reserving, however, our assent from many of the positions assumed by the writer, and in some instances dissenting entirely from the results of his reasoning. To the industry, curious research, and ingenuity which have produced this closing number, we can hardly accord an excess of praise. The future of the Mexican people, as connected with Slavery, and to be affected by the expansive tendencies of the new Southern Pro-Slavery Confederation, is the immediate topic, which the writer illustrates by an elaborate history of the rise, culmination, and decline of the system of involuntary labor among modern nations. The African Slave-trade is traced, back to its origin among the Portuguese, shortly after the discovery of the western coast of Africa; the introduction of African Slavery into the Spanish West Indies to replace the expiring race of aborigines; its extension to Mexico, the Spanish Main, and the Atlantic Coast of South America; its arrival in the English colony of Virginia and its subsequent adoption by the other English settlements, as they were gradually organized, are recorded with careful accuracy, and constitute so much of the history as embraces the rise of commercial Slavery. The culminating period Mr. DUNBAR discovers to have been reached about 1790, when France and England moved simultaneously toward the project of universal emancipation; the former taking one of these long and rapid revolutionary strides by which the reformers of that day were apt to leave veteran and effete institutions behind; the latter, persuaded by philanthropy in the first instance, but afterwards impelled by a commercial necessity, resulting from the policy of France. Mr. DUNBAR's history of the Abolition movement, through the period of decadence, is no less curious and instructive than the previous chapter, bringing together, as it does, a , mass of information previously inaccessible without a laborious exploration of libraries. His inquiries have led him to the belief that in 1790 there were 3,000,000 of Negro and 7,000 of Indian slaves in the Western Hemisphere; the entire free civilized population being at that time 6,000,000. In other words, that nearly two-thirds of the population were in bondage. In 1860, Mr. DUNBAR estimates the free civilized population at 65,000,000, while the slaves are calculated at 7,179,778; in other words, the servile population has declined so as to be no more than one tenth of the entire, population. This numerical evidence of the decay of Slavery, Mr. DUNBAR, strengthens by demonstrating the steady contraction of the limits occupied by the slave labor during the same period of seventy years; and by showing how nearly the Slave-trade, with its reinforcements of negroes, has ceased to exist. The conclusion is inevitable. And while there has been a general conviction, founded upon less minute investigation than Mr. DUNBAR's, that Slavery is hastening to extinction at an always accelerated pace, the proof has never unsil now been absolutely circumstantial. Of the labor which has furnished this useful data, we cannot be too sensible.

abstract: has had little time of late to attend to its favorite line of business. On Thursday, however, it so far recovered its ordinary temper as to consider what an admirable opportunity the concentration of the public mind upon the war afforded for little judicious speculations; and it proceeded to avail itself of the chance, by proposing to raise the salaries of some half-dozen officers connected with the Croton Water Department. This job, we presume, was intended to escape attention amid the din and clamor of martial preparations, an intention it gives us great pleasure to defeat. We beg to have the thing well understood. At the moment when our people are stretching every nerve to save the country; are cheerfully incurring a vast addition to the already intolerable burden of taxation for the outfit of troops and the supply of a Commissariat; and are depriving themselves of luxuries, and in many instances, even of comforts, in the promotion of the great national cause; these patriotic heroes of the Ring are devising new schemes of private enrichment, and still heavier additions to the public burdens for the benefit of their own creatures. The morale of the business is much the same as that of a convict to whom one of our Courts, the other day, awarded the longest legal term of imprisonment, for the aggravated crime of having robbed a sleeping soldier. It is stealing upon the secure hour of public calamity for purposes of plunder; and if the project be persisted in, the Common Council will find how dangerous it is to trifle with public patience at such moments of extraordinary excitement.

abstract: With the exception of the Winter Garden, where Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JEFFERSON keep large audiences in a constant state of jubilation, the theatres have not been especially cheerful during the past week.
lead_paragraph: With the exception of the Winter Garden, where Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JEFFERSON keep large audiences in a constant state of jubilation, the theatres have not been especially cheerful during the past week. The usual business of the season has been brought to an abrupt end. People find more amusement in an "extra" than in the most popular place of amusement, and at that modest recreation, even at war prices, is more economical than a seat in the parquet, people have taken to it with unusual kindliness. A drama, peculiarly suited to the times -- "Jessie Brown" -- was revived at Wallack's Theatre on Monday, but failed to awaken the old favor. It was played through the week, and withdrawn on Saturday. The caste was an acceptable one. All the principal members of Mr. WALLACK's old company were included in it, with the exception of Mr. BLAKS, who has retired from the establishment. His part was filled by Mr. PEARSON, a very useful actor. The heroine was impersonated by Miss MORANT; Nenah Sahib by Mr. NORTON. We have no hesitation in saving that we prefer Miss AGNES ROBERTSON and Mr. DION BOURCICAULT, the original representatives of the same parts. Still, in the absence of these artists, it is but just to say that their substitutes were quite good, and had no previous impression existed, would, perhaps, have created a stronger effect. Mr. LESTER and Mrs. HOEY sustained their old parts, and made them as interesting as ever. In the last act they are both especially good. And how admirable is that last act, with its innumerable touches of earnest human nature and pathos. HOURCICAULT, as a dramatist, was always artistic; his proclivities were to the generous side of a man's character; his aversion the delineation of its opposite. That peculiar kind of drama which boasts of its first and second villains never received a single contribution from his pen. The Phantom and Nena Sahib are the only characters of a sombre kind he has delineated, and they appear only as dark spots on pictures otherwise blight. When the cotemporary drama receives a fair share of justice, the last act of "Jessie Brown" will certainly be remembered as one of We best contributions that his been made to it. Mr. WALLACK will open his new establishment, at the corner of Broadway and Thirteenth-street, during the early part of the Fall. The old theatre has been leased for a popular Music Hall, and is therefore cut of the theatrical market.

abstract: LOST. -- The Administration has now an opportunity of striking a blow at the rebels, which to omit will go very far to destroy all confidence in its sincerity and energy. The Great Eastern is here, and we understand its officers have authority to arrange a charter with Government, looking to its immediate conversion into a transport ship. Let it be hired at once. It will be remembered that the Leviathan will comfortably accommodate an army of 10,000 men, with horses, artillery, and the most liberal stores for a long voyage. So furnished and dispatched to the Gulf of Mexico, the vessel would almost supersede the presence of a squadron, save the few frigates engaged in the blockade of three or four principal ports; for passing with the utmost speed from point to point, it would render the Gulf too hot for privateers; and threatening now one sea-port, and now another, it would furnish ample occupation for a rebel army of fifty thousand men. It is needless to remind the reader of its numerous and ample boats, by which a landing could be readily effected anywhere, -- or a hostile vessel taking shelter in shore, could he pursued and cut out. We trust the obvious economy of the warfare, the Great Eastern thus insures, will have such weight with the authorities as to cause its immediate charter and dispatch to Southern waters.

abstract: Secession in Mary and is not only sick, it is dead. The Up as tree, however, cannot at once, in all its roots, be so entirely eradicated, that it may not, under circumstances auspicious to its growth, here and there, occasionally, sprout up again. But, for the present, it has disappeared; and its wildes advocates admit, that any attempt at its resuscitation would, under the present condition of affairs, be not only vain, but mad.
