abstract: I have no confidence in any pacific movements that may be made here. The secession leaders are subtle and polite men. Everything will be kept quiet until they are ready for some overwhelming and irresistible movement, when another 19th of April scene will be enacted.
lead_paragraph: I have no confidence in any pacific movements that may be made here. The secession leaders are subtle and polite men. Everything will be kept quiet until they are ready for some overwhelming and irresistible movement, when another 19th of April scene will be enacted. I know that the attack upon the troops was an organized thing, and if the mob executed the leaders of the party planned, and inflamed the men's minds with whisky, and the idea that the troops were coming through to subjugate the South. There is a heavy responsibility resting upon THOMAS WINANS PARKIN SCOTT, TEAKLE WALLIS, GEORGE KANE, and many others. A man who gives his influence and means to the support of such outrages is more responsible than those hirelings who execute. I class them altogether; and, as transgressors of the good order and peace of the city, and as traitors to our common country, I would have each man held accountable for his words and actions.

abstract: Wells' Commercial Express, of Thursday last, reviews the business movements of the preceding week, at Chicago, thus: "The same causes frequently noted in our recent reviews of the markets, still continue to derange business and affect the values of produce, but with even greater force and more frequent fluctuation than before. The difficulty of fixing upon prices where so many classes of currency are used as medium without having a specie basis of calculation, can hardly be appreciated without being right in the midst of the confusion, and watching every turn. To describe it so as to make it perfectly intelligible to one at a distance is quite impossible. In the single case of Wheat alone, a difference of 7c. bushel was made to-day by the difference in the currency specified to be used in payment. But the partially secured currency still farms the bulk of that afloat, and prices without specification must be understood to be in that description of currency. Proceeding to write upon this basis, we note the following changes since our last: Flour closing dull a week ago, declined suddenly 15c.@25c., and has since ruled dull until to-day it was firmer and a little buoyant. Wheat went down suddenly on Thursday last, ruled heavy Friday and Saturday, was lower still on Monday and Tuesday, but rallied to-day and closed firm Corn has been less fluctuating, but has ruled lower than in the week previous. Oats lower and dull. Barley less active and prices drooping. Rye in good request and steady. Seeds very irregular. Vegetables without change. Fruits active. Provisions rather quiet at about previous prices. Fish rather lower. Cattle active and firm. Hogs in good request, but prices a little lower. Hides in better request and firmer. Tallow dull and nominal."

Wheat went down suddenly on Thursday last, ruled heavy Friday and Saturday, was lower still on Monday and Tuesday, but rallied to-day and closed firm Corn has been less fluctuating, but has ruled lower than in the week previous. Oats lower and dull. Barley less active and prices drooping. Rye in good request and steady. Seeds very irregular. Vegetables without change. Fruits active. Provisions rather quiet at about previous prices. Fish rather lower. Cattle active and firm. Hogs in good request, but prices a little lower. Hides in better request and firmer. Tallow dull and nominal."

abstract: We learn from the New-Orleans True Delta that the Governor of Louisiana has authorized the organization of a regiment of free negroes in that State, for active service against the "mean, false, dastardly black Republicans of the North;" and that FELIX LABATUT, Esq., of New Orleans, an "old, esteemed and wealthy citizen," will probably be appointed Colonel of the African contingent.
lead_paragraph: We learn from the New-Orleans True Delta that the Governor of Louisiana has authorized the organization of a regiment of free negroes in that State, for active service against the "mean, false, dastardly black Republicans of the North;" and that FELIX LABATUT, Esq., of New Orleans, an "old, esteemed and wealthy citizen," will probably be appointed Colonel of the African contingent. The Mobile Register also mentions that free negroes are volunteering in great numbers to fight for the South -- that their services are to accepted, and that they enter with alacrity on the discharge of their duties.

abstract: We ask foreign Cabinets, who may feel disposed to interpose in behalf of the great conspiracy, to call to mind the universal execration with which, throughout Europe, the manifesto of the famous Ostend Conference, which proposed to effect, by violence, what could not be accomplished by law or treaty -- to seize, by virtue of a strong arm, for the extension and perpetuation of Slavery, a province held by a friendly power -- was received. Modern history does not furnish an example equaling it in baseness, both in the motive, and the manner in which it was to be accomplished. Three Plenipotentiaries to the leading Courts of Europe, exhibited us to the world as a nation of robbers on a gigantic scale, to extend an institution which is an offence to the moral sense of mankind. The Ostend buccaneers were warmly hacked by their master, Mr. PIERCE, who was checkmated by an intractable Congress, which negatived his recommendation to send to Cuba an armed force, on the seizure of the Black Warrior.

abstract: Indignation at the attack on Fort Sumter seems to be the prevailing feeling throughout the Northern States. Mankind will always be more moved by the sound of actual warfare than by the violation of rights or the abandonment of compacts.
lead_paragraph: Indignation at the attack on Fort Sumter seems to be the prevailing feeling throughout the Northern States. Mankind will always be more moved by the sound of actual warfare than by the violation of rights or the abandonment of compacts. The Southern States may have torn the Constitution of the Union to pieces, but the patience of the North was not worn out until shot and shell had been poured into a Federal fortress, and a Federal officer had been led a prisoner through the rebellious City of Charleston. Now, however, there can be no doubt of the excitement all through the North. How long it may last, and whether it will survive a calm examination of the coming campaign, are other questions. For the present, there is an earnest desire in the Northern States to avenge the capture of Fort Sumter. The President's appeal has been responded to in every quarter. The feeling in New York City was so strong at the departure of the last steamer that the Herald, which has been throughout these troubles practically a Southern print, was forced to turn completely round and applaud the policy of the Government. The New England States and those of the West were also said to be zealous in the cause of the Union. Troops were being mustered in the leading towns and made ready to march for the defence of Washington, if not for the invasion of the Southern States. This outburst of loyalty may be attributed not a little to the restless character of the people. Year after year the military ardor of the Americans has been expended on militia field-days, on processions. Fourth of July demonstrations, and other proceedings equally showy and harmless. But something more has been demanded by the hot blood of the American youth. They leaped into the war with Mexico as if it were a relief from an intolerable tedium. It has required considerable judgment and forbearance to prevent a collision with Great Britain on several senseless disputes. Now, however, there is employment for every unquiet spirit. The Southerners have within a few hours come to be looked upon as enemies, against whom a crusade is meritorious. Even in New-York, which has been called with some justice a Southern city, where the productions of the South are dealt in more than in the southern cities themselves, where the Slavetracers are said to congregate, and where theparty of Mr. LINCOLN was small and weak a few months back, all traditions, all interests, all political feeling are now forgotten, and the whole community demands that justice should be done on the traitors of the South.

abstract: The Boston Commercial Bulletin states that Col. HAUPT, the distinguished engineer and contractor for building the Houses Tunnel, has made proposals to the War Department for raising the sunken vessels at the Gesport Navy-yard. He proposes to furnish competent men to perform the task at a reasonable compensation, and to superintend and give direction to the engineering department in person free of charge. All beyond this that he stipulates is, that the Government shall furnish a sufficient force to protect the [???] in their operation. He informs us that the work can be done in sixty days. The general plan of the operation may means of divers, who are to cover the holes with canvas, and where the portions are burned to insert timbers to support the canvas, and to eject the water by means of pumps worked by [???] locomotives. Those who are acquainted with Col. HAUPT, will at once have confidence in any such plan proposed by him. His eminent skill as an engineer has already been recognized by the Administration in placing him in the Board of Examination at West Point. Col. HAUPT also propose another plan, by way of suggestion to the Government. This is, to place powerful locomotive engine in the bottom of sailing ships for the purposes of propulsion, and by the process which he proposes an additional speed of the miles will be gained, the whole machinery to be arranged so as to leave no part expressed. The principles is, by means of pumps to [???] body of water from the bows of the ship to the stern. A conjunctive advantage will be, in case shot take effect under the water-line the first valves may be closed, and the water which comes in through the sh[???] be ejected, this converting themeans of destruction into those of service.

abstract: The advices which we publish this morning from the seat of Army operations seem to indicate that we are just at that point when almost the turning of a hair might cause a collision of the opposing forces, and we shall not be surprised to hear at any moment that the conflict has commenced.
lead_paragraph: The advices which we publish this morning from the seat of Army operations seem to indicate that we are just at that point when almost the turning of a hair might cause a collision of the opposing forces, and we shall not be surprised to hear at any moment that the conflict has commenced. A large force of Virginians yesterday moved down from Harper's Ferry to within twelve miles of the Relay House, and drove in the Federal scouts. Gen. BUTLER, who was at Annapolis, was immediately apprised of the movement, and sent to Col. JONES, who is in command at the Relay, a force of seven hundred men, beside the New-York Twentieth Regiment, which recently arrived there, as a reinforcement. Subsequently an additional reinforcement of sixteen hundred men and a body of cavalry and artillery was sent by Gen. MANSFIELD, to be ready to sustan Col. JONES at a moment's warning. Messengers who reached Washington late last night from Annapolis, by special train, stated that an attack was expected to take place upon Col JONES' position either last night or today. The Virginia forces, which were on Friday stationed at Alexandria, have also left that position, and it is possible that they may have marched to join those from Harper's Ferry.

abstract: The U.S. transport Chesapeake, VAILE, arrived yesterday afternoon from Washington, D.C. and reports on 9th inst., off New Point, passed a steam-frigate, (side-wheels,) bound to Fort Monroe, with a three-masted schooner in tow. On 10th inst., 7 o'clock A.M., off Cape Henry, passed U.S. gun-boat Quaker City, blockading the Chesapeake. Same date passed a ship bound up the Capes; supposed her name to be the Eliza Barber. The gun-boat Monticello was blockading the mouth of James River. Passed down the River Potomac, without any convoy. Saw no fortifications on either side of the river.

abstract: Immediately after the Baltimore "riot," the defendants in the never-ending suit of Ross WINANS vs. the North at large, that is to say, the shareholders in Northern railways, were informed that this notorious person had produced a steam centrifugal gun, and located the same in a principal street of that city, for the amiable purpose of throwing three hundred balls per minute into the bodies of a people he has never ceased to harass with lawsuits for "infringing" his worthless patent. This is the WINANS in whose favor a New-York jury recently found a verdict, in a patent case, which, if sustained in a new trial, will cost Northern railway companies several millions of dollars. When the profession heard that WINANS had brought out a gun, they were not very seriously alarmed; and, in fact, the gun, like WINANS' locomotives, cigar steamer, and engineering at large, proved a very bad job.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after the Baltimore "riot," the defendants in the never-ending suit of Ross WINANS vs. the North at large, that is to say, the shareholders in Northern railways, were informed that this notorious person had produced a steam centrifugal gun, and located the same in a principal street of that city, for the amiable purpose of throwing three hundred balls per minute into the bodies of a people he has never ceased to harass with lawsuits for "infringing" his worthless patent. This is the WINANS in whose favor a New-York jury recently found a verdict, in a patent case, which, if sustained in a new trial, will cost Northern railway companies several millions of dollars. When the profession heard that WINANS had brought out a gun, they were not very seriously alarmed; and, in fact, the gun, like WINANS' locomotives, cigar steamer, and engineering at large, proved a very bad job.

abstract: The United States transports Huntsville and Keystone State left the Brooklyn Navy-yard on Saturday. The destination of the latter is said to be Boston, as she has on board a marine guard for the United States steam frigate Mississippi, ordered to the blockade fleet. The Huntsville is to act as a gun-boat, and has naval sailors and an armament on on board.

abstract: Several homicides and fatal accidents have occurred among the troops in this military division, all tending to prove the importance of rigid discipline. Such occurrences are rare among regulars, and might be guarded against to a considerable extent among new levies, if the officers had the morel courage to enforce thearmy regulations.

abstract: During the past ten days very little has occurred worthy of note. There have been no arrivals from South or Central America, and our news from the interior of the Republic, although important, if true, is too meagre and indefinite to be much relied on. The U.S. Mail steamer Conway, from Carthagena, is due here to-morrow, just twenty-four hours too late to forward her news.

abstract: Capt. THOS. CHISHOLM, prize-master of the schooner Geo. M. Smith, arrived yesterday from Hampton Roads, and will deliver the vessel to Commodore BREESE, of the Brooklyn Navy-yard. He reports all on board the Cumberland well and impatient for action. Capt. C. believes that the officers and men on board the Cumberland, in case of an attack, would rather blow the vessel and themselves to atoms than see her fall into the hands of the enemy.

abstract: The city was the scene of another terrible tragedy last night. About 6 o'clock a large body of the Home Guards entered the city, through Fifth- street, from the Arsenal, where they had been enlisted during the day, and furnished with arms. On reaching Walnut-street, the troops turned westward, a large crowd lining the pavement to witness their progress.

abstract: The first great victory of the campaign will be consummated to-day, by the secession to the Free North of the free portion of Virginia, which embraces nearly if not quite one-half of the entire territory of the State. Thirty thousand square miles will be taken from nominally slave soil, to swell the already overwhelming preponderance of the free. Five hundred thousand people, who by their past political relations, have either been silent upon the subject of Slavery, or who have been ranked among, and have virtually been its supporters, will henceforth be as outspoken against it, as the freemen of Ohio or New-York.
lead_paragraph: The first great victory of the campaign will be consummated to-day, by the secession to the Free North of the free portion of Virginia, which embraces nearly if not quite one-half of the entire territory of the State. Thirty thousand square miles will be taken from nominally slave soil, to swell the already overwhelming preponderance of the free. Five hundred thousand people, who by their past political relations, have either been silent upon the subject of Slavery, or who have been ranked among, and have virtually been its supporters, will henceforth be as outspoken against it, as the freemen of Ohio or New-York.

abstract: The people of this country have been so long accustomed to the slow progress of things in time of peace, that the swift movements of the events of the day amazes and bewilders them. They go to bed at night expecting to hear of some great battle in the morning, and they enter upon the business of the day expecting that some wonderful thing, that shall settle the affairs of the nation, will happen before night. They see a gigantic conspiracy perfected against the Government, including certainly eleven, and probably thirteen States, with seven or eight millions of people, committed to its wickedness, and they look to see it crushed or successful in a week.
lead_paragraph: The people of this country have been so long accustomed to the slow progress of things in time of peace, that the swift movements of the events of the day amazes and bewilders them. abstract: The Philadelphia Press has this paragraph: Two prominent Baptist ministers evacuated their pulpits in this city on last Sunday -- Rev. J.H. CUTHBERT, pastor of the Fifth Baptist Church, corner of Broad and Arch streets, and Rev. MERRIWETHER WINSTON, of the Fifth Baptist Church, late Sansom street. Both these gentlemen are Southerners, the former being a son in-law of Dr. FULLER, of Baltimore, spokesman for the Young Mens' Christian Association Committee which recently waited upon President LINCOLN to plead the cause of a murderous mob. Mr. CUTHBERT's resignation on Sunday last was unexpected, unexplained, and, we learn, was received with surprise and regret by his congregation. Mr. WINSTON, we believe, returns to the sunny South at this time to recruit his health. The unceremonious departure of Rev. HENRY A. WISE from his charge in West Philadelphia, on the day that he was helped out of a barber shop on Chesnut street for uttering offensive secession sentiments, has already been made public. We have since learned that this distinguished son made his way to Dover, where, under an assumed name, he obtained a private conveyance to carry him to Accomac County, Va., that delectable spot, the pride of which his distinguished father once boasted was, that there was no newspaper published in it.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Press has this paragraph: Two prominent Baptist ministers evacuated their pulpits in this city on last Sunday -- Rev. J.H. CUTHBERT, pastor of the Fifth Baptist Church, corner of Broad and Arch streets, and Rev. MERRIWETHER WINSTON, of the Fifth Baptist Church, late Sansom street. Both these gentlemen are Southerners, the former being a son in-law of Dr. FULLER, of Baltimore, spokesman for the Young Mens' Christian Association Committee which recently waited upon President LINCOLN to plead the cause of a murderous mob. Mr. CUTHBERT's resignation on Sunday last was unexpected, unexplained, and, we learn, was received with surprise and regret by his congregation. Mr. WINSTON, we believe, returns to the sunny South at this time to recruit his health. The unceremonious departure of Rev. HENRY A. WISE from his charge in West Philadelphia, on the day that he was helped out of a barber shop on Chesnut street for uttering offensive secession sentiments, has already been made public. We have since learned that this distinguished son made his way to Dover, where, under an assumed name, he obtained a private conveyance to carry him to Accomac County, Va., that delectable spot, the pride of which his distinguished father once boasted was, that there was no newspaper published in it.

abstract: The recent document of the Sabbath Committee was entitied "The Civil Sabbath Restored." The unanimity and strength of public sentiment evinced in popular demonstrations of different nationalities, by the Press, by Legislative votes, by the decisions of Courts and Juries, and by the action of Police authorities, and the consequent suppression of the most offensive forms of Sabbath desecration, seemed to justify the claim that this great bulwark of morals and self-government had been reestablished.
lead_paragraph: The recent document of the Sabbath Committee was entitied "The Civil Sabbath Restored." The unanimity and strength of public sentiment evinced in popular demonstrations of different nationalities, by the Press, by Legislative votes, by the decisions of Courts and Juries, and by the action of Police authorities, and the consequent suppression of the most offensive forms of Sabbath desecration, seemed to justify the claim that this great bulwark of morals and self-government had been reestablished. But civil war, in its wide sweep of evils, so involves this important interest as te constrain some precaution, lost, in the patriotic struggle for the security and perpetuity of our free institutions, there should be a fatal weakening of their permanent moral foundations. If we would save our country we must hold fast to our Sabbath.

abstract: The Southern mind has long been in such a state of mental ecstacy, that nothing short of a sound drubbing, or signal exhibition of the power of the North, can ever bring the rebels to anything like reason, either in their conduct or ideas. Whatever they produce seeks its market by sea. Yet, without being able to put even a tub afloat without first stealing it, they grossly insult and attempt to destroy the Government of a first-class naval Power. In our contests with them, all our commercial, sea-going and coastwise steamers are just as effective as are ships-of-war, for the reason that the South have nothing to oppose to them. The Baltic, mounted with a few guns, can blockade as well as the Niagara. So many merchant steamers have been taken up by Government, that an adequate blockading fleet for every Southern port is or will soon be under weigh.

abstract: Our "Washington dispatches this morning are important, as indicating the number of secession troops now at and near Richmond, and the condition of affairs at various points in the South, especially in Memphis. A gentleman who has recently come through Virginia, stopping at Richmond, puts the number of troops there at 6,000, while surrounding the city, within a radius of 50 miles, are about 19,000 more, in all about 25,000. Another authority estimates the number at 30,000.These troops, however, as we learn from a letter published in the Charleston Mercury -- an authority not likely to misrepresent the matter to the disadvantage of the South -- have been brought together without any decided plan of action, and are still under the command of their respective State officers, not yet having been mustered into the service of the Southern Confederacy. Gen. PILLOW who has established his head-quarters at Memphis, has under his command, or can render available in a short time, about fifteen thousand troops, intended for a demonstration upon Cairo; but he suffers under disadvantages in point of position. The latest accounts from Cairo render it certain that an attack by him on that point would result in disastrous defeat to his forces. To render the position of the Federal troops there still more secure, Gen. SCOTT has recently, ordered the heights commanding it to be taken possession of and fortified, so that every approach to the place is commanded absolutely by Federal cannon.

abstract: The Spanish steam frigate Berenguela, Capt. ARRCOS, arrived at this port yesterday, in six days from Havana. She mounts 37 guns, and has 400 men. She came to this port to act as convoy, and brings Mr. DWIGHT, bearer of dispatches from Pensacola to Washington. She reports nothing new at Fort Pickens. She also brings 12 passengers and a mail from Havana.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish steam frigate Berenguela, Capt. ARRCOS, arrived at this port yesterday, in six days from Havana. She mounts 37 guns, and has 400 men. abstract: The body of JOHN L. REESE, late of the Seventh Regiment N.Y.S.M., who was accidentally killed at Camp Cameron on Thursday last, was brought to this city Saturday, and placed in his late residence in Cheever-place. The body was accompanied by a guard from his own company. The funeral exercises took place yesterday in Christ Church, corner of Harrison and Clinton-streets. The remains were escorted from the house to the church by the immediate relatives of the deceased in carriages, Company "B" of the Home Guard, Seventh Regiment in citizen's dress, a detachment of the Ninth Regiment in uniform, and the guard of honor sent on with the body. At the church, the body was received by the Rev. Dr. CANFIELD, and escorted to the church. The burial service peculiar to the Episcopal Church was then read. The pews on either side of the main aisle were reserved for the chief mourners and immediate friends of deceased.
lead_paragraph: The body of JOHN L. abstract: Capt. KEIHL of the Thirteenth Regiment, who is also Alderman of the Sixteenth Ward, reached here on Friday night last, and, it is presumed, will remain in this city until the new Board of Aldermen is organized. The Kings County boys who remain at home, it will be seen by the following, are not less ready to discharge their duty here, than those who go into the field. Ex-Capt. SUYDAM of the Kings County Troop, B.B. REMSEN, and eleven men from Canarsie, at 3 1/2 o'clock, Saturday morning, during the storm, took possession of the schooner M.L. Whetmore, 160 tons burthen, of Fair Haven, Conn., in Jamaica Bay, and seized three rifled cannon, supposed to have been shipped for the rebel service. The schooner had six men on board, but they did not make a strenuous resistance. The cannon were brought to Brooklyn yesterday.

abstract: It was stated some days since that Mayor MAYO, of Richmond, had returned to the Seventh Regiment his certificate of honorary membership. By way of reciprocating the compliment, we understand that a member of the Second Company of the Seventh has just sent back to the Mayor a handsome pair of game cocks, with which "His Honors" presented him a year ago.

abstract: The Great Eastern steamship looms up once more at her old anchorage in the North River. Being obliged, on account of the tide, to remain outside of the Hook until yesterday morning, she weighed anchor between 8 and 9 o'clock, and prepared to come over the bar while the tide was at its height -- about 9 1/2 o'clock. She came in without accident, under the skillful management of Admiral MURPHY, her former pilot, and turning the Southwest Spit at 9 3/4, came up the Bay in magnificent style.
lead_paragraph: The Great Eastern steamship looms up once more at her old anchorage in the North River. She came in without accident, under the skillful management of Admiral MURPHY, her former pilot, and turning the Southwest Spit at 9 3/4, came up the Bay in magnificent style.

abstract: The hero of Fort Sumter left Philadelphia in the 6 o'clock P.M. train of Saturday, in charge of a Committee consisting of Messrs. Catherwood, Case, Ford and Mr. Gordon, Clerk of the Common Council of Philadelphia, who accompanied him as far as Trenton, at which point, on inquiry of Col. ANDERSON as to whom he would be pleased to suggest as his escort to New-York, the Colonel designated Col. J. LAFAYETTE RIKER, of the Anderson Zouaves, special bearer of dispatches from Washington. Col. RIKER expressed his gratification at the high compliment paid him, and assured them that he would fulfill the mission intrusted to him to the best of his ability.

abstract: Mr. BARNEY, Collector of the Port of New-York, was absent from his office on Saturday, on a tour of inspection of the harbor. New-York is not only the centre of the military and naval operations of Government, but it is also the very place at which the rebels would seek to obtain supplies and materials for the war. There is no doubt that they have a large number of spies and agents in our midst, and not a few secret sympathizers. The most careful surveillance, consequently, is maintained over the three great entrances from the sea -- the Sound, the Narrows, and the Kill von Kull. In each entrance a guard-ship is placed, from which any vessel passing out is boarded, and if everything is not found right, detained. No merchant vessel whatever is allowed to leave the port between sunset and sunrise. At the Narrows, the oath to support, the Constitution was, at the request of the captain of the Corwin, administered to the officers and crew, who appeared to be most zealous in their attachment to Government, and in the performance of their duties. Only in one instance has a vessel gone to sea without showing her papers. For this breach of orders a satisfactory apology was rendered. The strict watch maintained does not interfere with the commerce of the City, while it is an effectual check upon the movements of all suspicious characters.

abstract: Col. OSCOLUMSKY, a Polish officer of distinction, who, at the time of the commencement of the secession furore in the South, was employed as engineer and draftsman, by the State of Florida, was driven out of the "Sunny South," because he failed to fee the beauties of rebellion, and arrived in this City some three months ago, where he has since remained. Since the Polish volunteers have been quartered at the Park Barracks, he has assisted in drilling his countrymen.

abstract: The Baptists of Georgia, not content with the management of their spiritual matters, have concluded to wade into the rebellion now rampant in that State. It was not enough that they should be traitors individually, but as a Church they must prostitute even their religion and their organization to the wicked purpose of dissolving the Union.
lead_paragraph: The Baptists of Georgia, not content with the management of their spiritual matters, have concluded to wade into the rebellion now rampant in that State. It was not enough that they should be traitors individually, but as a Church they must prostitute even their religion and their organization to the wicked purpose of dissolving the Union. We remember when the South made a great outcry because a number of New-England clergymen petitioned Congress for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law. It was a grave offence in the eyes of the South for them to leave their pulpits and their preaching to meddle in politics, even so far as to petition Congress for the repeal of what they regarded as an unjust and iniquitous law. They were denounced as false to their high calling, degrading the religion of the cross to the level of party politics, and making the pulpit the handmaiden of the grog-shop and the primary forum in the propagandism of party creeds. But this was in New-England, and that made all the difference in the world in the estimation of "our Southern brethren." Here is an entire denomination, a whole sect, acting not individually, but as a denomination, plunging officially into treason, and giving the sanction of their Church to rebellion against the Government.
headline: {'main': 'The Baptists Wading in.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Baptists Wading in.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To foreigners who have looked at this country simply in mass, and who have no experience of our institutions or sectional tendencies, and who only a few months ago saw the most peaceable and apparently amicable relations pravailing between the North and South, the present attitude of the two sections, breathing intense hostility, and with daggers drawn, threatening each other's existence, must be an astonishing spectacle.
lead_paragraph: To foreigners who have looked at this country simply in mass, and who have no experience of our institutions or sectional tendencies, and who only a few months ago saw the most peaceable and apparently amicable relations pravailing between the North and South, the present attitude of the two sections, breathing intense hostility, and with daggers drawn, threatening each other's existence, must be an astonishing spectacle. It certainly is so with ourselves, although with better opportunities for observation, we are beginning to appreciate more correctly the cause. The immediate contest has its origin in the question as to which Government, State or Federal, paramount allegiance is due. In Free territory, this is universally conceded to the latter, when the two come in collision. In Slave, the reverse is the rule. In the South, it is my State that commands the first duty, represents the nationality, and appeals to the patriotism of the citizen. In the North, it is the Federal Government, coextensive in its operations with the whole country, creating one mighty nationality, and impressing upon all its members the same grand tyye.

abstract: The steamship Roanoke, GEO. N. CONCH, Master, arrived from Washington, D.C., and sailed on Friday at 4:30 P.M. At 5 P.M. passed Alexandria, and saw the Secession flag flying. On Saturday, at 9:30 A.M., passed the United States steamship of war Pawnee, bound up the Potomac. At 2 P.M., passed steamship Bienville, with troops, at the entrance of the Potomac. At 4 P.M., passed steamship Matanzas, with troops, bound up the Chesapeake. At 7 P.M., passed steamboat Yankee, lying to at Cape Henry.

abstract: We understand that Postmaster TAYLOR has received instructions to dispatch a mail to Fort Monroe and Old Point Comfort, Va., by every transport sent from this port with troops, munitions, &c. By this arrangement the difficulties hitherto experienced by the obstruction of the inland route will be overcome. Letters and papers can be sent, by this means, to the Massachusetts Regiment and other troops at Fort Monroe, Va.

abstract: On Saturday a tall, splendid looking man, dressed in the uniform of the Allen Greys, Vermont, stood conversing with a friend on Broadway. He was entirely unconscious that his superior heights was attracting universal attention, until a splendid barouche drove up to the sidewalk, and a young man sprang from it and grasped his hand, saying, "You are the most splendid specimen of humanity I ever saw. I am a Southerner, but my heart is with the UNION; if it were not, such noble-looking fellows as yourself would enlist me in the cause." The subject of the remark, although surprised, was perfectly self-possessed, and answered the cordial greeting of the young Southerner with warm enthusiasm. He was several inches above six feet, and his noble open countenance beamed with the ancient patriotism of the Green Mountain Boys, of which he was so fine a specimen. He had walked fifteen miles from the village of Chittenden to enlist, and was the only representative of that village; but he was a host in himself. Long may he live to honor our Stars and Stripes.

abstract: Gov. CURTIN has addressed a message to the Legislature of Pennsylvania, telling them in general terms how the money appropriated by the act of April 12 has been expended. He concludes his message with an appeal to the Legislature to act in harmony, that the rebellion may be put down.

abstract: The Fourteenth Regiment was inspected on Fort Greene -- where it is now encamped -- on Saturday afternoon last. There were 850 men present. The Union Safety Committee of New-York were on the ground, and expressed themselves as much pleased with the appearance of the men, and particularly with their patriotic desire to he sent forward where they can serve their country. Col. WOOD, who is in command, has announced that marching orders will be issued to-day. The Fourteenth is thoroughly equipped in every particular, and a majority of the men are of the right kind for serious business.

abstract: Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER last evening delivered a timely and very interesting addresss to the Congregation of Plymouth Church upon the peculiar trials and temptations of camp life, and the duties of the community towards those who have enlisted, and who will continue to volunteer for the defence of the country. His text was in Deuteronomy, 23d chapter, 14th verse: "For the Lord thy God walketh in the midst of thy camp, to deliver thee, and to give up thine enemies before thee."

abstract: A young man who, until the 20th ult., was engaged in running a cotton lighter at Apalachicola, and who has just arrived in this City, states that the day before he left, it had been announced by telegraph that Lieut. Gen. SCOTT had resigned, and that the City of New-York was about to secede from the Union, and had offered to send a force of 40,000 men to join the army of the Confederate States. This news occasioned great rejoicing, and gun-firing was kept up in honor of it all night. The Northern merchants in Apilachicola were much distressed. Each had been called upon, and asked, in a menacing manner, "Are you, or are you not, willing to fight for the Confederate States?" Believing it necessary to save their lives, they had all answered that if necessary they would fight. On a similar question being asked our informant, by some persons who were strangers to him, he answered that he could not raise his hands against the Stars and Stripes. A crowd of rowdies immediately afterwards collected about him, and calling him an Abolitionist, a Northern spy, &c, threatened to take his life, but no one laid hands on him. A Colonel of militia called on him and asked him to volunteer, saying, at the same time, "I am ordered to bring a certain number of men from here. If that number does not volunteer by to morrow I shall draft them, I shall draft you for one. You can volunteer if you like." At night he got on board a schooner, which left the next day for Boston, and so escaped. He says that every one at Apalachicola publicly expressed secession sentiments, but many of his old acquaintances would in private express great regret at all that was occurring. No one doubted the success of the South in a war against the North.
lead_paragraph: A young man who, until the 20th ult., was engaged in running a cotton lighter at Apalachicola, and who has just arrived in this City, states that the day before he left, it had been announced by telegraph that Lieut. abstract: Ten o'clock P.M., and I have just come from the military levce at the White House. The rooms were filled, but not uncomfortbly crowded, and the scene was quite brilliant. At eight o'clock the carriages began to arrive at the President's mansion, and continued to roll up the graveled path leading to the main entrance until half past nine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON CITY, Thursday, May 9, 1861.

abstract: J. MCLEOD MURPHY's Regiment will be mustered into the United states service early this week. Capt. CHESTER, telegraph engineer, can take operators who can pass inspection into ranks for two or three days more only. They will serve as privates except when called on telegraph duty, when pay will be high. The quota being full, no more regiments will be accepted at present. Send word by telegraph to Capt. S. CHESTER, New-York, immediately, if ready.

abstract: "Your usurped right to dismiss me from the army might be acquiesed in; but you had no right to brand me as a traitor. This was personal, and I shall treat it as such, not through the papers, but in person. I shall, most assuredly, pay a visit to Lancaster, for the sole purpose of a personal interview with you. So, Sir, prepare yourself. I am well assured that public opinion will sanction any course I may take with you."

abstract: Tennessee, or rather the Tennessee Legislature, went out of the Union, on the 7th of May, with a great flourish. Five millions of dollars were appropriated for arming the State, and thus Tennessee stands defiantly on the side of secession, with a great army equipped, or to be equipped, -- on paper. Unfortunately for Tennessee, there are two or three very important difficulties in the way of her dissolving the Union, and slaughtering the loyal men of her own and other States.

abstract: At last, all who love the Union and the Constitution of the United States have come to the same conclusion: that the great rebellion is no contempore affair. So elaborate, and so minute, has been the preparation as to make it certain that even the details must have been far advanced long before any of the pretended causes for the revolt existed. The election of LINCOLN was but the pretence of a day -- and the conspirators were so far committed to the act of rebellion that they could not and would not recede in any event. Their best hope was that, in case of success in the election, they might use their preparation to overwhelm opposition and consummate their design without an armed conflict; but this hope having failed them, the present rebellion was a foregone conclusion.
lead_paragraph: At last, all who love the Union and the Constitution of the United States have come to the same conclusion: that the great rebellion is no contempore affair. So elaborate, and so minute, has been the preparation as to make it certain that even the details must have been far advanced long before any of the pretended causes for the revolt existed. The election of LINCOLN was but the pretence of a day -- and the conspirators were so far committed to the act of rebellion that they could not and would not recede in any event. Their best hope was that, in case of success in the election, they might use their preparation to overwhelm opposition and consummate their design without an armed conflict; but this hope having failed them, the present rebellion was a foregone conclusion.
headline: {'main': 'Long Preparation for the Rebellion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Long Preparation for the Rebellion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Robert M. De Witt vs. James Brooks et al. This was an action for an alleged infringement of copyright. The plaintiff claimed to be assignee of the copyright of the confession of the murderer and pirate Hicks, which the defendants had published in the New-York Express, of which they were the owners and publishers.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. De Witt vs. James Brooks et al. -- This was an action for an alleged infringement of copyright. The plaintiff claimed to be assignee of the copyright of the confession of the murderer and pirate Hicks, which the defendants had published in the New-York Express, of which they were the owners and publishers. The evidence of the plaintiff showed that the confession was taken down by a reporter from Hicks' own mouth, and that the plaintiff, under an agreement to pay part of the proceeds of the publication for the benefit of Hicks' wife, took an assignment of Hicks' right, and employed another party to put the confession into shape and prepare it for publication.

abstract: The delegates to the Convention of Western and North-Western Virginia, called to deliberate upon the best means of opposing the policy of Secession adopted by the late Convention at Richmond, assembled yesterday at Wheeling, and proceeded to business.
lead_paragraph: The delegates to the Convention of Western and North-Western Virginia, called to deliberate upon the best means of opposing the policy of Secession adopted by the late Convention at Richmond, assembled yesterday at Wheeling, and proceeded to business. A committee of one from each county was appointed, to whom was referred the subject of representation, and the duty of reporting officers for a permanent organization, when a short recess was taken. The subsequent proceedings consisted mainly of discussions as to the proper course to be pursued. The greatest enthusiasm prevailed, not only in the Convention, but outside.

abstract: In the House of Lords, on the 29th ultimo, Earl of Malmesbury, adverting to the state of affairs in America, said: I beg leave to put to my noble friend, the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, a question of which I have given him private notice, in reference to a subject which deeply interests this country, and, I may say, the whole of Europe.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on the 29th ultimo, Earl of Malmesbury, adverting to the state of affairs in America, said: I beg leave to put to my noble friend, the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, a question of which I have given him private notice, in reference to a subject which deeply interests this country, and, I may say, the whole of Europe. Almost all your lordships have, no doubt, read the accounts which arrived this morning from America, and must have learned with pain, as well as some astonishment, that a civil war had broken out between the Secessionists in that country and the other States of the Union. Fortunately, up to the date of those accounts, hardly any blood had been shed, and too much praise cannot, I think, be bestowed upon the commander of the fleet engaged in the transaction to which I refer for abstaining from entering on a useless contest. It is impossible, however, that a struggle such as that which seems now impending in America -- a struggle so unnatural, and calculated, I may add, to prove so fatal to the parties concerned in it -- should not produce a reverberation throughout the rest of the world. I may further observe that no country on this side of the Atlantic is, perhaps, more likely to suffer from the civil war which threatens the United States than our own; for, altogether apart from those feelings of regret with which we must witness the breaking out of strife between persons belonging to the same family as ourselves, and kindred to us in language as well as in blood, our political and material interests are deeply involved in this unhappy schism. That being so, I cannot but believe that Her Majesty's Ministers, feeling upon this question with all Her Majesty's subjects, have already done their utmost, by officious means, to bring about some arrangement by which so dreadful a calamity as that of which I am speaking, may be averted. I therefore wish to ask my noble friend what steps the Government have taken with that object; whether they have made any attempt to prevent the quarrel between the different States of the American Union from coming to a bloody issue; what hopes they entertain of succeeding in so laudable an endeavor, and whether they have invited, or are in correspondence with, any other European Government, with the view of obtaining their assistance in seeking to put a stop at the outset to a civil war, of which, if once fairly commenced, it will be impossible to foresee the end. [Hear, hear]

abstract: Justice STEERS yesterday day committed to prison two boys named WILLIAM JONES and HENRY VELSO, aged 15 and 17 years, to answer a charge of burglary. The young rascals were found, early in the morning, in the store Nos. 14 and 16 Division-street, occupied by EDWARD SCHOFF, they having forced the front basement door to gain admission. They were apprehended by private watchman and officer THOMPSON, who caught them in the act of forcing a door leading to an inner room. On being searched, $12 in change, which they had taken from the money-drawer, was found on them, besides a quantity of burglar's tools. In default of $1,000 bail, they were locked up.

abstract: David O. Nichols vs. the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company. -- The plaintiff in this case on the morning of the 9th of August, 1858, was riding on the seat with the driver of a one horse Sixth-avenue car. He wished to get off, and requested the driver to stop. Accordingly, the horse was checked to a walk, and the plaintiff rote to his feet for the purpose of springing off when the car was at rest. Just then, however, the horse suddenly started, and threw toe plaintiff on the track in front of the car, and under the wheels thertof. The wheel striking him in the loins, he was much bruised and injured internally; and now brought his action for damages. Plaintiff alleges that it was in consequence of the driver's carelessness that he was injured. On the other hand, the defendants deny carelessness and set up that the plaintiff caused the accident by his own negligence, in standing when the car was in motion.

abstract: There are, doubtless, loyal men all over the South, even in South Carolina, who would gladly see their several States return to their allegiance; men who would fight for the Union if there was hope for anything short of their own destruction.
lead_paragraph: There are, doubtless, loyal men all over the South, even in South Carolina, who would gladly see their several States return to their allegiance; -- men who would fight for the Union if there was hope for anything short of their own destruction. They are without arms, without organization, with treason, armed to the teeth and cruel as the tiger of the jungle, rampant all around them. The Press sweeps along with this insane sentiment of revolution, stimulating secession, and cheering on the hunt after every man in whose breast suspicion may whisper that a lingering regard for the national flag remains. A reign of terror, under the dictation of irresponsible committees and lawless mobs, prevails. The Courts are closed against, the habeas corpus suspended, trial by jury, if any such form exists, a mere farce, or rather the middle scenes of a tragedy, the closing tableau of which is judicial murder, the taking of innocent life under the mockery of law. With all these terrible surroundings, what wonder that the voice of loyalty is hushed into silence, and patriotism hides itself from persecution and death.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen divides its attention between the wants of patriotic soldiery, hurrying to fight for the country, and the lobby hungering for any manner of spoils to be had without fighting. We have pointed attention to the surreptitious attempt to enrich its creatures in the Croton Board, while the public was looking another way. An enterprise of the same description was achieved last night. From the Tax-levy, as sent to Albany, a number of items were erased by the Legislature, as appropriations, at once injudicious, corrupt and illegal. The Aldermen, defeated, gave up the fight; and but for an announcement from the Comptroller that $190,000 of the sum raised for the ensuing year was still in his hands without appropriation, it is quite possible that some choice tid-bits of plunder and profit might have escaped the Corporation cormorants. But the idea of money unappropriated, and quite unprotected by Albany legislation, is too much for these legitimate successors of the Forty Thieves. The Comptroller, by his unwise announcement, destroyed the entire morale of the Board. To get at, distribute and extensively share the surplus, was the irresistible instinct of those gentlemen who last night devised and ordained a variety of ingenious taps for the residuary treasure, so that of $190,000 snugly in the public coffers at sunset yesterday, only $40,000 can now be said to be certainly there. The balance is effectively carried to the credit, on bank account, of sundry persons, the confidential and peculiar business friends of the Aldermen.

abstract: At a meeting of this Board, last evening, a com munication was received from the City Inspector, in answer to a resolution of inquiry as to the manner in which Mr. Hackley had performed his contract for cleaning the streets.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of this Board, last evening, a com munication was received from the City Inspector, in answer to a resolution of inquiry as to the manner in which Mr. Hackley had performed his contract for cleaning the streets. The City Inspector says, that in view of the great obstacles which Hackley had to encounter at the commencement of his labors, resulting from unfavorable weather, and the great accumulation of filth in the streets, which, for want of appropriations for that purpose, had not been thoroughly cleaned for a long time; and, furthermore, to disprove the alleged opposition of his Department to the contract system of cleaning the streets, he had extended to Mr. Hackley every facility consistent with a due regard to the interests of the City, for the execution of his contract. He had, therefore, signed conditional certificates for Mr. Hackley, certifying the amount of work done, but in no case had he stated in such certificates that the streets had been thoroughly cleaned. In granting Mr. Hackley this leniency, he says he exercised a discretion which he thought to be for the best interests of the City, being assured by the contractor that, as soon as the preliminary obstacles were removed, he was determined to clean the streets according to the strict terms of his contracts and in a manner that should be perfectly satisfactory to the citizens of New-York. Those obstacles being now removed, he says that he has notified Mr. Hackley that hereafter his work must be done according to the strict terms of the contract. The communication was referred to the Committee on Cleaning the Streets.

abstract: We regret to announce the death of this eminent physician, who for upwards of thirty years has had a large practice in this City. Confined for six months to his room by a singular complication of maladies, he was almost daily attended by Dr. Valentine Mott, Dr. Carnochan, Dr. John O'Reilly and Dr. Brush. His death was the result of tetanus, produced by gangrene, which supervened on the disappearance of dropsy of the lower limbs, caused by enlargement of the heart. A large portion of Dr. REESE's efforts, during several years, have been devoted to the improvement of medical education, and several young physicians of much promise have been his office students. He was successively a Professor in the Castleton and the Albany Medical Colleges, and in the Medical College and Charity Hospital in this City. His voluminous writings are well known in this country and in Europe, and no medical author of this country has enjoyed a larger reputation in Europe. For many years he was a member and a lay preacher in the Methodist Episcopal Church, and as a public speaker he was earnest, lucid and extremely popular. His funeral will take place from his residence tomorrow.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening the opinion of the Corporation Counsel was received, stating that, in his opinion, it was the intention of the Legislature to prevent the increase of salaries of the members of the City Government during the year 1861; also, that under the law the Supervisors had ample power to take the ground in the Park, or any property, either of individuals or of the Common Council, for the purpose of erecting anew City Hall.

abstract: The Government of Washington acts completely within the bounds of prudence as well as right, in making the military preparations which it announces. We are glad it has taken this course. The presence of its 75,000 men, if it can get them together, will have a very desirable effect in deterring the hot spirits of the South from making an attack upon the Federal Capital, if, as seems most probable, such a project has been seriously entertained. They may even be wanted to suppress the civil disorder likely enough to be generated in more than one large town still within the Union by the excited feelings to which the present crisis gives rise. But we have extremely little fear that they are intended to be used for the purpose of taking active measures to reverse Major ANDERSON's defeat, or any other of the humiliations to which the United States have had to submit during the last six months. There is no trace of the popular feeling which would be required to sustain the Lincoln Administration in taking such a step, even if their own inclination pointed in that direction.

abstract: A premature recognition of the Southern Confederation would be a departure from the recognized course of England, and could not but therefore express a political bias in favor of the seceders. Now, is it even decent to ask an English House of Commons to express such a bias in faver of such a Power as that which has its seat of Government at Montgomery -- a Power which is based on Slavery as the very principle of its individual existence, and which, though it professes for the moment to have abolished the Slave-trade, is worked by men, many of whom have openly assailed the laws against that traffic as a gross violation of the rights of the South. The head of the Commission appointed to negotiate with the European Powers for the recognition of the Southern federation, Hon. W.L. YANCEY, of Alabama, has devoted a great portion of his public life to denouncing the obsolete views of WASHINGTON and the other great American statesmen of the last century on this subject. The men and the journalists who chiefly instigated secession were most of them deeply pledged to a repeal of the Slave-trade laws. * * Under these circumstances, we earnestly rejoice to see that Mr. W.E. FORSTER, has given police of an amendment to Mr. GREGORY's motion to the effect that "the House does not at present desire to express any opinion in favor of such recognition, and trusts that the Government will at no time make it without obtaining due security against the renewal of the African Slave trade." Such an amendment will come with the greatest weight from the representative of Bradford, -- a town which, though identified more with the worsted than the cotton trade, still represents fairly the public spirit of our Northern manufacturing interests. The determination of England not to let interested motives interfere with the high principle which she has always shown on the questions of Slavery and the Slave-trade, could not be expressed more fittingly than by the member for Bradford.

abstract: The stupendous uprising of the warlike yeomanry of the Great Northwest far surpasses the calculations of even those most familiar with the vast and gallant hordes which that section is capable of rallying to the field of battle.
lead_paragraph: The stupendous uprising of the warlike yeomanry of the Great Northwest far surpasses the calculations of even those most familiar with the vast and gallant hordes which that section is capable of rallying to the field of battle. The infernal echo of JEFF. DAVIS' cannon, which woke these great Eastern cities from their long dreams of peace, has reverberated over the hills and forests and prairies, till it reached the Rocky Mountains and the Red River of the North; and it has everywhere roused in its course the impetuous men of the Free West to the defence of their menaced rights and liberties. And now the free-hearted, sun-browned chivalry of the prairies, who never acknowledged a master nor cowered before a foe, are everywhere springing to the rifles they love so well, and, with proud, defiant mien, they go forth and demand, in Heaven's name, what these things mean? Every cabin furnishes its man -- every village its company of brawny militia -- till now the number of soldiers ready to march to the defence of the Union and the Constitution would seem to be limited only by the number of citizens capable of wielding rifle or sabre.

abstract: Whatever may have been the case in former times, war springs now less from the caprice of rulers than from the madness of the people. For three months President LINCOLN has threatened war, and now he has declared it. Yet, neither when he was haranguing on his journey from the Far West, nor now that he is apparently about to direct the Militia of the Northern States against the Seceders, does he, as far as we can see, act from the impulses of his own disposition. He has been and is the organ of the Republican Party. He is bound by his official position, and by the pledges through which he attained it, to declare war against seceding slaveowners. So he has called on the States which still own his authority to send their contingents to the Federal Government. But it is plain that this is little more than a formality. The President, by his own authority, could not bring five thousand men into the field. Congress could not, without the help of the State Legislatures, levy troops enough to recover Fort Sumter, or to save Fort Pickens. The Proclamation of President LINCOLN is an appeal to the feelings of the people, which the Chief Magistrate throws out, and wants to see how it is received. We hear of loans, of great activity in the Federal arsenals, of the muster of Federal troops, of the arrival and departure of Federal ships of war and transports; but it is pretty plain, after all, that the war must be carried on, not by the Federal organization, but by popular enthusiasm. The Proclamation demand for 75,000 men, the threat to reoccupy the forts situated on Southern territory are only, as it were, the "platform" on which the Unionists take their stand. The President indorses the opinions of the Northerners, and that is all he can do. If they wish to enforce them they must fight the battle themselves. New-York, and Pennsylvania, and Ohio have each their nominal contingent in the force which has just been demanded; but it remains with them whether they will supply the number required, or half of it, or none at all, or whether, on the contrary, they will rush to arms, and march on a crusade against the enemies of the Stars and Stripes. For the result of the Presidential appeal we must wait a few days. As yet we have but a confused notion of this great call to arms. Whether the President be bent on fighting it out, or merely performs his duty and fulfills his pledge by giving the Union an opportunity of defence, -- whether he operates against the forts or not, -- it is plain that any war which ensues must be carried on by the zeal of the two sections, without much assistaac from the central power of Washington. Like a great feudatory of the olden times rather than a modern ruler, President LINCOLN calls his retainers together for a raid on those who have thrown off his authority. He can do nothing without them; he can do little to help them. He can only open the war, pretty much as our own gracious SOVEREIGN would open an exhibition. He goes through a moral review at Tilbury Fort. Without an army, without constitutional authority to levy one till Congress sits in July, with a big indefensible village for a capital, with one of the two States which inclose Washington hostile, and the other at least dubious, with a large force of Virginia desperadoes ready for an attack on the city, the President has nothing to do but throw himself on the country -- that is, the section of the remaining Union which is attacked to the principles on which he was elected.

abstract: The subscriptions to the $1,000,000 loan authorized by the Common Council have reached $800,000, and the Banks subscribing have guaranteed to make up the whole amount if necessary. There are now quartered in the vicinity of the City from 6,000 to 10,000 troops, ready and anxous to be dispatched to the seat of war. The Union Defence Committee have used every effort to procure the immediate forwarding of these troops, but have been retarded in their efforts by the State authorities, who say that the complement of New-York State is already provided for. It is supposed that further drafts are to be taken from the interior of the State. The Committee is, however, opposed to the disbandment of the troops, and it is understood will succeed in prevailing upon the President to accept them under the general power, irrespective of the call upon the States. There is now in the City a telegraphic dispatch, informing the Committe that the Government needs that these troops should be forwarded without delay. The fund intrusted to the Committee is to be disbursed for the equipment and outfit of regiments, and for the relief of the families of soldiers. Most of the expenditures thus far made have been made under the first head. A sub-committee has, however, been formed, which, in connection with the Aldermen and Councilmen, is now engaged in reporting upon various applications and granting relief. The office for payment of sums granted by these Committees, is at No. 14 Fourth-avenue.

abstract: The new Board of Aldermen, which, according to the Charter, should have been organized one week ago, but which was postponed at the the dictum of the Mayor, on account of the absence of Alderman KEIHL, leaving the Board without a Democratic majority, met last evening, all the members being present and an organization was perfected. Mayor KALBFLEISCH took the Chair, and in violation of all previous practice, kept it until the adjournment, much to the chagrin of the newly-elected President of the Board.
lead_paragraph: The new Board of Aldermen, which, according to the Charter, should have been organized one week ago, but which was postponed at the the dictum of the Mayor, on account of the absence of Alderman KEIHL, leaving the Board without a Democratic majority, met last evening, all the members being present and an organization was perfected. abstract: But the mail arrived yesterday, besides the additional details of the most humane, if not the most satisfactory bombardment on record, brings us the proclamation of President LINCOLN, issued immediately on the receipt of the news that Fort Sumter had fallen, placing the seven seceding. Status beyond the pale of the Union, and calling for a contingent from ...
lead_paragraph: But the mail arrived yesterday, besides the additional details of the most humane, if not the most satisfactory bombardment on record, brings us the proclamation of President LINCOLN, issued immediately on the receipt of the news that Fort Sumter had fallen, placing the seven seceding. Status beyond the pale of the Union, and calling for a contingent from the non-revolting States of 75,000 men, to "suppress combinations and to cause the laws to be duly executed," and convening both Houses of Parliament for the 4th of July next. This proclamation was, it is stated, to have been followed by requisitions to be addressed to the Governors of the various States which still acknowledge the authority of the Federal Government. Pennsylvania and New-York will be asked for quotas of 13,000 men each, Massachusetts for 2,000, Maryland for 3,000, and "the other States in proportion." In estimating the effect of the President's proclamation, formidable as such a step may at first sight appear, we must not be led by reason of the attendant circumstances to regard this step as a direct declaration of war, and a hopeless committal of the Federal Government to hostilities with the South. The American President, when he heard that a collision had occurred between the Southerners and the forces of the Union, could not possibly have remained quiescent. Some action became indispensable if he and his colleagues were not prepared to resign their authority, and the trust it involves, to other hands; and a more harmless mode of proceeding than that of calling for a contingent from the States still within the Union could not have been devised. If we take this apparently energetic levy of 75,000 men in connection with the conduct of Major ANDERSON, and of the officer of the flotilla that witnessed the bombardment of Fort Sumter without firing a shot -- conduct which must, beyond question, have been prompted, or, at all events, acquiesced in by the Cabinet at Washington -- we shall be disposed to regard the proclamation and bombardment as about equally warlike. There is no doubt, however, that affairs are in a most critical position, and that a want of judgment now may precipitate a civil war. The passions of the South are roused, and it will require great management to prevent them breaking out into acts of violence, and bringing with them the Border States, who have been content, so far, to adopt an attitude of neutrality. It is difficult to see how, with any contingent he may raise, President LINCOLN can assume the aggressive, and carry the war into the Secessionists,' country, in order to suppress that combination which he says is no longer within the reach of "judicial proceedings, or the powers vested in the marshals by law." The North will find the necessary contingent, notwithstanding the rejection of the enrolment on the part of Kentucky; but Mr. LINCOLN, we may rest assured, does not contemplate marching an army into the Southern States, even if such a movement were practicable, which every one acquainted with the States knows it is not. The fleet of the Union is, it is true, in the hands of the Federal Government, but the approaches to Charleston, Mobile, and New-Orleans are too well defended to render an attack on any of those places a wise measure. Moreover, it must not be forgotten that the Southern interest has for the past eight years borne almost undisputed sway at Washington. During that period, we may be quite sure, every vacancy in the fleet has been filled up with officers whose sentiments are well understood. Who is to say, therefore, that the fleet would, if called upon, act against the Southerners? And the finding of officers to supersede those in command would, we may be sure, be no easy matter. Looking, therefore, at the state of affairs in America closely, and calmly considering, on the one hand, the reluctance of the Federal Government to engage in hostilities, and the great difficulty in the way of rendering any armed movement against the South effective by sea or by land; and on the other, the whole character of the movement amongst the Southerners, whose objects are really to be gained by negotiation, not by violence, we cannot come to the conclusion that either party has drawn the sword with the determinatin to throw away the scabbard. The contingent about to be raised will probably be employed in rendering Washington perfectly secure against attack, and when that security has been accomplished, we shall probably find that the Federal Government will pause before another step is taken in the direction of repression by force of arms.

abstract: In times like these, trustworthy information about the enemy can only be collected by comparing many individual statements from travelers and others experienced. We are convinced that the great danger of the party upholding the Government is in undervaluing the resources of the enemy. To avoid this it...
lead_paragraph: In times like these, trustworthy information about the enemy can only be collected by comparing many individual statements from travelers and others experienced. We are convinced that the great danger of the party upholding the Government is in undervaluing the resources of the enemy. To avoid this it becomes the duty of the Press to make known the views of individuals who have been residents in the South; and though they may not be accepted as entirely reliable, the public can derive from them many data for forming a correct conclusion.

abstract: THE NEWSBOYS' CONCERT. The Newsboys' Lodging house, being in want of funds, and we would remind our readers that this is really one of the most benevolent institutions of the City, a concert by the boys themselves was given last night, at the Central Presbyterian Church, corner of Elm and Broome streets. The pulpit was draped with the American flag.
lead_paragraph: THE NEWSBOYS' CONCERT. -- The Newsboys' Lodging house, being in want of funds, and we would remind our readers that this is really one of the most benevolent institutions of the City, a concert by the boys themselves was given last night, at the Central Presbyterian Church, corner of Elm and Broome streets. The pulpit was draped with the American flag. The boys, to about the number of 150, some of them ragged, and many of them barefooted, entered the Church in procession, each one carrying a diminutive copy of the Stars and Stripes. The audience was large, nearly filling the Church. Mr. T.M. HEWITT presided. Dr. J. QUINCY ADAMS read a portion of Scripture, and Rev. Dr. MURRAY prayed. Addresses appropriate to the occasion, occasionally serious, but mostly replete with such humor as was calculated to attract the attention of the boys, were made by JOSEPH HOXIE, Esq., Rev. J.Q. ADAMS, and Rev. Mr. PARKER. Several hymns were sung by the boys in a very creditable manner. The "Star-Spangled Banner" was quite a feature of the concert, the audience rising, and the boys joining in the chorus with a hearty will. A collection whs taken up, over $25 being subscribed. The Newsboys' Lodging-house is a most deserving charity, and, being in want of assistance, commends isself warmly to the liberality of our citizens.

abstract: The Convention of representatives from the Northwestern Counties of Virginia effected an organization at Wheeling yesterday, most of the Counties to which invitations were addressed, having delegates in attendance, and participating sympathetically in the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The Convention of representatives from the Northwestern Counties of Virginia effected an organization at Wheeling yesterday, most of the Counties to which invitations were addressed, having delegates in attendance, and participating sympathetically in the proceedings. It may be desirable to mark distinctly the lines the Convention proposes to include in its contemplated secession. Reaching from the Ohio and the Pennsylvania line on the north to the New River, Kanawha and Greenbrier, on the south, its eastern boundary is the Alleghany Mountains, and on the west, the line of Kentucky. The map thus laid out embraces the following Counties, which we enumerate with the total and the enslaved inhabitatns distinguished, as given by the Census of 1850. It is unnecessary, perhaps, to say, that the census of last year will show a very serious decline in the servile population. We may add, that Pleasants and Upshur Counties, set off since 1850, are omitted from the tables:

abstract: Jacob Sharp vs. Wm. W. Wright and James McDonald. -- This case has before been stated in the TIMES. The suit was brought to compel the repayment by Wright & McDonald to the plaintiff of $1,500, paid by him to them, and the cancelation of nine promissory notes made by him, and transferred to them, and for an injunction against their disposing of the notes. McDonald & Wright were the lowest bidders for the contract of building the Albany bridge; Sharp was the next lowest bidder.

abstract: A person employed in the special service visited Harper's Ferry, last week, and reached Chambersburgh to-day. He reports that the troops concentrated at that post number 6,000 altogether, about three-fourths of them armed. Most of these are well armed, but the balance are not armed at all. Only two hundred Kentuckians are there now, and one Company of South Carolinians.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURGH, Monday, May 13.

abstract: The Great Eastern yesterday weighed anchor and drifted to a position further up the North River, and near her former position opposite Hammond-street. It is brobable that she will be coated while lying in the stream, and prepared for her next trip without coming to the dock. The pilot who brought the Great Eastern into port was Mr. JAMES BRITTON, of the Edmund Blunt, No. 2, and not Mr. MURPHY, as heretofore stated. It is probable that she will be opened to the public before her departure.

abstract: The Southern people affect, and perhaps feel the utmost contempt of the military spirit and qualities of the North. This is the natural sentiment of a barbarous toward a highly civilized people.
lead_paragraph: The Southern people affect, and perhaps feel the utmost contempt of the military spirit and qualities of the North. This is the natural sentiment of a barbarous toward a highly civilized people. The South see the vast industries of the North, and believe the latter to be completely emasculated by their pacific pursuits, forgetting that their vast acquisitions are so many additional inducements for fighting in their defence, whenever their safety is imperiled. The South entertain towards the North the same sentiments that the Mexicans did toward the United States, and the Chinese toward England and France, previous to the lessons these barbarians have lately received. But all history tells that the higher the civilization of a people, the greater their military prowess. Knowledge is power. Roman intelligence conquered all the barbarous races that came in its way, despite the desperate courage and physical energy which characterized them. English civilization has carried its resistless march over a large portion of the globe; and in the same way and by a necessary law, is the civilization of the North to supplant, by its superior vigor and life, the semi barbarous civilization of the South. Northern civilization has a hundred steamships engaged in the transmission of troops and in blockading Southern ports. This fact is conclusive of the whole contest, for the mixed civilization of the South cannot, unaided, put afloat a single one of these terrible engines of war.

abstract: We are informed upon the best, most unnameable authority, that all this uproar is caused by the Belzebub of the Tulleries. Louisiana, Florida, Mississippi were all French possessions once. The French owned the half of St. Domingo, and many of the little fragments of a submerged continent which peep up above the waters, as the Antilles, were French. The Emperor has an idea -- it is to revendiquer frontiers. The inference is easy. He has set the Spaniards at St. Domingo and the Americans by the ears, that by and-bye he may step in as a benevolent mediator to stop the effusion of blood, and to quarter the palmetto of Carolina with the lilies of France. Quantities of rifled cannon and shells are sent to New-Orleans and Pensacola in French bottoms; but LOUIS NAPOLEON is a great manufacturer of artillery, and has always a store from whence to lend a friend. He cannot be blamed, for Virginia herself is casting cannon by night and day, and it is a toss up whether they are told to Northerners or Southerners. It is quite true that the French are making vast preparations in the naval department, but the American navy could all be be split into matches by La Gloire alone. The Emperor doubtless watches events, and as surely will "consult the interests of France" hereafter; but he has other objects nearer home at present, and the voyage to the Gulf of Mexico would exhaust all the coal his steamships can carry.
