abstract: Mr. GLADSTONE is not, of course, to blame that the dull American fure seems at length to be fast burning down to the powder; but he and the Government will incur a grave responsibility if, in the now altered state of the relations between this country and the United States, the Budget is proceeded with in its present form.
lead_paragraph: Mr. GLADSTONE is not, of course, to blame that the dull American fuse seems at length to be fast burning down to the powder; but he and the Government will incur a grave responsibility if, in the now altered state of the relations between this country and the United States, the Budget is proceeded with in its present form. Twice have we and the American people engaged in mortal conflict, and we may does, again before many weeks are over. And were such a war unhappily to arise, we ask our readers whether at the moment a real and not an imaginary surplus could be safely parted with? What would our nearest neighbor do were our hands to be filled unexpectedly with a gigantic war? Were our own shores not assailed, the fifteen French iron-cased ships which Lord CLARENCE PAGET says can be at sea in the course of the present Summer, would command the Channel, and the Continent be at once the prey of revolution. France has been for some time waiting an opportunity to employ its vast military and naval power, and what better occasion could present itself than when this country has to choose between submitting patiently to the bitter consequences of Whig folly and demanding cotton with the sword.

abstract: We cannot expect our neighbors to regard our misfortunes with a very sympathetic eye. Perhaps the most that a philosophic spirit can demand, is that they should not rejoice at our calamities. Still there are peculiar cirumstances that call from every generous.
lead_paragraph: We cannot expect our neighbors to regard our misfortunes with a very sympathetic eye. Perhaps the most that a philosophic spirit can demand, is that they should not rejoice at our calamities. Still there are peculiar cirumstances that call from every generous-minded man, and from every nation with any degree of sound public opinion, a certain noble sympathy. If, for instance, the American people, with all their supposed greed for money, and their sharp eye for a bargain, should hear of a dire struggle over the Atlantic among their kinsmen, wherein the objects professed on the one side, were law and the existence of an organized Government, and, on the other, anarchy and disorder, and where the results were to be on one side the unlimited extension of a debasing tyranny, and on the other the possible destruction of it, and their sympathies should go up and down the scale, according to their chances for trade, we, in our unsophisticated way, would call our public opinion base and selfish. We should say that our population bad no conception of a noble cause. We should conclude that the "eanker of gold" had eaten out our manhood. Still more should we lash our own baseness and hypocrisy, if for years we had been preaching about human liberty, and had pharisaically blessed ourselves that we were not as our kinsmen were, and now, when their grand effort, with untold pains, was being made to free themselves from their evils, we should look coolly on, and only speculate where we could make the most per cent.
headline: {'main': "The Englishman's Sympathies.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Englishman's Sympathies.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of Saturday last, you again urge the propriety of striking from the Stock List of the Board of Brokers the securities of seceding and seceded States, and go even so far as to call on the District Attorney to interfere, inasmuch as, according to your intimation, the cupidity of the members of that body overrules their patriotism.

abstract: The blockade of Southern ports necessarily raises a question of first-rate importance already attracting great attention in England whether cotton is to be exempted; and if not, whether it is to be allowed to be sent to market through the interior routes of communication, and through the free Northern ports.
lead_paragraph: The blockade of Southern ports necessarily raises a question of first-rate importance -- already attracting great attention in England -- whether cotton is to be exempted; and if not, whether it is to be allowed to be sent to market through the interior routes of communication, and through the free Northern ports. The attention of our Government, has already been called to this matter, and the answer indicates that the blockade is to apply to every kind of Southern produce. At the mouth of James River, where the blockade is now rigidly enforced, a considerable quantity of cotton has already been seized and held, showing that the instructions of Government include that as well as all other articles.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The admirers of fun and its best interpreters, Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON, should not neglect the two latest revivals at Mr. JACKSON's establishment -- "Mezeppa" and "Sketches in India." These Summer trifles, without in the slighest degree overtaxing the powers of the artists or the audience, supply an evening's entertainment of the heartiest kind. Mr. JEPFRESON, who has always been admirable in "Mazeppa," has added some new traits to the individuality of that unfortunate hero. It is now one of the most mirth-provoking efforts that can be witnessed anywhere. The houses are, of course, crowded.

abstract: No demonstration has yet been made on the part of the Government, indicative of the course which it intends to pursue. It is still engaged in strengthening its hands for the contest, and it is thought in some quarters that it will continue to do so, until the certainty of success cannot be questioned. It is believed that delay will be advantageous to the Government, while it will prove the contrary to its enemies.

abstract: In times like these, the agriculturist who allows an acre of his land to remain uncultivated, is lacking in patriotism as well as in duty to his family and himself. We must have an army to defend the country and uphold the Union in its integrity, and it must be fed and clothed. Soldiers can no more fight without eating than they can live without air.
lead_paragraph: In times like these, the agriculturist who allows an acre of his land to remain uncultivated, is lacking in patriotism as well as in duty to his family and himself. We must have an army to defend the country and uphold the Union in its integrity, and it must be fed and clothed. Soldiers can no more fight without eating than they can live without air. There will be during the current year hundreds of thousands of people, turned from the ordinary pursuits of peace in the Northern States alone, who must be provided for in addition to the ordinary supplies of the country.

abstract: No one doubts the patriotism of our Common Council, but it is getting, we fear, to be of that cheap sort which is at somebody else's expense. They have already voted a ...
lead_paragraph: No one doubts the patriotism of our Common Council, -- but it is getting, we fear, to be of that cheap sort which is at somebody else's expense. They have already voted a million of dollars to aid in fitting out volunteer regiments, which was a noble and a proper donation to a just cause. Next they resolved to continue the salary of every person in the employ of the City, who might volunteer, -- which was, perhaps, well enough under the circumstances.

abstract: PRISONERS PUNISHED--OFFICERS CENSURED. In this Court, yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Mr. Garvin, prosecuting for the people, David Sterling and Charles Tucker were placed at the bar. They had been convicted the day before, Sterling of a felonious assault, and Tucker of a simple assault. The former was sent to State Prison for two years, and the latter to the City Prison for thirty days.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. At the meeting of the Board, held yesterday, President STEWART in the Chair, a communication was received and read from the Board of Police Commissioners, in answer to a resolution of inquiry, stating that there was no existing necessity for the permanent increase of the Police force in the City.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- At the meeting of the Board, held yesterday, President STEWART in the Chair, a communication was received and read from the Board of Police Commissioners, in answer to a resolution of inquiry, stating that there was no existing necessity for the permanent increase of the Police force in the City. The property and lives of the citizens were believed to be perfectly secure under the protection of the present force. A communication was received from the Comptroller, stating that, is would be necessary, in order to pay additional salaries to Clerks of the Superior Court and the Court of Common Pleas, to transfer the amount of $2,250 from the account of "County Contingencies" to the account of "Salaries." A resolution, directing the transfer to be made, was adopted. After transacting some further business of minor importance, the Board adjourned till Tuesday next.

abstract: Rudolph Bloomingberg was put on trial for the third time for perjury, the jury having failed to agree on the two former trials. The perjury is alleged to have been committed in his justification as a surety on the bonding of the slaver Orion. The account for which he went surety was $7,500, and on examination, he testified to owning a five story house in Eighteenth street, besides other property, but when judgment was entered against him, no property could be found. The testimony does not vary materially from that given on the former trials, except by proving further indebtedness, judgments and executions against the defendant.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph Bloomingberg was put on trial for the third time for perjury, the jury having failed to agree on the two former trials. abstract: Speaking of the apparent toughness of these men as they embarked on Saturday, for Fort Monroe, an officer illustrated it by relating the performances of one of the men in the Burlington company. This man was sawing logs under a contract, in Jericho, when he determined to volunteer, and was obliged to find a man to take his place; whereupon, by sawing all night, he got a free day, in which he rode twenty miles on horseback, to engage his substitute; returned in the afternoon and evening, at 11 P.M. Started the saw again; sawed all that night, without stopping. In the morning, he walked three miles to take he train for Burlington; enlisted, drilled three hours, and the train back; sawed all that night and next day, and appeared in the ranks at Burlington, as fresh as any one, although he had worked three days and three nights without rest or sleep.
lead_paragraph: Speaking of the apparent toughness of these men as they embarked on Saturday, for Fort Monroe, an officer illustrated it by relating the performances of one of the men in the Burlington company. abstract: President LINCOLN is now free to act, and it may be worth our while to examine the means by which he proposes to coerce the seceded States back into the Union. Judging by his declaration to the Virginia ...
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN is now free to act, and it may be worth our while to examine the means by which he proposes to coerce the seceded States back into the Union. Judging by his declaration to the Virginia Commissioners, and his proclamation of war against the South, we are led to conclude that coercion will in no sense be invasion. The President designs merely to occupy and possess the property which belongs to the Federal Government, and few will dispute his right so to do, even though such occupation should entail civil war. This avowal gives us the clue to Mr. LINCOLN's policy, when taken in connection with the fact that every Southern port is to be blockaded, and the mails stopped to seceded States. It is not proposed to enter the States composing the Southern Confederation, but merely to regain the property which belongs, and always has belonged to the Federal Government. This is precisely what the South most desires to avoid, for of Mr. LINCOLN can retake and hold the Balize forts at the mouth of the Mississippi and the defences of Pensacola, Savannah, and Charleston, Southern independence will become impossible and the seceders be compelled to return to their allegiance. There is no community in the civilized world more dependent upon other nations than this newly-formed Republic; for the very necessaries of life are brought from the Free States, and every manufactured article is also imported. Cotton is the life-blood of the Confederation and of the citizens themselves, for cotton furnishes the wherewithal to carry on the Government and the means to supply the wants of the planners and their slaves. Unless the fibre be exported, and goods and provisions received in exchange, the whole community must starve; and Mr. Lincoln designs to put the seceders into this position, so as to compel submission. Whether he has the power to effect his purpose we need scarcely stop to examine, but he can, at all events, keep up such a state of alarm upon the Southern coast as will vitally affect commerce if it do not annihilate it. The Government of Montgomery evidently fears this result, but, as the Southern Confederation does not possess a navy, it is difficult to tell how that result can be obvisted.

abstract: The steam transport Chesapeake, which was to have railed Monday evening for Washington City after taking in part of cargo, had her orders countermanded, and will probably sail Saturday for Pensacola. Her cargo will be transferred to steamer Geo. Peabody, Capt. PRITCHARD, lying at Pier No. 12, N.R. It con-consists of 3,500 bbls. provisions, and 25 head of cattle. A portion will be landed at Old Point, the balance at Washington City.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The admirers Of fun and its best interpreters, Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON, should not neglect the two latest revivals at Mr. JACKSON's establishment " Mezeppa" and ...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The admirers of fun and its best interpreters, Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON, should not neglect the two latest revivals at Mr. JACKSON's establishment -- "Mezeppa" and "Sketches in India," These Summer trifles, without in the slightest degree overtaxing the powers of the artists on the audience, supply an evening's entertainment of the heartiest kind. Mr. JEFFERSON, who has always been admirable in "Mazeppa," has aided some new traits to the individuality of that unfortunate hero. It is now one of the most mirth-provoking efforts that can be witnessed anywhere. The houses are, of course, crowded.

abstract: The readers of the TIMES will recollect the case of RUDOLPH BLOOMINGBERG, indicted in this district for perjury in connection with the Slave-trade. The accused was arrested last winter, at the instance of the late United States District Attorney, Judge ROOSEVELT.
lead_paragraph: The readers of the TIMES will recollect the case of RUDOLPH BLOOMINGBERG, indicted in this district for perjury in connection with the Slave-trade. The accused was arrested last winter, at the instance of the late United States District Attorney, Judge ROOSEVELT. He was twice tried, the Jury on each occasion failing to agree. Mr. E. DELAFIELD SMITH, the present United States District Attorney, has taken hold of the case with an energy which has resulted in the conviction of the offender.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A grand military festival, by the First German Rifle Regiment, will take place here to-night. The proceeds are to be devoted to the families of the regiment, and it is to be hoped that quite a comfortable little sum will be raised by the entertainment. The occasion is peculiarly interesting, and fully in accordance with the spirit of the day. Beside a fine programme of vocal and instrumental music, there will be a presentation of colors to the regiment by a Committee of ladies, and a grand parade of all its members, headed by their military band.

abstract: We have insisted from the beginning of the wicked and baseless rebellion which now agitates the country, that the question of Slavery had nothing to do with it, and that the object of this great uprising of the loyal people was not to interfere with Slavery, but to sustain the Government and Constitution of the United States.
lead_paragraph: We have insisted from the beginning of the wicked and baseless rebellion which now agitates the country, that the question of Slavery had nothing to do with it, and that the object of this great uprising of the loyal people was -- not to interfere with Slavery, but to sustain the Government and Constitution of the United States. We have been confirmed in this position by everything said or done by the Government in this connection. In his first Proclamation President LINCOLN declared that, in the prosecution of the measures for the suppression of the rebellion, there would be no interference with the rights of property. Gov. BUTLER, at the very outset, returned to their master fugitive slaves who had fled to him for protection. We believe the general sentiment of the people commends this position of the Government.

abstract: The Annual Session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church commenced at Dr. MCLEOD's Church, in Twelfth-street in this City, last evening. A number of delegations was present from various portions of the country, but, owing to the war excitement, the attendance was rather slim. The Presbyterians have heretofore, by a conservative course, kept in a measure aloof from the disorganizing effects of the Slavery agitation, but it is expected that the present crisis will cause some definite policy with reference to the present condition of the country. The business of last evening was purely the delivery of the opening sermon. This morning the business of the Synod will be commenced, and will occupy probably the time consumed at the last the session of the Synod in this City, (some six years since,) when it continued its sittings one week.
lead_paragraph: The Annual Session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church commenced at Dr. MCLEOD's Church, in Twelfth-street in this City, last evening. abstract: ANOTHER WARNING. A terrible accident, resulting in a probable loss of life, occurred last night, at about 11 o'clock, at No. 742 Broadway.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER WARNING. -- A terrible accident, resulting in a probable loss of life, occurred last night, at about 11 o'clock, at No. 742 Broadway. WILHELMINA BLIGH, a German girl, employed as nurse in the family of Mr. GREEN, was filling a fluid lamp, when it exploded, scattering the flames over her person, and burning her so severely, that she cannot possibly survive. The lamp was blown into fragments. Her clothes were burnt completely from her body, and a child, which was in her arms at the time, was also severely burned, but not fatally. When found, she was lying at the foot of a narrow staircase, in a smouldering heap; the doorway against which she lay, was ignited, but prompt assistance extinguished the flames. The house was dark, and as some difficulty was experienced in procuring a light, her clothes were completely burned from her body before any material assistance could be rendered. Dr. GARDNER, who was fortunately near at the time, rendered professional aid and alleviated the sufferings as far as was possible with the scanty materials at hand. She was conveyed as soon as possible to the Hospital. The alarm of fire was given, and engines were promptly on the spot, but their services were not required. This sad accident adds another to the many warnings against the use of explosive fluids. Let every family, that has one of these explosive engines in use, throw it out of doors at once, and adopt some safer mode of illumination.

abstract: Theodore W. Riley vs. The ship, Obed Mitchell and Thomas W. Napier, claimant -- This was a libel to recover tee amount of a bottomry bond for $6,859 37 executed by Francis Smith, the master of the ship, Lima, in Peru, on the 21st of May, 1851 to Alsop & Co. of that place. The libelant sued as the assignee of Alsop & Co. The bond was payable at or before the expiration of twenty days after the arrival of the ship in the United States. She arrived at New-York Dec. 28, 1851, and the libel in this cause was filed on the 20th January, 1852.

lead_paragraph: We do not suppose there is a single member of the Administration who does not believe that in Maryland, left to herself, secession and anarchy would have been as triumphat to-day, as it is in Eastern Virginia or North Carolina. The same formidable conspiracy that has successively overmastered so many States, swept irresistibly over this, instantly instituting a reign of terror: and numbering in its support the City police and officers of Government, for a time held the whole people spell-bound in a paroxysm of fear. An assassin, or madman in arms, puts a whole village to flight.

abstract: Destiny is slowly but surely involving the "South" in the calamities her madness and folly have invoked. The blockade by sea is creeping from harbor to harbor along her coasts, while the armies of the Government are hemming her in landward. Her comerce is cut off from the ocean, and her trade ...
lead_paragraph: Destiny is slowly but surely involving the "South" in the calamities her madness and folly have invoked. The blockade by sea is creeping from harbor to harbor along her coasts, while the armies of the Government are hemming her in landward. Her comerce is cut off from the ocean, and her trade is stopped with the interior. Repudiation has ruined her credit, and her exchequer is empty of coin. Her commercial men are driven into bankruptcy, and insolvency is going the rounds of her trades-people. Forced loans have lost their efficacy, and the means of furnishing food and clothing for her army are becoming more and more precarious. With a scarcity of provisions at home, and her sources of supply from abroad cut off, her cry will soon be for bread.

abstract: We have received from Officer ROBB, of the Fourth Ward Police, a reply to Judge MCCUNN's denunciation of him on Tuesday, while sentencing STERLING for having shot at the officer with intent to kill him. The Judge denounced the officer for having called STERLING a thief, and ordering him away from the premises. Officer ROBB says in reply, that he knew STERLING to be a thief, and one of the most desperate ruflians in the City. He says he did nothing more than was absolutely necessary to drive him away, and that Judge MCCUNN has not the slightest shadow of justice for his remarks.
lead_paragraph: We have received from Officer ROBB, of the Fourth Ward Police, a reply to Judge MCCUNN's denunciation of him on Tuesday, while sentencing STERLING for having shot at the officer with intent to kill him. abstract: We have intelligence from Washington this morning which will gratify the numerous regiments in this City and Brooklyn, which have been organized, but which have, through the dilatory action of the State Military Board, begun to despair of ever being called into service. A delegation from the Union Defence Committee of this City, consisting of Messrs. DRAPER, BLATCHFORD, ...
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence from Washington this morning which will gratify the numerous regiments in this City and Brooklyn, which have been organized, but which have, through the dilatory action of the State Military Board, begun to despair of ever being called into service. A delegation from the Union Defence Committee of this City, consisting of Messrs. DRAPER, BLATCHFORD, SLOAN, ASTOR, LOW, MCCURDY, RICHARDS and RUSSELL, visited Washington yesterday, and through their intercession and influence the President, with the consent of the Secretary of War and Gen. SCOTT, has concluded to call into immediate service fourteen regiments, which comprise all organized in this immediate vicinity, without the necessity of their going through the tedious formalities of the circumlocution office at Albany. This will, of course, include the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, and several others which have for some time been kept in tantalizing suspense. Another good service which the delegation did yesterday was to visit the quarters of the various New-York Regiments quartered at and near Washington, and ascertain their wants, which, will promptly be attended to. It is understood that the new quota of troops will be about equally divided between the Capital and Fortress Monroe. No new movements of importance have been made by the Government forces at the Capital, and nothing further is reported of the secession forces across the Potomac.

abstract: "G.B. LAMAR, Esq., President of the Bank of the Republic, of New-York, and for many years a resident of that City, lately resigned that office. Soon after resignation he was waited on by a Committee of the citizens, and ordered to leave the City by a specified short time. It was Mr. LAMAR's desire and intention to leave the City, and his resignation was with reference to this, but the critical illness of his wife -- a fact that must have been known to some of the mob -- prevented an early removal. He informed the mob Committee that he could not and would not leave at their orders, and here the matter rested at our last accounts. What a commentary on free speech, free action and the abuse which has been lavished on the South by Pharisaic New-York!"

abstract: It will be seen by an advertisement in another column, that H.W. DERBY offers an immense collection of valuable books for sale, at prices very far below anything ever known in this City before. He has taken for the purpose the first floor of his beautiful Art Institute building, at No. 625 Broadway. A more spacious and stable store in which to stall books could not well be devised. Two hundred feet in length, and extending from Broadway to Mercer-street, without a single column to obstruct the view or impede pedestrianism, the first thought it inspires in these days of military enthusiasm is, "What a magnificent room for a drill." And this thought is rather heightened than dissipated by seeing a whole "quarter section" of the store occupied by HARDER's Military Tactics. Regiments of books in uniforms of plain cloth, of purple, of starlet and of glittering gold, stand in solid column along the line of shelves, presenting, by that martial etiquette which takes the place of civil courtesy, their backs to their friends, their faces to their fees, the blind walls. With closed ranks and firm lines they stand like NAPOLEON's Old Guard, -- more ready, however, to receive a charge than to repel one.

abstract: William Clarke vs. Charles A. Meigs and others. The complaint alleged that the defendants as stockbrokers, purchased, on account of the plaintiff, and by his order, two hundred shares of the stock of the Illinois Central Railroad Company, in November last, for the price of sixty one cects on a dollar of the par value of the stock; that said stock was payable and deliverable to the plaintiff at his option at any time ...
lead_paragraph: William Clarke vs. Charles A. Meigs and others. The complaint alleged that the defendants as stockbrokers, purchased, on account of the plaintiff, and by his order, two hundred shares of the stock of the Illinois Central Railroad Company, in November last, for the price of sixty one cects on a dollar of the par value of the stock; that said stock was payable and deliverable to the plaintiff at his option at any time within sixty days; that the defendants, in violation of their agreement and duly as brokers, and against the express instruction of the plaintiff, sold the stock four days after, for the price of fifty-two cents on the dollar; that the price of said stock on the fourteenth day of January last had risen to seventy-seven and a half per cent.; that the plaintiff has, therefore, suffered $5,000 damages for which he claims judgment.

abstract: The Union feeling is everywhere on the increase, and secession is running rapidly to decay. The Executive and Legislative departments of the Government were in the hands of the Disunionists. There, as in many of the States, the politicians and political adventurers were for dissolution, and would, if they had had the power, have hurried the State into rebellion. But the people were against them, and aided by the patriotic volunteers of St. Louis, and the Federal troops under the gallant HARNEY, have triumphed over them. Gen. HARNEY has declared kindly but firmly to the authorities of Missouri, his determination to maintain the power of the Federal Constitution, and they know right well that he is not a man to be trifled with. He is sustained by the people of the City and the State. The bluster of the Disunionists has ceased, and patriotism is paramount again in Missouri.

abstract: -- The Richmond Examiner is very savage over the supinenesss of the Virginia Government. It charges it with having done nothing at all towards fitting out privateers -- while PENDERGRAST is seizing vessels constantly. Its Parismouth correspondence says that up to the 8th, he had "captured twenty-five vessels, but only one of this number deserves the name of prize. That is reported to be a Richmond ship from some of the South American ports, ladened with 3,000 bags of coffee." We hope he will keep on dong so.

abstract: On Tuesday there was a trotting match for $2,000 on the Union Course, Long Island, between the br. g. Batavia Colt, entered by D. TALLMAN, and br. g. Bagged Sailor, entered by the owner. The distance trotted was 24 miles, and the time was 1 hour, 30 minutes and 55 seconds. The match was won by the Batavia Colt. There was a large number of persons present, and from the start the winner had the call, at $100 to $50. It is said to be the first 24 mile trot on record.

abstract: Valentine Lutz, and Wife, Respondent, vs. Frederick R. Meyer, Appellant. -- This is an appeal from a judgment of Special Term on the verdict of a jury in favor of the plaintiffs, and from an order of the Special Term denying the defendant's motion for a new trial on a case and exceptions. The cause was tried at the New-York Circuit before Judge Mullan and a jury in November, 1858, and was brought by the plaintiffs, as husband and wife, against the defendant, as master of the [???] Yorktown, to recover damages for injuries to the wife, occasioned by a plank falling upon her, on the passage from London to New-York, in September, 1864. It is alleged that the plank fell from the roof of a house upon deck, inclosing the passengers' galleys and the ships' galleys. On the trial, the jury gave the plaintiff $500 damages. This appeal is taken wholly upon exceptions taken on the trial of the cause, and are all strictly of a technical nature. Decision re served.

abstract: -- JAMES MARTIN was placed on trial at the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, for the murder of his own child on the 12th of January last, on Bergen, near Powers-street. The fact of the killing is not denied, but the defence is, that the prisoner has always borne a good character, and has been subject to fits of insanity; and, during one of these turns, he cut his child's throat. The testimony in the case was concluded yesterday; and the case will be submitted to the jury this morning.

abstract: Horace J. Fairchild et al vs. George W. Warren et al -- An argument made at the maturity of a note, between the maker and holder, that upon payment of part of the note and an agreement to pay the residue with interest, four months thereafter, to extend the time of payment of such residue for four months, and payment and acceptance of the portion, is not sufficient consideration to render the agreement to extend the time of payment obligatory. The holder of the note obtains nothing to which he was not entitled, and the maker parts with nothing that he had a right to withhold. Motion granted with $10 costs.

abstract: The trial of Rudolph Bloomingberg for perjury was concluded to-day. Judge NELSON, in charging the jury, though he left it entirely with them to say whether the accused swore falsely, commented strongly on the failure of the defence to give clear and positive proof as to the value of the goods claimed by him to be in store, or those in bond, or to explain at all how the accused came to be connected with the claimants of the Orion and her cargo, which were condemned and forfeited for being engaged in the Slave-trade.

abstract: The Government is about sending to Europe a Naval Officer to report on the most improved model of naval ship building, with a view to commence the construction of the new steam sloops-of-war after it. One of the attaches of the Brooklyn Navy-yard had been detailed for the duty, but the exigences of the home service necessitated his presence here for a time. It is not settled whether the new men-of-war shall be of wool or iron, or iron plated.

abstract: After a perilous journey of eight days from Richmond, I have arrived in this City, having left behind me everything except the clothing I happened to have upon my person at the time of my escape. abstract: Soon after his celebrated sparring tour, JOHN C. HEENAN received a very tempting offer to connect himself with a money-making establishment in New-Orleans, which he accepted, and went to that city toreside. He had not been there long, however, before the secession fever ran high among the people, and companies were formed to fight against the Government. When JEFFERSON DAVIS was made President of the so-called Confederate States of America, HEENAN received an offer of a high position in the rebel army, provided he would fight against the Government of the United States. He refused the position tendered, and declared that he had fought under the Stars and Stripes a year ago, and never would fight under any other flag. This offended the rebels, and his position there becoming very unpleasant, he left, and is now in Cincinnati. He is expected here early in June.

abstract: The repudiation of Southern securities, which is rendered almost inevitable by secession, is among the evils from which, whatever may be the result of their insane war, the Southern States will never recover. For a State or nation to think of occupying a respectable position in the popular opinion of the world, that refuses, whether from necessity or organic knavery, to pay its honest debts, is one of the absurdities of the Southern brain. Bankruptcy, from whatever cause, is one of the sins that nations neither forget nor forgive. They will admit of no explanation or excuse. Payment is what they demand, and that alone will command their respect -- that only will vindicate faith or preserve honor.
lead_paragraph: The repudiation of Southern securities, which is rendered almost inevitable by secession, is among the evils from which, whatever may be the result of their insane war, the Southern States will never recover. abstract: Only a few years back, the European Powers assembled at Paris, at the close of an European war, and moved, by a common desire, to adjust the laws of war to the circumstances of a world much changed by the growth of commerce, laid down, and mutually bound themselves to abide by, five rules of maritime warfare. The most remarkable of the changes thus effected amounted to no more than a solemn recognition of the principle, that "a free bottom makes free goods" -- the very principle to maintain which the United States went to war with Great Britain in 1812. So far, what was proposed was a concession to the demands of the great commercial and non-military Republic. But, tacked to this, was a condemnation of, and an agreement to renounce, the practice of privateering. And when the European programme reached Washington, it was on this ground rejected. The States, we were assured, could not dispense with the right to issue letters of-marque to private adventurers, authorizing them to "burn, sink, and destroy" -- and plunder -- the shipping of any Power with which they might be at war, seeing that otherwise, not having, and not choosing to maintain, a powerful navy, they would be incapable of injuring their enemy at sea. The other available use of a navy -- that of protecting their commerce -- privateers could not supply. They are simply destructive, and can neither convoy a fleet of merchantmen nor guard the entrance to a port. And for this purely destructive purpose -- and avowedly for this purpose -- the States would retain the right.
lead_paragraph: Only a few years back, the European Powers assembled at Paris, at the close of an European war, and moved, by a common desire, to adjust the laws of war to the circumstances of a world much changed by the growth of commerce, laid down, and mutually bound themselves to abide by, five rules of maritime warfare. The most remarkable of the changes thus effected amounted to no more than a solemn recognition of the principle, that "a free bottom makes free goods" -- the very principle to maintain which the United States went to war with Great Britain in 1812. So far, what was proposed was a concession to the demands of the great commercial and non-military Republic. But, tacked to this, was a condemnation of, and an agreement to renounce, the practice of privateering. And when the European programme reached Washington, it was on this ground rejected. The States, we were assured, could not dispense with the right to issue letters of-marque to private adventurers, authorizing them to "burn, sink, and destroy" -- and plunder -- the shipping of any Power with which they might be at war, seeing that otherwise, not having, and not choosing to maintain, a powerful navy, they would be incapable of injuring their enemy at sea. And for this purely destructive purpose -- and avowedly for this purpose -- the States would retain the right.

abstract: We have still our Minister at Washington, and the American Minister is still resident in London. It is true delegates have been sent from the Southern Convention, but they have not been received here, nor, so far as we have heard at any of the Courts of Europe. Apart, then, altogether from the question
lead_paragraph: We have still our Minister at Washington, and the American Minister is still resident in London. It is true delegates have been sent from the Southern Convention, but they have not been received here, nor, so far as we have heard at any of the Courts of Europe. Apart, then, altogether from the question of the inherent sovereignty of any State or number of States -- the argument on which Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS relies in issuing his letter of-marque -- we seem, so long as we maintain uninterrupted diplomatic relations with the Federal Government, to be precluded from recognizing any act done in hostility to that Government, or in derogation of its authority. If this view of the case be correct, we cannot recognize the proclamation of the Southern President; and, in as much as the Federal Government has declared privateering on the port of the Southerners to be piracy, we have no alternative but to regard it in the same light, until we have, by an overt act of recognition, conceded to the Southern Convention the position of a Government de jure, and established with it relations similar to those which already exist between our Government and the Cabinet of Washington.

abstract: Last evening the officers of the Empire City Regiment serenaded Mrs. President LINCOLN, who is at the Metropolitan Hotel. The field and staff officers of the Excelsion Brigade, were present as the guests of the officers of the E.C.R. At about a quarter to eleven o'clock, the officers and guests fell into line at the head-quarters No 594 Broadway and marched down to the Metropolitan Hotel. Lieut.-Col. MULLYGAN, who was in command, called "hualt" under Mrs. LINCOLN's windows which are the fifth and sixth from Prince-street on the second story. The regiment band then played "The Star Spangled Banner," "When the Swallows Homeward Fly," "Hail to the Chief," and the "Wicher Polka."
lead_paragraph: Last evening the officers of the Empire City Regiment serenaded Mrs. President LINCOLN, who is at the Metropolitan Hotel. The field and staff officers of the Excelsion Brigade, were present as the guests of the officers of the E.C.R. At about a quarter to eleven o'clock, the officers and guests fell into line at the head-quarters No 594 Broadway and marched down to the Metropolitan Hotel. Lieut.-Col. The regiment band then played "The Star Spangled Banner," "When the Swallows Homeward Fly," "Hail to the Chief," and the "Wicher Polka."

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington are important, as indicating the course likely to be pursued by the European Governments in the pending war, shadowed forth in the attitude of the diplomats at the Capital. The Ministers Resident are represented to be utterly astounded at the exhibition of vigor on the part of the Administration, and the overwhelming response made by the people to the call of the Government for aid. Their last dispatches to Europe, if anything, exaggerate this great uprising of the people, and on those dispatches this Government will take definite action in preference to any which have gone before, based upon the condition in which the country was left at the close of Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration. The President and Cabinet have no fear that the Government of either England or France will assume an attitude hostile to the Union on account of the blockade of the Southern ports.

abstract: The steam transport Chesapeake, WILLETS, lying at Pier No. 13 North River, sailed yesterday at 3 P.M. for Key West and Tortugas. She has a bulk of 3,000 bols. provisions. The steam transport Parkersburgh, BERRY, lying at Pier No. 9 North River, will sail this afternoon for the West and Fort Pickans. She has on board 100 tons ice, 25,000 lbs. fresh beef packed in ice, 300 live hags, 150 live sheep. Also a large quantity of preserved meats, vegetables. &c. The steam gun boat Mount Vernon, WATSON, of II act as convoy.

abstract: Powell Lopell and Ellis Elling were put on trial, charged with passing counterfeit coin. abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Mr. Garvin prosecuting for the People, Thomas Cosgrove, indicted for grand larceny, was tried. From the testimony given, it appears that the prisoner, an Englishman who had been in this country but seven months, was foreman in a silk factory in Newark, N.J. About twenty pounds of silk, worth $7 a pound, was missed, and subsequently found in the possession of a man by the name of Howard, who had taken it to a dyer's establishment to be colored, so that its identity might be obscured. Suspicion was directed against the prisoner as the thief, and his subsequent statements tended in a measure to strengthen the suspicion. But in the lack of any direct proof, the Jury rendered a verdict of acquittal, and the prisoner was discharged.

abstract: This regiment consists of ten companies and an engineer corps. Four companies have been already inspected; the remainder will be mustered in immediately. The men belong to this regiment are mostly volunteers in the regular malitie, consequently the most of them are well drilled. Col WM. B. OLMSTEAD is in command, and his men are now quarted at Jones' Wood and Elm Park. In a few days they will brave for Fort Tompkins; the engineer corps is already there living out the grounds to enable the regiment to commence artillery practice immediately on their arrival.

abstract: Day by day we have new revelations of the spirit of Baltimore and of the character of the assassins of the 19th of April. The leaders in the dastardly outrage of that day it is now well known were men who had enjoyed the hospitalities of that portion of the country which has remained faithful to the laws; but after the cowardly assaults there were further developments, to two of which our attention has been specially directed, as showing woman in her true and generous state, and woman degraded by wrath and selfishness.

abstract: The blockade which has, probably, by this time, been practically instituted in all the ports and harbors of the Gulf of Mexico, will soon be a matter of deep concern to the commercial interests of New-Orleans, and, indeed, the whole valley above that city, and turn a portion of the public attention to the mouths of the Mississippi River, from which commercial vessels are henceforth, for a season, to be excluded, and privateers, if it is possible to send them to sea, are to enter upon their hazardous cruises.

abstract: Early in July, in the next session, of Congress, a new War bill will be prepared to enable the Government to meet the exigences of the present situation. It will be a measure of the utmost importance, and we trust will have upon it all the light which the widest military experience and the best medical science can give. The Army should be made into a perfect machine for the most complete service. All unsuitable regulations, belonging to a routine now cast aside in the beef European military systems, should be summarily thrown overboard. Many rules which wore adapted to our forces, scattered over a distant frontier, should be allowed, under our present circumstances, a more lax interpretation. Wants which were never felt in time of peace should now be filled up.

abstract: The commercial telegrams to-day from America describe business as having been brought to a total stand, and quote the rate of exchange 106 3/4. The accession of Virginia to the Southern Confederation gives it an additional population of 1,500,000, of whom only 500,000 are slaves. The relative populations of the various sections of the country are now as follows: 6,600,000 the seceding States, including Virginia; 5,800,000 the other Slave States; and 19,200,000 the Free States. As 44 per cent. of the population of the seceding States consists of slaves, the contest is terribly unequal as regards numbers; but the South have the advantage in the fact of the country being inconvenient and unhealthy for an invading force at the approaching season. Still, as the Slave States depend upon their ability to export their cotton and to import the greater part of the food for their slaves, it is impossible to conceive that, under such a blockade as it will be in the power of the North to institute, they can maintain their resistance for any very protracted period.

Still, as the Slave States depend upon their ability to export their cotton and to import the greater part of the food for their slaves, it is impossible to conceive that, under such a blockade as it will be in the power of the North to institute, they can maintain their resistance for any very protracted period.

abstract: GEOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY. -- The annual election for officers in this Society held last evening resulted in the success of the socalled Reform ticket, with the exception of the President. The candidates for this office were the distinguished traveler. BAYARD TAYLOR, and A. RUSSELL. Each received the same number of votes; the remainder of the successful ticket was as follows: Vice-President, Henry Grinnell; Foreign Corresponding Secretary, John Jay; Domestic Corresponding Secretary. E.G. Squier; Recording Secretary, William Starcuck Mayo; Treasurer, Paschal W. Turney; Librarian, Charles B. Norton; Council Joseph B. Varnum, Jr., Edward A. Stransbury, Samuel Dexter Bradford, Jr., Charles Congdon.

abstract: Another act in the terrible drama of blood that opened so fearfully on Friday, was enacted last evening, and six more victims were added to the already sad list of dead. Two scenes of blood so close together, and so frightful in their results, have seldom before plunged a city into mourning. At about half-past five o'clock in the evening, a large body of the German Home Guards entered the city through Fifth-street, from the arsenal, where they had been enlisted during the day, and furnished with arms. Large crowds collected to witness their march, and they passed unmolested along until they reached Walnut, when they turned up that street and proceeded westward. Large crowds were collected on these corners, who hooted and hissed as the companies passed, and one man standing on the steps of the Church fired a revolver into the ranks. A soldier fell dead, when two more shots were fired from the windows of a house near by. At this time the head of the column, which reached as far as Seventh, suddenly turned and, leveling their rifles, fired down the street, and promiscuously among the spectators, who lined the pavement. Shooting as they did directly towards their own rear ranks, they killed some of their men as well as those composing the crowd. The shower of bullets was for a moment terrible, and the only wonder is that more lives were not lost. The misslies of lead entered the windows and perforated the doors of private residences, tearing the ceilings and throwing splimers in every direction. The house of Mr. MATHEWS was entered by three bullets, and Mr. MATHEWS' daughter was struck slightly by a spent ball. On the street, the scene presented as the soldiers moved off, was sad indeed. Six men lay dead at different points, and several were wounded and shrisking with pain upon the pavements. The dead carts, which have become familiar venicles since the scenes of the last two days, were soon engaged in removing the corpses from the ground. The wounded were carried to the Health Office. Four of the men killed were members of the regiment, and two were citizens. Last night the former had not been recognized. JERRY SWITZELAN, an engineer on the river, was passing by the door of Mr. H. GLOVER's residence, on Seventh-street, next to Walnut, when a pail struck him in the head, and scattered his brains over the door and walls. A pool of blood marked the spot where he fell, after his body had been removed. JEREMIAH GODFREY a hired man of Mr. COZZENS, County Surveyor, was working in the yard of Mr. COZZENS at the time of the occurrence. While, stopping over, in the act of fastening some flowers to a frame, three soldiers entered the gate, and approaching within the yard, fired three shots into his body. Fortunately, none of them were fatal, being all flesh wounds. The family witnessed the affair, and says that the man had not been out of the yard, and was unaware of the approach of his assailants until stricken down by their bullets. CHARLES H. WOODWARD, a clerk in POMEROY & BENTON's store, was shot in the shoulder, and will have to have his entire arm amputated. He was carried into the residence of Mr. MATHEWS and kindly cared for. JAMES F. WELSH, living at No. 189 Wash-street, between Fourteenth and Fifteenth streets, was shot through the foot. MICHAEL DAVY, residing between O'Fallen and Cass avenue and Sixth and Seventh, received a ball through the ankle, and amputation will be necessary. JOHN NELUS was wounded in the cheek. Several others were injured slightly. The houses on the right side of Walnut, from Fifth to Seventh, were considerably injured by bullets, and the inmates in several cares had very narrow escapes. At a late hour in the night the bodies of JOHN GABNIN, whose brother keeps a livery-stable on Market street. WILLIAM CODY, a book peddler, from New-Orleans, and JOHN DICK, a German soldier, were recognized among the dead. Immense crowds of people filled the streets after the occurrence, and the whole city presented a scene of excitement seldom witnessed.
lead_paragraph: Another act in the terrible drama of blood that opened so fearfully on Friday, was enacted last evening, and six more victims were added to the already sad list of dead. Two scenes of blood so close together, and so frightful in their results, have seldom before plunged a city into mourning. At about half-past five o'clock in the evening, a large body of the German Home Guards entered the city through Fifth-street, from the arsenal, where they had been enlisted during the day, and furnished with arms. Large crowds collected to witness their march, and they passed unmolested along until they reached Walnut, when they turned up that street and proceeded westward. Large crowds were collected on these corners, who hooted and hissed as the companies passed, and one man standing on the steps of the Church fired a revolver into the ranks. A soldier fell dead, when two more shots were fired from the windows of a house near by. At this time the head of the column, which reached as far as Seventh, suddenly turned and, leveling their rifles, fired down the street, and promiscuously among the spectators, who lined the pavement. Shooting as they did directly towards their own rear ranks, they killed some of their men as well as those composing the crowd. The shower of bullets was for a moment terrible, and the only wonder is that more lives were not lost. The misslies of lead entered the windows and perforated the doors of private residences, tearing the ceilings and throwing splimers in every direction. The house of Mr. MATHEWS was entered by three bullets, and Mr. MATHEWS' daughter was struck slightly by a spent ball. On the street, the scene presented as the soldiers moved off, was sad indeed. Six men lay dead at different points, and several were wounded and shrisking with pain upon the pavements. The dead carts, which have become familiar venicles since the scenes of the last two days, were soon engaged in removing the corpses from the ground. The wounded were carried to the Health Office. Four of the men killed were members of the regiment, and two were citizens. Last night the former had not been recognized. JERRY SWITZELAN, an engineer on the river, was passing by the door of Mr. H. GLOVER's residence, on Seventh-street, next to Walnut, when a pail struck him in the head, and scattered his brains over the door and walls. A pool of blood marked the spot where he fell, after his body had been removed. JEREMIAH GODFREY a hired man of Mr. COZZENS, County Surveyor, was working in the yard of Mr. COZZENS at the time of the occurrence. While, stopping over, in the act of fastening some flowers to a frame, three soldiers entered the gate, and approaching within the yard, fired three shots into his body. Fortunately, none of them were fatal, being all flesh wounds. The family witnessed the affair, and says that the man had not been out of the yard, and was unaware of the approach of his assailants until stricken down by their bullets. CHARLES H. WOODWARD, a clerk in POMEROY & BENTON's store, was shot in the shoulder, and will have to have his entire arm amputated. He was carried into the residence of Mr. MATHEWS and kindly cared for. JAMES F. WELSH, living at No. 189 Wash-street, between Fourteenth and Fifteenth streets, was shot through the foot. MICHAEL DAVY, residing between O'Fallen and Cass avenue and Sixth and Seventh, received a ball through the ankle, and amputation will be necessary. JOHN NELUS was wounded in the cheek. Several others were injured slightly. The houses on the right side of Walnut, from Fifth to Seventh, were considerably injured by bullets, and the inmates in several cares had very narrow escapes. At a late hour in the night the bodies of JOHN GABNIN, whose brother keeps a livery-stable on Market street. WILLIAM CODY, a book peddler, from New-Orleans, and JOHN DICK, a German soldier, were recognized among the dead. Immense crowds of people filled the streets after the occurrence, and the whole city presented a scene of excitement seldom witnessed.

abstract: Among the humbugs of these times there is none so preposterous as this idea of subjugation, and yet there is no word in the English language upon which so many changes have been rung. If a fort threatened by secession is reinforced by the Government, it is denounced as an effort at subjugation. If a regiment is raised to defend the Capitol from lawless invasion, it is denounced as an attempt at subjugation. If an army is called for to defend the country and maintain the integrity of the Union against an armed rebellion, it is stigmatized as a preparation for subjugation. It the President of the United States issues his proclamation calling upon all good citizens to obey the laws and uphold the Constitution, the cry of subjugation is raised, and the President is denounced as a usurper and a tyrant. When it is asserted that the fundamental principle that underlies all representative or popular Government, that the will of the majority constitutionally expressed, and acting in a constitutional way, shall control, it is denounced as a heresy, and as equivalent to subjugation.

abstract: John Purdy, assignee and survivor of George Rapelye, Respondents, vs. John R. Peters, Jr., et als, executors of John R. Peters, Appellants. This is an appeal by the defendants from a judgment rendered
lead_paragraph: John Purdy, assignee and survivor of George Rapelye, Respondents, vs. John R. Peters, Jr., et als, executors of John R. Peters, Appellants. This is an appeal by the defendants from a judgment rendered upon the direction of one of the Justices of the Court, upon a trial without a jury. The action was brought upon a guarantee, by which the defendants' testator guaranteed to the plaintiff and Rapelye, as copartners, the payment of a certain certificate of deposit, payable two years after date, issued by the North American Trust and Banking Company to the said testator, and by him transferred to Rapelye and Purdy. The defence is substantially that the certificate of deposit was illegal and void, and consequently the guarantee was void. The points taken on the part of the appellant are, first, that no action can be maintained on the instrument set forth in the complaint the same having been, prior to the commencement of this action, declared null and void by a Court of competent jurisdiction, the judgment therein being in full force, and not reversed. If, then, the instrument issued by the banking company is illegal and void, the guarantee is also void.

abstract: Some eighty years ago, in a letter to the philanthropic HARTLEY, FRANKLIN expressed his apprehensions lest the success of the private-armed vessels employed in the Revolution, and in the prior French wars, should have given the American people too strong a relish "for that most mischievous kind of gaining mixed with blood." "I do not wish," he added, "to see a new Barhary rising in America, and our long extended coast occupied by piratical States." He little thought that in less than a century has worst fears in this regard would be realized. The privateering proclamation of JEFFERSON DAVIS, and the privateering act of the Confederate Congress, with the numerous applications that are reported for letters-of-marque and reprisal, menace us too clearly with a new Barbary that, at all eclipse the infamy of the old.

abstract: The question which was last night asked by Mr. JOSEPH EWART, on the subject of American privateers, cannot of course be dissociated from the proclama- tion which Mr. LINCOLN has recently issued, declaring a blockade of the Southern ports, and announcing that the Federal Government will treat as pirates all letters of marque which may be fitted out by the insurgent States. Mr. EWART, representing the greatest em-
lead_paragraph: The question which was last night asked by Mr. JOSEPH EWART, on the subject of American privateers, cannot of course be dissociated from the proclama- tion which Mr. LINCOLN has recently issued, declaring a blockade of the Southern ports, and announcing that the Federal Government will treat as pirates all letters of marque which may be fitted out by the insurgent States. Mr. EWART, representing the greatest emporium of American trade which exists not only in this country, but in the world, is naturally enough anxious to ascertain the amount of protection which her Majesty's Ministers are prepared to afford to British commerce in the Gulf of Mexico. This interpelation was in every sense equaly timely and necessary. Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, the President of the Southern Confederation, anticipating by a few days the action of the federal Government, has stated his intention of commissioning privateers. He has practically thrown down a challenge and instituted a policy which the North, to insure success, has only to imitate and enforce. But, considering that the great staple export of the South is cotton, upon every bale of which the new. Confederation has lately levied a war tax, the legality of this trade, whether carried on in foreign or American ships, becomes a matter of deep and serious consideration. The South possesses no commercial marine which could not be easily swept from the seas by the privateers of New-York and, Boston; but, if the privilege of issuing letters-of-marque were once conceded to the insurgent, the whole of the commerce between Europe and American would be placed in a position of imminent peril and danger. Under these circumstances Lord JOHN RUSSELL, in reply to Mr. EWART, simply stated that Her Majesty's Government felt very deeply that it was imperative on them to take all possible means to avoid any participation in this lamentable conflict, and that nothing but the imperative duty of protecting British interests could jointly them in interferfering, adding these emphatic words, "We are now free, and for Goo's sake let us keep out of the quarrel." We do not image that British shipowners, with the fear of risks and insurances before their eyes, will be rash enough to endeavor to carry on an illicit and lucrative trade by accepting the protection which either bellegerent may offer. There can be no doubt that the President, in strict interpretation of public law, has a right both to declare a blockade of the Southern ports and to treat Southern privateers, when captured, as pirates. With regard to the one, he has this condition to observe, namely, that the blockade be effectual, which has always been the American practice, as well as the rule within the recognized the lake treaty of Paris With regard to the employment of privateers, the American Government has always maintained a position of isolation. It has refused to surrender the privilege of granting letters-of-marque except the concession were accompanied by the assertion of the rule that in the of war all commence not contraband of war should enjoy equal immunity upon land and sea. This is not only a fallacious but an impossible doctrine, because we all know from history that property on land, whenever the exigencies of war require it, is as liable to confiscation and destruction as goods at sea. Mr. LINCOLN is acting in strict conformity with precedent in declaring that he will treat and punish all Southern privateers as pirates. In the Mexican War, when it was supposed that foreigners might be disposed to intervene in the contest on behalf of Mexico, Mr. POLK issued a proclamation declaring that he would deal with all such offendors as robbers and pirates. The present case is one infinitely stronger. The Federal Government is engaged in war with the Southern Insurgents, whose independent and separate existence, either dejure or de facto, has never yet been recognized by any Power in the world.In contemplation of public law they are simply rebels; and, as against them, the policy which Mr. Lincoln has announce is not only valid in itself, but is one which oreign nations are bound to admit and respect. Believing that the present movement can only be effectually repressed by a maritime war which, by depriving the South of its resources, would in all probability speedily reduce the new Confederation to national bankruptcy, we think that Mr. LINCOLN has acted wisely and in conformity with strict law in having availed himself of the means which, it must be admitted, he can exercise without offence or injury to any foreign Power. To preserve that policy of neutrality which Lord JOHN RUSSELL last night so forcibly expressed is the duty of this country. Interference can do no good either for commercial or political purposes. The civil war which unhappily rages in America must be left to work itself out, however disastrous its results may be to the commercial and manufacturing industry of this country.

abstract: The advices at hand respecting the blockade by the Federal Government of all the ports of the seceding and cotton-growing States, will naturally cause serious apprehension throughout the manufacturing districts as to the future supply of cotton, more especially as the certainty which these advices give us of a sanguinary struggle between the Free and the Slave States, which may most probably interfere materially with the next crop of cotton, should the slaves choose this as an opportunity to secure their freecom. For theimmediate future, however, the supply of cotton in this country will be fully adequate to the wants of the trade, more especially as with the continued unfavorable state of trade in Manchester, spinners show no inclination to increase their stocks. Whether this is a prudent course time will develop. There can be no question that, sooner or later within the next nine months, there must be a considerable amount of short time worked by spinners, as, even with no obstruction to the shipment of cotton from the United States, the present crop, estimated at fully one-million bales less than last year, cannot be equal to the increased requirements of the world.

abstract: The session of the Synod of the Reformed Presbyterians, held in Dr. MCLEOD's Church in Twelfth street, was resumed yesterday morning. Proceedings wore commenced with prayer by Rev. Mr. STERRITT, of Philadelphia, after which certificates of the different delegations were read by the Secretary. Rev. GARVIN MCMILLAN, D.D., was appointed moderator, and Dr. MCLEOD and Rev. J.A. CRAWFORD clerks. The Secretary then read the minutes of Wednesday's business, when the following resolution was offered and adopted: That the hours of meeting be from 9 1/2 A.M. to 12 M, and from 3 P.M. until adjournment by motion, the first half hour of the morning session to be passed in devotional exercises

abstract: On May 6, Senator JOHNSON of Tennessee had nearly reached Knoxville, in his canvass against the Secessionists. The style of this canvassing may be judged of, from the commencement of his speech at Cleveland, Tenn., where threats against him had been largely indulged in. He told the crowd that he "did not come there to be shot, but to shoot;" that if there was to be a fight, he and his friends were ready for it, and that he preferred to finish up the fighting before he made his speech. Nobody coming forward to fight, the intrepid Senator preceeded to speak, and by the time he had finished, nineteen-twentieths of the audience were with him. He told them, among other things, that JEFF, DAVIS and the Governor of the State ought to be hanged, and would be hanged at that not far distant period when the judicial power of the Government could be brought to bear upon them.

abstract: The Fourteenth Regiment marched through the streets yesterday, and their improved appearance was the theme of all who saw them. At the corner of Oronge and Willow streets, a splendid silk regimental flag, -- manufactured at an expense of $100, by the friends of the corps, -- was presented by Rev. Mr. ROBINSON, and was received on the part of the Regiment by the Chaplain, Rev. J.S. INSKIP, who in receiving the colors, said, -- taking to the burying of the national flag in Kentucky, -- that before that flag should be buried, they would have to bury the Fourteenth Regiment without a Chaptain.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board, last evening, Mr. PINCKNEY offered a resolution to discontinue the New-York Daily News and the New-York Day-Book as Corporation papers. Mr. BARNEY (Dem.) warmly supported the resolution. These papers, he said, were supported by the City Government, and they repaid this support by doing all in their limited power to excite discord among our citizens in reference to the treason and rebellion now existing in a portion of our country, and to weaken the loyalty of our people to the General Government. Their aim appeared to be to so excite the minds and outrage the sentiments of the citizens of New-York as to cause a riot which should demolish their establishments, hoping thereby to compel the City to pay for their rotten concerns, which were unable longer to support themselves. Words were powerless to express the contempt he felt for the course pursued by these journals. He hoped the resolution would be adopted forthwith.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board, last evening, Mr. PINCKNEY offered a resolution to discontinue the New-York Daily News and the New-York Day-Book as Corporation papers. Words were powerless to express the contempt he felt for the course pursued by these journals. He hoped the resolution would be adopted forthwith.

abstract: It is said that nearly all the chief officers of the United States army stationed in California, and at all the Western forts, will be recalled. The exigencies of the service at the seat of war make their presence in the Department of the East of the greatest importance. Already three high regimental functionaries, have come home, and several ethers are ordered to return, Junior officers and new appointments will be sent to replace them. There are over thirty distinguished officers now in the West, who would be of the greatest value here.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The latest novelty at this house is the "Invisible Prince" -- a buriesque, which, if not absolutely fresh as a literary production, possesses at least a useful receptive power sufficient to adapt it, more or less, to the popular exigencies of the moment. Some new jokes have been recruited for the present occasion, and pass muster readily. For the rest we may say, briefly, that the piece has been put on the stage satisfactorily, and that Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JEFFERSON in the two principal parts are particularly good. It will be repeated to-night, preceded by the comic drama of "Robert Macaire."

abstract: It is now definitely known that, at the urgent solicitation of several members of the Safety Committee who reside in Brooklyn, the Fourteenth Regiment will be included in the recent order obtained for the marching of fourteen more regiments from this vicinity. It is not improbable that definite orders will be issued to day.
lead_paragraph: It is now definitely known that, at the urgent solicitation of several members of the Safety Committee who reside in Brooklyn, the Fourteenth Regiment will be included in the recent order obtained for the marching of fourteen more regiments from this vicinity. It is not improbable that definite orders will be issued to day. This Regiment is still encamped on Fort Greene, and the camp is visited daily by thousands of citizens. There is much complaint as to the quality of the provisions furnished, and it is alleged by those who ought to know, that tainted meat has been served out, at least on one occasion.

abstract: Yesterday forenoon, the encampment in the City Hall park enjoyed the honor of a visit from Mrs. LINCOLN, the wife of the President of the United States. In anticipation of the visit, the "Park Barracks," which always present a neat and tidy appearance, had received an extra polish, and were in a condition to reflect credit upon the soldiers quartered there, and to elicit the warmest praise, even from so good a housewife as Mrs. LINCOLN. Previous to the arrival of the distinguished visitor, the soldiers, to the number of nearly 2,000, had been drawn up in line, extending two deep around the whole length of the inclosure, and facing a large assemblage of ladies and gentlemen who had obained tickets of admission. At 11 1/2 o'clock Mrs. LINCOLN arrived at the entrance gate in an open barouche, accompanied by her business manager, Mr. WOOD, and by Mrs. GRIMSLEY, and Mrs. DENNISON. On alighting from the carriage she took the arm of Paymaster-General T.B. VAN BURIN, the Colonel commanding the Park Barracks, and by him was escorted into the inclosure, through the barracks, and along the whole line of soldiers, the band meantime playing Hail Columbia. After viewing all the objects of interest in the encampment, Mrs. LINCOLN and her companions were conducted to the officers' quarters in the barracks, where a tasteful collation had been prepared, and where she was introduced to the officers in command of the forces at the encampment, and others who chanced to be present, among them Quartermaster-General Arthur, Col. Brown, Capt. Chalmers, Capt. Pike, Capt. Greene, aid to Col. Van Buren, Col. Arthon, and many more. After a few moments spent in conversation with the officers, to whom she expressed the most unfeigned delight and admiration at what she had seen, Mrs. LINCOLN returned to her carriage, and was driven from the grounds amid enthusiastic cheers from the thousands of people who had gathered about the inclosure. Mrs. LINCOLN appeared in excellent health, and evidently enjoyed her visit to the Park Encampment as much as any place she has visited during her stay in the City.

abstract: William N. Pierreport, indicted for felonious assault, was next tried. From the testimony, which was very brief, it appeared that on the 24th December last the prisoner went into the store of the complainant, Joanna Jones, and without provocation plunged a knife into her. She ran out, screaming, and was followed by the prisoner, who shut at her, the ball passing through one temple and cut at her eye, entirely destroying it. The explanation of the act was found in the jealousy of the prisoner, who on the death of the complainant's husband had been rejected as her suitor, and was now fired with a jealous rage, which was claimed by tee prisoner's counsel as amounting to an insanity which made him an irresponsible being. Several witnesses proved his previous good character, and the Jury rendered a verdict of guilty. The prisoner was sent to State Prison for ten years.
lead_paragraph: William N. Pierreport, indicted for felonious assault, was next tried. Several witnesses proved his previous good character, and the Jury rendered a verdict of guilty. The prisoner was sent to State Prison for ten years.

abstract: papers are a great deal amused at the demonstrations by some of our contemporaries, that two or three hundred persons were killed during the bombardment of Fort Sumter: The Courier says that "the whole force actively engaged in the attack on Fort Sumter, and within range of its firing, was not as large as the number killed, according to the wishes and belief of some of the Northern editors." This corroborates what we have already stated, that the whole number of persons within Fort Moultrie during the action was 103.

abstract: J.W. Page et al vs. L.O. Wilson et al. -- This appeal is taken on the part of the defendants from a judgment rendered at a Special Term of this Court, in favor of the plaintiffs. The complaint in the action alleges that the defendants, by false and fraudulent representations, obtained from the plaintiffs an extension on their paper, which, it is alleged, fell due in the Fall of 1857. It is claimed that the extension never took effect, it having been predicated of a condition which never arose. It is claimed that another portion of the cause of action having been demanded in an action prior to this, and an action having been commenced in the Supreme Court -- the judgment record of which was put in evidence in this action --that the present action cannot be maintained, the former judgment being a bar to this. It is argued that the whole debt from Wilson & Co. to Paige & Co. being due when the first action was brought, and not having been claimed in that action, cannot be recovered in this.
lead_paragraph: J.W. Page et al vs. L.O. Wilson et al. -- This appeal is taken on the part of the defendants from a judgment rendered at a Special Term of this Court, in favor of the plaintiffs. The complaint in the action alleges that the defendants, by false and fraudulent representations, obtained from the plaintiffs an extension on their paper, which, it is alleged, fell due in the Fall of 1857. It is claimed that the extension never took effect, it having been predicated of a condition which never arose. It is claimed that another portion of the cause of action having been demanded in an action prior to this, and an action having been commenced in the Supreme Court -- the judgment record of which was put in evidence in this action --that the present action cannot be maintained, the former judgment being a bar to this. It is argued that the whole debt from Wilson & Co. to Paige & Co. being due when the first action was brought, and not having been claimed in that action, cannot be recovered in this.

abstract: York Bible Society has made special efforts to supply all the troops stationed in this City and vicinity, and passing through it, with the Scriptures, and have given notice of a public meeting, in furtherance of this enterprise, to be held in Irving Hall, corner of Irving-place and Fifteenth-street, on Sunday evening, 19th inst, at 7 1/2 o'clock. WM. ALLEN BUTLER Dr. HITCHCOCK and Dr. TYNG are to speak. The object is one which commands and deserves the public sympathy, and a meeting of the character indicated in the call for it, is the best way of promoting it. The military enter cordially into the distribution of Testaments, and the work should be encouraged by a full attendance at Irving Hall on Sunday evening.

abstract: There has never been an instance in history, in which a nation, in so short a time, displayed such vast power, as that put forth by the United States within the last thirty days.
lead_paragraph: There has never been an instance in history, in which a nation, in so short a time, displayed such vast power, as that put forth by the United States within the last thirty days. From a condition of profound peace, more than 100,000 men, thoroughly armed, equipped, and provisioned, all drawn from avocations they were quietly pursuing, have been put into the field. The number might have been increased to 200,000 or 300,000, had the call embraced so many. Within three months, the number might be raised to 500,000 men, all eager to enroll themselves, who appreciate thoroughly the nature of the contest, and who are prepared, not only to fight but to die for it. This immense host is only the advance-guard of 20,000,000 people, who freely proffer themselves and their whole means for the contest. Such a power is irresistible unless opposed by one similar in numbers, intelligence, spirit and means, which is not to be found on this continent, and we may say not in the world. As we are fighting for a principle, in the ranks are to be found the best blood of the land -- intelligence, skill, capacity for military subordination, and an experience in the use of firearms, to which our people from their youth are habituated.
