abstract: The official statement, furnished by the Superintendent of the Census, of the number of men between the ages of 18 and 45, in the several States and in the sections, shows the ultimate result of the pending contest.
lead_paragraph: The official statement, furnished by the Superintendent of the Census, of the number of men between the ages of 18 and 45, in the several States and in the sections, shows the ultimate result of the pending contest. The total for the Free States is, 3,778,000, and for the Slave States, 1,655,000. There are in the Territories and District of Columbia, 51,000, which may be added to the strength of the North, and 22,000 in Delaware, which should be taken from the Southern and added to the Northern Column. But even these explanations fail to exhibit the full strength of the free element, and the weakness of the slave element in the Union, since hundreds of thousands in Maryland, Virginia, Kentucky and Missouri, have openly taken the side of the Government in the effort it is making to preserve the Union. Maryland, in fact, has unconditionally cast her lot with the Union; and we shall be within the mark in assuming that one-third the population of Virginia, Kentucky and Missouri, have done, or will do likewise.

abstract: The Synod resumed its session yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. After some time passed in devotional exercises, reports from the various Committees were taken up and considered. The first report was on the subject of the Sabbath, means for its better ob servance being therein suggested.
lead_paragraph: The Synod resumed its session yesterday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock. After some time passed in devotional exercises, reports from the various Committees were taken up and considered. The first report was on the subject of the Sabbath, means for its better ob servance being therein suggested. The second report(that on Slavery) took the ground that all who did approve of the abolition of that relic of barbarism were little better than traitors. Both were referred back, with instructions. The Secretary then read the general reports from the different Presbyteries, showing how the different. Churches had prospered during the year. A report was subsequently received from the Board of Education, accompanied by a letter from the Secretary of that Board, excusing himself from attendance on the Synod, for the reason that he was at Camp Scott, fulfilling his duty as Colonel of a Regiment of Volunteers. Before closing, the morning session, a resolution was passed, making the question of Domestic Missions the order of the day for Monday.
headline: {'main': 'The Presbyterian General Synod.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Presbyterian General Synod.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: While nothing is more futile than the attempt to predict the results of the struggle through which our people are about to pass, there are a few points which may already be set down as infallibly certain.
lead_paragraph: While nothing is more futile than the attempt to predict the results of the struggle through which our people are about to pass, there are a few points which may already be set down as infallibly certain. It is certain for example that the men who have misled the South into its present ruinous position will be called to rigid account. Every day discloses some fresh miscalculation on the strength of which secession has been grounded; false estimates of aid and sympathy to be expected from the North; false estimates of the courage, energy and self-assertion of the Government; unreasonable expectations of foreign support, to be won by diplomacy, or commanded by cotton; exaggerations of their own resources and powers of endurance; all these delusions have been persistently and confidently inculcated by men of presumed wisdom and statesmanship; and their vanity is already demonstrated. It is as if the principal partners in a commercial enterprise contributed as capital, promises to pay, all of which at maturity proved worthless. The business, of necessity, collapses.

abstract: Nearly all the members of the Legistatare have gene home. Few are still lingering to get companies accepted. abstract: ations which JEFF. DAVIS and his secession followers are compelled to bear, is to be found in the fact that the President will not declare war against them. They insist that the Southern Confederacy is a Power on the earth, a great nation against whom war must be formally declared, and which must be conducted according to the custom of nations in relation to such affairs. The Government, however, is obstinate on this subject, and persists in regarding secession as a conspiracy, -- the warlike pranks of our Southern friends as simply and only rebellion, and JEFF, DAVIS and all his followers as rebels, nothing more, nothing less. This is not only revolting to their pride and self-conceit, but it involves a question in which their necks are in some sort concerned. A prisoner of war, to be provided with rations and comfortable subsistence until the peace, or discharged upon parole, is a very different thing from a captured traitor to be tried by the courts and judged by the laws against treason. The one enjoys an honorable restraint, while the other may have to swing for it.

abstract: We published yesterday a letter addressed by Judge CAMPBELL, lately of the United States Supreme Court, to Hon. W.H. SEWARD, with sundry accompanying documents.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a letter addressed by Judge CAMPBELL, lately of the United States Supreme Court, to Hon. W.H. SEWARD, with sundry accompanying documents. The object of the letter was to show that Mr. SEWARD, in giving him certain assurances concerning the intentions of the Government, had intentionally deceived him; and be further states that, in his judgment, this bad faith on the part of the National Government was the principal cause of the attack on Fort Sumter. Judge CAMPBELL was acting as the medium of communication in this matter between the Secretary of State and the Commissioners from the Southern Confederacy.

abstract: A National Hymn seems almost as indispensable an appanage of nationality, as a national flag. Patriotic feeling, excited by any unusual incident, always seeks expression in verse and music those universal mediums of emotion.
lead_paragraph: A National Hymn seems almost as indispensable an appanage of nationality, as a national flag. Patriotic feeling, excited by any unusual incident, always seeks expression in verse and music -- those universal mediums of emotion. The operation is twofold and reciprocal; the song both expresses national sentiment and excites it. One of the first movements toward the restraint of an incipient French Revolution, is the suppression of the "Marsellaise Hymn." It is only a few weeks ago, that the Poles, in Warsaw, charged and fired upon by the Russian troops, as they assembled to present a petition, fell upon their knees and sang the national hymn, thus fortifying themselves to endure, without flinching, an attack which they were then powerless to repel.
headline: {'main': 'A National Hymn.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A National Hymn.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. CHARLES WELDEN, the well-known litterateur, for several years employed on this paper, fell suddenly dead last night. He left the office about 11 o'clock, apparently in his usual health, and on reaching Tammany Hall, where he was staying, he seemed in the best of spirits. Before he reached his chamber, however, he was stricken with death, and the hand that had but a moment before given the clasp of friendship was forever powerless. Mr. WELDEN was a native of New-York, and about forty years of of age.
lead_paragraph: Mr. CHARLES WELDEN, the well-known litterateur, for several years employed on this paper, fell suddenly dead last night. Mr. WELDEN was a native of New-York, and about forty years of of age.

abstract: Samuel Collins, Lewis Featherstone, John Dunlevy and John Kelly, were put on trial charged with murdering Geo. W. Pike, the Captain of the ship Gen. Parkhill. Before commencing the trial, Mr. Smith, the District Attorney entered a nolle prosequi against Kelly, proposing to use him as a witness.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Collins, Lewis Featherstone, John Dunlevy and John Kelly, were put on trial charged with murdering Geo. W. Pike, the Captain of the ship Gen. Parkhill. Before commencing the trial, Mr. Smith, the District Attorney entered a nolle prosequi against Kelly, proposing to use him as a witness. One of the crew named Smith was put on the stand and testified that the defendants were sailors on board the ship, which left Liverpool in the morning of Feb 25, 1861; there seemed to have been same difficulty during the day between the Captain and the men, as he as he heard some of the men crying out; in the evening the men were together, and Dunlevy said they were going to stop this work, (by which he understood the Captain's sulking the men,) and that if they stauck him be would strike back, and would serve any one who would not join them in the same way, but witness declined to join them; that after that, about halt-past eight o'clock, the men and the Captain had a fight on deck, and he heard, the Captain cry out, "I am murdered," and he staggered to the cabin; the mets came up at the noise of the affray, and was stabbed and fell, but refused to go into the cabin, wren Dunlevy came up with a handspike and knocked him down, saying that the mate had tried to kill him, and he would kill the male; one of Dunlevy's eyes was almost closed at the time, as by blow; the [???] they went into the cabin, and the men called for three cheers, and when the second mate came out they, insisted, upon the ships, going back to Liverpool, and she was put back.

abstract: The United States transport Cahawba, J.B. BAKER commanding, arrived yesterday from Washington, D.C. making the passage in 40 hours, where she landed the Second Connecticut Regiment. Capt. BAKER wishes to express publicly his thanks to Mr. GEO. F. MOORE, pilot of the gun-boat Quaker City, for volunteering to pilot the Cahawba from Hampton Roads to Washington City and back to the entrance of Chesapeake Bay. The pilot who was on board being confined to his room by sickness, and had it not been for the kindness of Mr. MOORE, the Cahawba would probably have been detained a day at Hampton Roads, as pilots are very scarce and not reliable in those waters. The following gun-boats are on the blockading squadron and doing effective service: Harriet Lane, off the mouth of James and Elizabeth River; Monticello, off York River; Quaker City, at mouth of Chesapeake Bay. The Dawn and Yankee were at anchor off Fort Monroe, waiting orders. The steam-frigate Minnesota, Flag-officer STRINGHAM, arrived off Old Point Comfort on the morning of the 13th inst. All well.
lead_paragraph: The United States transport Cahawba, J.B. BAKER commanding, arrived yesterday from Washington, D.C. making the passage in 40 hours, where she landed the Second Connecticut Regiment. The following gun-boats are on the blockading squadron and doing effective service: Harriet Lane, off the mouth of James and Elizabeth River; Monticello, off York River; Quaker City, at mouth of Chesapeake Bay. abstract: Florida, "the smallest toad in the puddle" of secession, has spread upon the record of the C.S.A. Congress her protest against certain portions of the Constitution of that august Confederation. She protests against any scrutiny into the qualifications of her voters for President and members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Florida, "the smallest toad in the puddle" of secession, has spread upon the record of the C.S.A. Congress her protest against certain portions of the Constitution of that august Confederation. She protests against any scrutiny into the qualifications of her voters for President and members of Congress. She insists, so far as these officers are concerned, that the right of suffrage shall be extended to "all her inhabitants," whether native or foreign, naturalized or aliens, negroes, of course, always excepted. This is perfectly in keeping with the past history of Florida. She is the smallest, but by no means the least noisy of the Confederates. She is the poorest in purse, and lowest in intelligence. She has a larger proportionate number of floating population than most of the other Gulf States, and proposes to make the most of them.
headline: {'main': 'A Characteristic Protest.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Characteristic Protest.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news from the Federal Capital this morning is not of special importance, excepting as indicating the continued vigor with which the Administration is preparing everything for the great struggle which is now impending.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Federal Capital this morning is not of special importance, excepting as indicating the continued vigor with which the Administration is preparing everything for the great struggle which is now impending. The recently received dispatches from the South, to the effect that the rebels have nearly completed their preparations for an attack upon Washington are not credited. The secret agents of the Government have forwarded advices to this effect, but it is believed that their dispatches have been based upon the assertions of the rebel leaders, made for the purpose of blinding the Government as to their real intentions. While, therefore, ample measures will be taken for the security of the Capital in any emergency, the Government will not suffer its attention to be diverted from other important points, especially in Virginia. Gen. BUTLER has not yet been assigned to a command in his capacity as Major-General, though there is little doubt that he will go to Fortress Monroe. He was in consultation, yesterday, with the War Department and with Gen. SCOTT. At any rate, whenever he goes, then we may look for some forward movement of the first importance.

abstract: STABBING AND PROBABLE DEATH. -- WARREN WENDELL, a negro, twenty-one years of age, was dangerously and probably fatally stabbed in the left breast, on Friday afternoon, by a mulatto known to the Police as "SANDY MILLER." WENDELL was quietly passing the corner of West Broadway and Thomas street, when he was suddenly and violently assaulted and kicked by MILLER. Wishing to avoid trouble, he broke away and passed on, but was quickly pursued by MILLER, who drew a dirk from this coat sleeve and inflicted the wound as above stated. WENDELL was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, and after an examination, the House Surgeon was of the opinion that the weapon had penetrated the lungs, and that there is very little hope of his discovery. The assailant immediately fled towards Broadway, and has not yet been arrested. Officers HOBRELT and MCCLARY are in pursuit. Coroner SCHIRMER was notified to take an ante mortem examination.

abstract: Mr. OCHILTREE, of Texas, offered in the Montgomery Congress, the other day, a resolution in relation to the protection of the Indian tribes scattered over the territories, in which he speaks flippantly of the "late United States."
lead_paragraph: Mr. OCHILTREE, of Texas, offered in the Montgomery Congress, the other day, a resolution in relation to the protection of the Indian tribes scattered over the territories, in which he speaks flippantly of the "late United States." According to the notions of these Texan gentlemen, their revolution is accomplished, the Union is destroyed, and the great Republic of the United States has already become a thing of the past -- taken its place in history among the things that have been. Under an imbecile Administration, when the President was conniving at treason, and consenting to disintegration; when his Cabinet was robbing the Treasury, and placing the armaments of the country at the disposal of conspirators who were plotting its overthrow; when Southern States were plundering armories, and Southern chivalry was stealing the contents of sub-treasuries and mints, it was not singular that an idea should prevail that the Federal Government was becoming a myth -- that its vitality was lost past hope of recuperation, and that dissolution was already among the accomplished facts of the age. With an army equipped from the spoils of Federal property, organized and drilled into efficiency by deserters from the Federal ranks, and ready to work for the destruction of the Union, while not a soldier was summoned, nor the voice of a Federal officer raised in remonstrance, or invoking aid in its defence, the Southern revolutionists might well suppose that there would be no opposition to their schemes, and that history had already recorded the edict of their triumph. But a new light has dawned upon the world, and these Southern gasconaders are blind that they do not see it. The twenty millions of the East, the North, and the West, embracing all of the Free States, and at least two of the Slave, have risen in their unity and their might, resolved that these United States shall not be reckoned among the things that have been. They have declared that this Republic of North America is more than ever before a living entity, full of organic strength and enduring vitality, and that it shall be handed down in all its fair proportions, to the generations who are to come after them. The imbecility and inertia of the past has given place to a living and resistless energy; the inertia of the late Administration, its cowardice, and its corruptions, has been succeeded by an almost superhuman activity, a patriotism that looks only to the salvation of the Union, and a coinage that is intimidated by no menaces of its overthrow. This rally of the North is confined to no locality, no section, no political organization, no class. The whole country is awake and speaks with one voice. All party bickerings, all political prejudices, all political associations, have been swept away, and the whole North moves in a solid phalanx, a mighty brotherhood, impelled only by the spirit of patriotism to the defence of the Constitution and the Union. All hope of aid from the North, so confidently cherished by the South, has vanished away. Loyalty has hushed the voice of dissension, and these twenty millions think and speak and act to-gether, on the momentous issue of the day. Their money, their energies, all their treasure, all their blood, are at the service of their country, and all their strength ready on the instant in its defence. These twenty-one loyal States, with their twenty millions of men, are more than the thirteen States, with their seven millions of men, who have declared for secession, even if Missouri and Kentucky shall join the great conspiracy. They are richer, stronger, more united, and fixed as destiny in the resolve that the Union shall not be destroyed.

abstract: --To put a book afloat at the present time would be much like a man's standing on the seashore and endeavoring to make himself heard when the waters were lashed by a violent storm. Publishers and authors are fully conscious of this fact, and act accordingly.
lead_paragraph: -- To put a book afloat at the present time would be much like a man's standing on the seashore and endeavoring to make himself heard when the waters were lashed by a violent storm. Publishers and authors are fully conscious of this fact, and act accordingly. Aside from political pamphlets and hooks devoted to military tactics, there are very few new publications to chronicle. The issues of standard works commenced before the complexion of the country took its present motley hue, still continue, but the publishers are moved by the same principle which impels the captain of a ship when he has once left port to continue the voyage to the end, heedless of tempest, -- unless he founders in mid-sea. Of the miscellaneous publications below noticed, the majority were published before the storming of Sumter.

abstract: This officer has been for many years a resident of Quincy. His father was shot in the streets of that city by an old enemy. There had been the most bitter feud between the two for a long time, and the quarrel was finally settled at the West -- by an appeal to arms, and a bloody verdict. So that Col. PRENTISS comes of a race that always had fight in it. This is not his first experience in the martial front of battle. When the war with Mexico stirred up our young men to go in defence of the National flag, then, as now, there was a call for volunteers: and then, as now, Col. PRENTISS was foremost among those who signified their intention of responding to the call. He was only a lieutenant then in a company from Quincy. But when the regiment came to be organized, and the well-remembered JOHN J. HARDIN was elected colonel, he followed the usual custom of selecting his adjutant from his lieutenants, and PRENTISS was chosen. With HARDIN he went to Mexico; by HARDIN's side he fought in every battle until that gallant chieftain fell, and with his own hands he helped to dress his corpse for the last rites of humanity. Daring that entire campaign, he was the most intimate friend of that lamented officer, and the sash which he wears now at the head of his regiment is the one which HARDIN wore on that last fatal field. Not only has Col. PRENTISS acquired a character for intrepid bravery and military skill, but he is also an accomplished orator. By trade, he is a rope maker, and the knack of spinning yarns never deserts him. He came to Springfield at the head of his company, to assist in the funeral obsequies of Gov. BISSELL. Though not a professed politician. Col. PRENTISS is too well known, and too popular where known, not to be of some note. In 1860 he ran for Congress in the fifth district against MORRIS, but his party were too far in the minority to elect him. He is now very much talked of for Brigadier-General of the forces of this State.

abstract: The telegraph informs us of the arrest, as a spy, at Harper's Ferry, of a correspondent of this paper. The gentleman in question had been in attendance upon the proceedings of the Wheeling Convention, upon the adjournment of which he took the usual train upon the Baltimore and Ohio Road for Washington; ...
lead_paragraph: The telegraph informs us of the arrest, as a spy, at Harper's Ferry, of a correspondent of this paper. The gentleman in question had been in attendance upon the proceedings of the Wheeling Convention, upon the adjournment of which he took the usual train upon the Baltimore and Ohio Road for Washington; and, as usual, the train, was stopped and its passengers carefully scrutinized by the troops in possession of Harper's Ferry. Mr. UNDERHILL being easily identified, was at once placed under arrest, and is detained in custody.

abstract: Harpers' Monthly is before the public with its customary promptitude. The number for June may be characterized as unusually good, and even above the happy average which this periodical has secured for itself. "What is Best"--a keen and biting paper from the pen of CHARLES NORDHOFF, Esq., is searching as a nor'wester, and equally health-giving.
lead_paragraph: Harpers' Monthly is before the public with its customary promptitude. The number for June may be characterized as unusually good, and even above the happy average which this periodical has secured for itself. "What is Best"--a keen and biting paper from the pen of CHARLES NORDHOFF, Esq., is searching as a nor'wester, and equally health-giving. "Grace and I," is "A tale with a purpose," written by Mrs. KATHERINE S. WILLIAMS, a lady who is rapidly securing for herself a recognition as one of the most original thinkers and sparkling pencilers known in Magazinedom. We have before spoken of an admirable feature in Harpers' -- the editorial compilations of new books, by which the public are enabled to arrive at the gist of the principal new publications without being obliged to wade through an ocean of chaff. The article in the present number, Adventures in Gorilla Land, under which may be written GUERNSEY fecit, is excellent, in both style and illustration. "George Rogers Clarke" is the conclusion of a capital biographical sketch of a man whose life has never before been fairly written. In addition to what we have mentioned, the June number contains articles by FITZ JAMES O'BRIEN, T.S. ARTHUR and other well known litterateurs. One peculiarly excellent feature in it is the scarcity of love stories proper, and the greater space given to more profitable matter.

abstract: Allen's Compendium of Hardee's Tactics, is the title of a new book just published by Mr. DOOLADY, No. 49 Walker-street, compiled by H.H. ALLEN. It contains all the elementary instruction in the schools of the soldier, company and battalion, with the manual of arms, in the briefest possible space, so that the student soldier can learn all that it is immediately necessary for him to know, without having to wade through pages of matter relative to military science, which he is not prepared to grapple with or understand.

abstract: The official world of Spain seems to be enjoying at this moment a profound tranquillity. Queen ISABELLA is at Aranjuez, a magnificient royal residence, passing the first fine days of Spring, and getting ready to give birth to a fourth prince or princess. The head of the Government, O'DON- ELL, Marshal Duke of Tetuan, has just got happily through a rather severe tempest in the Cortes.
lead_paragraph: MADRID, Spain, Sunday, April 28, 1861.

abstract: "A paragraph is going the rounds of the press that our fellow-townsman, W.W. CORCORAN, had offered the Treasurer of the United States a large amount of gold in exchange for Treasury drafts on New York, and had been rudely refused, and told that he must fight for and defend his own gold.
lead_paragraph: "A paragraph is going the rounds of the press that our fellow-townsman, W.W. CORCORAN, had offered the Treasurer of the United States a large amount of gold in exchange for Treasury drafts on New York, and had been rudely refused, and told that he must fight for and defend his own gold. There is no particle of truth is the statement, nor the least foundation for the report Mr. CORCORAN made no application or offer of the kind, as he had no occasion to do so; and, if he had, there is no doubt the offer would have been gladly and courteously accepted, for it would have been an accommodation to the Treasury, in saving them the expense and risk of transporting gold from New-York to Washington, which it is constantly doing in order to meet the heavy outlay at this place. The reported reply of the Treasurer to Mr. CORCORAN is of course equally without any foundation, both as to the actual fact itself and the reason assigned."

abstract: WHAT DOES AN ARMY REPRESENT? As we have said in our last article, an army is a government by itself, having a distinct and separate code, ruled by its own laws, and acting, in a certain sense, outside and independently of the civil society in the midst of which she moves.

abstract: In the course of the rapid succession of events which press upon the minds of the American people, it becomes important at intervals to call to view some of the leading facts which mark the character of the present widely extended conspiracy against them as a nation, and against the ...
lead_paragraph: In the course of the rapid succession of events which press upon the minds of the American people, it becomes important at intervals to call to view some of the leading facts which mark the character of the present widely extended conspiracy against them as a nation, and against the Government as the constituted authority and embodied power of the nation. In this view it is not proposed to dwell on the dark picture which this conspiracy presents in its various aspects; the frequent secret conclaves in the Senate of the United States by perjured Senators, sworn to support the Constitution and the laws, premeditating and contriving a treasonable overthrow of that Constitution and of those laws; the securing the cooperation of the equally perjured Governors of several of the States, and through them the power of those States, in this treasonable project; the concerted and criminal abuse and perversion of high functions of the National Government to its destruction by the not less perjured Ministers of a weak, timid and vacillating President -- functions provided to preserve it; the designed removal of the National arms to distant scenes of anticipated rebellion by one of those Ministers, the Secretary at War; the exhaustion of the Treasury, and the deliberate assault upon the public credit by the officer charged with its care by another of those Ministers, the Secretary of the Treasury; the purloining of a mass of public securities held in trust to discharge sacred obligations for the support of Indian tribes; the robbery of trusts, the occupancy of hospitals, driving out the invalids to make room for insurgent bandits; the seizure of revenue vessels; the repeated insults to our flag; the terrorism controlling fiercely loyal citizens; the forced loans -- all these acts culminating in three great emerging facts: Foremost, an organized plot to assassinate, by a stimulated mob, the recently elected President of the United States on his quiet way, accompanied by his wife and child, to enter upon the ministration of his sacred trust. Second -- The investing and bombardment of a fort of the United States by bands of rebel troops under rebel banners, marked with a ferocity forbidden in lawful war; and third -- The dastardly murders by that stimulated mob of loyal soldiers, the sons of freedom-loving Massachusetts, moving peacefully, at the call of their President and Commander-in-Chief, to protect from assault and desecration the Capital of the United States.

abstract: The vote of Kentucky for the Union has cleared up two or three little difficulties, which were not unembarrassing. Gov. MAGOFFIN has thought proper to order the furling of all secession flags, whether standard or covering rebels, and there is no longer danger of the Ohio line affording coigns of vantage for marauding attacks upon the northwestern States. This is clear gain eminently so for Kentucky itself. While the sentiment of the majority of its people was unpronounced, the stoppage of articles of food and other necessary supplies was perfect along the frontier. Complaints arose at all points of a blockade so thoroughly effective. But the Union vote has thrown down the barriers; provisions and goods are once more pouring in from Cincinnati and New-Albany, and the momentary abstinence has left the Kentuckians a happy and satisfied people.

abstract: Of all the many maps of the "seat of war," decidedly the best is that published by A. RUMPF, No. 175 Broadway. It gives a panoramic view of the country, and enables the observer to obtain a much better idea of the situation and location of the points where the common interest now centers, than he could derive from the old-fashioned straight lines and blue and yellow dots and patches.
lead_paragraph: Of all the many maps of the "seat of war," decidedly the best is that published by A. RUMPF, No. 175 Broadway. It gives a panoramic view of the country, and enables the observer to obtain a much better idea of the situation and location of the points where the common interest now centers, than he could derive from the old-fashioned straight lines and blue and yellow dots and patches. There is one great defect, however, which we hope to see remedied in another edition. There is no scale of distances appended, and one consequently is somewhat at a loss in following the army movements, and jumping from one point to another. But, all in all, it is a capital and most timely chart, and does much credit to the gentleman by whom it was drawn and lithographed, Mr. JOHN BACHMAN.

abstract: -- A terrible disaster happened on Seneca Lake last evening, resulting in the drowning of a number of men. A steam-tug was coming down the lake, having in tow eleven canal boats, loaded with coal, and when about twelve miles from Geneva a storm came on, and the boats broke loose from the tug, and three of them went to the bottom, with their crews.

abstract: The very sudden death of Mr. CHARLES WELDEN, an attache of the NEW-YORK. TIMES, briefly alluded to in this paper yesterday, will excite the profound regrets of numerous friends. Engaged in his usual duties in this office until a late hour at night, he had retired to his longings, when he was suddenly prostrated by death while in the act of ascending the stairs. A post mortom examination ascribed the event to disease of the heart.

abstract: The world of amusement is so circumscribed now, that a man may walk from one end of it to the other without experiencing the slightest fatigue. So far as theatricals proper are concerned, it begins with Lau- ra Keene's and ends with the Water Garden.
lead_paragraph: The world of amusement is so circumscribed now, that a man may walk from one end of it to the other without experiencing the slightest fatigue. So far as theatricals proper are concerned, it begins with Lau- ra Keene's and ends with the Water Garden. For Barnum's Museum, although an excellent dramatic entertainment is furnished there, does not covet or rightly come under the title of theatrical places of amusement. At the first-named establishment the town traveler will find but little to detain him; for who is there of our healthy population that has not seen the "Seven Slaters," laughed over their terrestrial experience, longed to join them here above or there below, and desired generally to experience the sensation of existence in these estatic regions, where even a Butterfly is born in a Bower of Fern, and with a degree of pomp and circumstance which poor mortality in a colder world cannot command.

abstract: At the opening of the United States Circuit Court in Boston on May 16, Judge SPRAGUE delivered a charge to the Grand Jury, in which he defined the state of our laws with reference to the crime of piracy After citing provisions from the laws of 1790, 1820, 1825, 1846 and 1847, as to what constitutes the general crime, with the different degrees of penalty, the Judge remarks that these enactments were founded upon the clause in the Constitution which gives Congress the power to define and punish piracy. But the constitutional power to regulate commerce also affords a basis for additional penal enactments, covering all possible aggressions and depredations upon our commerce. The Judge then lays down the following important principles, the bearing of which will be sufficiently evident in the present crisis:

abstract: The latest news from Montgomery tells us that the Confederate Congress has authorized a new loan of $50,000,000, and probably before the first one of $15,000,000 has been taken. This immense sum indicates the pressing necessities of the rebels, and the manner in which the call for more money will be met, will do more than anything else to give a finishing blow to their already sinking cause.

abstract: about to make one of his periodical retirements to private life, tells his friends that they must be confident and cheerful, "and they will reach the promised land." The allusion is not happy. The Southern people already regard their exodus from the Union with much the same discontent as accompanied the wanderings of the Hebrews in the wilderness; the same fear of starvation, and the same distrust about the predicted result of their enterprise. These modern wanderers are also receiving hourly evidences that their leaders are uninspired; that they have no miracles at command to refills the empty reserviors of the treasury, or to feed a people whose corn is yet in the seed, and for whom there are no daily provision of manna. No wonder they need the assurance which the ex-Secretary kindly offers; they already so greatly need it, indeed, that it is a question of days when faith shall yield to desperation, and the engagements of COBB & Co. be presented for sudden redemption. Imposture and delusion, involving a cost so heavy, will not much longer escape close examination and exposure.

abstract: OGILVIE BYRON YOUNG, who has added to an unenviable notoriety by his intrigues with the Secessionists, is now confined in Cincinnati, charged with treason. He was arraigned before Judge LEAVITT on May 14.
lead_paragraph: OGILVIE BYRON YOUNG, who has added to an unenviable notoriety by his intrigues with the Secessionists, is now confined in Cincinnati, charged with treason. He was arraigned before Judge LEAVITT on May 14. Be pleaded "not guilty" to the indictment, and the Judge directed a special venire, to issue returnable on the 27th inst. The accused appeared to be much amused at the quaintness of the indictment, which among other things charged that the "with force and arms maliciously and traitorously did conspire consent and degree with one JEFFERSON DAVIS, one L.P. WALKER, and divers other false; traitors, to and assist, and to seduce and procure other citizens of the said United States to aid and adjust the said persons, falsely styling themselves the 'Confederate States of America.' "

abstract: We are not sure that Government is not putting "too fine a point upon it," in a recent letter to Mr. HEINECKEN, of the New-York and Virginia Steamship Company, touching the proposition of Governor LETCHER to become the purchaser, for the State of Virginia, of the steamships Yorktown and Jamestown.
lead_paragraph: We are not sure that Government is not putting "too fine a point upon it," in a recent letter to Mr. HEINECKEN, of the New-York and Virginia Steamship Company, touching the proposition of Governor LETCHER to become the purchaser, for the State of Virginia, of the steamships Yorktown and Jamestown. As we understand the matter, the chivalry I have seized the ships, and hold them as their own property by the "simple rule" and "good old plan" of plain theft. By some unaccountable sting of official conscience, Governor LETCHER is impelled to offer payment for them to the proprietors, probably in Virginia bonds, or some similar currency; but, al all events, payment of some description. The owners wrote to the State Department to inquire if it would answer for them to take the Governor's money, and the Secretary replied that the executive authorities of Virginia are "public authorities" -- that to sell them steamships to be employed in the business of overthrowing the Government of the United States would be to give them "aid and comfort" -- all of which we hold to be good sense and good law. But the Secretary goes on to say -- that "to receive money from them in payment for vessels which they have seized for those purposes, would be to convert the seizure into a sale, and would subject the party so offending to the pains and penalties of treason; and the Government would not hesitate to bring the offender to punishment."
headline: {'main': 'Treason--The Vessels Seized by Virginia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Treason--The Vessels Seized by Virginia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There cannot be much doubt regarding the position of Ex-Gov. STEWART, of Missouri. At a mass meeting in Savannah, on May 11, he declared that he would rather stand life moment under the thirty-four stars and thirteen stripes than serve to all eternity under the ill starred flag of the South; and that he would not exchange the "Star-Spangled Banner" ...
lead_paragraph: There cannot be much doubt regarding the position of Ex-Gov. STEWART, of Missouri. At a mass meeting in Savannah, on May 11, he declared that he would rather stand life moment under the thirty-four stars and thirteen stripes than serve to all eternity under the ill starred flag of the South; and that he would not exchange the "Star-Spangled Banner" and "Yankee Doodle" for all the negro "Dixiez" in creation. He had heard it said that any man that does not walk under miserable flag, with its seven plague spots and three broad snipes, is an Abolitionist, and ought to be driven from the land. He would advise those men to be very careful about laying hands on some men, or in any manner interfering with them. He was willing to be called an Abolitionists if he could be instrumental in putting "Dixie" to sleep and waking up "Yankee Doodle." Gov. STEWART denounced secession as a most damnable heresy, and declared that YANCEY, COBB and others had resorted to it simply because they had been disappointed politically. If the Secessionists should carry the State out of the Union, they could not arm the people. "How can you buy arms?" he asked. "You have neither money nor credit. You have twenty-four millions of hands quoted at forty cents. You cannot borrow a dollar, for who will lend money to a dissolving firm? If secession success in this State our public credit is a myth. We have the highest assurance from men in authority in Washington that if we remain in our present position we shall not be injured; that what will be our condition if we secede? I call on you, by the blood of your sons, by that patriotism which impelled them to do, dare and die for the flag you have just raised, to act now for the presentation of the liberties you have hitherto enjoyed."

abstract: The Boston Commercial Bulletin, of the 18th instant, says: "Business generally continues at a stand still. Those of our Northern merchants who hold Southern paper regard it as worthless. The continued difficulties with exchanges at the West, aggravate the condition of things. Arising from both these causes ones the necessity for many really sound and solvent houses to suspend temporarily, or ask extension. The difficulties in New England are fast passing away, the worst for this section having been seen; while, out of New England, the reports of our correspondents show an average decrease in failures of at least twenty-five per cent, for the past week from the week preceding."

abstract: WYANDOTTE, Kansas, Saturday, May 11, 1861. This has been a glorious day for Wyandotte. Three weeks ago to-day, just two miles below us and in plain sight of us, the Secessionists raised the black piratical flag of the Southern Confederacy. To-day, in full view of that flag, we have hoisted, one hundred and thirty feet high, the old flag of the Union. Although it was rainy and muddy, everybody seemed ...

abstract: We take it for granted that reason will one day return to the Southern mind, and the truths of history be comprehended by the Southern people. When that time shall come, they will hold a stern reckoning with the demagogues who have deluded and the leaders who have betrayed them.
lead_paragraph: We take it for granted that reason will one day return to the Southern mind, and the truths of history be comprehended by the Southern people. When that time shall come, they will hold a stern reckoning with the demagogues who have deluded and the leaders who have betrayed them. When the destruction of their material interests shall be made manifest through the agency of ocean blockades, and the obstruction of the channels of business landwards; when their cities shall be desolate, and their rivers a waste of waters; when their commerce shall be annibilated, and their trade destroyed; when their cry of sorrow for their killed in battle shall be heard in their dwellings, and the wounded and maimed of their armies shall return to their homes to languish and to die; when labor shall find no employment; when the poor shall cry for bread, and the wealthy shall be persecuted by the tax-gatherer; the inquiry will be made, whence their sufferings came, and why they should be visited wish this blight of death. No matter who shall triumph, or who suffer defeat in this unnatural struggle, the question will still be asked, What great evil was to be avoided, or what good achieved, that they should be thus required to tread the glowing plowshares with uncovered feet? Were they subjected to a tyranny that required these mighty sacrifices in defence of their rights or their manhood? Of all the governments in the world, there is none so free as that of these United States -- no constitutions so full of guarantees in favor of liberty -- no laws so just -- no institutions so liberal. In no other country on the face of the earth are human rights so effectually guarded, human freedom so perfectly protected. The principle of self government, in all its broad significance, underlies all our institutions, not in theory merely, but as a great practical fact. Every man's home every man's person, every man's property, every man's family, all his interests and all his rights, are sacredly guarded by all the guarantees which law can throw around them. Our officers are of our own choosing, selected at short periods and by our own suffrages. The laws are of our own enacting, and even our Constitution was of our own framing. We had no standing army to eat up our substance or overa we our action, for with thirty millions of people our whole military force was less than fifteen thousand. Of all the people in the world we are least burdened by taxation. There is no distinction of caste, no privileged classes, no aristocracy. Each individual is free to think, free to speak, tree to act -- all the employments of business, all the avenues to wealth, all the paths to preferment and honor are open to him; he is free to go everywhere without question and without espionage. The Courts are open to him for the adjustment of his rights and the protection of his person and his property. All the resources of wisdom, all the promptings of humanity, all the instincts of patriotism, were exhausted in framing our institutions, so as to secure to all men the broadest possible freedom compatible with human government and the necessities of civilization.

abstract: The month of April has produced its fair quota of transient excitements, which appear to have become inseparable from Mexican life. We have had a ministerial crisis, a change of cabinet, several alarms arising from reported conspiracies, several arrests of State criminals, one execution of a State prisoner, a continued chatter about the meeting of the National Congress, and a few other less important topics for conversation, which have had their brief hour and passed into, obscurity -- the only thing remaining to attract present attention being the Congress and the new Minister of Finance. The former not having plunged into the great questions of the day, for want of a quorum, remains, like all untried things in Mexico, a terror to the community. The latter, that is Senor MATA the new Minister of Finance, has made himself conspicuous by knocking on the head, for the present, a host of transactions that were quietly sliding through the palace, to the great advantage of certain specutators, but of every little advantage to the nation. Senor MATA has suspended all payments except to the military in actual service, and with the exceptions of the laments of a few interested persons we hear this step highly praised. The fact that over twenty-five millions of dollars worth of clergy propert, have been entered and disposed of since the beginning of the present year, and that notwithstanding the treasury is empty, was sufficientty alarming to justify the proceedings of the new Minister of Finance in suspending laments for a short time at least, until he could understand the actual position of the national credit. We have no doubt that before renewing payments, Senor MATA will give to the public the results of his researches in the Finance Department, and be forced to expose some rare transactions that have been made in the past four months.
lead_paragraph: The month of April has produced its fair quota of transient excitements, which appear to have become inseparable from Mexican life. We have had a ministerial crisis, a change of cabinet, several alarms arising from reported conspiracies, several arrests of State criminals, one execution of a State prisoner, a continued chatter about the meeting of the National Congress, and a few other less important topics for conversation, which have had their brief hour and passed into, obscurity -- the only thing remaining to attract present attention being the Congress and the new Minister of Finance. The former not having plunged into the great questions of the day, for want of a quorum, remains, like all untried things in Mexico, a terror to the community. The latter, that is Senor MATA the new Minister of Finance, has made himself conspicuous by knocking on the head, for the present, a host of transactions that were quietly sliding through the palace, to the great advantage of certain specutators, but of every little advantage to the nation. Senor MATA has suspended all payments except to the military in actual service, and with the exceptions of the laments of a few interested persons we hear this step highly praised. The fact that over twenty-five millions of dollars worth of clergy propert, have been entered and disposed of since the beginning of the present year, and that notwithstanding the treasury is empty, was sufficientty alarming to justify the proceedings of the new Minister of Finance in suspending laments for a short time at least, until he could understand the actual position of the national credit. We have no doubt that before renewing payments, Senor MATA will give to the public the results of his researches in the Finance Department, and be forced to expose some rare transactions that have been made in the past four months.

abstract: No army movement of special interest has occurred at Washington within the last twenty-four hours, if we except the arrival there of the New- York Eighth Regiment, which left the Relay House, yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: No army movement of special interest has occurred at Washington within the last twenty-four hours, if we except the arrival there of the New- York Eighth Regiment, which left the Relay House, yesterday morning. Absurd rumors were flying about the city, last evening, of a probable immediate attack from the Virginians, which had the effect of creating a little temporary excitement, but there was not the slightest foundation for them. The approaches to the city, in every direction, are guarded in the most complete manner, and there are now a sufficient number of troops there to render any attack of the Secessionists, in their present disorganized condition, the height of madness. Gen. BUTLER, -- who, by the way, one of our correspondents informs us, was superseded at Baltimore by Gen. CADWALLADER, because he advanced on that city without orders, -- has positively been assigned to the command at Fortress Monroe, and will leave for that post to-day, if possible. It is understood that he will make an effort to have all the Massachusetts troops concentrated there, in order that the Southern desire to meet them in deadly conflict may be gratified. Tacre is no doubt that he will soon attempt the recapture of the Federal property at Gosport Navy-yard.

abstract: The Committee having accepted Messrs. GOUPIL & Co.'s generous offer of an exhibition room, for the contributions of artists for the aid of the families of volunteers, beg to state that they have opened a Free Exhibition, at GOUPIL's, corner of Ninth-street and Broadway, of upwards of seventy pictures; that they solicit further gifts of works of art from artists, and also amateurs who desire to aid the cause; and to inform the public that on Wednesday, the 20th of May, the whole will be sold by auction at the Merchants' Exchange, at 12 M, by Mr. LEEDS, who has volunteered his services. H.P. GRAY, Chairman.

abstract: THE ENCAMPMENT AT PALACE GARDEN. abstract: We have no satisfactory intelligence regarding the election for delegates to the Convention to be held in North Carolina on May 20; but there can be no doubt that immediate Secessionists have been elected through the State. Messrs. W.W. HOLDEN, GEO E. BADGER and KEMP P. BATTLE, have been returned from Wake County by a small majority. They are moderates, but will help to carry the State out of the Union.

abstract: Mr. DAVIS, President of the Confederate States, in his recent message, bases the right and act of secession on two great grievances suffered from the Federal Government--excessive impost duties and hostility to Slavery. He tells us that as soon as the North obtained a majority in Congress, it commenced a system of high duties for the protection of its ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. DAVIS, President of the Confederate States, in his recent message, bases the right and act of secession on two great grievances suffered from the Federal Government--excessive impost duties and hostility to Slavery. He tells us that as soon as the North obtained a majority in Congress, it commenced a system of high duties for the protection of its manufactures, by which it has grown rich at the expense of the South, and that this grievance at last became so intolerable as to justify revolution and the disruption of the Government. Mr. STEPHENS, Vice-President of the Confederate States, in a speech delivered soon after the election of Mr. LINCOLN, to show that this was no cause of dissolution, proved conclusively that however wide the two sections might have been apart on this question, they were now a unit -- the two opposite States in the Confederacy, Massachusetts and South Carolina, having joined hands; and to use his phrase, "the lion had lain down with the lamb.'" Below we place side by side extracts from Mr. STEPHENS' speech, which was delivered before the Legislature of Georgia, on the 14th of Nov. last, and also extracts from the late message of Mr. DAVIS, in reference to the subject of the tariff:

abstract: Senator BAYARD publishes a lengthy address to the people of Delaware, vindicating himself from false charges against him. He declares that his visit to New-Orleans was solely on social and business purposes, which was contemplated more than a year ago, without any anticipation of the exciting events which were occuring during his visit. He made no political arrangements at Montgomery, and returned ...
lead_paragraph: Senator BAYARD publishes a lengthy address to the people of Delaware, vindicating himself from false charges against him. He declares that his visit to New-Orleans was solely on social and business purposes, which was contemplated more than a year ago, without any anticipation of the exciting events which were occuring during his visit. He made no political arrangements at Montgomery, and returned home as speedily as possible in consequence of exciting events. He alludes to the threatening mob at Philadelphia, and the courteous and judicious action of the Mayor and his police in protecting him; also to the many dangerous innuendoes concocted by his enemies at Wilmington, threatening his person. He is particularly severe on the newspapers of Philadelphia for the indirect support they gave of mob violence. In conclusion, he says he knows his duties as a citizen of Delaware and of the United States, and is conscious of no violation of them. His term of office as Senator does not expire until March, 1863, but, when satisfied that civil war, to which he is opposed,cannot be averted, and finds that the public sentiment of Delaware prefers such a result to a peaceful separation, he will resign. It will require but a few days after the assembling of Congress, for him to determine whether the last hope of peace has fled, and he can then act. He will not betray the confidence of the people or misrepresent their will, but the right of private opinion and its expression is a private right, beyond public control. He has no faith in a government of the sword, or mob, and will resist the establishment of other.

abstract: An auction sale of the flour stands on the business floor of the new Produce Exchange was commenced yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, and closed at 2 o'clock. Mr. THOS R. MINTURN, of the firm of MINTURN PATRIDGE, was the auctioneer.
lead_paragraph: An auction sale of the flour stands on the business floor of the new Produce Exchange was commenced yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, and closed at 2 o'clock. Mr. THOS R. MINTURN, of the firm of MINTURN PATRIDGE, was the auctioneer. He commenced by explaining the terms of the sale. The small moveable tables were to be sold to the highest bidder, and the price thus realized should be the annual rent. The choice of the drawers in the large tables was to be sold also to the highest bidder. Each of these drawers was to be sold subject to an annual rent of $10. The sale in each instance was to be for a term of five years from the first of the current month of May.

abstract: The Nashville Banner publishes an authorized synopsis of the speech delivered by Hon. JOHN BELL, on April 23, at the Court-house in that city, and which he claims was not correctly reported. In it he clearly advocates a military alliance or league with the Southern Confederacy, while he argued against absolute secession. Mr. BELL states that he used every endeavor to induce Mr. LINCOLN to withdraw the forces from the Florida forts, but that he gave no pledge that this was his purpose.

abstract: If the disposition to take liberty with other people's property were not attended with a disposition to take still more wanton liberties with facts, it would be easier work to deal with the people of the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: If the disposition to take liberty with other people's property were not attended with a disposition to take still more wanton liberties with facts, it would be easier work to deal with the people of the Southern States. It might not be possible to instil a profounder reverence for the rights of meum and tuum; but the excuses which are found for theft and hostility in the character of the Northerner might be swept away, and the improper acts left to stand upon their own demerits. There is no doubt, however, that the wretched conspiracy which is directing the South to its ruin, is systematically sustained by a misrepresentation of the motives of Northern men; by deliberately invented libels upon their lives and characters; by the ascription to them of principles they do not entertain, and of wishes, which, in spite of Southern convictions, have been loyally subordinated to law and order; in short, by a wicked inversion of all that goes to the foundation of Northern society, or enters into its statesmanship and politics. And the frequency and constancy with which these falsehoods are reiterated, cannot fail to deceive a people peculiarly docile to the teachings of its Press and political leaders.

abstract: Judge MASON, arrested yesterday, was released to day and sent over the Maryland line. His discharge meets with approval amongst the most judicious residents.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner has not acquired a reputation for conservative views and calm councils. At present, the movement in the Northwestern counties is entirely too provoking for any affectation of equanimity;
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Examiner has not acquired a reputation for conservative views and calm councils. At present, the movement in the Northwestern counties is entirely too provoking for any affectation of equanimity; in fact, the Examiner raves at the impunity with which the leaders of that movement are permitted to form their arrangements. "Why," it properly asks, "does not the Governor interfere to put down this sedition and servile insurrection in its incipiency? The loyal sons of Virginia demand of their Governor that steps be at once taken to have these wretches hung."

abstract: In this hour of patriotic fervor, when benevolent forethought seems to animate all who can in any way afford aid and comfort to the soldier, it might be well to make such suggestions as will systemize these efforts. The daily experience of different societies and sewing circles proves, that a saving in time and labor can be effected, as well as advantage gained on ...
lead_paragraph: In this hour of patriotic fervor, when benevolent forethought seems to animate all who can in any way afford aid and comfort to the soldier, it might be well to make such suggestions as will systemize these efforts. The daily experience of different societies and sewing circles proves, that a saving in time and labor can be effected, as well as advantage gained on all sides by comparing notes; finding out what is most needed, and what changes in model or material, the circumstances call for. There must be a head to every organization, and this head should be cognizant of all its members, and be accessible to them.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches this morning give still further indications that we are on the eve of movements of a highly important character. Immense bodies of troops are to be transported to Fortress Monroe with the least possible delay, including the entire quota from Massachusetts, and a number of regiments from New-York. The Massachusetts Fifth have already received their orders, and will go by way of Annapolis.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington dispatches this morning give still further indications that we are on the eve of movements of a highly important character. Immense bodies of troops are to be transported to Fortress Monroe with the least possible delay, including the entire quota from Massachusetts, and a number of regiments from New-York. The Massachusetts Fifth have already received their orders, and will go by way of Annapolis. The troops from the Old Bay State, now at the seat of war, are all expected by Gen. BUTLER to be in the Fortress before Thursday night next. They are, of course, much gratified at being placed under his command. Gen. BUTLER will repair to the fortress immediately -- probably to-day -- and will establish his headquarters there, as commander of the Military Department of Virginia, North Carolina and Tennessee. It seems to be doubtful now whether any attempt to retake Harper's Ferry will be made immediately. There is now no longer any danger of a descent upon the Capital from that direction, and the rebel troops now there will probably do as little damage to the cause of the Union there as anywhere. Their proceedings, at any rate, are not calculated to impress their neighbors in Maryland favorably towards them. It will be seen, from our dispatches, that the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, after patient waiting under many disappointments, have at last safely reached the centre of army operations. They arrived in Washington last evening.

For all of which the public at large, whose hourly peril, in the street, in the house, in the rain, in the steamer, -- everywhere, -- is to be violently killed by a boiler explosion, has reason to be truly thankful.

abstract: The more thoroughly foreign governments comprehend the true state of affairs in this country, the greater will be the dilemma in which they will find themselves placed.
lead_paragraph: The more thoroughly foreign governments comprehend the true state of affairs in this country, the greater will be the dilemma in which they will find themselves placed. We cannot expect their sympathy in a contest waged for the maintenance of purely Democratic or popular institutions, against an oligarchy copied, in spirit at least, somewhat after their own. Although we are resisting the aggressions of Slavery, and fighting in defence of the best features of the English constitution, we must not look for a word of encouragement or approbation from their Government. Its Minister for Foreign Affairs, when the subject was brought up in Parliament, only asked that England may not become involved in the contest, leaving it to be inferred that its merits are exactly balanced. This cold shoulder is well calculated to dampen the newly-awakened ardor of filial love to the venerable parent, which the visit of the Prince of Wales awakened in the hearts of our people. Had this sentiment been properly reciprocated, the most solid friendship might have been cemented between the two countries. But Englishmen could not penetrate the meaning of the great ovation to a Prince of the blood. They set it down to our love of excitement, our national impertinence, and in uneradicated love for monarchical institutions. England, like an aged, and not over-fond parent, happy to be rid of troublesome and restless children, sends so thought after the adventurers that for centuries have quit her shores, for colonization or mercantile adventure, but plods along in her beaten path indifferent to all that does not come within the round of daily observation and experience. Not so with the children and the descendants of those that have left her soil and her firesides. To them England stands as the type of everything cherished and endeared. From it they derive their language, literature, laws and nationality. They go to England to trace back the line of their descent, if possible, to remotest times, and visit with uncovered head, gushing heart and moistened eye the sacred spot which their ancestors consecrated with their presence, or which now holds and protects their bones. Such sentiments are the deepest and most lasting in human nature. All of us would make, if we could, a pilgrimage to the Mecca where our hearts are enshrined. This the presence of the Prince brought, in idea at least, to each one of us, and the yearnings of a lifetime for an instant had full fruition. England could not reach the sublimity of our passion nor respond with anything but churlish indifference and repulse.

abstract: SEWER ACCIDENT. Two men were instantly killed, on Saturday evening, by the caving in of a sewer bank, where they were, on Jay, near Yorkstreet. There were several other men who narrowly escaped losing their lives. The names of those killed were Owen BRACKEN and MICHAEL CLARK. Coroner HORTON held an inquest, and the Jury rendered a verdict that their death was the result of accidental causes.
lead_paragraph: SEWER ACCIDENT. -- Two men were instantly killed, on Saturday evening, by the caving in of a sewer bank, where they were, on Jay, near Yorkstreet. abstract: the capital of the Southern Confederation. The new, and insufficiently oiled machinery of government will be transferred thither from Montgomery before the heats of Summer render the latter dusty metropolis unbearable; and there the wisdom of the South will gather to consolidate the strength and sow the seed which shall hereafter spring up an abundant crop of glory. There the sublime spectacle of a free people returning to patriarchal institutions, and demonstrating their capacity for self-government by resigning the privileges of selecting their own rulers, ratifying their own constitutions, and approving their own legislation, will be exhibited to an admiring world, naturally interested in a movement so beneficial to the whole human family, with a certain necessary local and ethnological exception. There, we may enthusiastically predict, the Rome of the Western World will spread along the waters of the James, with a scheme of centralized government which Rome, even in its era of imperial splendor, could not have rivaled. These are reasonable expectations, and to be ardently indulged, provided two or three preliminaries are satisfactorily settled.

abstract: We have received from a lady of fortune, as well as of position and intelligence, in this City, the following memorandum of a proposal which she was intending to make when the present war broke out, of a plan to give the country a jubilee fifty years from the present time by the emancipation of the slaves.
lead_paragraph: We have received from a lady of fortune, as well as of position and intelligence, in this City, the following memorandum of a proposal which she was intending to make when the present war broke out, of a plan to give the country a jubilee fifty years from the present time by the emancipation of the slaves. Whatever may be its merits in other respects, it shows at all events that, while the two sections of the country are rushing to meet each other in battle array, there are some whose thoughts are turned on peace, and who are willing to make large sacrifices for its attainment, by the removal of the primary cause of our dissensions.

abstract: A letter received by a gentleman in Lawrence Mass., from one of the volunteers from that city, now at the seat of war, states that one of the members of a Massachusetts regiment, while doing duty as a picket at Annapolis, saw a rough looking personage eyeing him from behind a pile of rubbish, where he appeared to be concealed. The soldier suspected mischief, and charged upon him with his bayonet. The man appeared to be very much frightened, fell upon his knees and implored mercy, swearing that he meant no harm. He said he had heard a good deal about Massachusetts volunteers, and wanted to see them. He was conducted to head-quarters, and was finally released, nothing out of the way being found upon him, except a sheath knife, tucked into one of his suspenders, which he represented to be for mechanical purposes only. He admitted that he had been in favor of secession, but said he was for the Union now.

abstract: We learn from the Kingston Daily News of Thursday morning, that the steamer Comet collided with the schooner Exchange, on Tuesday night, and sunk in eighty feet of water. The Comet was on her passage from Kingston to Toronto and Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: We learn from the Kingston Daily News of Thursday morning, that the steamer Comet collided with the schooner Exchange, on Tuesday night, and sunk in eighty feet of water. The Comet was on her passage from Kingston to Toronto and Hamilton. After the collision the pumps were worked until the fires were out and the men stood waist deep in water. The life-boat was swung out with three lady passengers, one gentleman and the lady's maid, with as many of the crew as was deemed safe. The yawl was also launched and two hands put aboard, but a sudden blow against the steamer's guards while they were bailing threw them over, and they were lost. The small yawl was then put out and with thirteen men, in a heavy sea, put for the shore. With great difficulty and peril they reached shore at Nine Mile Point.
headline: {'main': 'Loss of the Steamer Comet on Lake Ontario.; TWO LIVES LOST.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Loss of the Steamer Comet on Lake Ontario.; TWO LIVES LOST.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: LAUNCH OF THE YACHT HRNRIETTA. The launch of this fine yacht, which was to have taken place on Saturday, at 4 o'clock, from the shipyard of Mr. HENRY STEERS, at Greenpoint, was unexpectedly retarded by the chains which held the poppets of the launching-ways, under the quarter, getting jammed fast in the ground, for want of sufficient space being excavated to clear her great depth of keel.
lead_paragraph: LAUNCH OF THE YACHT HRNRIETTA. -- The launch of this fine yacht, which was to have taken place on Saturday, at 4 o'clock, from the shipyard of Mr. HENRY STEERS, at Greenpoint, was unexpectedly retarded by the chains which held the poppets of the launching-ways, under the quarter, getting jammed fast in the ground, for want of sufficient space being excavated to clear her great depth of keel. She moved gently on the ways, for nearly fifty feet, when she fetched up, just at the water's edge, where she lays perfectly safe. She will not be finally launched, till Monday afternoon or Tuesday morning, at high-water. The Henrietta belongs to Mr. JAS. GORDON BENNETT, Jr. She is 153 tons, custom-house measurement, heavily built, and with Mr. IVE's new yacht, Hope, of 120 tons, also built by Mr. STEERS, belongs to the New-York Yacht Squadron. By a recent resolution of the yacht owners of the New York Yacht Club, their yachts were tendered by Commodore STEVENS, to the United States Government, for any purpose compatible with their capacity, and the above are the first yachts selected by the Government, and their owners have been appointed Lieutenants Commanding.

abstract: The seizure and arrival at the North of vessels which failed in the attempt to run the blockade of the Southern ports, raise questions of immediate practical importance. What disposition shall be made of them?
lead_paragraph: The seizure and arrival at the North of vessels which failed in the attempt to run the blockade of the Southern ports, raise questions of immediate practical importance. What disposition shall be made of them? In cases of the kind occuring between independent belligerent nations, all vessels thus captured become prizes, and are sold after proper reservations in behalf of Government, for the benefit of the captors. Is a domestic and internal warfare to be conducted upon precisely the same general principles as regulate an international conflict? And if so, shall these cargoes of tobacco, and future cargoes of cotton, become the property of the blockading squadron as the rewards of its vigilance?
headline: {'main': 'The Blockade in Earnest.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Blockade in Earnest.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steam transport A.H. Bowman, lying at Pier No. 13 North River, is now loading lumber and provisions for Washington City. The steam transport Anthracite is now taking in Government stores for Philadelphia Navy-yard and sailed yesterday evening. The Second Regiment, which was encamped at the Battery, 1,000 men, rank and file, left their quarters at 11 1/2 A.M. yesterday, and proceeded to Jersey City, where they took the cars for Washington City.

abstract: We may not yet fully understand the position that may have been taken by the British Government in reference to our controversy with the rebel States, but enough has been received to create a feeling of disappointment and apprehension by the manner in which this is viewed, and the proposed action in reference to it. The whole object of the rebellion was to overthrow our Government, as a means of extending the area of African Slavery. In such a contest, the antecedents of England led us to suppose that her sympathies would be on the side, not only of humanity, but of order, and that she would do nothing to encourage one of the vilest conspiracies that have disgraced the annals of history. We know that in her intercourse with nations, she has no higher standard than the low one of apparent self-interest; but we supposed that even this would incline her to our side. We know that in all the struggles for freedom, she has, without exception, ranged herself on the side of despotism, and that not only by her diplomacy, but by her military arm, sought to crush the efforts of patriots to throw off the most galling oppressions; but we put such things down to her political system, which is of a piece, and in fullest sympathy with the despotisms of the old world. We know that her governing classes have always looked with unfriendly eyes upon this country, and that the present Premier had always steadily cherished an undisguised hostility toward us, but we did not think they would seize upon the first opportunity to display an hostility to us, in our efforts to maintain a Constitutional Government, and to put a limit to the further extension of human servitude. It seems we have been mistaken. England undoubtedly imagines this country to be irretrievably rent asunder, and does not hesitate to widen the breach, by extending aid and comfort to the weaker party in the struggle. The position she takes is that the rebel States are belligerents, and not in rebellion against the constituted authorities. Several sequences result, or may be claimed to result, from this premise. In the first place, privateering is allowed, and her own Courts opened for condemnation of prizes. In the second place, the existence of the rebel government, de facto, may be accepted; in the third, all Southern ports, not actually blockaded by a competent force, are to be opened to her vessels. The object of all this is apparent. It is to secure the customary supply of cotton, and to give to the contest a semblance of equality, and thereby aid indirectly, perhaps, in breaking up the Confederacy. The precedent brought forward by England to justify her recognition of privateering on the part of the South -- the right awarded to Greece in her contest with the Turks -- is certainly not flattering to our national vanity, nor does it seem to have much applicability to the present ease. In the first place, Greece was a conquered province, -- never a part of the Turkish empire by compact or consent. She was considered by all Europe as having abundant grounds for a revolt from cruelties and oppressions, which, in an advancing civilization, were no longer to be borne. This is a well-established fact in history. Still, her independence was not acknowled for years. Neither did England recognize her right to send out privateers till she had so far destroyed the Turkish fleet as to be master of the seas. She subsequently lost much of the superiority she had gained; but when her right as a belligerent was recognized, she was believed to have substantially achieved her independence. But England proposes to recognize the rights of the South as belligerents, even before a shot (except at Fort Sumter) has been fired, -- before she has put a vessel to sea, or made single demonstration upon land. The Government of the United States is not to be put upon a par with that of Turkey. The Southern States were a component part of it by their own consent and compact. They do not allege a single act of oppression or injustice, or that a single illegal or unusual step bas been taken, or that any cause of complaint exists, except that they cannot extend Slavery and rivet more firmly its chains. The precedent cited consequently has not the slightest parallelism to our own case, and its citation is the gravest insult that could be offered to us. The resort to such an authority shows how desperate is the case by which it is sought to be sustained. In the Greek war of independence, England, whatever her motives, took sides with Christianity and Civilization, against the most odious social, religious and political despotism which at that time disgraced the face of the earth. She now proposes to ally herself with the most repulsive social and political system existing at this day, against the most perfect realization of all that is grand and noble in her own Constitution.
lead_paragraph: We may not yet fully understand the position that may have been taken by the British Government in reference to our controversy with the rebel States, but enough has been received to create a feeling of disappointment and apprehension by the manner in which this is viewed, and the proposed action in reference to it. The resort to such an authority shows how desperate is the case by which it is sought to be sustained. In the Greek war of independence, England, whatever her motives, took sides with Christianity and Civilization, against the most odious social, religious and political despotism which at that time disgraced the face of the earth. She now proposes to ally herself with the most repulsive social and political system existing at this day, against the most perfect realization of all that is grand and noble in her own Constitution.
