abstract: The question as to the disposition of European powers to embark in the American war, only becomes important when we have found them in a position to indulge it. No one of them is at this moment in such position.
lead_paragraph: The question as to the disposition of European powers to embark in the American war, only becomes important when we have found them in a position to indulge it. No one of them is at this moment in such position. A conflict such as has not been witnessed since the first years of the century, is impending over Europe, and is so universally expected to burst north at any moment, that public stocks stand permanently at the war level, and speculation confines itself to conjectures as to where the shock shall first be felt. Never were so many questions, involving so many Powers, awaiting at the same moment the arbitrament of battle. Northern Europe witnesses the gathering of Prussian armies on the Eider, prepared to adjudicate the question of the Duchies; while Denmark is straining every energy, by land and by sea, to oppose the Germans. The Czar of Russia is only momentarily restrained from realizing private arrangements with France in regard to Turkey, by the irrepressible uprising of Poland, to subdue which the best of his armies will be needed. The embers of revolt smoulder equally in Hungary, where the assassination of the popular TELEKI will doubtless fan the fire into flames of insurrection. While Austria has to watch this imminent source of danger, she is challenging, on the other side, a contest with Sardinia, upon the subject of Italian unity and the temporal authority of the Holy See. To all these issues, France is directly or indirectly a party, retaining, however, the invaluable choice of side and time, when the period comes for plunging into the great Continental melee. England, in the meantime, is in the angriest of tempers about the French occupation of Syria, and sends a fleet to watch the French army. Quite conscious that the Emperor, reversing the policy which produced he Crimean war, is pledged to a final settlement of the Eastern question by a partition of Turkey, which shall give him Egypt and a highway to India, the British Government can only follow with fretful impatience the development of the policy which is to supersede that to which, through sixty-five years, it has devoted all its military and diplomatic energies. What with its petulant remonstrances on the subject of Nice and Savoy; its arrogant correspondence about the Syrian business; and its openly declared suspicion that the Emperor is provoking a general war, merely for the purpose of expanding the boundaries of France, England is aware of the many grounds of reasonable hostility NAPOLEON III. possesses, and that a conflict may at any moment commence. Hence the haste in mustering and drilling volunteers; in building enormous defensive lines and fortifications; in vieing with France in the production of steel-plated frigates and steam gunboats; in recruiting, by the offer of war bounties, the army and navy. The two nations are, in fact, already engaged in an active war of resources, which a word of incautious language may convert into one of arms.

abstract: A gentleman who has but recently returned from Pensacola, informs the Montgomery Advertiser that, on May 10, a company of suspicious persons were arrested by a detachment of Alabama Mounted Rifles, of Wilcox county, and brought to the headquarters of Gen. BRAGG. One of them -- a fellow by the name of ANTONY -- was arrested, some time since, for supposed disloyalty to the Southern Confederacy, but was discharged on condition he would leave that portion of the country. Not being sufficiently wise to adhere to his pledge, he has been rearrested, charged with provisioning and communicating with the fleet off the harbor. Another person, in whom Gen. BRAGG formerly had confidence, has also been arrested for attempting to inform the commander at Fort Pickens of the position of the vessels which he had assisted to scuttle and sink in the channel. Both of there parties were arrested on the Perdido Bay. It is extremely probable that they have already, or will suffer death, as they were to be tried on Saturday.

abstract: Among several plans named unofficially as entering into the scheme of the campaign is the establishment of two great camps, for the concentration and education of troops.
lead_paragraph: Among several plans named unofficially as entering into the scheme of the campaign is the establishment of two great camps, for the concentration and education of troops. One of these is to be placed in the interior, convenient to the line of operations along the frontier. The other is assigned to a point on the seaboard, from which the forces when needed can readily be transported to any point on the Southern coast line, whither it is deemed proper to carry the war, either in the way of alarming, harrassing, and diverting the enemy, or of recovering possession of Federal property. The suggestion is one of great value and importance. The urgent pressure of danger having passed, there is no longer excuse for hurrying forward volunteers imperfectly equipped, provided and drilled; especially as with the large number of transports engaged by Government, and the variety of internal lines of communication, an army of 75,000 men can be transferred from the position of reserve to the seat of war within thirty-six hours. The probation of camp-life will also gauge the fitness of officers and privates for active service. Enthusiasm, courage, love of adventure, always act primarily in filling the ranks; but these, without personal health, strength, docility, and subsequent discipline, are not simply of no value, but are a deceptive and unmalleable raw material, which defeats the efforts of commanders and demoralizes the whole force. In these educational encampments, besides, the part which each subdivision of the force is to play in the operations of larger bodies, is learned as it cannot be otherwise; and ignorance of such matters is historically the source of half the reverses fresh troops experience on their earlier battle-fields. Such is an outline of the profit to be anticipated from the contemplated plan.

abstract: De Witt C. Marvin vs. Dennis Lewis. -- The plaintiff herein brings this action to recover for an assault and battery, alleged to have been perpetrated upon him on the 19th day of November, 1858. It appears from the evidence that the plaintiff is the manager of a canal-boat, and on the day in question had brought his boat into a vacant space at Coenties-slip. The defendant, who is a clerk in the employ of the American Transportation Company, who, being on the pier at the time, disputed the plaintiff's right to moor his boat at that pier. The plaintiff; however, succeeded in fastening a line to the pier for the purpose of mooring his boat, when the defendant seized a cooper's adze, severed the line, and let the boat loose. The plaintiff then seized hold of defendant by the lappels of his coat, telling defendant that he had a right there; that he paid for the privilege. The defendant, however, as testified to, struck plaintiff with the adze, and bruised him so that he was helpless for upward of three weeks. For this assault the plaintiff claims damages to the amount of $5,000.

abstract: The Macon (Ga.) Telegraph says: "From a party in a position to know we learn that the military plans of President DAVIS are but very partially disclosed even to Congress itself. The President reposes perfect confidence in the capacity and qualifications of Gen. LEE. Men are proffered in abundance; of money there is enough for the present, and if the war should be protracted, which it is believed will be the case, favorable prospects are opening for the future. The utmost confidence exists of maintaining Southern honor and independence. Mr. RUSSELL, the special correspondent of the London Times, left Montgomery amply satisfied on these points: First -- The order, docility and loyalty of our servile population. Second -- The substantial unity of our people in this struggle for independence. Third -- The utter impossibility of reconstruction "

abstract: This Regiment, under command of Mr. VON GILSA, is now complete, numbering about 900 men. The Artillery Regiment, which had been organized under Mr. LICETENHEIN, not having completed in time to be accepted by the State, decided to join the De Kalb Regiment. Col. VON GILSA returned from Philadelphia yesterday, with about 150 men, which bring the Regiment up to the number mentioned. Mr. SIMEON DRAPER and Mr. R.A. WITTHAUS, of the Union Defence Committee, inspected the Zouave Company, under Capt. DUYSING, on Sunday, and expressed the highest gratification at the proficiency of these men. The Regiment will be equipped during the week, and men of the highest authority have guaranteed that they shall be accepted and received into the regular service to-morrow. Shoes, stockings and shirts have been supplied to those requiring them, and the families of those needing assistance have been or will be provided for.

abstract: In his recent admirable speech, on the presentation of a national flag by the ladies of Frederick to the Home Guard, Mr. REVERDY JOHNSON precisely defined the true character of the revolutionary control of the Confederate States when he styled it "the usurped Government at Montgomery." An usurpation is an unjust or illegal seizure and occupation of public power and property.
lead_paragraph: In his recent admirable speech, on the presentation of a national flag by the ladies of Frederick to the Home Guard, Mr. REVERDY JOHNSON precisely defined the true character of the revolutionary control of the Confederate States when he styled it "the usurped Government at Montgomery." An usurpation is an unjust or illegal seizure and occupation of public power and property. In so far as JEFFERSON DAVIS and his associates have renounced the authority of the laws and Government to which they owe allegiance, and have taken arms to resist them, they are rebels and traitors; but this does not comprehend the whole enormity of their offence. To the crime of rebellion, they add the crime of usurpation. They have defied and plundered the United States. No less outrageously have they cozened and cheated the people of the States over which they have erected themselves into an absolute Government. A few disappointed politicians, as Mr. STEPHENS described them in his Union speech of November -- a few men who have long enjoyed public honors, and are now sacrificing the nation's welfare and the welfare of their own section "to retain official power," as they are described by Mr. JOHNSON -- now constitute an usurped Government at Montgomery, without the sanction of the popular vote of any one of the States which they claim as members of their Confederacy, unless the violent and fraudulent election in Texas can be regarded as an exception. The people of the Confederate States have been handed over to a little knot of managing and turbulent Georgia politicians by illegal and unauthorized combinations of men, in the same way in which Virginia was conveyed to JEFFERSON DAVIS, and is now claimed by him as a "Confederate" in full communion; and in the same way in which Maryland would have been conveyed, if her traitorous Legislature had succeeded in the establishment of their revolutionary Board.
headline: {'main': 'The Montgomery Usurpation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Montgomery Usurpation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The idea that Republican Government is a failure, based upon the fact of a widespread and dangerous rebellion in this country, is one of the errors that seem just now to have taken possession of a portion of the European mind.
lead_paragraph: The idea that Republican Government is a failure, based upon the fact of a widespread and dangerous rebellion in this country, is one of the errors that seem just now to have taken possession of a portion of the European mind. Whatever the result of that rebellion may be, whether it shall be crushed by the power of the Government, or be carried forward to successful revolution, the folly of regarding it as an evidence of organic weakness of Republican institutions is not the less conspicuous. There is not an empire in the world that has not at some period of its existence been convulsed by rebellion, not a throne has been erected that has not been threatened by revolution. England has not escaped. Dynasty after dynasty has been expelled from her realm; and on the Continent of Europe the Bourbon family has been driven from all their inheritances. The kingdoms of the old world are but fragments of former empires, or the aggregations of principalities at some former time independent of each other, and of the power that now rules them. And yet it does not seem to have occurred to the statesmen of Europe that these changes are an evidence that monarchy itself is a failure.

abstract: No movements have yet taken place indicating the exact intentions of the Government, though circumstances still point to Fortress Monroe as probably the first place at which active aggressive operations will commence. The rapid concentration of troops there can hardly mean anything else, though we are assured by our correspondent that the great centre of operations will still remain at Washington, and that a large body of troops will beretained there, in addition to those required merely for defence. There are now stationed there upwards of twenty-five thousand effective men, a large proportion of whom could be marched across the Potomac at a moment's notice; and it is not to be supposed that they will remain inactive while Gen. BUTLER and his command are attempting, the recapture of Gosport Navy-yard, which there appears to be little doubt they will do. A report was current at Washington yesterday, and was telegraphed to the evening papers, that an action had taken place between one of the coast guard vessels which got ashore at the mouth of the Potomac, and an armed propeller from Norfolk, in which several United States soldiers were killed and others wounded, but it proved to be entirely devoid of truth.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Mr. Garvin prosecuting for the people, Edward Corvin, indicted for grand larceny, was first tried. The facts, which were undisputed, were, that the prisoner in the morning hired a horse at a stable, giving a false place of residence for himself, and later in the day, while intoxicated, sold it for $25, which was only one-third of its value. An officer who was by at the sale made the arrest. The defence set up was, that the prisoner's condition of intoxication conclusively refuted the presumption of felonious instant in selling the horse. The jury gave a verdict of guilty, and the prisoner was sent to State Prison for three years.

abstract: A new evil has fallen upon South Carolina. She is sadly in want of small change. Half-dollars, quarters, dimes and picayunes have disappeared in some mysterious manner, while, of course, twenty dollar gold pieces, eagles and half-eagles are plenty as blackberries. When a gentleman wants a cigar or a julep, be orders the articles, lights the Havana or tosses down his eye-opener, and hands out a handful of the latter coin from his breeches pocket. But here arises a difficulty, which is altogether against the vender of these absolute necessaries of Charleston life. He can't make change; for silver coin is among the impossibilities of Charleston traffic. The purchaser can't afford to give gold-pieces for smashes and tods, even though both pockets are full. The vender can't take back his commodities, for they have gone down into cavernous depths from which there is no return. All this, it will be seen, is not so greatly to the disadvantage of the purchaser, and he is serene under the infliction. "Here," says he, "is the gold; give me my change." Now it is easy to say, "give me change," but to furnish the practical fact is altogether a different matter. If the shopkeeper is in possession of "nary a red," how is he to give change, we should like to know? It would help Charleston somewhat if the banks were a little differently situated. But with only moonshine in their vaults, and absolved from legal obligations to redeem their issues, their bills, whether of large or small denominations, may answer for lighting cigars, but are of very little practical use for any other purpose. Hence the trading community of Charleston find no relief from the Charleston banks.

abstract: A lady who left Charleston about a week ago, and who arrived here yesterday, gives some interesting particulars of the state of affairs in that city. She is an intelligent person, and is thoroughly conversant with the state of feeling among all classes. The people are enthusiastic in the belief that the conquest of the North will be an easy matter. They do not, however, expect that there is to be any more fighting in Charleston, or that South Carolina will be much burdened, by the war -- that it will be mainly borne by Virginia and other States. The feeling against any persons suspected of harboring Union sentiments is very bitter, and a great many are leaving. A man was recently shot in the leg, while escaping from a mob, he being accused of furnishing information to the NEW YORK TIMES. His name, the lady says, was COATES. After his injury he was taken into the office of Dr. PETTIGREW, but she knows nothing further of the matter. She is well-informed as to the sentiments and feelings of the free colored and slave population of Charleston. She states that they are unanimous in the desire for an insurrection, if there is the slightest chance of being successful. They all believe that the army of the North is coming down to set them free. On the plantations there is so much apprehension that the hoes, axes, and every other implement that is likely to be made available as weapons, are locked up at night, to prevent their being used by the slaves.

abstract: There is authority for saying the formidable steam battery at Hoboken, which has been so many years in the course of construction, as a defence of the harbor, requires only six weeks of industrious labor to fit her for the reception of her armament, and for active service. This finishing work should not be delayed. So long as a people is unconscious of any unfriendly feeling or hostile policy on the part of a foreign nation, it may wisely dispense with extraordinary precautions. But the moment such dangerous sentiments are discovered, its very defencelessness is the surest provocative of a war; while, it is almost tautology to say, a state of perfect defence discourages the hostile intention. New-York may be made a very Cronstadt in impregnability. It it were so, an attack -- upon the recognized principle that perfect fortifications, absolutely destructive arms, and indestructible shipping, must eventually give peace to the world -- would be the remotest of dangers. Impregnable let it be made; and when we have witnessed the completion of the Stevens Battery, we may consider what system of defences, whether BARNARD's or MORTON's, will afford us the best shelter from an enemy. There cannot be too much energy thrown into these preparations.

abstract: Mr. MURRAY, the United States Marshal for this District, on Monday afternoon proceeded, in company with Mr. KENNEDY, the Superintendent of Police, to the office of the American Telegraph Company, and seized all the telegrams on file which have been sent from the office for a year past.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MURRAY, the United States Marshal for this District, on Monday afternoon proceeded, in company with Mr. KENNEDY, the Superintendent of Police, to the office of the American Telegraph Company, and seized all the telegrams on file which have been sent from the office for a year past. The seizure was made in pursuance of orders from Washington, and similar orders, it appears, had been given, and like seizures made, simultaneously, in all the Northern cities and towns. The precise object which the Government have in view in this proceeding has not transpired, and the Government officials in this City are entirely ignorant, or non-communicative upon the subject. It is supposed, however, that an examination of the telegrams will throw a flood of light upon the history of the Southern conspiracy, the length of time it has been actively at work, the material aid it has received from the North, and the names of many of those who have been implicated in it, -- including, as is believed, some who are now professing great zeal for the Union. The seizure was made very quietly,and it was the expressed wish of the Telegraph Company, with which the Marshal coincided, that it should not be made public; but the impossibility of this soon became apparent, for before the Marshal had left the office, telegrams came flying in Boston, Philadelphia and other places, announcing that similar seizures had been simultaneously made at those offices. The telegrams are under a guard of Deputy Marshals, awaiting further orders from Washington. It is expected that agents will be deputed by Government to examine them and report the contents of such as trace any significance in connection with the Southern conspiracy. A large force will be required for this purpose, the number of telegrams at the New-York office alone, being sufficient to keep a dozen clerks busy for the next three months.

abstract: The blockade fleet presents the unprecedented spectacle of six American flag-ships, with full-rank Commodores attached, all on one squadron. The Colorado will fly the wide flag of Flag-officer MERVINE; the Wabash, that of SAMUEL MEBOER; the Cumberland, that of G.J. PENDERGAST; the Sabine, that of H.A. ADAMS; the R.R. Cuyler, (chartered,) that of F.B. ELLISON; the Mississippi, that of T.O. SELFRIDGE; and the Minnesota, "the flagship of them all," that of Commodore STRINGHAM, of New-York. The Powhatan will doubtless soon have a Flag-officer appointed to her, and the Roanoke also.

abstract: The most interesting event which occurred yes- terday at Washington was the funeral of Col. VOSBURGH, late commander of the Seventy-first Regiment, of New-York. The services were performed at the Navy-yard, where the regiment is stationed, and were attended by the President and his Cabinet, besides a great number of officers of regiments now in Washington, and of the Army and Navy.
lead_paragraph: The most interesting event which occurred yes- terday at Washington was the funeral of Col. VOSBURGH, late commander of the Seventy-first Regiment, of New-York. The services were performed at the Navy-yard, where the regiment is stationed, and were attended by the President and his Cabinet, besides a great number of officers of regiments now in Washington, and of the Army and Navy. The remains were subsequently escorted to the railroad depot, and will reach this City to-day. No army movements of special importance are reported as having taken place at the Capital. At the Relay House, on Monday night, the outposts, consisting of detachments of the Massachusetts Sixth, were fired upon, but with no effect. They immediately rallied, and made a search for their assailants, who, however, being horsemen, succeeded in making their escape. We have no definite news relative to the movements of the secession troops in Virginia, further than that they continue to make incursions across the Potomac into Maryland for purposes of plunder. Gen. BUTLER has not yet left for his post at Fortress Monroe.

lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 9th inst., Mr. W. E. FORSTER asked the Secretary of State for the Home Department, whether it was not a criminal offence against the provisions of the Foreign Enlistment Act for any subject of Her Majesty to serve on board any privateer licensed by the person assuming, as President of the Southern Confederacy, to exercise power over a part of the United States, or for any person within Her Majesty's dominions, to assist in the equipment of such privateer; and, if so, whether he would take measures to prevent the infringement of the law, either by Her Majesty's subjects, or by any agents of the President of the Southern Confederacy, who are now in England; and, also, whether any such privateer, equipped in a part of Her Majesty's dominions, would not he liable to forfeiture.

abstract: We have at last the text of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S declaration in Parliament, in regard to the policy which the British Government has decided to adopt concerning the issue of letters-of-marque by the so-called Southern Confederacy. He announces that the rebellious States are, in this respect, to be regarded by the British Government "as belligerents;" and, in the remarks with which he accompanies this declaration, quoting precedents ...
lead_paragraph: We have at last the text of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S declaration in Parliament, in regard to the policy which the British Government has decided to adopt concerning the issue of letters-of-marque by the so-called Southern Confederacy. He announces that the rebellious States are, in this respect, to be regarded by the British Government "as belligerents;" and, in the remarks with which he accompanies this declaration, quoting precedents for this action, he fully vindicates our statement, made when the telegraph first announced this debate, and which has been severely contested by correspondents, that the privateers of the South are to be recognized and protected by the British Government when they bring prizes into British ports. We repeat what we said then, that this is an unfriendly act, and if carried into practical effect, will be so regarded and treated by the Government of the United States. The British Government strains a point of international law, -- discards utterly the established principle, that none but an established nation, having a recognized national flag, and already received by formal action into the family of nations, can issue letters-of-marque against private property, -- and cites the absurdly inapplicable example of the Greek Revolution as a precedent to justify its giving the most effective aid it could possibly render to the Slave Oligarchy now in rebellion against the Government of the United States. Such an act will not pass unpunished. If it does not at once force the present Ministry to give place to better men, it will lay the seeds of hostility which will bear fruit long after the present rebellion has been extinguished.

abstract: It will be seen by an advertisement in another column, that Mr. DERBY has added to his extensive stock of books a long list of publications of peculiar interest at the present moment. It contains histories of campaigns in all ages of the world, from the wars of the Romans down to the nearer contests in which the present struggles for freedom are involved; the lives of noted generals, ...
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by an advertisement in another column, that Mr. DERBY has added to his extensive stock of books a long list of publications of peculiar interest at the present moment. It contains histories of campaigns in all ages of the world, from the wars of the Romans down to the nearer contests in which the present struggles for freedom are involved; the lives of noted generals, and dissertations upon politics, and political economy -- sciences which may be termed the remote movers of all wars. In addition to all these, Mr. DERBY'S catalogue contains a list of books devoted to Guns and Gunnery, projectiles and explosive compounds. As the quickest and surest method of killing is now the absorbing topic in all latitudes, both north and south, he will undoubtedly receive orders from every section of our belligerent country. The books are offered at war prices; and the sale continues for forty days longer, at the expiration of which period the books will be notched up again to their more common valuation.

abstract: The Committee appointed by mass-meeting of the workmen of the Brooklyn Navy-Yard, consisting of Benjamin F. Delano, Esq., Naval Constructor, Treasurer; Thomas H. Faron, Master Machinist; Romez Friganza, Master Joiner; William Merrifield, Master Smith; and John Fox, Master Blockmaker, meet every evening for the perfection of the arrangements for the distribution of the funds, (which now amount to about $5,000,) collected from the various departments, for the benefit of the families of those who have left their employment in the Yard, and volunteered their services for the defence of the Union.
lead_paragraph: The Committee appointed by mass-meeting of the workmen of the Brooklyn Navy-Yard, consisting of Benjamin F. Delano, Esq., Naval Constructor, Treasurer; Thomas H. Faron, Master Machinist; Romez Friganza, Master Joiner; William Merrifield, Master Smith; and John Fox, Master Blockmaker, meet every evening for the perfection of the arrangements for the distribution of the funds, (which now amount to about $5,000,) collected from the various departments, for the benefit of the families of those who have left their employment in the Yard, and volunteered their services for the defence of the Union.

abstract: DEAR SIR: Your letter reached this office while I was in Macon. I now reply that my proclamation applies alike to each and every debt due each and every citizen of any one of the so called Free States, with which we are at war. The law of nations makes no distinction, and it is not for the debtor here to decide that one of the citizens of a hostile State is our friend and another our enemy. It is the duty of the debtor to withhold payment till the end of the war in every case where the creditor is a citizen of a State which maintains a hostile attitude toward the Confederate States, of which Georgia is a member.

abstract: Certain "Union men," so called, in some of the Southern States, have taken strong ground against secession, and have even proceeded to arm and organize themselves in aid of the Government. At the same time they announce that they do so simply to protect their own homes and to maintain, as it were, a neutrality between the South and the North, giving it to be understood that they will oppose an equal resistance to either party attempting to invade or march through their territory.

abstract: The pretty story of Gen. BUTLER's African nativity was, it seems, improperly credited to the New-Orleans Picayune; the Philadelphia Press now claiming the authorship, with an admission that it was intended as a burlesque upon Southern representations of Northern men and matters, and was, therefore, jocosely ascribed to the New-Orleans papers. This is an act of desirable justice to the Picayune. But the Press, from the incident, will probably learn that irony and badinage are the most hazardous of weapons for promiscuous use. Where they gratify and amuse a few, they confound many, and to the larger number they are as unintelligible as the Vedas. An illustration to the point is before us in a note mildly suggesting that we are probably misinformed in stating Gen. B.F. BUTLER to have been a candidate for Vice-President in 1848, as, if the writer's memory serves him, it was another BUTLER, whose initials were, he thinks, W.O., and who lived in Kentucky. Our correspondent is not only literal, but literally correct.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 6th inst., Mr. GREGORY said that in consequence of the news which had arrived from America since he had given notice of his question on this subject, he had been obliged to alter its wording. Mr. LINCOLN had proclaimed a blockade of the ports of the seven Confederate States, and therefore it was necessary to ask a question with regard to two other States which were in an attitude of hostility to the United States, although they did not belong to the South. He had to ask the noble lord the Foreign Secretary -- 1st. Whether any attempt of the Government of the United States to levy Federal dues off foreign vessels outside the ports of North Carolina and Virginia before such vessels break bulk would not be an infringement of international law, and, if so, whether our Minister at Washington had received instructions to that effect? 2d. Whether the Government of the united States had been informed that a blockade of any port of the Southern Confederated States, unless effective, will not be recognized? 3d. The Government of the United States having refused to relinquish the belligerent right of issuing letters-of-marque, the seven Southern Confederated and Sovereign States having become to the United States a separate and independent foreign Power, whether Her Majesty's Government recognizes the right of the President of the Southern Confederacy to issue letters-of-marque, and, if so, whether our Minister at Washington had been notified to that effect? [Hear, hear.]
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 6th inst., Mr. GREGORY said that in consequence of the news which had arrived from America since he had given notice of his question on this subject, he had been obliged to alter its wording. Mr. LINCOLN had proclaimed a blockade of the ports of the seven Confederate States, and therefore it was necessary to ask a question with regard to two other States which were in an attitude of hostility to the United States, although they did not belong to the South. He had to ask the noble lord the Foreign Secretary -- 1st. Whether any attempt of the Government of the United States to levy Federal dues off foreign vessels outside the ports of North Carolina and Virginia before such vessels break bulk would not be an infringement of international law, and, if so, whether our Minister at Washington had received instructions to that effect? 2d. Whether the Government of the united States had been informed that a blockade of any port of the Southern Confederated States, unless effective, will not be recognized? 3d. The Government of the United States having refused to relinquish the belligerent right of issuing letters-of-marque, the seven Southern Confederated and Sovereign States having become to the United States a separate and independent foreign Power, whether Her Majesty's Government recognizes the right of the President of the Southern Confederacy to issue letters-of-marque, and, if so, whether our Minister at Washington had been notified to that effect? [Hear, hear.]

abstract: The State has at length furnished the equipments long waited for by Col. DURYEA's regiment, and it will start for Virginia probably on Thursday. Maj. Gen. DIX, in command of the division to which the Advance Guard is attached, told one of the Colonel's staff on Saturday that Fortress Monroe would be the destination of the corps. There probably it will encamp without the walls, for the fortress is already full of soldiers, and doubtless, if there is a movement upon Norfolk and towards Richmond, the guard will be in advance. If It does not give a good account of itself in the stirring scenes which -- the indications are -- will speedily be enacted there, it will not be because it has not the elements which achieve brave deeds, and the commandant who knows how to control and direct them. The thousands of visitors who have recently inspected the troops are unanimous in the declaration that they are true soldiers -- hardy, reliable, well informed men. It is the stuff that veterans are made of. The note of busy preparation has sounded at Fort Schuyler for a day or two. The old-fashioned muskets have been packed up and sent back to the State authorities, and new rifled muskets from Springfield are to be placed in the hands of the men to-day. It is not entirely certain that they will not to-day start for the seat of war. On their way thither they will march through New-York City, landing at Fourteenth-street, East River, and proceeding around Union-square and down Broadway to the place of embarkation. They have multitudes of friends here, and, doubtless, the occasion of their departure will be that also of a memorable ovation. The peculiarity of their uniform will make the display a novelty. Too much must not be expected of soldiers, who, a few weeks ago did not know the muzzle of a musket from the tail-band, but from what we have seen at the Fort, we are satisfied that military men will be surprised at the precision of their movements already.

abstract: The schooner Ike Marvel, of Norwich, Conn., from Boston bound to Philadelphia, was totally destroyed by fire on the 19th inst., at 2 A.M., when about fifty miles off Montauk. The fire originated by the bursting of a camphene lamp in the cabin. The captain and crew were taken off by the schooner Balloon, from Bangor bound to Philadelphia.

abstract: If the necessity of perfecting the Southern blockade has not been recognized heretofore, it must be so in the light of our European advices. The ports must not only be closed, but sealed hermetically. There is no time for laxity or imperfect measures. With a small but pestilent enemy eager to get out, and a large and rapacious neutral who avows his purpose to get in, the only alternative of their success lies in the erection of a barrier hopelessly impassable to both.
lead_paragraph: If the necessity of perfecting the Southern blockade has not been recognized heretofore, it must be so in the light of our European advices. abstract: The defeat amongthe Aldermen of the resolution withdrawing the Corporation printing from the Daily News and the Day Book is recklessly ascribed to the machinations of Mayor WOOD. Nothing could be more unjust. The Mayor has manfully placed himself on the Union platform; has demanded the punishment of the traitors who would overthrow the Government and desecrate the National flag; and no doubt, in the fullness of his loyal sentiments, as heartily detests the sedition of the News, as the most burning patriot within the municipal limits, and would spare no proper means of silencing it. We can believe nothing less of his Honor after his stirring and patriotic eloquence at Union-square, and his recommendations of Corporate munificence to the popular cause. If these unreflecting censurers had named Mr. BENJ. WOOD, (who really owns the paper, as his published certificate attests,) instead of his brother; and had asserted that he compelled the "Ring" to forbear by threats of disclosing the particulars of the Hackley Street-cleaning contract, there would have been no more truth, perhaps, but certainly much more probability in the invention.
lead_paragraph: The defeat amongthe Aldermen of the resolution withdrawing the Corporation printing from the Daily News and the Day Book is recklessly ascribed to the machinations of Mayor WOOD. Nothing could be more unjust. The Mayor has manfully placed himself on the Union platform; has demanded the punishment of the traitors who would overthrow the Government and desecrate the National flag; and no doubt, in the fullness of his loyal sentiments, as heartily detests the sedition of the News, as the most burning patriot within the municipal limits, and would spare no proper means of silencing it. We can believe nothing less of his Honor after his stirring and patriotic eloquence at Union-square, and his recommendations of Corporate munificence to the popular cause. If these unreflecting censurers had named Mr. BENJ. WOOD, (who really owns the paper, as his published certificate attests,) instead of his brother; and had asserted that he compelled the "Ring" to forbear by threats of disclosing the particulars of the Hackley Street-cleaning contract, there would have been no more truth, perhaps, but certainly much more probability in the invention.

abstract: Secession has now come to an imperative halt. Every State which could be cajoled or coerced into leaving the Union, has now gone. Maryland and Delaware, by the will of their people and by the necessities of their position, cleave to the old Republic; Missouri is riveted to it by the triple bolts of her geographical position, as well as by the legions of her loyal sons, and by all her present interests and her hopes of future greatness; while Kentucky has just again pronounced for adhesion by a vote so overwhelming that it can hardly be circumvented by the legerdemain of the most adroit conspirators.

abstract: Judge CADWALADER devoted a part of his charge at the opening of the United States district Court in Philadelphia, on May 20, to a consideration of the law of treason. He showed how the Government had become involved in a war, which it was its duty to prosecute to the end, by the treschery of those who should have been its supporters. Any person carrying arms against the Government was of course guilty of treason, so was any one who accepted a commission in the service of the rebels, who attempted to furnish them information, though it did not reach them.

abstract: Harbor Police-boat No. 6, coxwain NESBITT, yesterday morning at 7 o'clock, discovered the sloop Times in the North River, deeply laden, and looking very suspicious. Upon boarding her, she was found to have 150 kegs powder snugly stowed. The parties having the sloop in charge were arrested, and sent to the Station-house for examination, while the vessel remains in the hands of the Police.

abstract: The state of affairs in the United States has compelled Ministers to strengthen the squadron under the command of Sir ALEXANDER MILNS; and on Friday the Challenger, a powerful screw corvette, mounting 22 guns; the Rinaldo, a screw aloop, mounting 17 guns; and the Driver, a paddle-wheel steam sloop, mounting six guns, were commissioned, and in all probability will be dispatched as soon as ready to the North America and West India station.
lead_paragraph: The state of affairs in the United States has compelled Ministers to strengthen the squadron under the command of Sir ALEXANDER MILNS; and on Friday the Challenger, a powerful screw corvette, mounting 22 guns; the Rinaldo, a screw aloop, mounting 17 guns; and the Driver, a paddle-wheel steam sloop, mounting six guns, were commissioned, and in all probability will be dispatched as soon as ready to the North America and West India station. In the meantime, other vessels now ready for sea will be ordered off at once to protect British interests. With reference to these movements, the London Observer says:

abstract: Military reconnoisance has been pushed from here inside of the Virginia lines, at two points since yesterday, viz.; Sheppardstown, ten miles above Harper's Ferry, and Williamsports, twenty-three miles above. At Sheppardstown there are three hundred men and three brass pieces. Pieces of artitlery are stationed on the Virginia side of the river command- ...
lead_paragraph: Military reconnoisance has been pushed from here inside of the Virginia lines, at two points since yesterday, viz.; Sheppardstown, ten miles above Harper's Ferry, and Williamsports, twenty-three miles above. At Sheppardstown there are three hundred men and three brass pieces. Pieces of artitlery are stationed on the Virginia side of the river commanding the approaches to the bridge, also the approaches to the town. Part of the soldiers are in citizens' dress, and part are uniformed in common oil skin caps with brass eagle front; the videttes has been pushed over the Maryland side. The Maryland outpost is stationed near the house of a Mr. DOUGLAS, a Secessionist preacher. There are a dozen tents the other side of the bridge. The soldiers look like common countrymen. About twenty men stood lounging about the bridge as a guard. The main body of the troops are quartered in the town.

abstract: About 2 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the three-story stone building, No. 29 Pine-street, occupied by the Surveyor of the Port. The fire originated among some waste paper upon the ground floor, destroying the best of the first story, while the upper ones suffered considerably from the smoke and water. The firemen, however, succeeded in speedily extinguishing the flames.

abstract: Matter of the Probate of the Will of Augusta J. Blankman. -- The testimony in this case again proceeded, after nearly a month's postponement, in consequence of the absence of the Surrogate. The contestants introduced three or four witnesses to impeach the character of Mr. Kirkpatrick, one of the main witnesses for the will, all of whom made pretty hard statements respecting the general character of Mr. Kirkpatrick. Some of them would not believe him under oath, and others testified that very serious charges had been made against him in times past. A nol. pros., however, was entered in the worst case.

lead_paragraph: A letter from Toulon says: "The civil which seems on the point of breaking out between the disunited States of America is about to open for the French arsenals a market for exportation which certainly was not foreseen. It is stated that American agents havecome to France to purchase arms and military equipments, which the storehouses of the State will be only too glad to get rid of."

abstract: We see it stated that the Medina Union Volunteer Company, including all the officers and men, have taken a pledge to abstain from the use of spirituous liquors during the term of their enlistment. We are glad to hear this. It is an example worthy of all praise, and one which it would be well for every company to follow. Temperance is a great thing everywhere, and under all circumstances, but nowhere else in the world is its influence more beneficial than upon the soldier, amidst the changes and vicissitudes of camp life. Intoxicating liquors, even if procured in a pure state, do a great deal of mischief by their use, but the adulterated stuff sold in the neighborhood of camps, is rank poison. It disables more men than the weapons of the enemy. It creates more disease, prompts to more insubordination, occasions more disaffection with the service, than all other causes combined. Habits of sobriety are quite as essential to the soldier as to any other citizen. They give calmness to the hours of repose, and vigor and strength in time of exertion. The weary marches, the long watches, and the fierce struggle of the battle-field, all require that his energies shall not be wasted by the use of poisoning stimulants, which undermine the constitution while they demoralize the man.

By advice of counsel they pleaded guilty to an endeavor to make a revolt, and Judge SMALLEY, then sitting in the ...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. James Morris and twenty-one others. -- This matter came up on habeas corpus. The men were part of the crew of the ship Staghound, and were indicted for a revolt and mutiny on board the ship in Angler Roads. By advice of counsel they pleaded guilty to an endeavor to make a revolt, and Judge SMALLEY, then sitting in the Court, on the 26th January last, sentenced them to be imprisoned at hard labor -- Morris for five years, four others for two years and six months each, and the rest for a year and a half each.

abstract: -Our Paris correspondent announces the immediate return to the United States of Col. FREMONT, who leaves his most important negotiations with the French Government, in regard to the Mariposa mines, to take his part in defence of the Union. It was his intention, we learn, to leave by the Persia, but having been detained, he sailed by the steamer of the 18th. His services had already been tendered to the President in a letter, which must have been peculiarly gratifying; for, in declining the high positions tendered him before his departure for France, he had given reason to believe that his detention abroad would be necessarily protracted. It will be with a sense of relief and of augmented confidence the country will hear of this gallant and experienced officer sharing in the military counsels at Washington.
lead_paragraph: -Our Paris correspondent announces the immediate return to the United States of Col. FREMONT, who leaves his most important negotiations with the French Government, in regard to the Mariposa mines, to take his part in defence of the Union. abstract: We have kept no accurate count of the number of times the clerks of the several departments at Washington have been brought to book, and required to swear their fidelity to law and Constitution, but a figure something less than twenty will probably cover it. The process has just been repeated. Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT himself, of whose secret design to join the enemy there is as much reason to entertain fears, as that Mount Washington will go over to the Black Hills of Carolina, has repeated his solemn evidence of loyalty we hardly dare say how often. This is all very well, and in itself quite harmless. But of what use? All servants of the Federal Government inaugurate their official career by taking the oath of allegiance. The clerks who are now sworn and resworn, swore quite as terribly before they were ministerial to the treason of FLOYD, or under COBB arranged the details of rebellion. The declared purpose of the oath is to distinguish the treasonable from the loyal; but the oath when readministered only proves by the number of traitors it brings to light, how worthless its previous administration must have been. Besides, the one quality that more than any other characterizes the secession business, is its disregard of the most sacred compacts, obligations and oaths. The President of the Southern Confederacy, and nearly all of his advisers and aiders, passed from the service of the Union to their present work, with the oath of fidelity fresh on their lips. The rebel army is officered with men who had bound themselves by the same sanction; the whole machinery of rebel government is composed of officials similarly perjured. Nor is this accidental. The very germ of secession is the superiority of State over Federal authority; an ample power of absolution residing in the former to acquit its citizens of all allegiance to the latter. This principle is announced as the dictum of the rebel judiciary; so that the spy who chooses to take the monthly oath tendered him as a Federal servant, has legal warrant for believing he is fulfilling his duty as a subject of the Montgomery usurpation. A handful with tender consciences, refusing to accept this sort of casuistry, may resign, and may leave twice their number to communicate all the transactions of the Government they betray to the one they serve. The better plan is, evidently, to clear out the various bureaus thoroughly, leaving no one whatever found in them on the 4th of March. And then if their places be filled by competent men, regardless of party, we shall have some chance of business being conducted with the necessary secrecy. Under the present system, the Southern spy is probably communicating more knowledge of the plans of Government and the army to the leaders of Montgomery, than reaches the entire New-York press.

abstract: LONG ISLAND RAILROAD INCREASED FACILITIES FOR TRAVEL. The change of termini of this road from the foot of Atlantic-street, Brooklyn, to Hunter's Point, in Queen's County, has already produced a marked increase in the travel over the road, because of the increased facilities for travel afforded to persons ...
lead_paragraph: LONG ISLAND RAILROAD -- INCREASED FACILITIES FOR TRAVEL. -- The change of termini of this road from the foot of Atlantic-street, Brooklyn, to Hunter's Point, in Queen's County, has already produced a marked increase in the travel over the road, because of the increased facilities for travel afforded to persons residing or doing business in the upper portion of the City of New-York. By the new route, passengers are taken on boats from James-slip and Thirty fourth-street, New-York, and landed in the depot at Hunter's Point, where steam cars are at will entered, and the former tedious passage at a snail's pace through the streets of Brooklyn is avoided. The new route has been operated for about three weeks, and the receipts for passengers greatly exceed that of any previous year for the same period of time. A large number of people now pass over the road daily in search of boarding places for the Summer, or selecting permanent locations, and the indications now are that the travel over the road this season will be larger than ever before.

abstract: A most important item of army news has just reached us from the territory of New-Mexico. A distinguished officer has favored our Military and Naval Reporter with a report of the new signal experiment, about which so much interest has been felt in the service.
lead_paragraph: A most important item of army news has just reached us from the territory of New-Mexico. A distinguished officer has favored our Military and Naval Reporter with a report of the new signal experiment, about which so much interest has been felt in the service. Now, when the desertion of elevated officers has partially put our Generals at the enemy's mercy, in regard to signalizing, this triumph of science will be additionally valuable. Major MYER, of the army, some months since announced the discovery by himself of a new system of military signals, which would, in a great measure, revolutionize the management of modern forces. The signals are made by means of a flag attached to a pole, from twelve to sixteen feet long. The different movements which the flag is made to go through represent numbers, which in their turn represent letters of the alphabet. The letters, of course, are combined into words that lead out the message. By the intervention of the numbers, none but the officer who directs the flag-man, and those who have been previously informed of the arrangement of the system, can understand the language of the flag, which flag is moved in three directions, to right, left, and front. This is done by soldiers who are especially drilled for the purpose, and who in the trial, managed the bunting with astonishing accuracy. For night signals, torches are substituted for flags; otherwise, the signals are similar to those made in the day time. All the implements necessary for the service, can be embraced in a small packet, can be transported from point to point by a a single man, and be put in readiness for use in fifteen minutes.

abstract: The vital qualities necessary in cannonmetals are strength to resist the explosion of the charge, and hardness to endure the bounding of the projectile along the bore, and in case of the rifle bore, to resist the excessive ...
lead_paragraph: The vital qualities necessary in cannonmetals are strength to resist the explosion of the charge, and hardness to endure the bounding of the projectile along the bore, and in case of the rifle bore, to resist the excessive wear of the projectile in the grooves. All the metals employed have their defects. Cast iron is quite tenacious, if a sufficient weight is employed, and tolerably hard, but its comparative elasticity (an important element of strength) is so small that its tenacity is invariably destroyed after a certain number of applications of the straining force. The difficulty of obtaining sound castings, by reason of the unequal shrinkage of the metal, is unfavorable -- so much so that the strongest "high" iron, by its superior contraction, does not, as a rule, make so strong a gun as a metal in itself weaker. The great weight of cast-iron, for a given strength, has confined its use generally to heavy cannon for siege and sea-coast purposes. Bronze -- a more tenacious compound -- is prepared for portable guns, and this, in turn, has its serious defects. Its density (an element of strength in cannon-metals) and tenacity are considerable, but its softness unfits it, for reasons already stated, for long service, particularly when rifled. And its cost is considerably greater than that of cast or wrought iron, or semi-steel -- that is, steel made directly from the pig iron. Wrought iron has a tensile strength double that of the best cast-iron, and is much more elastic, but somewhat softer. Authorities generally unite in stating that it was. when most in use, an provement on cast-iron, but the difficulty of producing large masses sound and homogeneous, has prevented its extensive introduction. The celebrated Armstrong gun, and other modern "built-up" cannon are, perhaps, more durable, and certainly stronger than any solid piece can be made, owing to the difficulty of forging or casting large masses of uniform strength, in the present state of the art; but it is generally conceded that the same expense devoted to a larger number of cheaper guns will be more effective in the long run.

abstract: There is a Board of Chief Engineers in session at the Navy-yard for the examination of candidates for admission to the Engineers' Corps of the Navy. The Board consists of Chief Engineers WILLIAM H. SHAOK, BENJAMIN F. GARVIN and A.C. STIMERS.
lead_paragraph: There is a Board of Chief Engineers in session at the Navy-yard for the examination of candidates for admission to the Engineers' Corps of the Navy. The Board consists of Chief Engineers WILLIAM H. SHAOK, BENJAMIN F. GARVIN and A.C. STIMERS. They are authorized to examine candidates for admission to the grades of First and Second Assistants, without any application to the Secretary of the Navy on the part of the candidate. Candidates for the grade of Third Assistant must apply to the Secretary of the Navy, as usual, for permission to appear before the Board. The following are the regulations which govern the Board in their examination of candidates:

abstract: It is evident that the British Government is taking a view of the state of affairs on this side of the water that may involve that country in results quite as calamitous as any that can happen to ourselves. We are greatly disappointed at the want of recognition of the principles and objects for which we are fighting ...
lead_paragraph: It is evident that the British Government is taking a view of the state of affairs on this side of the water that may involve that country in results quite as calamitous as any that can happen to ourselves. We are greatly disappointed at the want of recognition of the principles and objects for which we are fighting and our pride and sensibility are offended at being told by the great organ of the nation "that there is no principle whatever in the contest, only a mere sectional struggle for aggrandizement -- that the whole North is in war-paint, brandishing the tomahawk and scalping-knife, and that men are still living to see the fall of the Great Republic that witnessed its formation." We have no right to complain of a want of sympathy, although a reciprocal feeling of good-will and mutual respect is a great bond of peace. But when a foreign Power takes a position that encourages a local rebellion, and gives a national dignity to a purely domestic quarrel, then it becomes us to see how we can defend ourselves, and exact, by virtue of our strength and position, what we had a right to expect from courtesy, and from those sentiments of humanity and attachment to Constitutional Government which have been the boast of England.

abstract: The greed of the Common Council admits of no holidays. It might be supposed the spectacle of the City, with its business suspended, straining every nerve and offering every dollar for the restoration of order and peace, would shame them into some show of decency and some affectation of economy, but a reference to the official proceedings, and the columns of corporation advertisements, will show how vigorously the business of plundering the Treasury with needless contracts and monstrous jobs is prosecuted. These crimes against the Union movement, -- for they are fully equivalent to treason, in that they lend aid and comfort to the enemy, by robbing the people of the means to carry on the war, -- are among the accounts which, when the conflict is over, will be brought to a dangerous settlement. The reaction will make the reckoning somewhat sterner than the thieves anticipate.

abstract: Our news from the Federal Capital this morning is of a highly important nature. It discloses the fact that the Government have struck an effectual blow at the rebels in a quarter from whence they least expected it, that their privateering schemes ...
lead_paragraph: Our news from the Federal Capital this morning is of a highly important nature. It discloses the fact that the Government have struck an effectual blow at the rebels in a quarter from whence they least expected it, -- that their privateering schemes are entirely frustrated, and that the aid which they have looked for from England, France, and other European nations, in raising our blockade of the Southern ports, will not be forthcoming, -- in a word, that the leaders in the wicked attempt to overthrow the Government have been foiled at every turn by the superior diplomacy of the Administration. On the 24th of April last, Secretary SEWARD sent instructions to our Ministers in Europe to notify the parties to the Treaty of Paris that the United States Government had accepted the first point of the Treaty, which abolishes privateering. This will prove an effectual bar to all the schemes of the Jeff. Davis Government in that direction. The acceptance of this point makes the U.S. Government a party to the entitre reaty, the fourth point of which recognizes all blockades which are made effectual, -- so that no interference can take place in our blockade of Southern ports, provided we enforce it with a sufficient number of vessels. We received intelligence by the Persia, also, that the efforts of the rebel agents in Europe, who have been sent over for arms, have been entirely unsuccessful. They had found it impossible to obtain anything whatever upon the securities offered by them.

abstract: The Regiment, known as the Brooklyn Phalanx, was not inspected yesterday, because the officers had not sufficient notice to enable them to get their men together from different parts of Long Island. The inspection is now ordered to take place on Friday next, and all who have signed the muster roll, are requested ...
lead_paragraph: The Regiment, known as the Brooklyn Phalanx, was not inspected yesterday, because the officers had not sufficient notice to enable them to get their men together from different parts of Long Island. The inspection is now ordered to take place on Friday next, and all who have signed the muster roll, are requested to report themselves on or before that day. Now that the Fourteenth Regiment has left for the seat of war, the Plymouth Church Society, it is understood, have taken the Brooklyn Phalanx under its special protection, and will do all that it is possible to secure a proper outfit for the command. A son of the Rev. Mr. BEECHER will go with the Phalanx as Adjutant.

abstract: -Very general, and, we fear, well-grounded complaints and apprehensions exist of great corruption and wastefulness in contracts for our Army and Navy. We have heard of several cases of direct jobbery, and of most improvident transactions, which will enormously swell the expenses of the war. We wish to say nothing to discourage the spirit of enthusiasm which exists, but it is evident that we shall need every penny we can get, even if honestly expended. Now that the first gush of enthusiasm is over, confidence is to be maintained only by a scrupulously rigid and correct administration of affairs. Our people will bear any burdens, so long as they are seen to contribute to success, but will become restive and impatient the moment they see a large per centage of their money going in the shape of commissions to party favorites or political sycophants. The Government should at once look to this matter, or it may find itself compromised, and its efficiency and power greatly weakened.

abstract: The Mayor of Memphis has addressed a note to a firm of cotton brokers, assuring them that the people of that city have no thought of interfering with the transmission of cotton by any route to marker, but by whomsoever owned or purchased, or whatever the direction it might take, the rights and interests of all parties, both North and South, would be scrupulously respected, and that "a Committee of Safety" has been appointed to prevent the interference of any lawless individuals or combinations. Assuming such a determination to express the feelings of the producers of cotton throughout the South, we take it that what a people are careful to produce, they will eagerly sell, we shall have no lack of cotton offered to us to send to market over our interior routes, on the blockade of Southern ports. The question is narrowed to the point, whether we will allow its exportation through any route, not that it will not be raised and offered for sale. Consumers in England and elsewhere should lose no time in ascertaining the views of our Government upon this important matter.

abstract: James Cassin vs. Laurence Delany. -- This action is brought to recover on the ground of an alleged false arrest and imprisonment. The plaintiff, as appears from his own testimony, was, in November, 1855, in the employ of the defendant's wife as the collector of her rents and as clerk in her store. About this time, at the instigation of the defendant, he was arrested on a charge of embezzling $15, and brought before a magistrate on that charge. The magistrate, not thinking the charge sufficiently well established, discharged the plaintiff from custody, whereupon he brings this action. On the trial he testifies that on a certain day in November, a bill came into the store to be discharged. It was a bill due for paper; that not being sufficient funds in the drawer to pay the bill, plaintiff recollecting that a Mrs. King still owed certain rent to Mr. Delany, went to see her, and collected $95; with $15 of this he paid, the bill, returning the other to Mrs. Delany and her husband, and, as plaintiff says, telling them what he had done. Shortly after this, at the instance of the defendant, he was arrested for an alleged embezzlement of the $15.
lead_paragraph: James Cassin vs. Laurence Delany. -- This action is brought to recover on the ground of an alleged false arrest and imprisonment. On the trial he testifies that on a certain day in November, a bill came into the store to be discharged. It was a bill due for paper; that not being sufficient funds in the drawer to pay the bill, plaintiff recollecting that a Mrs. King still owed certain rent to Mr. Delany, went to see her, and collected $95; with $15 of this he paid, the bill, returning the other to Mrs. Delany and her husband, and, as plaintiff says, telling them what he had done. abstract: One of the most fantastic dreams indulged in by the Secessionists has been that California would undoubtedly unite her fortunes and her destiny with theirs that they had but to shake the tree, and the golden apple of the ...
lead_paragraph: One of the most fantastic dreams indulged in by the Secessionists has been that California would undoubtedly unite her fortunes and her destiny with theirs -- that they had but to shake the tree, and the golden apple of the Pacific would drop into their hungry mouths. Thus, with the possession of New-Mexico, Arizona and the Indian Territory, all of which the Confederate "Committee on Territories" seem to regard as now under their jurisdiction, they flattered themselves that their domain would extend from ocean to ocean along its whole breadth, and their "institution" find ample scope and verge enough for expansion for centuries to come. The splendor of the prize, both in a geographical, political, commercial, and above all, in a monetary (COBB comprehends that) point of view, certainly rendered it worthy of a long and desperate effort to win it. Hence, failing to clutch the whole of California ten years ago, a persistent effort has been making ever since to secure the division of the State, and the establishment of Slavery in the Southern half. Being foiled in this also by the Californians, the disunion conspirators have latterly tried to make use of certain local broils of bygone feuds, of party affinities, and also of the disaffection engendered by the neglect of California interests by the General Government; and hoped that by suddenly precipitating the State into confusion, and proclaiming a Pacific Republic, either the whole of the State, or, at all events, the Southern half of it, would gently but surely glide into their hands. California, moreover, had been so long represented, both in the Senate and House, by politicians of the ultra Pro-Slavery school, who considered themselves as possessed of an absolute control of the State, that it was supposed the secession scheme had only to be boldly attempted to secure its success.

abstract: The most exciting trot of the season took place on Tuesday, over the Fashion Course, Long Island, between Flora Temple and Princess -- mile heats, best 3 in 5 to wagons, for $500. There were between 4,000 and 5,000 spectators present, and the betting was very heavy. Flora had the call, at $100 to $25, and her backers, having great confidence in her powers of endurance, offered their money freely. Flora won easily in three straight heats, which surprised many turfmen who had made bets on time, anticipating extraordinary results. The weather was delightful, and the track was in good condition. The following, is a summary of the race:

abstract: When the present Emperor of France was a candidate for Imperial honors, and submitted his claims to the purple to the suffrages of the French people, he surrounded the voting booths with his troops, and guarded the sacred ...
lead_paragraph: When the present Emperor of France was a candidate for Imperial honors, and submitted his claims to the purple to the suffrages of the French people, he surrounded the voting booths with his troops, and guarded the sacred urn in which the ballots were to be deposited, with the bayonets of his soldiery. This movement had a wonderful effect in producing unanimity of popular sentiment, and the result was an overwhelming majority in his favor. His example seems to have attracted the admiration of the Virginia authorities. The rebel troops are to secure freedom of opinion and of the right of suffrage to the people of that Commonwealth in the election that is to come off there to-day. Everybody is to vote exactly as he pleases. The citizens are to be under no restraint or coercion. If they desire to stay in the Union, all they will have to do is to say so. There will be this slight drawback, however, which may dampen the ardor of Union men and prevent, to some extent, the free expression of their opinions. The man who votes against secession, who speaks through his suffrage his respect for the Constitution and his love for the country at large, will find a strong cord and a short shrift to dismiss him from the turmoils and cares of this life.

abstract: The Union Defence Committee are making a move in the right direction when they call for parades of the various regiments now organized and accepted or in process of being organized in this City. But we think that the notice allowed for parades should not ...
lead_paragraph: The Union Defence Committee are making a move in the right direction when they call for parades of the various regiments now organized and accepted or in process of being organized in this City. But we think that the notice allowed for parades should not be, at the furthest, more than twelve hours. By giving a notice of four or five days, or even three days, there is a possibility that many more men than those regularly enrolled and ready for service may answer to their names on the parade; and thus, even the officers themselves be deceived as to the number of men it may yet be necessary to recruit. Quarters should be at once provided for accepted regiments, so that the officers and members of the Union Defence Committee may know exactly for how many men rations and equipments should be provided.

abstract: -In contrast with the profuse, voluble and arrogant discussionof events in America, which fill the English papers, is the taciturnity of the French Press. The official and semi-official journals of the Empire have stated the news without note or comment. The liberal Press has been frank and cordial in its approbation of the course taken by Government for the restoration of the Union; the Opinione Nationale, the Siecle and Revues Contemporaine and de Deux Mondes, paying eloquent tributes to the worth of the Union, and uttering their decided reprobation of the aims and motives of the Southern conspiracy. The eccentric GRANIER DE CASSAGNAC continues to advocate peaceful separation in the Pays; but he stands alone on that side of the question; for the Presse, inspired by M. GAILLARDET, whose interests in the South doubtless biased for a time his judgment, has come to recognize the revolution in its true light; closing with the following words, its latest article on the subject:

abstract: The Regiment, known as the Brooklyn Phalanx, was not inspected yesterday, because the officers had not sufficient notice to enable them to get their men together from different parts of Long Island. The inspection is now ordered to take place on Friday next, ...
lead_paragraph: The Regiment, known as the Brooklyn Phalanx, was not inspected yesterday, because the officers had not sufficient notice to enable them to get their men together from different parts of Long Island. The inspection is now ordered to take place on Friday next, and all who have signed the muster roll, are requested to report themselves on or before that day. Now that the Fourteenth Regiment has left for the seat of war, the Plymouth Church Society, it is understood, have taken the Brooklyn Phalanx under its special protection, and will do all that it is possible to secure a proper outfit for the command. A son of the Rev. Mr. BEECHER will go with the Phalanx as Adjutant.

abstract: Some years since a correspondent submitted to the New-York TIMES a new system of Banking which he had studied out, and which, if adopted, he affirmed would be the most brilliant thing of the age. He argued that the discounting of paper payable at the convenience of the lender, was all wrong, and ought to be abolished. He insisted further that the practice of requiring indorsers was embarrassing to the borrower, who was frequently too poor to obtain them, and thus many who needed them most were deprived of all the benefits of Bank accommodations. His grand plan was to establish a People's Bank in every village, and a sufficient number in the cities to meet the business wants of the citizens. These Banks were to discount poor people's notes without an indorser, and moreover all notes were to be made payable at the convenience of the borrower. This, according to his notion, would not only make money abundant, but tiring it within reach of those who needed it most. It was easy to suggest a difficulty in regard to redemptions on the part of the Banks. "Redemptions!" -- he was ready to reply -- "what is the use of redeeming at all, so long as the bills are current?" But what if the Banks break? "Let them break and begin again," was the response, as he turned on his heel in huge contempt at the lack of appreciation of his theory. The man was entirely in earnest, but his wits were none of the soundest.
lead_paragraph: Some years since a correspondent submitted to the New-York TIMES a new system of Banking which he had studied out, and which, if adopted, he affirmed would be the most brilliant thing of the age. He argued that the discounting of paper payable at the convenience of the lender, was all wrong, and ought to be abolished. He insisted further that the practice of requiring indorsers was embarrassing to the borrower, who was frequently too poor to obtain them, and thus many who needed them most were deprived of all the benefits of Bank accommodations. His grand plan was to establish a People's Bank in every village, and a sufficient number in the cities to meet the business wants of the citizens. These Banks were to discount poor people's notes without an indorser, and moreover all notes were to be made payable at the convenience of the borrower. This, according to his notion, would not only make money abundant, but tiring it within reach of those who needed it most. It was easy to suggest a difficulty in regard to redemptions on the part of the Banks. "Redemptions!" -- he was ready to reply -- "what is the use of redeeming at all, so long as the bills are current?" But what if the Banks break? "Let them break and begin again," was the response, as he turned on his heel in huge contempt at the lack of appreciation of his theory. The man was entirely in earnest, but his wits were none of the soundest.

abstract: We are glad to learn from our Washington correspondent, that our Government has already given notice to the several Powers represented at the Conference of Paris in 1856, that we concur in the declaration of principles then set forth. It is stated that this notice was given in a dispatch dated April 24. It could scarcely have reached England at the date of our latest advices from that country. We shall soon learn, however, its reception.

abstract: The Venetian Council of Ten, which, by an elaborate system of espionage, contrived to penetrate the secrets of every European Court, never foresaw that a time would come when the mere natural operation of a purely scientific appliance would furnish a detective apparatus infinitely more potent than their complicated contrivance.
lead_paragraph: The Venetian Council of Ten, which, by an elaborate system of espionage, contrived to penetrate the secrets of every European Court, never foresaw that a time would come when the mere natural operation of a purely scientific appliance would furnish a detective apparatus infinitely more potent than their complicated contrivance. The regime of the telegraphic offices requiring the filing, for a year, of the originals of all dispatches sent over the wires, which the Government availed itself of the other day, (seizing a twelvemonth's dispatches simultaneously throughout the North,) has put this powerful instrument of retrospective police into the hands of the Federal authorities; and the fact that the seizure in this City alone included over a quarter of a million messages, may help the mind to form a conception of the enormous mass of materiel pour servir acquired by this stroke.
