abstract: Our Washington dispatches at last justify hopes of activity. The Government has discovered that its previous information respecting the rebel force in and near Harper's Ferry has been erroneous, and that, instead of an unarmed, disorganized and half-fed rabble, there is a well-appointed army of fifteen thousand men, amply provided.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington dispatches at last justify hopes of activity. The Government has discovered that its previous information respecting the rebel force in and near Harper's Ferry has been erroneous, and that, instead of an unarmed, disorganized and half-fed rabble, there is a well-appointed army of fifteen thousand men, amply provided. How many troops may be behind these men is not known, but the probability is they are the advance guard of a column which is supplied at Charlottesville, by two steady upward tides from the Atlantic coast on the one hand and the Southwest on the other. It is asserted in certain quarters, which claim to have the knowledge, that the threatened capture of Washington was a feint; Philadelphia being really the first, and New-York the second point of attack. The ardor of the rebels is represented to be kept at fever heat by glowing pictures of plunder and riot, where they shall be able to exchange their worthless shinplasters, in those cities, for Yankee gold; their scanty rations for revels in Fifth-avenue palaces, and to banquet upon the luxury of demonstrated power, and ample vengeance. Whatever grounds these stories may have, the authorities at Washington must have become impressed with the necessity of breaking up the strategic arrangements of the enemy, by cutting off this advanced division on the Potomac; and our correspondent intimates the probability of an immediate movement of our troops into Virginia so as to take the rebels in the rear, and stopping their south-ward communications and their supplies. Such evidence of activity, if safe and practicable,would have a two-fold beneficial effect It would remove a suspicion which discourages the popular heart, that some secret influence stays the advance of our army in Virginia; and it would satisfy European spectators of our serious purpose in commencing hostilities, of pushing them earnestly and unsparingly. The harmlessness of the firing at Fort Sumter has created almost ludicrous doubts in the minds of people accustomed to scenes like those at Sebastopol and Gaeta.

abstract: There is a most unfortunate difference between the Union men in the Fourth Congressional District of Baltimore one, too, which may lose them the coming election. A few evenings since, Hon. H. WINTER DAVIS was nominated for reelection to Congress, his principal competitor being Hon. JOHN P. KENNEDY, who received 14 votes to Mr. DAVIS' 48.
lead_paragraph: There is a most unfortunate difference between the Union men in the Fourth Congressional District of Baltimore -- one, too, which may lose them the coming election. A few evenings since, Hon. H. WINTER DAVIS was nominated for reelection to Congress, his principal competitor being Hon. JOHN P. KENNEDY, who received 14 votes to Mr. DAVIS' 48. The Baltimore American at once threatened a bolt, and has ever since been urging Mr. DAVIS' friends to withdraw his name, affirming that there were a large number of voters who would not support him under any circumstances. On Monday evening, Mr. DAVIS addressed his constituents, accepting the nomination. He indignantly denied the imputations that this honor had been secured by packing the Convention, and defied the power of his enemies, private or public; he had accepted the nomination, and meant to stand by it, and he had been put forward, too, on the basis of "unconditional" adherence to the Union, and the understanding that he would stand in the way of no one of that stamp who might be preferred before him. Mr. DAVIS then defended his vote for Mr. PENNINGTON as Speaker of the House, repudiated the idea that he had ever encouraged rowdyism at the polls, and then vindicated at length his course in refusing to vote for the Crittenden Compromise, which he declared was only the Breckinridge Platform in disguise. It was an entirely impracticable scheme, and he preferred to it Mr. COSWIN's amendment, which granted all that the Southern States could ask or hope to get. Mr. DAVIS then applauded the firm stand made by Gov. HICKS, denounced the Legislature and its treasonable designs, and declared that there was no such thing as the right of secession. If a body of men had seized territory belonging to the United States, he was for punishing them summarily, whether they were Spaniards or Americans, and if the Confederates were still amenable to the laws and the Constitution, he was for enforcing those laws at every hazard. With the exception of calling out volunteers for three years, all Mr. LINCOLN's acts had been constitutional, and this he was ready to defend on the ground of necessity. The mission of the volunteers would be to defend the Union men in the disloyal States, and this must be done at every hazard. Mr. DAVIS spoke for two hours and ten minutes, and was frequently applauded.

abstract: It is a medical fact that a change in water is frequently more disastrous to the health of the Summer traveler, than a change in air is beneficial; care as to drink is a matter of as much importance as care about atmosphere, food and clothing. Sickness is the immediate result of neglect in either department, particularly in the case of soldiers already predisposed by heat, fatigue and the miasmata of Southern climates, to the very diseases that bad water and food engender. A constant supply of pure water, then, for soldiers on the march, as well as for troops in encampments and fortresses, would seem to be an imperative necessity. Distilled water is the only pure water, and when properly aerated, the only wholesome water that can be obtained at all in many places. Distilling apparatus, then, for forts, and portable distilleries for the march, would appear desirable at any expense, inasmuch as this operation is simpler, for extensive purposes, than any manner of filtering yet common.

Distilling apparatus, then, for forts, and portable distilleries for the march, would appear desirable at any expense, inasmuch as this operation is simpler, for extensive purposes, than any manner of filtering yet common.

abstract: The steamer Adelaide, from Old Point, reports that Major-General BUTLER and Staff had arrived at Fortress Monroe at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and were received with the customary military honors. The spectacle was magnificent, and there was great enthusiasm among the men.

abstract: The obsequies of the late Col. VOSBURGH, of the Seventy-first Regiment, yesterday, were characterized by unusual solemnity, and by far the most general testimonial of respect to the memory of a deceased citizen that has been witnessed in the City for many days. Not only were the public buildings and many stores closed during the afternoon, but almost universally throughout the City the national ensign was placed at half-mast, while the streets were lined with spectators anxious to witness the funeral pageant.

abstract: FIRE IN GOWANUS. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a fire broke out in a row of three-story brick buildings, owned by GEORGE BRAISDELL, on Eleventh-street near Third-avenue, and before the flames could be stayed, five of the buildings were destroyed, and several others were more of loss injured. Mr. BRAISDELL and WM. HUNT occupied two of the houses, and the others were unoccupied. Mr. BRAISDELL is insured for $8,000, sufficient the cover the entire less on his property. A frame cottage adjoining the above buildings, owned by ROBERT YOUNGS and occupied by CHARLES WAKEFIELD, was damaged to the extent of $200. The other houses, occupied by William Ward, Jno Baxter, Charles and George Hedges, W. Keenan and Joseph Martin, were slightly damaged. The fire is supposed to have been caused by children playing with motches.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge WELLS, the trial of William Robinson, for murder, which was commenced on the day previous, was continued. For the people, Mr. Sweeney testified to having seen the affray, which he described essentially as the other witnesses had done. The testimony for the prosecution was concluded with the reading of Dr. Ward's deposition, to the effect that the deceased came to his death from the wounds inflicted in his side.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Judge WELLS, the trial of William Robinson, for murder, which was commenced on the day previous, was continued. For the people, Mr. Sweeney testified to having seen the affray, which he described essentially as the other witnesses had done. The testimony for the prosecution was concluded with the reading of Dr. Ward's deposition, to the effect that the deceased came to his death from the wounds inflicted in his side.

abstract: The Convention of Virginia, when it passed the ordinance of secession, made its validity dependent upon the approval of the people. The popular vote was to be taken yesterday; and every Virginian was then to declare whether, so far as his action was concerned, Virginia should remain in the Union or not.
lead_paragraph: The Convention of Virginia, when it passed the ordinance of secession, made its validity dependent upon the approval of the people. The popular vote was to be taken yesterday; and every Virginian was then to declare whether, so far as his action was concerned, Virginia should remain in the Union or not. If ever a perfectly free and unconstrained vote was the sacred right of every citizen, it was on this occasion. The State of Virginia professes to have a Republican form of Government, - and even the usurpers in the Convention retained sufficient respect for the fundamental principle of all Republics, to submit their action to the vote of the people.

abstract: The progress of civil discord in the American Republic has been attended by a marked change in public feeling in this country respecting it. At first incredulity was the prevailing sentiment. The evils of a disruption of the Union appeared so great and palpable, and its good to any party so obscure and questionable, that people in England could not imagine the possibility of so ruinous a course being actually adopted.

abstract: The departure, yesterday, of Col. DURYEE's Fifth Regiment of Volunteers, was the occasion of a popular ovation which has not been excelled in general enthusiasm since the departure of the Seventh Regiment.
lead_paragraph: The departure, yesterday, of Col. DURYEE's Fifth Regiment of Volunteers, was the occasion of a popular ovation which has not been excelled in general enthusiasm since the departure of the Seventh Regiment. The established reputation and wide-spread popularity of the old Colonel of the Seventh Regiment; the excellent materials which he has succeeded in bringing together in a brief space of time for his command; the rapid progress which they have made since they went into camp at Fort Schuyler, and the known character and ability of the associate officers of the Regiment, had attracted towards them unusual interest, and all which contributed to bring out the New-Yorkers in large force to witness their departure for the theatre of war. The Regiment having some unavoidable delay received their muskets, on Wednesday prepared to leave. Early in the morning the camp was astir with the work of preparation, and at noon the entire regiment, with camp equipage and baggage, were ready to march. The latter were sent directly on board of the Alabama, and the regiment came to the City on board of a steamer provided for purpose of landing at the foot of Fourteenth-street, East River. Broadway being occupied with the funeral cartege of Col. VESBURGH, some delay occurred in marching. The citizens thronged the entire length of Fourteenth-street, to witness the march, and Broadway has seldom been more compactly crowded than it was on this occasion. The style of uniform -- that of the French Zouave, with the full flowing pants of red flannel, and red cap, with a cape of white flannel, which partially concealed the face, strongly reminded the spectator of the Baski Bazourks who figured so conspicuously in the Turkish Army during the Crimean War. The personnel of this Regiment is certainly equal in every particular to the best troops which have yet been dispatched from this City.They are composed, in great part, of young men innuled to labor and hardship, many are experienced gymnasts, and not a few are stalwart in frame, standing six feet in height. Their march through Broadway was a continued ovation, the crowd which lined the side-walks, and filled the windows and balconies, cheering and waving to them as they passed. The familiar face and soldierly bearing of New-York's old favorite, Col. DURYEA, who has so promptly responded to the call of the country, seemed to inspire a furore of enthusiasm wherever he appeared; and it must be confessed that much of the applause seemed intended for this veteran and popular commander. At 5 1/2 o'clock P.M. the regiment entered the Park, and were drawn up in front of the City Hall, a space having been cleared for them by the admirable arrangements of the Police. The Regiment here went through with a few of the manual movements which elicited applause for their precision. Mayor WOOD, accompanied by Judge EDMONDS and several City officials, reviewed the regiment, expressing, at the close their high admiration of the men, and the excellent state of discipline in which they appealed.

abstract: Those of our readers who take pains to compare the extracts we are daily giving from English exchanges, in regard to American topics, will notice a decided improvement in tone. An article from the Manchester Guardian, of the latest date, is given in another column at length, because it is the most significant gauge of this change.
lead_paragraph: Those of our readers who take pains to compare the extracts we are daily giving from English exchanges, in regard to American topics, will notice a decided improvement in tone. An article from the Manchester Guardian, of the latest date, is given in another column at length, because it is the most significant gauge of this change. The Guardian, we need hardly remind our readers, stands in the front rank of provincial journals; and, published in the heart of the cotton-consuming region, its sentiments may be accepted as truthful reflections of the opinions current among the demigods of the factories At the outset of our difficulties, and even as late as the 7th inst., the Guardian, as was to be expected, had no disposition to conceal its sympathy with the South, which found vent in denunciations of Mr. LINCOLN and his policy, and in heaping upon his shoulders the responsibility of inaugurating a needless and sanguinary contest. A glance at the article we reproduce today will show how entirely this hostile ground has been abandoned. The war has become one of high and inevitable necessity; and the entire world is bidden to cast in its sympathies on the side of the National Government. In the punishment and redaction to obedience of the rebels the only hope of permanent peace is recognized; and the uprising and arming of the loyalists is pronounced one of the grandest spectacles of history, and one that appeals to the highest admiration of mankind. This is a symptom, in connection with others, that England is coming to her senses. In her first excitement she was foolish enough to be alarmed at the rebel boast that the cotton crop was a resistless sword which could be wielded to the ruin of England. Calmness would have suggested that while it was so, the handle is held by the North, and its double edge may be equally fatal to the labor of American planting States, and British manufacturing counties.

abstract: The story of the Great Rebellion will always form one of the most interesting and instructive chapters in the history of this country, as we can trace most accurately its cause, and its successive stages of development under the various phases of State rights, nullification and secession. In the Northern States, the Confederated Government has, from its birth, steadily become more and more consolidated, effacing local distinctions, and blending the several States into a common nationality. The grand agency to such a result has been commerce, uniform protection, and an identity of material interests. The Erie Canal was constructed by the State of New-York with an exclusive eye to the promotion of the advantage of its people. It was nearly ten years before it became the channel of commerce of the people of other States. This work will deliver at one harbor, the present year, 2,000,000 tons of Western produce, to 400,000 tons from the State of New-York. It has consequently become five times as valuable to other States as to our own. The country could afford to pay $200,000,000 rather than this great artery should be closed. In the advantages it confers, it belongs as much to Michigan, Illinois, and Massachusetts as to New-York. If New-York were to secede, the fear of excessive charges upon it, of duties laid upon the commerce of all foreign States, would convulse the whole country. Every man in the North, consequently, is the earnest advocate of a Confederacy that shall embrace under one system of law and taxation every foot of the continent. He does not wish to be distinguished as a New-Yorker, a Pennsylvanian, or a citizen of Massachusetts or Ohio, but of a Confederacy that blends what is good in all, and that opens to him a field of enterprise as wide as our vast domain. He may be attracted by birth, or relationship, or habit, to a particular spot, while his property a thousand miles distant has the same protection and immunity as that under his personal control.

abstract: PERILOUS FREAK OF A CRAZY MAN. -- About 9 yesterday morning a man was discovered climbing the flag-staff on the top of the shot-tower in Centre-street near Pearl. Supposing that the object was to haul down the flag at the top of the staff, and perhaps thinking that some Secessionist might be around loose, Officers DAVIS and DONAHUE, of the Sixth Ward, hurried into the tower and up after him. When they got to him he had cut the halliards, and had the flag down and was attempting to tear it in pieces. The fellow strenuously resisted the officers, doing all he was able to prevent an arrest. He was, however, secured and taken to the Station-house. He refuses to give any reason for his conduct, says his name is LOUIS JUADINI, and that he lives at No. 122 Leonard-street, and is a Frenchman. It was suggested in his hearing that he was insane, but he insists that he is not. As the officers descended the tower with their prisoner, they discovered that he had broken on his way up, evidently with a small bar of iron he had with him, every pane of glass and window-sash in the passage-way, injuring the building to the amount of about $260. A neighbor of his says that he had never been suspected of being insane, but that the flag was in plain sight of where he worked, and he had been heard to say he would tear it down. An examination will he had to ascertain his sanity, which will probably determine wheather or not he goes to the Lunatic Asylum.
lead_paragraph: PERILOUS FREAK OF A CRAZY MAN. -- About 9 yesterday morning a man was discovered climbing the flag-staff on the top of the shot-tower in Centre-street near Pearl. abstract: The second commencement of the Columbia College Law School took place in the hall of the Historical Society, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, last evening. President KING occupied the Chair. Upon the platform were seated the Faculty of the Law School, the Collegiate Faculty occupying the seats directly in front of the platform. A large audience of ladies and gentlemen was present, and appeared highly pleased with the entertainment.
lead_paragraph: The second commencement of the Columbia College Law School took place in the hall of the Historical Society, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, last evening. President KING occupied the Chair. Upon the platform were seated the Faculty of the Law School, the Collegiate Faculty occupying the seats directly in front of the platform. A large audience of ladies and gentlemen was present, and appeared highly pleased with the entertainment. The exercises opened with prayer, after which Professor DWIGHT delivered a brief address to the Alumni of the school, which was followed by the ceremony of conferring degrees. G.V.N. BALDWIN. Esq., of the class of 1860, delivered an oration before the Graduating Class, and Hon. MURRAY HOFFMAN, of the Superior Court, made the address. The following graduates received the degree of Bachelor of Laws:

abstract: Our dispatches this morning are of a startling character, and indicate that the Government at last feels itself in a position of sufficient strength to warrant a foward movement. The Seventh, Twelfth and Sixty-ninth New-York Regiments, and the Rhode Island Brigade, last night received marching orders, with directions to prepare several days' rations.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches this morning are of a startling character, and indicate that the Government at last feels itself in a position of sufficient strength to warrant a foward movement. The Seventh, Twelfth and Sixty-ninth New-York Regiments, and the Rhode Island Brigade, last night received marching orders, with directions to prepare several days' rations. The orders were received with the greatest enthusiasm by the troops, who made the air vocal with cheers. It was expected that they would take up their position on Arlington Heights, and throw up entrenchments immediately. Thus, probably before this paper reaches our readers the "sacred soil of Virginia" will have been invaded. The Firemen Zouaves were also to move last night five miles down the river, to a point opposite Alexandria, and the steamship Pocahontas and the river steamer Mount Vernon were to move down the Chesapeake with a detachment of the Seventy-first Regiment on board, their destination being Fort Monroe, to support the forces there in case of a movement on Gosport Navy-yard, which is expected to take place immediately. The Government has now two hundred and fifty thousand men under arms, at various points, and these troops are all equipped, or will be by to-morrow night.

abstract: Like most other trades, treason requires capital to begin with. The Southern rebels stole enough for a limited and short-lived business, and only save themselves from insolvency by flooding the community with those financial "shirts upon a pole," bank issues. without specie beneath them; and shinplasters, redeemable in bank issues.
lead_paragraph: Like most other trades, treason requires capital to begin with. The Southern rebels stole enough for a limited and short-lived business, and only save themselves from insolvency by flooding the community with those financial "shirts upon a pole," bank issues. without specie beneath them; and shinplasters, redeemable in bank issues. The bonds and treasury notes of the Montgomery Government are simply other forms of the same worthless paper medium. The nearest the holder of these symbols gets to that substantial thing, money, is the exchange of one irredeemable promise to pay for another. And so they bargain and buy, sell, hire and make war, with a currency as valuable as the wampum of the aborigines. Gov. JACKSON, of Missouri, is a traitor without pecuniary means. He is quite resolved to arm the State and hand it over to the rebels, who, since it would simply burden them with a vaster frontier to defend with inadequate forces, decline to take it unarmed; and arms and the other material of war exact money. The State is without money. If the Federal Treasury had funds in Missouri there would be no difficulty; but in the absence of an opportunity for theft, other expedients must be resorted to; and of these two have presented themselves to the mind of the Governor. One is, to induce the banks to assent to the diversion of the $500,000 pledged by them to meet the July interest on the State debt; another, to induce them to make advances upon the bonds authorized by the late Military bill, to which the Legislature, in the last hours of its stay at Jefferson City arose at midnight, that they might lend the form if not the validity of law. The whole fate of treason in Missouri is therefore dependent upon the banks. If they decline to meet the views of the Governor, there will be rebellion, no hanging for treason, no devastation of the State by marching armies; and the faith of the State will be preserved by the payment of the semi-annual interest. If they consent, they sign the death warrant of all that makes Missouri great, prosperous, and respected.
headline: {'main': 'A Way to Save Missouri.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Way to Save Missouri.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A proclamation has been issued by the British Government relative to affairs in the United States, warning British subjects against engaging in the American war, and all doing so will be held responsible for their own acts.
lead_paragraph: A proclamation has been issued by the British Government relative to affairs in the United States, warning British subjects against engaging in the American war, and all doing so will be held responsible for their own acts. The proclamation declares the intention of that Government in maintaining the strictest impartial neutrality between England and the Government of the United States, and certain States styling themselves the Confederate States of America. It warns all British subjects, if they enter the military service of either side, or join ships of war, or transports, or attempt to get recruits, or fit out vessels for war purposes or transports, or break or endeavor to break any blockade lawfully or actually established, or carry soldiers, dispatches, or any material contraband of war, for either party, they will be liable to all the penalty and consequences, and will do so at their peril, and in nowise obtain the protection of their Government.

abstract: A person whose credibility is fully indorsed by the Washington Star, informs that paper that the utmost difficulty has been met with in inducing the Virginia musters to take the oath disavowing allegiance to the Government of the United States. Only fifteen of the men quartered at Warrenton, and only ten of those at Alexandria, could be persuaded to foreswear their fealty. The greater portion of the troops at Harper's. Ferry had manifested similar obstinacy upon this point, and the same fact is affirmed of those strung, along the fines of road, between Alexandria and Richmond. The circumstance is is not at all surprising. These people, are country farmers and planters, of a much more intelligent order than those from the tropical parallels, and are less driven by senseless and uninquisitive impulse. Their prompt resort to arms was the effect of the panic naturally produced by the outcry about coercion, invasion, subjugation and compulsory emancipation, raised at Richmond by the secession plotters; and accustomed to seek instruction from the Richmond Press, they conceived the possibility of the Federal policy involving all the tremendous calamities those journals predicted. The result as to Maryland has proved the falsity of all this. The advance of the Federal Army has guarantied, not destroyed property. Its presence has been the restoration of confidence and order. Neither servile insurrection nor stampedes or negroes, nor plunder, nor violence, has attended the encampment of the national troops in Maryland; while the only outrages and spoliations the people of that State have suffered, have come from marauding squads of Secessionists on the Virginia line. Where the Union forces are in the ascendant, industry and agriculture proceed, as usual. They are only suspended where rebellion raises its head.

abstract: The news of the murder of Col. ELLSWORTH, at Alexandria, Virginia, created a most profound excitement in this city yesterday almost as much, in fact, as the firing upon the starving garrison at Fort Sumter. The people at first doubted the intelligence, and the terrible fact was not believed generally until the evening papers published the details of the affair in which he lost his life.
lead_paragraph: The news of the murder of Col. ELLSWORTH, at Alexandria, Virginia, created a most profound excitement in this city yesterday -- almost as much, in fact, as the firing upon the starving garrison at Fort Sumter. The people at first doubted the intelligence, and the terrible fact was not believed generally until the evening papers published the details of the affair in which he lost his life. There were no outbursts of passion; but the compressed lip and the stern eye indicated how deeply all felt the calamity, and their determination to seek redress for the life of an officer so wantonly taken. The military ardor of the whole community was aroused to a high pitch, and many who have heretofore held back from taking any active part in the military preparations, because of a doubt as to whether their services would be required oraccepted even, resolved upon immediate steps to raise a reserve force, and have it in readiness to serve in the field, should more troops be called for from this State.

abstract: UNITED STATES MARSHAL's OFFICE. -- Mr. W.L. ORMSBY, the well-known bank-note engraver, on Thursday brought to the Marshal's office a large quantity of bank-note impressions, with the plate upon which they were printed, on account of the Whitfield Bank of Dalton, Georgia. He had been ordered to forward the goods by express, with bill for collection, but upon ascertaining that they would be considered in the light of giving aid and comfort to the enemy, the Marshal gave the following receipt:

abstract: The Government, at last, has moved in force upon Virginia. On the night of Thursday, ten thousand men crossed the Potomac, at Washington, captured Alexandria without resistance, while a detachment pushed forward to seize the point of junction of the Manasses Gap, with the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, to cut off all communication between Richmond and the Northern portion of the State.
lead_paragraph: The Government, at last, has moved in force upon Virginia. On the night of Thursday, ten thousand men crossed the Potomac, at Washington, captured Alexandria without resistance, while a detachment pushed forward to seize the point of junction of the Manasses Gap, with the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, to cut off all communication between Richmond and the Northern portion of the State. This movement, if successful, completely breaks the lines of the rebels, isolates Harper's Ferry from the base of their operations, and involves either the dispersion or capture of the forces at that point. We also learn that a body of Ohio troops is moving from Wheeling by way of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad upon the same point. We had no intelligence yesterday from Fort Monroe, but it is probable that the troops concentrated at that fortress under Gen. BUTLER, have moved in the direction of Richmond, so that every important point on the enemy's lines will, at the same instant, be either threatened or attacked.

abstract: The duty which the Federal Government is proceeding to fulfill, is to relieve the loyal and much-abused people of Virginia from military tyranny, by expelling the invaders and restoring the control of the State to the hands of its loyal citizens. To do this skillfully, promptly and thoroughly, requires a deliberate study of the military positions occupied by the force of the usurpers, and by those of the Government.

abstract: The Government has recalled the troops now occupying the Territories of New-Mexico and Utah. The motive of this measure is not easily penetrable -- seeing that the loyal States are ready to offer tenfold their number of as effective men for any service to which this force may now be transferred; but we may presume the change is not made without sufficient grounds. It is only left to inquire what steps have been taken for the protection of the over-land route. That line of communication with the Pacific runs through a country disputed by hostile tribes and fillibusters, of which latter the announcement of the departure of the national forces will bring large bodies to occupy Arizona and threaten Sonora. Through this dangerous and now unprotected tract the entire Pacific mail is to pass, after the 1st of July; and if privateering be as general as it is feared, the treasure which now goes to the Isthmus will have to come by the same route. It is of indispensable importance that the force now withdrawn should; be replaced at once with one of ten times the. strength, or we shall run the hazard of being as effectually cut off from California as we are from Mexico. If the service has no men to spare for the duty, let the business be taken in hand by California. The assumption of this talk will gladly be accepted by the country as a commutation of all other aid in the contest.
lead_paragraph: The Government has recalled the troops now occupying the Territories of New-Mexico and Utah. abstract: In accordance with the programme published in the TIMES yesterday morning, an advance of Federal troops was made into Virginia on Thursday night. The New-York Second, Seventh, Twelfth, Sixty-ninth, Seventy-first, and ELLSWORTH'S Zouaves, the New-Jersey and Michigan brigades,
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the programme published in the TIMES yesterday morning, an advance of Federal troops was made into Virginia on Thursday night. The New-York Second, Seventh, Twelfth, Sixty-ninth, Seventy-first, and ELLSWORTH'S Zouaves, the New-Jersey and Michigan brigades, and some of the Washington troops, constituted the force, which numbered about 13,000, besides those sent down the Potomac to act in conjunction with the troops at Fortress Monroe. This force has been disposed at various important points -- Alexandria, Arlington Heights and Fairfax Court-house -- the movement on the latter point being made for the purpose of taking possession of the junction of the Orange and Alexandria and Manassas Gap Railroads. The advance into Virginia was made from three points -- over the Long Bridge, at the mouth of the Potomac Aqueduct at Georgetown, and at Alexandria. The first troops which passed over the bridge, constituting the advance guard, were the Washington City National Rifles, and they were followed by other District volunteers, acting in a similar capacity, who drove in the Virginia pickets. Our troops had possession of all the points for which they were destined by 2 o'clock yesterday morning, and immediately commenced the necessary operations to insure their positions. The occupation of Alexandria was the most important movement accomplished, and this duty was gallantly performed in part, by the New-York Fire Zouaves, -- but not without a loss which must be deeply deplored. Their dashing young commander, Col. ELLSWORTH, was basely assassinated in the Marshall House, by the landlord, named JACKSON, while descending the stairs of the hotel with a secession flag in his hand, which he had taken from a flag-staff on the roof. Retribution for the base act was swift, however, as the murderer was immediately shot ard run through the body by a bayonet, by one of Col. ELLSWORTH's men. As the regiment entered the town, at the wharves of which they landed in steamboats, the rebel forces fired upon them without effect, and then fled. Almost simultaneously with the entry of the Zouaves into the city, the First Michigan Regiment arrived by the road from the Long Bridge, and took possession of the railroad depot, when they succeeded in surprising and capturing a troop of rebel cavalry, with their horses, arms and equipments.

abstract: On May 20 the General Assembly of the (N.S.) Presbyterian Church, now in session at Syracuse, adopted strong resolutions relative to the National crisis. That body declares it to be its duty to protect against the unlawful and treasonabla acts which...
lead_paragraph: On May 20 the General Assembly of the (N.S.) Presbyterian Church, now in session at Syracuse, adopted strong resolutions relative to the National crisis. That body declares it to be its duty to protect against the unlawful and treasonabla acts which have been perpetrated against the Government; that there is no blood or treasure too precious to be devoted to the defence and the perpetuity of the Government in all its constitutional authority; that those who are endeavoring to uphold it in the exercise of its constitutional prerogatives, are entitled to the sympathy and support of all Christian and law abiding citizens. All the pastors and churches are exhorted to pray for those in authority, and it was voted to send the resolutions to Mr. LINCOLN.

ELLSWORTH'S Fire Zouaves, on taking a stroll through the country, some distance from their camp, into Prince George's County, came across a farmer who was busily engaged in planting corn, and as he expressed some concern that he should not be able to get the crop into the ground in season, they determined to help him out; so, pulling off their...
lead_paragraph: The Washington star has this incident: "The other day some of Col. ELLSWORTH'S Fire Zouaves, on taking a stroll through the country, some distance from their camp, into Prince George's County, came across a farmer who was busily engaged in planting corn, and as he expressed some concern that he should not be able to get the crop into the ground in season, they determined to help him out; so, pulling off their jackets, they pitched in with hearty good will, and did the job up in short order. They then marched back to camp, as tickled as a cat with two tails."

abstract: An imperfect investigation into the conduct of the Commissariat of the Pennsylvania troops has demonstrated the existence of excessive abuses and corruption, and excited a storm of popular indignation at Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: An imperfect investigation into the conduct of the Commissariat of the Pennsylvania troops has demonstrated the existence of excessive abuses and corruption, and excited a storm of popular indignation at Philadelphia. Suspicions that similar mismanagement prevails in the conduct of the corresponding department here, where the business is so transcendently important, and where millions of dollars have already been expended in the purchase of provisions, arms and equipments, and the chartering of transports, have obtained extended currency, and produced a very general desire for investigation. We are daily in receipt of communications tendering absolute proof of the guilt of various parties holding positions of trust in this connection, and imploring the NEW-YORK TIMES to constitute itself the immediate means of exposure and punishment. This task we must, for the present, at least, decline. While there is much reason to fear that discretion and unimpeachable integrity have not uniformly characterized the distribution of contracts, it must be remembered that disappointed bidders seldom fail to charge corruption upon the more successful; and circumstantial evidence of fraud -- always to be had -- is seldom conclusive. But even admitting the justice of the charge, the present is no time to investigate how wisely or honestly the money we have freely given is to be expended. The men through whose hands it is passing are well known, and when the war is ended, their accounts will be rigidly audited; doubtless, all the more rigidly for these strongly adverse popular impressions. When our reckoning with the Southern rebels has been completed, another reckoning with their Northern promoters, helpers and sympathizers is to be had, at which those who have taken, advantage of the people's generous patriotism, to enrich themselves at the public cost, and at the expense of the self-sacrificing volunteers, sent to the field ill-armed, half-equipped, and unfed, and without the comforts with which they might very easily be provided, will come in for very weighty punishment. If guilt there is, the impatient accuser may rest assured that the trial is only delayed to be more thorough, and the judgment more merciless.

abstract: Chief Engineer DECKER received a telegram last night from Alexandria, stating that JOHN BUTTERWORTH, of No. 11 Engine, had been shot dead by a sentry -- he having refused to give the countersign when approaching the lines. The sentry, of course, only did his duty. His body will reach this City this morning with Col. ELLSWORTH's, and will be suitably received and disposed of by the Fire Department.

abstract: Ex-President BUCHANAN has written a letter to the National Intelligencer, in which he speaks of "the facility with which military gentlemen relieve themselves form their oaths and change their allegiance."
lead_paragraph: Ex-President BUCHANAN has written a letter to the National Intelligencer, in which he speaks of "the facility with which military gentlemen relieve themselves form their oaths and change their allegiance." In criticising with a just severity the conduct of those officers who not only resign their commissions, but enter the armies of secession to fight against their country, he says: "When Major BEAUREGARD discharged the first gun against Fort Sumter, he lighted a flame which it will require a long time to extinguish." When history shall have made up its record of the times in which we live, it will be found that wicked and dishonorable as the treason of BEAUREGARD and the other deserters of the flag of their country may have been, there was one man on whom rests a much heavier responsibility than on them, and that man was JAMES BUCHANAN. Placed at the head of a great nation by the suffrages of its people, sworn to preserve its integrity, to guard its honor, and protect it alike from foreign invasion and domestic treason; -- bound by all the obligations pertaining to solemn oaths, all the duties pertaining to official trust, all the instincts of patriotism, all the traditions of the past, the prosperity of the present and the hopes of the future to preserve intact the freest, most benign and perfect institutions ever framed by wisdom of man; with the power of perpetuating them in his hands, and perfectly within his control, he saw conspiracy ripening into treason; treason expanding into open and armed rebellion, and rebellion growing into revolution, without one word of remonstrance or one effort to check their demoralizing and destroying progress. He saw the Federal arms disposed of by his Cabinet Ministers so as to be within reach of the conspirators, and the Treasury of the Union spoiled for their benefit. He saw the Army ordered to distant frontiers and the Navy to foreign coasts, so that the strength of neither could be invoked in aid of the Government. He saw fort after fort taken possession of, and arsenal after arsenal plundered by the traitors. He saw rebellion levying armies and equipping them from the spoils of the Federal Government, commanded by officers educated to skill in war by Federal money, whose resignations he had voluntarily accepted, ready to march to the capture of the Capital and the overthrow of the Union, and yet took no step, did no act, summoned not one soldier to resist this monstrous crusade against the very existence of the Republic. Ten words from him would have dismissed his traitorous Cabinet and supplied their places with true men. A trifling forecast would have held possession of the forts, and saved the contents of the arsenals. A little show of courage would have overawed treason in its incipiency, and baffled the schemes of the conspirators. A degree of firmness, far short of Roman, would have preserved the peace of the nation. But there was a total and incomprehensible absence of all these on the part of President BUCHANAN, and the melancholy sequence is seen in the actual presence of a civil war, the progress and end of which humanity shudders to contemplate. Whether this disgraceful inertia was the result of a craven spirit -- a cowardice which happily does not belong to the American character, or a criminal sympathy with the purposes of the conspiracy, it is scarcely worth while to inquire. In one or the other of these categories Mr. BUCHANAN will at last find a resting-place, and the world will visit upon him a much larger share of the responsibility for the upheavals that may follow, than upon the treason of army officers who deserted the service, or the firing of the "first gun at Fort Sumter." Cowardice and treason, in a crisis like the present, are too near of kin in their consequences to allow of nice distinctions. Even imbecility is counted on the side of dishonor, and history covers all with the pall of infamy.

abstract: The idea seems to prevail in certain circles in Europe, and has a place in timid minds even in this country, that the spontaneous uprising of the North is a mere ebullition of enthusiasm that when the actual presence of war, the hardships incident to camp life, and the derangements of business and finance which follow the sudden change from tranquillity to national strife, shall have become practical facts, the ardor of the people will abate; that the armies now so readily recruited will dwindle away, and the demand for peace, even at the expense of dissolution, will be as imperative as that which now calls for vigorous warlike action. Those who entertain this opinion have but an imperfect knowledge of the American people, and entirely misunderstand the sentiment by which they are inspired. There is no people in the world in whom the love of country is more firmly rooted, none in whom attachment to the institutions under which they live, none whose instincts and affections cling with more tenacity to their form of Government than the people of these States, and especially of the Northern and now loyal States. There is no people less given to enthusiasm than they. Their habits of thought, their steady and persevering pursuit of gain, the competitions with which they are always in conflict, together with climatic influences, engender a coolness and caution altogether opposed to any tendency towards wild excitement or undue enthusiasm. They are, above all other people, practical; given, from the peculiarities of their position and surroundings, to studying the exigencies of the present and calculating the eventualities of the future. Their patriotism may not be of that sublimated kind which, under all circumstances, ignores personal interests for the good of the country. It may be, and doubtless is, tinctured more or less with that selfishness which is organic in human nature, but there is no people on the face of the earth who, when present and real danger menaces the nation, are more capable of submitting, with a cheerful patience, to any sacrifices demanded in its support. The history of the past proves this, and the struggle of the present will furnish a new demonstration of its truth.
lead_paragraph: The idea seems to prevail in certain circles in Europe, and has a place in timid minds even in this country, that the spontaneous uprising of the North is a mere ebullition of enthusiasm that when the actual presence of war, the hardships incident to camp life, and the derangements of business and finance which follow the sudden change from tranquillity to national strife, shall have become practical facts, the ardor of the people will abate; that the armies now so readily recruited will dwindle away, and the demand for peace, even at the expense of dissolution, will be as imperative as that which now calls for vigorous warlike action. abstract: In modern times the military arm of a nation may by no means be the most effective one it can exert. The great object of all such organizations is to preserve the national wealth and prosperity; but this may often be more fatally attacked by a people that does not send a soldier into the field than by one that boasts of a standing army of half a million veterans.
lead_paragraph: In modern times the military arm of a nation may by no means be the most effective one it can exert. The great object of all such organizations is to preserve the national wealth and prosperity; but this may often be more fatally attacked by a people that does not send a soldier into the field than by one that boasts of a standing army of half a million veterans. Wealth is the result of commerce, and of the diversified industries of society. Great Britain exports, annually, to foreign countries, products to the value of $600,000,000. Their manufacture employs one-half her population. Were her customers to refuse to continue their ordinary purchases, her people would be threatened with annihilation. They have no means of support outside their usual avocations. Their soil cannot supply them with food. This they must obtain in exchange for their products, or starvation stares them in the face. Of these, the United States, for the past year took some $150,000,000. The total importations from that country and its colonies being nearly $200,000,000. If we should buy nothing from her the present year, we should deal her a blow tenfold more effective than we could inflict by the most vigorous military or naval demonstrations we could make. Should she lose at a blow the market for one-third of her products, every interest in the kingdom would be prostrated, and wide-spread ruin and distress sweep over the land. It would be as if an army had stopped every spindle and loom in Manchester or Bradford, and every furnace in Scotland and Wales. It would matter not, as far as she was concerned, in what manner we dealt the blow, whether by an overwhelming force, or by remaining quietly at home, refusing to consume anything she produced.

abstract: The Winter Garden has monopolized all the dramatic interest of the past week, and this, too, without a great expenditure in the way of novelty. Where artists of thorough excellence are engaged, an entertainment of some degree of freshness can always be guaranteed.
lead_paragraph: The Winter Garden has monopolized all the dramatic interest of the past week, and this, too, without a great expenditure in the way of novelty. Where artists of thorough excellence are engaged, an entertainment of some degree of freshness can always be guaranteed. Improving on this fact, Mr. JACKSON has adhered to a steady repertoire of "approved good" pieces, simply adapting them to the exigencies of the moment. Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON have done the rest, and been rewarded with houses over crowded with delighted faces. The only novelty on the programme has been a London farce, called "Bowled Out," which was played on Thursday last with only moderate success. It comes from the Adelphi Theatre, and is as extravagant as pieces from that locality are apt to be. As a caricature of a certain phase of Dissenting life -- the worst, we imagine -- it may have its saliencies in the great metropolis, but here its exposures of cant are some what fame and miss fire lamentably. Hence, notwithstanding much excellent acting on the part of both the artists we have named, it was a failure. The management withdrew it after the second right. Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON completed his engagement at the Winter Garden last evening. He has listened to the voice of the charmer, and departs now for California, where we trust he will meet with a reception due to his great merits as an actor. It will be long before we meet with the right man to fill his place. As a comic artist, he is, we believe, the most finished and generally excellent one we have ever had Remembering, as any one may readily remember, the many characters he has sustained before a I New-York audience, it is, we believe, impossible to recall a single instance of bad taste, of grossness, of violent effort after applause, in all his varied impersonations. The esteem which he has hereby justly won has been by legitimate means, and by the purest efforts of a quick genius. Mr. JEFFERSON is the representative man of the American stage; the one who draws less on tradition than any other. As such he made his mark here -- where taste is exacting, and will surely make it in California, Australia and England, if he finds it worth his while to make the experiment. One thing is certain, and it my be recorded to his credit. He leaves an audience that does not wish to part with him. Of all the artists that have tried to win a degree of remembrance and consideration amid the deafening roll of the drum, he alone has succeeded. From the opening night of his engagement to the closing one, the houses have been all that a manager could desire, or the most popular favorite expect.

abstract: If any one doubted that the popular sympathy is with the gallant volunteers who are going out to fight in defence of the Union and our liberties, the demonstration of yesterday afternoon must have convinced them to the contrary.
lead_paragraph: If any one doubted that the popular sympathy is with the gallant volunteers who are going out to fight in defence of the Union and our liberties, the demonstration of yesterday afternoon must have convinced them to the contrary. The announcement that the Union Defence Committee was to inspection regiments of New-York volunteers, brought out a very largo self-constituted committee of approval on the part of our citizens. Three o'clock was the hour at which the regiments were to form in line in Fourteenth street. Long before that hour, Fourteenth-street, from river to river, was lined with an enthusiastic concourse of citizens. And not Fourteenth-street only, but every avenue and street leading to it, also pound out its tidal tribute. As the crimson regimental current poured through the avenue-arteries leading to the heart, where it was to centre, cambric handkerchiefs from loaded balconies and clustering windows waved snowy God-speeds to the brave volunteers, and eyes, brighter than the unacabbarded swords and glistening bayonets below, showered down smiles of approval. And many a fervent prayer went up that those called upon to go forth in their country's defence might return, or, failing in this, find a proud death-bed on the field of fame. However apathetic a community may be, it is certain that the first notes of the bugle awake a spirit of chivalry which animates even the basest clay, though for long years it may lie dormant. Thus yesterday, men, the greater part of whose lives have been devoted to trade, and whose only aspirations seemed to tend to the accumulation of dollars and cents, cast aside for the moment all sentiments of the shop, and flung up their hats in loud huzzas for our improvised army. Wrinkled wrists, whose pulses might be supposed to be chilled by the frosts of age, thrust forth their hands to give a warm friendly clasp to the passing soldier. Fervent "God bless you, boys, God bless you!" ran along the long lines of citizens, as the various regiments passed in rapid review -- the picturesquely costumed Zouaves, the plumed Garibaldi Guards, and the plainly attired citizen soldiery who had not yet assumed the coats of many colors prescribed by fanciful Colonels, and the regulations of war. There was that in the manifestation of popular sentiment yesterday which fully justifies the lines of TENNYSON, wherein the idea is expressed that though the canker of peace may cut deeply into a nation's vitals, when its rights are threatened by either foreign foes or traitors, at home, the most sordid of shopkeepers is ready to jump.

abstract: A few days since, while in Harrisburgh, Gov. BIGLER was called on for a speech. In the course of his remarks he referred to the known fact that he had not assisted in placing the present Administration in power, but that nevertheless, in the present contest, forced upon the country by men in arms against the constituted authorities, all past political differences were merged in the one great duty of upholding the Government and enforcing obedience to the Constitution and laws wherever rebellion against their sacred authority dated to show is audacious front. It was a question between government and anarchy, that admitted of no two sides, no differing views, no doubt as to the line of duty, and upon the issue rested the vital result as to whether we have a home, or a country, or a government at all. In this mighty contest Pennsylvania, with a unanimity that was perfect, without a dissenting voice, had taken her noble position to restore and preserve that Union which had so prospered and blessed the land and rated this Republic to the head of the great nations of the earth; his lot was cast in that great patriotic State; her cause was his cause, her enemies were his enemies, her battles were his, and liberties and protection he looked to in all future time for the guardianship of his home and his valued rights. He spoke of the uprising of the masses in such a cause as evidence that true patriotism glowed in every heart and as affording encouragement to the hope that all opposition to the Government would be speedily putdown, and our Union placed again on its glorious career of prosperity, shedding its blessings upon a happy and united people."

abstract: The City was agitated by a succession of alarms yesterday, growing out of various reports of desperate fighting at Alexandria, Arlington Heights, Harper's Ferry, and other points most of which were totally devoid of foundation, and all of which were greatly exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: The City was agitated by a succession of alarms yesterday, growing out of various reports of desperate fighting at Alexandria, Arlington Heights, Harper's Ferry, and other points -- most of which were totally devoid of foundation, and all of which were greatly exaggerated. The little fountain of fact from which the great stream of fiction flowed, was simply a skirmish between the Federal pickets, near Arlington, and a roving body of Secessionists, which amounted to not even one man killed, so far as is known. An alarm was given, however, in Washington, and a signal of three guns was fired, which immediately put all the troops in the District under arms, and a large body was thrown across the Potomac into Virginia, ready to take part in any duty which might be required. The rapidity and certainly with which these sudden movements were accomplished are represented to have been absolutely astonishing. Infantry, artillery and cavalry were in arms and across the Long Bridge, proceeding in the direction of the supposed danger, in the shortest possible time. It was soon ascertained that the alarm was a false one, and the greater portion of the troops returned again to Washington. The Sixty-ninth New-York Regiment, however, which occupies Arlington Heights, which is being fortified, were under arms all night, in anticipation of an attack from a body of rebels at Culpepper Courthouse.

abstract: Our telegrams from Cape Race are at once so important and so provokingly meagre, that to found upon them any decided opinions would be the extremity of rashness. In the case of the Queen's proclamation in regard to American affairs, had the benighted and unenterprizing agent who transmitted the news reflected that nothing short of the literal text could satisfy the curiosity and solicitude of the public, he would have omitted all else rather than not give the language in its integrity. As it is, the only material point of which we have assurance is, that England proposes, notwithstanding the casuistry of the London Times, to recognize the blockade. The rest is excessively ambiguous. True, in alluding to the Rebel Government, the proclamation speaks of "certain States styling themselves the Confederate States of America," and without proper consideration this may be understood as intimating a friendly regard to the Southern movement. But any less qualified language would have been a recognition of the independence of the new Confederation -- a recognition which would have been equivalent to a declaration of war against the National Government, and would therefore have defeated the neutrality the proclamation is designed to assure. As to the character of this neutrality, there is little room left for doubt. The British Government substantially pronounces the parties to the contest equal in its sight. To lend aid and comfort to either constitutes the offence the paper defines. All claims of sympathy, all ties of long-established and friendly intercourse, to say nothing of the peculiar character of the warfare we are engaged in, commanding, as it should, the Godspeed of all men, are without influence with the British Government, which exhibits as much respectful regard for the traitorous and perjured usurpation of a day's growth at Montgomery, as for the unquestionable and loyal Government at Washington. The telegraphic abstract warrants, we fear, this unwelcome impression; and unless the text speaks differently, we can only regard the position of England as designed to aid the weaker side. A declaration of undisguised sympathy with the National cause might not directly augment our power to carry the war to a triumphant close; but in the reprobation it would imply of the treason we wrestle with, it would omit to give it that moral status which it receives from a concession of the equality of the combatants. In this light, therefore, the proclamation is an act of unfriendship to the United States, negative, certainly, but of inestimable value to the public enemy.

abstract: The remains will arrive by an early train from Philadelphia on Sunday morning. Gen. HALL will detail a military escort. The Chief-Engineer of the Fire Department will direct an escort of firemen, which, together with the Fund Committee of the Firemen's Zouave Regiment, will receive the body at the railroad depot in Jersey City, They will then proceed to the Astor House, where the remains will be given into the charge of the family of deceased, who will hold them till 10 o'clock A.M. There will be a private funeral service during the interval.

abstract: The Cincinnati Commercial, of May 22, publishes the following interesting information derived from Rev. J.A. REUBELT, Professor of German in the Southern University, Greenboro', Alabama. Prof. REUBELT left Greenboro' to avoid being drafted into the Southern army. He left Montgomery, Ala., Saturday noon last, traveling North to Atlanta, Chattanooga, Nashville and Louisville, reaching Cincinnati yesterday at 7 A.M. In his company was the engineer of the Mobile and Pensacola Railroad, with his wife and child, a Kentuckian by birth, who received warning that he was about to be drafted for Southern military service. This engineer came on as far as the Kentucky line,where the Professor and he parted company. From him be learned that the forces under BRAGG at Pensacola were on Tuesday last between 9,550 and 10,000. The great body of the rebels were at a point two miles and a half from Fort Pickens.

abstract: The Fifty-fifth Regiment, under the command of Major THOUROT, formed for inspection on Fourteenthstreet, between First and Second avenues, the soldierly bearing of the men eliciting the encomiums of the spectators. Col. LE GAL appeared on the ground in citizen's dress, acting as General of the Third Brigade.
lead_paragraph: The Fifty-fifth Regiment, under the command of Major THOUROT, formed for inspection on Fourteenthstreet, between First and Second avenues, the soldierly bearing of the men eliciting the encomiums of the spectators. Col. LE GAL appeared on the ground in citizen's dress, acting as General of the Third Brigade. After nearly two hours' delay, Capt. DODGE and Dr. CRAWFORD, of the United States Army, Mayor WOOD, Ex-Gov. FISH, and other members of the Union Defence Committee, arrived and inspected the regiment. There were 414 men on parade. Some 450 members, impatient and in [???] at the quantity of red tape measured off to this regiment, have joined other regiments, some of which have left for the seat of war, while the others expect to go in a few days; 53 went with the Fourteenth Regiment, of Brooklyn; 62 go with the Garibaldi Guard, 25 with the Ninth Regiment and Swiss Guard, and the remainder with other regiments. The officers of the regiment are as follows:

abstract: The Yankee arrived here to-day, from Fortress Monroe, and brings the report that General BUTLER yesterday Captured Sewall's Point, with a loss of 84 killed and wounded; that the enemy lost between three and four hundred killed and wounded; that many prisoners were taken perhaps 600, and that on Thursday evening the enemy's pickets near the Fort were surprised, and 300 prisoners brought to the Fort. The War Department has information to the same effect.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday, May 25.

abstract: There is reason to hope that Tennessee will imitate Kentucky in declining to take a posi tion hostile the Union. In the Eastern part of the State the Union sentiment is predominant; in the middle a sort of modified secessionism is probably in the majority, while in the southwest, in the counties around Memphis, which produce cotton, and contain vast numbers of slaves, treason is rampant and aggressive.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The Boston Traveller of May 20 says: The State Treasurer is already examining engraved plates prepared by the America's Bank Note Company, the Natural Bank Note Company of New York, and by private associations, from which to issue the new scrip, authorized at the present extra session. The amount expences by Massachusetts up to Saturday [???] is about $325,000, all or nearly all taken from the loan voluntarily offered by the Banks. The Treasurer has thus far barrowed of the Banks, mostly but not altogether of the Boston Banks, the sum of $700,000, in sum's of not less than $20,000, not over $50,000, from each Bank. The first issue of the scrip will be to repay this $700,000 at par, the Treasurer's note given for those loans building both State and Banks to exchange the temporary notes for the permanent scrip, which insured.

abstract: Among the peculiarities of the American people, the facility with which they adapt themselves to changing circumstances of the times, is not the least conspicuous.
lead_paragraph: Among the peculiarities of the American people, the facility with which they adapt themselves to changing circumstances of the times, is not the least conspicuous. They grapple with the practical facts of the present, dealing with them always as actualities, without reference to the past, and with scarcely a dread of the future. Their business is with to-day, and they apply themselves to it with an earnestness that astonishes the slow people of other countries. While they thus take care of to-day, they have an abiding faith in to-morrow, and though busy and contented, in the main, with the present, they are always looking for a good time coming. Eight months ago there was not a people on the face of the earth so prosperous as ours. Peace everywhere prevailed. Business moved along with unwonted facilities. The merchant increased his commercial ventures, and the tradesman enlarged his stock of wares. The manufacturer doubled his purchases of the raw material and added to the number of operatives in his factories. The mechanic increased the dimensions of his workshop, and the agriculturist planted additional acres. In all the departments of industry, increased activity prevailed, and energy, life, rapidity of interchange of traffic was the order of the day everywhere. Six months passed away, and a frightful war loomed upon the horizon. Commerce called home its ships. Trade contracted its operations. Manufacturers limited the number of their operatives, and through all the branches of industry a timely and sagacious caution manifested itself. The genius of the Americas people was furling sails for the storm that was approaching. The trumpet-call to arms sounded over the land, and was responded to by a promptness and enthusiasm never before witnessed in any country. In two months, eighty thousand armed men lined the frontiers, while regiment after regiment defiled along this streets on their way to the field of honor, and perhaps to death. Here again, was exhibited the genius of the American people adapting itself to the new exigency, forgetting the tranquility of the past in answer to the demands of the present.
headline: {'main': 'The Genius of the American People.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Genius of the American People.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The mornig steamer from Norfolk is in. Gen. BUTLER only took nine hundred men, and did not go as far as Lyndhaven, but to a point nearer Fortress Monroe, where he is encamped. He will wait there until reinforcements arrive from New-York, when he will resume his march for Norfolk. He has expressed his determination to take the Navy Yard, or parish in the attempt.

abstract: We have a certified copy of the bill to arm the State, passed at the recent session of the Missouri Legislature. It provides that all the money in the Treasury, or which may be recovered from the proceeds of the special tax of one tenth of one per cent. on the $100, levied to secure the completion of certain railways, shall be part of the military fund that created, except the amount due in the month of June, 1861, on revenue bonds, and also to except a sufficiency to carry on the State Government, and pay the special appropriations to the Southwest Expedition, to the Blind Asylum, to the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, the Penitentiary, and two-thirds of the amount provided by law for the support of the Lunatic Asylum.

abstract: The Garibaldi Guard, Col. FREDERICK GEORGE D'UTASBY, took their position at 2 1/2 P.M., between Fifth and Sixth-avenues, marching by the head-quarters of the Union Defence Committee. They numbered about eleven hundred, and are still recruiting. This corps is composed largely of Germans, but there are in the regiment, many Italians, Hungarians, Swiss, Spaniards and Portugese. Their uniform is a suit of blue-black, the pants having a narrow red stripe, and the facing of the frockcoat being of red. Their hats are black, round, topped, wide, stiff brims, with a black feather and eagle. They have shoes with gaiters protecting the ankle and calf.

abstract: In analyzing the theory of Government under which the English Colonists in America became independent of the sovereignty of the parent State, and derived to themselves a national existence, permanently and indissolubly established under the present Federal Constitution, it is important to revert to the origin and development of those elements of social and political fraternity which originated and established the Federal Sovereignty, while they also secured to the people in general, as well as to the States in severalty, the enjoyment of their own peculiar and distinctive laws, customs, rights, privileges and independent forms of municipal government and jurisdiction within their own territorial precincts.

abstract: Mrs. WILLIAM McDONALD, and five children, reached this city yesterday, having arrived the same day in the Keystone State, with other fugitives, from Virginia. Mrs. McDONALD's story is one that has often been repeated.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. WILLIAM McDONALD, and five children, reached this city yesterday, having arrived the same day in the Keystone State, with other fugitives, from Virginia. Mrs. McDONALD's story is one that has often been repeated. Her husband, WM. MCDONALD, for a long time worked in the Brooklyn Navy-yard, as a ship carpenter, where he bore the character of an industrious man and a good citizen. Two years ago he accepted of an offer of work in the Gosport Navy-yard, at Portsmouth, Virginia, and went there, accompanied by his wife and five children. He had steady employment, and succeeded in saving about $500, which he placed in the Savings Bank at Portsmouth, of which TAZWELL TAYLOR is President. A few weeks ago, and just before the burning of the Navy-yard, he, in a private conversation with his fellow workmen, expressed a strong attachment for the Union, and the next day he received a notice to leave the State with his family, forthwith. He left home for the purpose of making the necessary arrangements to leave, but did not return; and Mrs. MCDONALD supposes, that he was murdered by the Secessionists. She waited for his coming until she received notice to leave, and then went to the Savings Bank to draw the money there deposited to enable her to leave. To her surprise, the President of the institution, Mr. TAYLOR, told her that she could have no money, but gave her some worthless skinplasters on the Bank of Virginia. As this was the best she could do, she received the worthless stuff, and through the aid of friends was enabled to take passage on the above steamer, leaving, furniture and other property behind. She landed in Brooklyn penniless, and was kindly provided for temporarily by Coroner ALFRED E. HORTON, who will see that she does not suffer until benevolent citizens, who are better able, make some permanent provision for her support. Any person disposed to aid Mrs. MCDONALD, can learn office particulars by calling at Coroner HORTON's office in Joralemon-street, at the rear of the City Hall.

abstract: A citizen of Kansas, formerly a resident of Virginia, has just returned to this city form a tour of observation through Northeastern Virginia. abstract: The Pine and Palm, JAMES REDPATH'S organ, has this contradiction of current rumors, which may be regarded as authoritative: JOHN BROWN, Jr., has never been in an "encampment of negroes, between Newcastle and Beaver," nor had one under his direction, nor been "plotting treason" there nor elsewhere recently. He has enough of his father's character to refuse to yield to any outside pressure when he knows that it is not pushing in the right direction. In what respect, pray, has this Government changed since it chased 200 colored men from Chicago? or flung poor LUCY, of Cleveland, back into the hell of Southern Slavery? Why should we fight its battles yet? JOHN BROWN, Jr., came to the East on business; and, while here, fully concurred in the views above given.

abstract: The name of Lieut. Col. FARNHAM, who succeeds the late Col. ELLSWORTH in the command of the Firemen's Brigade, has been erroneously confounded in some of the City papers with that of Capt. FARNHAM, formerly in the Mexican war, Col. NOAH ...
lead_paragraph: The name of Lieut. Col. FARNHAM, who succeeds the late Col. ELLSWORTH in the command of the Firemen's Brigade, has been erroneously confounded in some of the City papers with that of Capt. FARNHAM, formerly in the Mexican war, Col. NOAH L. FARNHAM, who now commands the regiment, is a merchant doing business on Broadway. He is the son of GEO. W. FARNHAM, of this City, and has long been identified with the Fire Department, having been several times elected Assistant Engineer. He is personally known to almost every member of the Department, and is universally popular. He was for some time a member of the Seventh Regiment, has a thorough knowledge of military tactics, and is possessed of every requisite for a good and efficient officer. Like his predecessor, Col. ELLSWORTH, he is somewhat diminutive in stature, from which fact he has long borne the soubriquet among the firemen of "Pony Farnham." In lamenting the sad loss sustained by the regiment in the fall of Col. ELLSWORTH, it is some consolation to know that it will continue to be commanded by one every way worthy to be his successor.

abstract: If the necessity of bringing the civil war to a prompt conclusion is universally recognized at the North, the Southern conspirators must be still more thoroughly convinced of it. Afraid of venturing too suddenly upon the experiment of direct taxation, which would, for the first, bring home to the slave-owner an awkward practical result of property in man,...
lead_paragraph: If the necessity of bringing the civil war to a prompt conclusion is universally recognized at the North, the Southern conspirators must be still more thoroughly convinced of it. Afraid of venturing too suddenly upon the experiment of direct taxation, which would, for the first, bring home to the slave-owner an awkward practical result of property in man, they founded their expectations of carrying on the peaceful machinery of Government by the continuance of duties upon imports, and of prosecuting the war with loans, secured by a pledge of certain export duties upon cotton. By thus taxing at once the ebb and flow of trade, they confidently calculated on meeting both the ordinary and extraordinary expenses of their Government, and in time of paying off the principle of their borrowed money. But in retaining the tariff system, it was necessary to make some concessions to the innovators, who had placed Free-trade in the front rank of the blessings to be realized in their negro Utopia. A tariff was, therefore, declared to be a temporary resort, in the absence of other immediate means of raising revenue; but it was to be fixed on a scale so far below that of the Federal Government as to insure to Southern ports that command of direct foreign intercourse, which a scheme of perfect Free-trade would only render more absolute. A tariff which is to take effect on the 1st of August was therefore arranged at a rate averaging ten per cent. below that of the Northern Custom-house; and this tariff has been looked to as guaranteering a vast access of foreign commerce, and of course a large addition to the revenue.

abstract: The First Regiment of Voluteers, Col. ALLEN commanding, positively got away on Monday without further disappointment. Several times they have been under orders for immediate departure, only to have their hopes of quickly seeing service, dashed by a countermand at the last moment--strangled by some unexpected coil of pestilent red-tape.
lead_paragraph: The First Regiment of Voluteers, Col. ALLEN commanding, positively got away on Monday without further disappointment. Several times they have been under orders for immediate departure, only to have their hopes of quickly seeing service, dashed by a countermand at the last moment -- strangled by some unexpected coil of pestilent red-tape. But their eager anxiety to be fairly in arms is at last accomplished, and by this morning they are bounding on their way to Fort Monroe in the good steamship State of Georgia.
