abstract: Always miscalculating, the rebels seem to have been wholly unprepared for the passage of the National troops across the Potomac. They had taken no pains to preserve and guard their communication with the force now isolated on the Maryland line; no concentration of troops is sufficient strength for...
lead_paragraph: Always miscalculating, the rebels seem to have been wholly unprepared for the passage of the National troops across the Potomac. They had taken no pains to preserve and guard their communication with the force now isolated on the Maryland line; no concentration of troops is sufficient strength for service had been effected at any convenient point; and our advices indicate the extremely imperfect organization and equipment of the scattered parties, to be found between Alexandria and Richmond. There is good reason, also, for believing their commissariat to be quite neglected, the frequent stories of their predatory excursions and forced contributions betraying the hard necessity which drives them to such violent expedients. Had the activity of Gen. SCOTT been anticipated, their own activity would certainly have been increased so as to meet his forward movement with a force adequate to dispute the soil with the invaders, before they had been so strongly reinforced as to defy attack.

abstract: The Ninth Regiment of New-York State Militia, which now musters its full complement of men, and is on the tenter hooks of anxiety to get away, had a grand parade and inspection on Saturday afternoon. They did not turn out with the volunteers and regular militia regiments that showed on Fourteenth street, but held a special review in Washington Paradeground, where the Union Defence Committee had...
lead_paragraph: The Ninth Regiment of New-York State Militia, which now musters its full complement of men, and is on the tenter hooks of anxiety to get away, had a grand parade and inspection on Saturday afternoon. They did not turn out with the volunteers and regular militia regiments that showed on Fourteenth street, but held a special review in Washington Paradeground, where the Union Defence Committee had appointed to meet them, and once more convince themselves of the Regiment's remarkable efficiency. That the Ninth is one of the most magnificent bodies New-York will be likely to send to the wars, is a great and uncontrovertible fact. It is composed almost entirely of young and stalwart Americans, most of whom have given up good situations, profitable trades, and paying mechanical employments, in their enthusiastic ardor to serve their country's cause against the common enemy of naitorous insurrection. They have been ready and eager to be called into immediate action for goodness knows how long; and have, on several occasions, actually been under marching orders, always, however, to be eventually disappointed and relegated, in vexation and disgust, to their respective company head-quarters. The regiment is superbly drilled, thoroughly equipped, and ought to be used as soon as possible.

abstract: One of the most remarkable features of the present crisis in our national affairs are the crude and inadequate views taken of it by foreigners, particularly Englishmen. They appear to think the tie that holds the States together is a mere rope of sand, to be severed at will; that there is no good reason why the country should not be broken into two, three,...
lead_paragraph: One of the most remarkable features of the present crisis in our national affairs are the crude and inadequate views taken of it by foreigners, particularly Englishmen. They appear to think the tie that holds the States together is a mere rope of sand, to be severed at will; that there is no good reason why the country should not be broken into two, three, or four Confederacies, instead of constituting one. They say that if the present Union combines elements that are uncongenial, or that have a mutual repulsion, why not leave them to their natural tendencies, instead of holding them together by force? The same idea was prevalent among a portion of our people at the North till the rupture actually occurred, when the alternative instantly presented itself to each section -- the triumph over the whole country of its own ideas, institutions and industries, or subjection of all these to the other.

abstract: Hon. AARON HARLAN, nominated to the vacancy caused by Minister CORWIN'S resignation, must be set down as an unconditional Union-man. In his speech, accepting the nomination, he said that he was in favor of voting the largest supplies, the most numerous hosts of men, [cheers,] as the very best means of bringing this unballowed rebellion to a speedy close. [Loud cheering] If it cost the nation thousands of millions of treasure, even that was better than going a holly to the devil at once! [Prolonged and uproarious cheering]. Better sacrifice a million of the best fives of the country, than let anarchy prevail. He deprecated any effusion of blood, any armies, any debt; he deplored all this, and the almost everlasting consequences that would follow; but he held that this mode of conducting the war was the cheapest and the most merciful. [Cheers.] Whip them quick, [cheers,] and whip them well. [Prolonged cheering, and cries of "good"] Overrun and crush them at once, as the very best thing for them as well as for us! [Prolonged cheering.]

abstract: Letters received in Brooklyn from members ofthe Fourteenth Regiment represent the men to be "in excellent health and good spirits, and in good fighting order." The oath of allegiance was administered to the Regiment, on Thursday, by Gen. MCDOWELL. With the exception of about fourteen, chiefly of Companies E and F, the troops were sworn in for the war. Mr. WM. C. BOOTH, of Col. WOOD's Staff, arrived in Brooklyn yesterday morning. We says the troops are in the best condition. There is no truth in the report that Col. WOOD contemplates returning home shortly. Yesterday afternoon at two o'clock, the Brooklyn Phalanx, Col. ADAMS, formed at the Armory, corner of Henry and Cranberry streets, and marched to Fourteenth-street. New-York, for inspection with other regiments of that City.

abstract: Gen. BUTLER appears to be turning his legal education, to good account, in the construction of the law in reference to articles that are contraband of war. Three negroes, having escaped into Fort Monroe, he set them at work on the fortifications, and when demanded by an F. F. V., he replied that they were contraband of war, for the reason that they might be employed by the enemy, for the service to which he had assigned them. We believe the General did so far modify his refusal, as to offer to give up the negroes, providing their owner would take the oath to support the Constitution of the United states! All this, upon the Sacred Soil of Virginia! We think the people of the State will find the General a match for them in more ways than one.

abstract: BRUTAL STABBING IN THE FOURTHY WARD.--A brutal case of stabbing, which will probably result in death, occurred in the Fourth Ward on Friday night, about 11 o'clock. The occurrence happened at a sailors' boarding-house, kept by Mrs. PENDERGAST, at No. 87 Cherry-street. A Welshman, named HENRY L.JONES, one of the mates of tha bark Genesee, of Brunswick, Maine, accompanied by a friend, went...
lead_paragraph: BRUTAL STABBING IN THE FOURTHY WARD. -- A brutal case of stabbing, which will probably result in death, occurred in the Fourth Ward on Friday night, about 11 o'clock. The occurrence happened at a sailors' boarding-house, kept by Mrs. PENDERGAST, at No. 87 Cherry-street. A Welshman, named HENRY L.JONES, one of the mates of tha bark Genesee, of Brunswick, Maine, accompanied by a friend, went into the house No. 87, where he had formerly boarded, and after remaining a short time, JOHN SAMUELS, a boarder in the house, also a Welshman, came in somewhat intoxicated. He immediately commenced a conversation with, JONES, and was very insolent and threatening. Soon he picked up a pitcher of water, and threw it into JONE's face, and fled. JONES and his friend remained about half an hour, when SAMUELS returned, and procuring a sheath-knife, met JONES in the hall, and assaulted and stabbed him. The knife entered the abdomen on the right side, inflicting a terrible wound, from which the intestines immediately protruded. SAMUELS endeavored to escape, and in his flight dropped the knife, which was picked up by a Mr. HOGAN, who secured the assassin. He was handed over to Roundsman ROBB, and by him conveyed to the Station house in Oak-street. Mr. JONES was immediately attended by Dr. MCGINN, who sewed up the wound, and the patient was then removed to the City Hospital. The wound is dangerous, and considered, fatal. SAMUEL's says that he once sailed under JONES, and was cruelly treated by him. He was not, however, with him on his last voyage. JONES is 33, and SAMUELS 20 years of age.

abstract: Below we give the order of Gen. PILLOW to the Tennessee troops to rendezvous at Jackson, Madison County, Tennessee. He says that immediate service demands the early presence of all the volunteers of that State. A glance at the map will reveal the fact that Jackson is a railroad centre, and that a road leads direct from that place to Columbus, Ky., twenty miles below Cairo, Jackson is easily reached by railroad from all parts of the South, and a large force can be speedily concentrated at that point. Here is the order:

lead_paragraph: The first regiment from the Granite State arrived here yesterday morning. It left Norwich in two detachments, (on the steamers Commodore and Connecticut;) the first arrived at the foot of Vestrystreet, North River, at 9, the second a little after 10 o'clock. The sons of New-Hampshire resident in this City met at 7 o'clock A.M. at the Brandreth House, in order to form a committee to welcome the regiment on its arrival. A.A. PETERSON, Esq., was appointed Chairman, and J.P. MARCH Secretary. After passing some resolutions, the meeting, numbering nearly five hundred, was addressed by H.H. PARKINS, Esq., Judge PEABODY, and others. They also joined in singing, "My Country, 'tis of Thee;" "The Star Spangled Banner," and the "Old Hundred." When the regiment landed, after being welcomed by the Committee, it marched down Canal-street to the Brandreth House, where it halted. Judge B.W. BONNEY, on behalf of the sons of New Hampshire resident in this City, presented to the regiment a handsome American flag, splendidly bordered with gold fringe, and with heavy golden tassels. Judge BONNEY said:

abstract: Letters received in Brooklyn from members of the Fourteenth Regiment represent the men to be "in excellent health and good spirits, and in good fighting order." The oath of allegiance was administered to the Regiment, on Thursday, by. Gen. MCDOWELL. With the exception of about fourteen, chiefly of Companies E and F, the troops were sworn in for the war. Mr. WM. C. BOOTH, of Col. WOOD's Staff, arrived in Brooklyn yesterday morning. He says the troops are in the best condition. There is no truth in the report that Col. WOOD contemplates returning home shortly. Yesterday afternoon at two o'clock, the Brooklyn Phalanx, Col. ADAMS, formed at the Armory, corner of Henry and Cranberry streets, and marched to Fourteenth-street, New-York, for inspection with other regiments of that City.

abstract: The Administration has taken measures which will probably settle the relation between Missouri and the Union. Large bodies of troops are to concentrate along the boundary of the State, in Illinois, Iowa and Kansas, ready to cooperate with the Union men and the Federal forces at St. Louis, should the effort be made to precipitate the State into rebellion; and to punish acts of outrage inflicted upon loyalists. It is unfortunate that the military spirit within the Slave States has been almost monopolised by the very class who now seek to destroy the Government, the Union men addicting themselves to peaceful pursuits, as if without suspicion of the plans by which they were being hurried into revolution. They have thus been left without organization and the means of resistance, and if they are to be saved, it will have to be by the paternal assistance of the National Government.

abstract: The long-promised Convention of delegates from the Border States meets to-day at Frankfort, Ky. At the time the meeting, was summoned, eight Slave States were entitled to representation, as still within the Union, and still having to decide whether or not to remain in it. Arkansas, Tennessee, North Carolina, and Virginia, declining to wait for advice on the subject, have already gone over to the rebels. Delaware, Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri remain; but Delaware adheres to her duty; Kentucky has finally declared for neutrality; Maryland and Missouri, overawed by national armies, are unable to act, though perhaps viciously disposed. The Convention, therefore, is of no possible consequence. Few will be present, and those few will be without authority to determine a policy, and without power to put it in action. It is questionable, indeed, whether any delegates will attend, save from Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: The long-promised Convention of delegates from the Border States meets to-day at Frankfort, Ky. abstract: GOV. KIRKWOOD, of Iowa, on May 19, sent in his Message to the Legislature now in session. It is uncompromisingly for the Union, and unsparing in its denunciation of the conspirators. One regiment has been mustered into service by the Government, and GOV. KIRKWOOD says that he is daily expecting the requisition for a second. Companies enough have been offered him to make up five regiments more, or seven in all GOV. KIRKWOOD calls attention to the unprotected state of the Missouri frontier, but does not recommend any specific action for its defence. The outrages said to have been perpetrated by the Indians on the western frontier he thinks have been exaggerated. He earnestly recommends a full exercise of all constitutional powers, on the part of the Legislature, to punish all persons who show any intention to give the rebels aid or comfort.
lead_paragraph: GOV. KIRKWOOD, of Iowa, on May 19, sent in his Message to the Legislature now in session. It is uncompromisingly for the Union, and unsparing in its denunciation of the conspirators. abstract: Among the passengers by the Africa, last week, was Mr. R.C. PARSONS, of Cleveland, Ohio, the newly appointed Consul of the United States for the port of Rio de Janeiro. We do not call attention to the fact that Mr. PARSONS, in order to insure a speedy arrival at the capital of Brazil, goes by way of Europe, making a voyage of nine thousand miles,...
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers by the Africa, last week, was Mr. R.C. PARSONS, of Cleveland, Ohio, the newly appointed Consul of the United States for the port of Rio de Janeiro. We do not call attention to the fact that Mr. PARSONS, in order to insure a speedy arrival at the capital of Brazil, goes by way of Europe, making a voyage of nine thousand miles, while from our own coasts the distance is only live thousand, but we wish to express our satisfaction that the Government has chosen a gentleman so well qualified by his abilities, character and social position, to fill this important Consulate, (so poorly filled for the last four years;) and also to say a few words concerning our diplomatic relations with the most important Government of South America.

abstract: The Ninth Regiment of New-York State Militia, which now musters its full complement of men, and is on the tenter books of anxiety to get away, had a grand parade and inspection on Saturday afternoon. They did not turn out with the volunteers and regular militia regiments that showed on Fourteenth street, but held a special review in Washington Parade ground, where the Union Defense Committee had...
lead_paragraph: The Ninth Regiment of New-York State Militia, which now musters its full complement of men, and is on the tenter books of anxiety to get away, had a grand parade and inspection on Saturday afternoon. They did not turn out with the volunteers and regular militia regiments that showed on Fourteenth street, but held a special review in Washington Parade ground, where the Union Defense Committee had appointed to meet them, and once convince themselves of the Regiment's remarkable efficiency. That the Ninth is one of the most magnificant bodies New-York will be likely to send to the wars, is a treat and uncontrovertible fact. It is composed almost entirely of young and stalwart Americans, most of whom have given up good situations, profitable trader, and paying mechanical employments, in their enthusiastic order to serve their country's cause against the common enemy of traitorous insurrection. They have been ready and eager to be called into immediate action for goodness knows how long; and have, on several occasions, actually been under marching orders, always, however, to be eventually disappointed and relegated, in vexation and disgust, to their respective company headquarters. The regiment is superbly drilled, thoroughly equipped, and ought to be used as soon as possible.

abstract: Since the alarm at Washington on Saturday, caused by the report that a battle was proceeding at Alexandria between the Federal forces and the rebels, no extraordinary excitement has occurred there. Movements of troops are constantly going on, but only in elaboration and perfection of the plan which was so consummately executed on...
lead_paragraph: Since the alarm at Washington on Saturday, caused by the report that a battle was proceeding at Alexandria between the Federal forces and the rebels, no extraordinary excitement has occurred there. Movements of troops are constantly going on, but only in elaboration and perfection of the plan which was so consummately executed on Thursday night, when thirteen thousand men were thrown into Virginia with so much celerity and quiet that even the inhabitants of Washington did not know of the movement until it was accomplished. At Alexandria the troops are engaged in constructing strong defensive works, and the Sixty-ninth Regiment, on Arlington Heights, have thrown up an earthwork one mile long and seven feet high. A considerable quantity of arms and ammunition has been discovered concealed in Alexandria, and of course seized and confiscated. The pickets there were fired upon, on Friday night, but no damage was done. An alarm, however, was given, and the troops slept on their arms the remainder of the night. Additional troops are almost hourly passing over from Washington into Virginia, and the force there now cannot number much less than twenty thousand. It is stated that the Government has determined to order 20,000 more troops to rendezvous at Washington. Gen. CAMERON, Secretary of War, is expected to visit this City shortly, on important business connected with his Department.

abstract: Henry H. Evertson and others, vs. Mary Ann Given, et al. The plaintiffs are the children of Waller Evertson, deceased, and their guardian, George B. Evertson, invested $6,000 of their money in 6-11ths of a bond and mortgage for $11,000 in his own name, and in such form as not to disclose his fiduciary character.
lead_paragraph: Henry H. Evertson and others, vs. Mary Ann Given, et al. -- The plaintiffs are the children of Waller Evertson, deceased, and their guardian, George B. Evertson, invested $6,000 of their money in 6-11ths of a bond and mortgage for $11,000 in his own name, and in such form as not to disclose his fiduciary character. Being indebted to the estate of Nicholas Evertson, deceased, for an antecodent debt, George B. Evertson assigned said 6-11ths of this bond and mortgage to Eliza Evertson, the sole acting executrix of the will of Nicholas Evertson, deceased, as security for said debt. The plaintiffs filed their bill against the executrix alone in June, 1830, alleging these facts, and that George B. Evertson had died insolvent; that Eliza Evertson had received considerable sums of money by means of the mortgage, and prayed for an account against her, and that their part of the mortgage might be decreed to them, and the executrix be restrained from collecting it, and for further relief.

abstract: The recent advance of the Federal troops into Virginia from the District, indicates the intention of the Government to effect an early evacuation by the rebels of the points now held by them on the Maryland line; or, in the event of their still holding their position at...
lead_paragraph: The recent advance of the Federal troops into Virginia from the District, indicates the intention of the Government to effect an early evacuation by the rebels of the points now held by them on the Maryland line; or, in the event of their still holding their position at Harper's Ferry, to dislodge them at an early day, with the cooperation of troops from Pennsylvania or the Relay House. The topography of the country happily lends itself to this strategic movement; and the condition of the rebels is such as to give promise of their shortly being compelled to save themselves from capture by a retreat through the Valley of the Shenandoah.

abstract: Mr. WILLIAM A. HARRIS, a well known citizen of the village of Newtonville, in Newton, was arrested yesterday by order of the town authorities, on the charge of cruelty to his cattle. He was brought before Justice RUTTER for examination, and was bound over for trial next month. The attention of the Selectmen was directed to the barn of Mr. HARRIS, and the promises visited. A scene was presented to the officials which will scarcely be credited. The carcasses of seven cows and a horse were found, under circumstances which left little doubt that the animals had starved to death.

abstract: Twelve years ago, a nation, after long submission to wrongs that were known to all the world, asserted the rights guaranteed in its Constitution, and separated itself from the Government that oppressed it.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, a nation, after long submission to wrongs that were known to all the world, asserted the rights guaranteed in its Constitution, and separated itself from the Government that oppressed it. It was a secession justified by the compact of union; it was based on principles of public right, and made in the cause of Constitutional Liberty. The seceding people spoke a different language from the other; they had different courts, different institutions, different tariffs, and a Constitution of their own, which had lasted near a thousand years. If ever there was a revolution which England might have recognized, it was the Hungarian Revolution of 1848 and 149.

abstract: Our Washington advices contain information showing how extremely unprepared are the rebels for active hostilities. For the occupation of the important junction of the Manassas Gap with the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, whereat communications with Harper's Ferry may be kept open and an advance on Richmond opposed, only 5,000 men had been detailed, and these imperfectly armed and equipped, and with no disposition to assume the offensive.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington advices contain information showing how extremely unprepared are the rebels for active hostilities. For the occupation of the important junction of the Manassas Gap with the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, whereat communications with Harper's Ferry may be kept open and an advance on Richmond opposed, only 5,000 men had been detailed, and these imperfectly armed and equipped, and with no disposition to assume the offensive. They were busy, when last observed, entrenching their position, as if it were merely a defensive one. It is quite time to inquire into the whereabouts of that great patriotic army, with which Gov. LETCHER engaged to sweep the first invader of the sacred soil into the Potomac. Its opportunity for a speedy redemption of the pledge is swiftly disappearing. Had the blow been struck last week, it might have succeeded. This week, with the reinforcements thrown in from Washington, it has become doubtful. Next week it will be impossible. Aux armes, LETCHER! or your head may do penance for its weakness in vulgar hemp.

abstract: So far as the returns have been received from the northeastern and northwestern counties of Virginia, the result of the vote upon secession is surprisingly adverse to that measure. The counties of Louden, Berkeley, and Morgan, at the eastward of the Alleghanies, and actually in the occupation of the troops mustered to combat feudal authority, have given an aggregate majority of 2 300 for the Union. From the west of the Alleghanies the returns are of the same character. No county yet reported has failed to declare for the Union; and yet among those reported are several which had been universally conceded to the Secessionists, and whose defection must cause very disagreeable sensations at Richmond. Kanawha, Cabell and Wayne are so largely slaveholding as to authorize a previous confidence in their identification with the Southern movement. Kanawha gives 1,200 for the Union, Cabell 650, Wayne 800. It would be no matter of surprise if results of a similar character were to come from all the trans-Alleghanian counties, down to the Tennessee line, thus proving how averse the freemen of the West are from the destructive policy which the Richmond nest of reckless conspirators has marked out for the Commonwealth, and how willingly they would remain in a Union which is assuring them unexampled prosperity and opulence.
lead_paragraph: So far as the returns have been received from the northeastern and northwestern counties of Virginia, the result of the vote upon secession is surprisingly adverse to that measure. abstract: The General Assemblies of the two great branches of the American Presbyterian Church, (Old and New School,) now convened respectively at Philadelphia and Syracuse, have defined their position toward the Government in this crisis of its being.
lead_paragraph: The General Assemblies of the two great branches of the American Presbyterian Church, (Old and New School,) now convened respectively at Philadelphia and Syracuse, have defined their position toward the Government in this crisis of its being. In the New School Assembly a series of resolutions, bold, decisive and unmistakable in their loyalty, has been passed unanimously, and in the most solemn manner. The unholy conspirators who in their lust of power, have violated every command of the Decalogue, every precept of the Gospels, and every canon of the Church Catholic, received a just castigation; while unable to find words in which to record their estimate of these pirate-traitors, the Assembly could only "express its amazement at their wickedness, and at the bold advocacy and defence thereof." The castigation of the sword, also, now in store for them, was solemnly indorsed; and, before "God, the Supreme Lord and King of all the world," they proclaimed that, "in the judgment of the Assembly, there is no blood or treasure too precious to be devoted to the defence and perpetuity of the Government in all its constitutional authority."

abstract: There is no change of importance to note in the disposition of the Federal forces in Virginia. They are busily engaged in fortifying the positions then have occupied, and the general impression is that for the present no further important advance will be made towards Richmond and other points in the interior of the State until Gen. BUTLER con siders himself in sufficiently strong force to advance on Norfolk.
lead_paragraph: There is no change of importance to note in the disposition of the Federal forces in Virginia. They are busily engaged in fortifying the positions then have occupied, and the general impression is that for the present no further important advance will be made towards Richmond and other points in the interior of the State until Gen. BUTLER con siders himself in sufficiently strong force to advance on Norfolk. This, it is understood, he will not do until his command numbers at least fifteen thousand men, beside a sufficient force to garrison Fortress Monroe, and hold it secure. The Government doubtless intends to make a movement on Richmond, Norfolk, and Harper's Ferry simultaneously.

abstract: Owing to the civil war that has unhappily broken out in America, there are fewer vessels of that country in this port than usual, and there is good reason to conclude that our trade with our young republican sister will be greatly checked, if not altogether interrupted, so long as the present disputes exist. The measures resorted to by the Southern Confederacy to grant letters-of-marque, are viewed with great concern by shipowners. On Wednesday last, Capt. ROWLAND, of the New York ship Joseph Fish, applied to the magistrates presiding at our Police Court for the purpose of asking permission to take the oath of allegiance to Her Majesty. It appeared from his statement that he is a native of Barnstaple, but he has been naturalized in America. He is about sailing from this port with a cargo of cost for Cuba, but it is apprehensiv, as the ship is an American, that he may be captured. As he felt desirous of sailing under British colors, he also wished to transfer his allegiance to the Crown of Great Britain. The magistrates informed him that he must have his ship duly chartered as a British one, in accordance with the provisions of the merchant Shipping Act, if he wished to secure the protection of the British flag. The captain thanked the magistrates, and left the acurt somewhat perplexed as to the best course that he could adopt to secure the speedy departure of his ship, which is laden with barrels of small coal. The American shipowners and masters who are now in this port are placed in a similar painful situation. Some of them are determined to hoist British colors their passage outwards, while others declare they will lose every stick rather than lower the American flag. The American news is eagerly anticipated every day, not only by the natives of that country, but also by the shipbrokers and mercantile men of the port, who are seriously affected by the war that has broken out. Exaggerated rumors of a very gloomy character are continually circulated throughout the town. One train brings intelligence of the complete or partial stoppage of iron, tin, and other works in the neighborhood of Dowlais, Merthyr, Newbridge, Abersychan, and other districts on the hills, whilst reports are rife that the masters have given notice of a reduction of no less than twenty per cent in the wages, in consequence of the want of confidence which is naturally felt in such troublous times. We fear that this town and neighborhood will, for some time to come, be serious sufferers by the war that has just broken out.

abstract: The portion of the British people who will be the greatest sufferers by the terrible convulsion which is now shaking society and disturbing all the peaceful pursuits of industry in the United and the Confed erate States of America is that which resides in the northwestern district of England, consisting of Lancashire and Cheshire, and in the western districts of
lead_paragraph: The portion of the British people who will be the greatest sufferers by the terrible convulsion which is now shaking society and disturbing all the peaceful pursuits of industry in the United and the Confed erate States of America is that which resides in the northwestern district of England, consisting of Lancashire and Cheshire, and in the western districts of Scotland, in and around the flourishing city of Glasgow. These districts not only find in the Northern and Southern States the best markets for the products of their industry -- in common with the whole of the mining and manufacturing districts of England -- but they also derive from the Southern States much the greater portion of their supply of cotton and tobacco, and from the Northern States a large, if not the largest, portion of their supplies of grain, flour and provisions. In addition to there commercial relations, the ports of the Mersey and the Clyde are interested to a great extent in the shipping trade of the Atlantic, which is placed in considerable peril by the blockade of the Southern ports, and by the issuing of letters-of-marque, which will soon cover the ocean with privateers, who, at the best, are only one degree removed from pirates. Lancashire and the West of Scotland, containing between them a population of at least 4,000,000 inhabitants, are thus deeply affected, not only as producers, but as consumers and ship-owners, by the civil war which has broken out between the people of the Northern and the Southern States. It requires much greater sagacity than we possess, or, indeed, than is granted to man, to foresee all the evils that may be involved in this terrible conflict; yet even at this early state of the strife, and when so much is still wrapped in obscurity, it may he well to consider, and endeavor to estimate some of the evils which it may bring upon these populous districts. The experience of the American war of Independence, and of the second American war, in 1812-15, proved that a war with the United States was the greatest misfortune that could happen to those districts. During both those wars the ordinary course of industry was stopped, great multitudes of people were thrown oat of employment, and beggary and pauperism prevailed in every town and village of these districts. We are now about to witness, not a war with the American people, but a war amongst the American people, and it deeply interests us to known how far the effects of the latter will resemble those of the former.

abstract: Some two months ago the bark Sarah was seized at this port as a slaver, but it was not until a few days since that United States Marshal MURRAY received the order for the breaking out of her cargo, an inspection of which merely showed that it was only such as is carried by all vessels bound to the Coast. A day or two since, however, the Marshal found a young man named DELANO, who had shipped to go in the Sarah, to whom the captain, named DAVID REED MILLER, voluntarily stated that he was going to the Coast after a cargo of negroes. Two or three other witnesses are also ready to swear to the same statement. The case having been set down for trial yesterday, the captain appeared at the United States Marshal's Office to testify in the case, but while he was waiting for the proceedings to commence, a warrant was made out for his arrest, and he was detained for trial. An inspection of the articles of the Sarah shows that the captain's name is entered as DAVID REED -- leaving off the MILLER -- that DELANO's name is put down as "Comstock," and, in fact, that the crew list does not compare at all with the names of the men who had shipped. The case was postponed on account of the absence of a material witness.

abstract: Perhaps the best chance for pacification which now exists, is that both sides should marshal and measure their forces at the distance preserved between them by those States, which, whatever their leanings, have not yet committed themselves to an actual part in the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the best chance for pacification which now exists, is that both sides should marshal and measure their forces at the distance preserved between them by those States, which, whatever their leanings, have not yet committed themselves to an actual part in the conflict. There may still be some hope that, the longer they look at each other, and the more coolly they calculate -- on the one hand, the difficulty of carrying the war into the Southern enemy's territory -- on the other, the undeniable danger, at the South, that a civil war may draw after it a servile one -- the more probably counsels of prudence and moderation may regain the ascendancy; and a protracted conflict, from which neither party can rationally hope for advantage, may be avoided. Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS' Message, of the 29th ult., to the Montgomery Congress, states that the South will resist subjugation, to the direst extremity. It is the temper or the South to regard itself as unduly subjugated, when it is not unduly ascendant; it broke out from the Union because it could not have all its own way in it. But the very intemperance of that final outbreak -- preceded, as it had been, by so many other intemperances -- sufficiently showed, to our mind, that the South was not a fit component part of a Union which had become resolved not to endure a progressive series of encroachments of Southern -- that is, slaveholding -- dominion over free communities which had abolished Slavery in their own States, and were not willing to submit to its extension in new territories, where the local majorities proved adverse to its admission.

abstract: When DANIEL WEBSTER was last in this country, some fifteen years ago, he dined one day in society with SIDNEY SMITH. After a good deal of sparring, in which the reverend wit worked the sore subject of repudiation, from which he had suffered heavily, with many of his friends, he asked WEBSTER -- abruptly, as it seemed to the gentleman from whom the story comes, and who was present -- whether he anticipated a disruption of the Union, at no very remote date. WEBSTER'S answer was a prompt and unqualified "Most decidedly." "Will it, in your opinion, be accompanied with bloodshed?" was SIDNEY'S further question. "Most probably," was WEBSTER'S answer. Indeed, after the "nullification" business, the chance of Southern secession must always have presented itself as on the cards to all American minds but those of the optimist order, which is not largely represented among statesmen.
lead_paragraph: When DANIEL WEBSTER was last in this country, some fifteen years ago, he dined one day in society with SIDNEY SMITH. After a good deal of sparring, in which the reverend wit worked the sore subject of repudiation, from which he had suffered heavily, with many of his friends, he asked WEBSTER -- abruptly, as it seemed to the gentleman from whom the story comes, and who was present -- whether he anticipated a disruption of the Union, at no very remote date. WEBSTER'S answer was a prompt and unqualified "Most decidedly." "Will it, in your opinion, be accompanied with bloodshed?" was SIDNEY'S further question. "Most probably," was WEBSTER'S answer. Indeed, after the "nullification" business, the chance of Southern secession must always have presented itself as on the cards to all American minds but those of the optimist order, which is not largely represented among statesmen.

abstract: WIGFALL, late of Texas, now of the C.S.A. generally, has written a letter to somebody down South, in which he declares his fixed determination to take possession of the City of Washington as early at least as the 15th of June: that he will not postpone its capture an hour beyond the setting of the sun on that day. We regret to hear this of WIGFALL. We had hoped to be permitted to retain the Capital until about the 1st of August. Congress has been called in extra session for the Fourth of July, and it will require the better part of a month to finish up the business which will bring it together. A good deal of legislation is necessary, nay indispensable to the welfare of the Republic, (we mean, of course, the U.S.A. Republic,) and if the Capital shall be taken possession of by WIGFALL before the 4th, we really do not see where Congress will have a safe place for its meeting. It might, perhaps, find temporary accommodations in Toronto or some other Canadian city, but that would be expensive. Besides, who knows that when WIGFALL shall have taken possession of Washington, he will not be for taking possession of Toronto, or of all Canada for that matter. Those "seven-league boots" of his are doubtless capable of making the longest strides. We hope that WIGFALL will reconsider his determination in respect to this matter, and that Gen. SCOTT will use his influence with him to produce a result so much to be desired. It will be greatly more convenient for all parties to pass the Capitol over to WIGFALL, after Congress shall have adjourned -- that is to say, if WIGFALL has really made up his mind to take possession of it. If he insists upon its occupancy before fore Congress meets, we may be compelled to fight for it. If he will wait, the authorities may possibly say to him as the coon said to Capt. Scott, "We'll come down." We trust WIGFALL will not be precipitate.

abstract: The French Government has no more idea than the English of participating in the American quarrel; and it nevertheless takes, like England, the surest method of becoming a party. The Secretary for Foreign Affairs, M. THOUVENEL, has, we are told, addressed a circular to the agents of his Government in the...
lead_paragraph: The French Government has no more idea than the English of participating in the American quarrel; and it nevertheless takes, like England, the surest method of becoming a party. The Secretary for Foreign Affairs, M. THOUVENEL, has, we are told, addressed a circular to the agents of his Government in the insurgent States, instructing them to preserve the strictest neutrality; in no case lending their countenance or support to one rather than to the other of the hostile factions. We submit that international discourtesy could take no more offensive form. The Government of France has official knowledge of only one power within the territorial bounds of the Union, and that is the Government of the United States. Its commercial agents hold their places by virtue of the exequatur granted by this Government; and the treaties of friendship and alliance existing between the two countries, and all the various commercial privileges and arrangements which the Consule are appointed to administer, are so many obligations to the fulfillment of every friendly service to the Federal Government. But strict neutrality is an assumption of the existence of two Powers instead of a single one within our national limits; and an admission that of those two Powers one has no more claims upon the alliance, sympathy and support of a foreign Government than the other. We are thus arraigned for trial at the bar of mankind as the equal of a perjured, rebellious and disloyal conspiracy; and we shall only know with which side go the good wishes of France when we shall know which side is victorious. This willful ignoring of the lofty claims of the American Government -- this indifferent choosing between Christ and Barabbas -- will not strengthen the regard we are accustomed to entertain for the people and the Government of France. It might even appear advisable to withdraw the exequatur of all the French Consuls in the seceding States, not with the purpose of damaging French commerce in their ports, for there is no commerce of any sort there to be injured, but simply as an assertion of proper national self-respect against foreign depreciation and insult. Our business in this deplorable contest is to prove we have a Government -- a proof that seems to be as much needed at Paris as at New-Orleans.

abstract: The demoralization of the South is a matter which may well puzzle the brain of philosophers. Judged by the ordinary rules of human action, it is as incomprehensible as it is universal.
lead_paragraph: The demoralization of the South is a matter which may well puzzle the brain of philosophers. Judged by the ordinary rules of human action, it is as incomprehensible as it is universal. The States repudiate their stocks, and the people select, as their leader and chief, the originator and leader of repudiation, thus making the trampling upon State obligations a principle of political action. Dishonesty on the part of the State is reflected in the taint of commercial honor. Merchants whose wares were purchased on credit, complaining of no lack of ability to pay, and with abundant means of meeting their notes, repudiate their obligations, witnessing in triumph the bankruptcy which they bring upon their creditors. Collecting agents, holding funds collected of their own people in trust for Northern creditors, apply them to their own uses, making the war, which themselves aided in originating, the apology for their violation of faith. Cabinet Ministers who, while in the service of the Government, plundered the National Treasury in aid of rebellion, who, while the nation was confiding in their honor, and their regard for official oaths, were concocting treason; and who, while enjoying the dignity and receiving the emoluments of official place, played the peculator, the conspirator, and the spy, are placed high in position, made Generals, have a place among Southern gentlemen, and are accepted in all respects as honorable men. Military and naval officers, who were educated by the Federal Government, who were clothed by it, fed by it, supported by it, given a high status in society by it, desert the flag they have sworn to support, and join in a grand conspiracy for its destruction. With all this infamy attached to them, Southern society pets, and "Southern chivalry" honors them. Foreign Ministers and Consuls prostitute their positions to the injury of the nation they represent, and play the traitor through the letters which gave them credence, and violate the instructions which they were sworn to respect. All these violations of duty, all these perversions of principle, all this abandonment of manhood, all this trampling upon everything which honorable men all over the civilized world hold sacred, is accepted by the Southern mind as evidences of patriotism, and no word of dissent is uttered by Southern society, and no lisp of censure finds a place in the Southern Press. Governors applaud, and legislatures approve it all, while the universal sentiment pronounces it in accordance with Southern ethics, and the sanctions of chivalry.
headline: {'main': 'The Demoralization of the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Demoralization of the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. CHARLES GAYLOR is WATER GARDEN. Mr. CHARLES GAYLOR is probably the best known American dramatist of the day. He it is who supplies our stars with the literary fuel whereby they burn brightly in the remoter barns of this great and glorious country.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. CHARLES GAYLOR is WATER GARDEN. Mr. CHARLES GAYLOR is probably the best known American dramatist of the day. He it is who supplies our stars with the literary fuel whereby they burn brightly in the remoter barns of this great and glorious country. The amount ofsin which he has in this way committed cannot be estimated, nor is it always spared to us her, where star authors are at a discount, and their productions voted a bore. To inter into the spirit of Mr. GAYLOR's muse, it is necessary to transport one's self to the country. He is the SOVIET of the provinces. His works are an Alexandrian library is themselves. Every actor, actress and infant, prodigy possesses a manuscript. If the Cocktail Guard should happen to die on the field of glory -- a very unlikely thing, to be sure -- it would be found that each of its members had a specially written play by Mr. CHARLES GAYLOR. carefully preserved to his knapsack.

abstract: The Government has already made contracts with the Novelty Iron Works and other establishments for a small number of gunboats, and its engineers are rapidly completing designs for the six larger war-vessels ordered by the last Congress, the keel of at least one of them being laid. It is further understood that tenders will be invited for a large
lead_paragraph: The Government has already made contracts with the Novelty Iron Works and other establishments for a small number of gunboats, and its engineers are rapidly completing designs for the six larger war-vessels ordered by the last Congress, the keel of at least one of them being laid. It is further understood that tenders will be invited for a large number of gun-boats, to be built as soon as may be. It is possible that the delay in getting this work started will have done no damage; a discussion of the subject would hardly accelerate matters; but, in the present hurry, the Government should be as little embarrassed as possible by examining, testing and weighing the new plans and improvements of ambitious inventors and builders, however excellent they might prove if there were plenty of time to develop them. While light machinery, economical as to fuel and maintenance, should in ordinary times be a leading consideration, the demand of the present emergency is simply for gun-boats -- up to the ordinary standard of design and workmanship, of course, but not necessarily beyond it, if the improvement is to cause much further delay, or any risk of temporary inefficiency while new devices are being adapted and perfected.

abstract: A well known lawyer and democratic orator was summarily punished at a saloon in the vicinity of City Hall Square, Monday night, for uttering unpatriotic sentiments. He gave it as his opinion, that Col. ELLSWORTH had no business to enter the Marshall House at Alexandria, as it was invading private rights, and therefore the proprietor was justified in killing him. A bystander promptly knocked down the utterer of this opinion. The rebels have some sympathizers in this City, but they generally act with discretion and keep quiet.

abstract: Salutes of minute guns were fired at the Army posts at this station yesterday, in deference to the memory of Surgeon-Gen. THOMAS LAWSON, of the United States Army, who died recently. Dr. LAWSON served in the Wars of 1812-'15, and accompanied Gen. GAINES at the relief of Florida. His extraordinary efforts to promote the interests of the service was so marked, that the very uncommon honor for a medical officer, of being made a Brigadier-General in the Army, was conferred upon him. The service flags were all at half mast from muster to sundown, at Forts Columbus, Hamilton, &c.
lead_paragraph: Salutes of minute guns were fired at the Army posts at this station yesterday, in deference to the memory of Surgeon-Gen. THOMAS LAWSON, of the United States Army, who died recently. abstract: Further important movements, by way of strengthening the positions occupied by the Federal troops in Virginia, are reported as having occurred at the seat of war within the last twenty-four hours. The Sevently-first Regiment of New-York yesterday left their quarters at the Washington Navy-yard, and proceeded down the river, and it was reported that their destination was Acquia Creek, but this report proves to have been incorrect.
lead_paragraph: Further important movements, by way of strengthening the positions occupied by the Federal troops in Virginia, are reported as having occurred at the seat of war within the last twenty-four hours. The Sevently-first Regiment of New-York yesterday left their quarters at the Washington Navy-yard, and proceeded down the river, and it was reported that their destination was Acquia Creek, but this report proves to have been incorrect. They proceeded to Alexandria, to support the Michigan Regiment and the Fire Zouaves, making a force of three thousand men there, besides a battery of flying artillery. The Government has made arrangements to put the Orange and Alexandria Railroad in operation again, which will greatly facilitate the transportation of Army material, preparatory to a demonstration in the direction of Manassas Gap Junction, where the rebel forces are entrenching themselves and increasing their numbers. The command of the Federal troops in Virginia was yesterday vested in Brig.-Gen. MCDOWELL, of the regular Army. -- Gen. SANDFORD being returned to his command of the NEW-YORK forces in the District of Columbia.

abstract: -THE SARNIA AND GREAT WESTERN ROUTE. The schooner Alpha arrived here yesterday morning with a cargo of corn from Hamilton, which was shipped from Chicago on the 11th, per propeller Alleghany via Sarnia and Great Western Railways time from Chicago to Oswego, six days. This cargo was contracted through to NewYork and last night left here in Old Oswego Line canal boats for its destination.
lead_paragraph: -- THE SARNIA AND GREAT WESTERN ROUTE. -- The schooner Alpha arrived here yesterday morning with a cargo of corn from Hamilton, which was shipped from Chicago on the 11th, per propeller Alleghany via Sarnia and Great Western Railways -- time from Chicago to Oswego, six days. This cargo was contracted through to NewYork and last night left here in Old Oswego Line canal boats for its destination. By running propellers between Hamilton and Oswego, no route leading to the seaboard can equal this in reference to speed. The benefit grain receives by being shipped over the railways connecting Lakes Huron and Erie with Ontario, together with the fact in view that Welland Canal tolls have been raised on produce coming to American ports, should stimulate increased shipments over this route, which last year became so popular among shippers West. -- Oswego Times.

abstract: The obvious intention of those European Powers with whom friendly relations are desirable, is to apply to the United States principle of international law invented or revived for the occasion; and wholly uncurrent between themselves. In the European code, privateering is piracy; yet it ceases to be piracy when a causeless rebellion in America desires to use it for the destruction of the most forbearing of Governments.
lead_paragraph: The obvious intention of those European Powers with whom friendly relations are desirable, is to apply to the United States principle of international law invented or revived for the occasion; and wholly uncurrent between themselves. In the European code, privateering is piracy; yet it ceases to be piracy when a causeless rebellion in America desires to use it for the destruction of the most forbearing of Governments. The right of a nation to blockade its own ports was never doubled in Europe; and yet the London Press recommended almost unanimously a denial of the right to the United States, on the strength of an inadequate precedent, which the Disunionists, in their control of this Government, created as a preliminary of their intended conspiracy. The light of search is an established principle of European international law, and has never been questioned in this country, where our only objections have applied to the made of exercising it; and yet we are told with the voice, by the European Press, that the right is not, possessed by the Government of the United States.

abstract: It is propable that the Conservative Union ment of Northwestern Virginia, who checked the active movement, in the Wheeling Convention, of that portion of the State for immediate organization for a defence against the incursion of armed rebels from east of the mountains, have learned the ill effects of taking counsel from their fears in times of revolution. The predictions of Mr. CARLILE, that traitor solidiery would within a few...
lead_paragraph: It is propable that the Conservative Union ment of Northwestern Virginia, who checked the active movement, in the Wheeling Convention, of that portion of the State for immediate organization for a defence against the incursion of armed rebels from east of the mountains, have learned the ill effects of taking counsel from their fears in times of revolution. The predictions of Mr. CARLILE, that traitor solidiery would within a few days be in their midst, to crash out the liberties they still maintained, have probably been realized. Grafton, at the junction of the Parkersburgh Branch, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, where but one man, in a vote of four hundred and fifty-two, cast his vote for ratifying the secession ordinance, it is reported, has now a thousand armed rebels quartered within its limits; with a large number at Fettermann, a little village to the west.

lead_paragraph: The only Government in the world which resembles our own in all its essential features is that of Switzerland. It is composed of twenty-two cantons, each one independent in the exercise of every function that does not conflict with the national pact, which is the paramount law of the land. It has preceded us in the same experience through which we are now passing, and has settled for itself for all time the great question which must sooner or later arise in all confederated States -- the relative power and authority of the general or local Governments.

abstract: We are disgusted to learn from about a hundred and fifty Confederate newspapers most of them, by-the-way, dingy, illegible and fureily ungrammatical concerns that the people of these Free and United States are groaning under the mostly earnings and bloody despotism that ever existed. It seems that a beastly drunkard and human baboon to use the genteelest epithets with which the chivalry...
lead_paragraph: We are disgusted to learn from about a hundred and fifty Confederate newspapers -- most of them, by-the-way, dingy, illegible and fureily ungrammatical concerns -- that the people of these Free and United States are groaning under the mostly earnings and bloody despotism that ever existed. It seems that a beastly drunkard and human baboon -- to use the genteelest epithets with which the chivalry characterize the President -- has fully got his head on the [???] of the twenty-two millions of white men in the twenty-three loyal States, having subjugated them with an case which, to say the least, bodes ill for the two-or three-millions of contumacious Confederates who flatter themselves that their paper ordinances and one-horse Government can stop him in his march to undivided empire. He controls all the presses, dictates in all the pulpits, [???] tribute on a hundred cities, coerces Wall-street, butchers all the white-men and negroes who venture to differ from him in opinion, lights his post-prandial cigar with the Constitution, and indeed rules generally with a ruthless ferocity compared with which the iron away of DIOCLETIAN was divide. Against such a monster who would not fight? But still -- let us be pardoned the vulgarism --we don't see it.
headline: {'main': 'Hard to See.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Hard to See.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. REAGAN, the Postmaster-General of the C.S.A., has issued a proclamation announcing that, after Friday next, he shall assume the entire control of the postal service of the seceding States. Until very recently the United States have enjoyed the privilege of transporting the mails in those States, from the postage on which they have received a revenue bearing but a lean ratio in proportion to the expenses incurred. Some of the Postmasters have paid over the amounts collected by them, and some have repudiated payment. The honoring of drafts by Southern debtors has not of late been popular in the Southern States, and Postmasters have not ventured to any great extent upon singularity in this respect. Still the Government bore the expenses of the service with becoming patience, which expenses the C.S.A., while they accepted the favor with a consistency rarely departed from, declined to share.
lead_paragraph: Mr. REAGAN, the Postmaster-General of the C.S.A., has issued a proclamation announcing that, after Friday next, he shall assume the entire control of the postal service of the seceding States. abstract: A NEW MAP OF THE UNITED STATES. -- GOLDTEWAIT's Map of the United States, just published by J.Q. COLTON, No. 145 Nassau street, contains some novel and interesting features. On all the railroads, the distance of every ten miles is distinctly marked. The dile and width of gauge is shown, also the double and single trank, position of forts, the population of each State from 1796 to 1860, ratio of slaves to total population in the Slave States, the time of day at any centre of longitude when compared with soon at Washington and Greenwich. The map is about three feet square, and is admirably adapted to general use, especially in there times, when we follow accurately and intelligently the movements of troops.

abstract: In olden times, when the Latin races poured forth their thousands to punish the infidel history recorded their prosreas and their career of glory gave birth to a new word Clivalry. To-day, when the state is greater than it was then, and when the word is in danger of losing its significance, we find the descendants of these heroic peoples true to their historic fame. Once more they have buckled on their armor
lead_paragraph: In olden times, when the Latin races poured forth their thousands to punish the infidel history recorded their prosreas and their career of glory gave birth to a new word -- Clivalry. To-day, when the state is greater than it was then, and when the word is in danger of losing its significance, we find the descendants of these heroic peoples true to their historic fame. Once more they have buckled on their armor to succor the distressed, to rescue the helpless from captivity, to avenge a grievous wrong to the civilization of the age, and to make a name in the brilliant pages of the only pure history in the world. It is the privilege of the Garibaldi Guard to renew the great traditions of the several nationalities of which it is composed. Those who saw the noble battalions, as they filed down Broadway yesterday, cannot doubt the manly strength that will do this. A finer body of men has not left the City. The majority have seen service in other fields; know what war means, and would not, except from that sense of duty which makes all men heroes, renew its horrors. But the cause for which they now fight is their own cause, and, we may depend upon it, they will make it good. No knightly behest is more sacred to them than the championship of the Union; no devoir more gallant than fighting for its preservation.

abstract: Some of our best artists have volunteered for the war. They are now in the ranks. When their knapsacks are turned out a good provision of sketches will probable be found to constitute a part of the kit. An artist is never to much pleased that the he cannot take a sketch. BOGARTH and many others used to turn the nail of their thumb into a cartoon. Many a rough idea of a great work has been limned on that brief ceaves. With such means, or better, readily at hand, we may at none future day expect a fine supply of rough materials. The war, sooner or later, will be illustrated perfectly. At the exhibition of next year, or the year after. we shall be called upon, like Uncle Toby, to fight all our battles over again.

At the exhibition of next year, or the year after. we shall be called upon, like Uncle Toby, to fight all our battles over again.

abstract: SINGULAR DEATH. -- ERMIL DIVERBOIS, late of the Garibaldi Guard, died at the New-York Hospital yesterday, from the effects of a wound received in a very singular manner. On Wednesday last deceased attempted to draw the retired from the barrel of his rifle, which was rusty on the inside of the barrel so that the rod stock fast. In trying to remove it, the rod was suddenly and unaccountable forced out of the barrel with such force that its upper and entered the nostril of deceased, and passing up through the nose, penetrated the brain. Coronel SCHIRMER was noticed to hold an inquest.

abstract: It will be recollected that on the 30th day of April last, the body of a man was found floating in the water near the dock at the foot of Weehauken Hill, under circumstances which led to the belief that he had been murdered. The body was taken in charge by Coroner BORDSTEDT, of Hoboken, and upon examination it was found that he had been shot and stabbed. The ball entered the left breast and passed through the heart; a knife wound was also found on the right arm. A sinsular circumstance was the fact that the ball and knife wounds took effect against the naked skin, as the garments were not pierced, and the coat, vest and shirt were all buttoned up.

abstract: The controversy between Chief Justice TANEY and Gen. CASWALLADER is in all respects unfortunate. A collision of civil and military authority is always to be, if possible, shunned; because the majesty of law must, in all cases, succumb to the necessities of war, and the respect which the magistracy must assert for itself in a period of peace, is impaired by the sight of a fruitless struggle for supremacy at a period when military law is in the ascendant. In the case of JOHN MERRIMAN, the interposition of Chief Justice TANEY can only be regarded as at once officious and improper. If the questions of right in the matter had to be tested, there were other legal authorities, whose intervention would have been quite as effectual as that of the Chief Justice, before whom, should the case give rise to litigation, it may eventually come for final adjudication. The issue, moreover, was one to which the State of Maryland was a party, and which therefore should have been raised by a magistrate of that State. In thus energetically interposing, Judge TANEY presents the ungracious spectacle of a judicial and a military authority of the United States at variance, the soldier eager to punish, and the jurist to exculpate a traitor. The antithesis might have been very easily avoided; and an impression that the zeal of the Justice might have been less fervent, had not the prisoner been a citizen of has own State a neighbor, and a personal friend, would not have countenanced.

abstract: In olden times, when the Latin races poured forth their thousands to punish the infidel, history recorded their progress and their career of glory gave birth to a new word -- Chivalry. To-day, when the stake is greater than it was then, and when the word is in danger of losing its significance, we find the descendants of these heroic peoples true to their historic fame. Once mere they have buckled on their armor to succor the distressed, to rescue the helpless from captivity, to avenge a grievous wrong to the civilization of the age, and to make a name in the brilliant pages of the only pure history in the world. It is the privilege of the Garibaldi Guard to renew the great traditions of the several nationalities of which it is composed. Those who saw the noble battalions, as they filed down broadway yesterday, cannot doubt the manly strength that will do this. A finer body of men has not left the City. The majority have seen service in other fields; know what war means, and would not, except from that sense of duty which makes all men heroes, renew its horrors. But the cause for which they now fight is their own cause, and, we may depend upon it, they will make it good. No knightly behest is more sacred to them than the championship of the Union; no devoir more gallant than fighting for its preservation.

abstract: Matter of the Probate of the Will of Augusta J. Blankman. -- The proponents have commenced their evidence, rebutting the testimony offered by the contestants respecting the reliability of Mr. Kirkpatrick's statements. A number of witnesses were examined who testified that they would readily believe his testimony under oath. His character for truth and veracity was as good as that of most men. Some bad never heard it questioned. Proponents also offered testimony tending to show that the signature of the testatrix annexed to the Will was genuine.

abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF THE BROOKLYN SAHBATH SCHOOL UNION. The Thrity-second Anniversary of the Brooklyn Sabbath School Union was celebrated yesterday in an appropriate manner. The weather being pleasant, there was a large turn-out of scholars and teachers, numbering come 25,000.
lead_paragraph: ANNIVERSARY OF THE BROOKLYN SAHBATH SCHOOL UNION. -- The Thrity-second Anniversary of the Brooklyn Sabbath School Union was celebrated yesterday in an appropriate manner. The weather being pleasant, there was a large turn-out of scholars and teachers, numbering come 25,000. The schools were divided into two divisions, Western and Eastern; the former formed and countermarched on Remsen and [???] streets, to the music of Dodworth's Land, and the latter were concentrated on Fort Greene. In the Western Division, it is estimated that there were about 15,000 children, and in the Eastern Division there were 10 562 scholars and 500 teachers. The teachers and children carried numerous tiny National flags, and many wore Union rosettes and the "Star Spangled Banner" was sung with heartfelt spirit by all. After the parade, the Schools assembled in their respective churches, where there were suitable exercises, consisting of singing, reading of the Scriptures, and short addresses suitable to the occasion, nearly all of which were of a patriotic character. At the close of the exercises, the [???] partook of a collation and received presents. The whole demonstration passed off without a single accident. To day the Williamsburgh Schools and also those of Flatbush, will parade, if the weather is pleasant.

abstract: We learn that on Saturday evening about 9 o'clock, a party of about 40 persons visited the residence of Mr. WM. A. HARRIS, who has become somewhat notorious on account of the starvation of cattle in his barn, and three or four of them entering the house, informed Mr. HARRIS, who was just going to bed, that his carriage was in waiting and invited him to take a ride. Not liking the idea of such a ride as he suspected was in store for him, Mr. HARRIS declined to leave the house, when he was violently taken out doors and placed upon a rail which had been provided, when the party proceeded about three quarters of a mile towards the railroad depot with their victim. On the way, HARRIS was pelted with rotten eggs and any other disagreeable missile that could be laid hold of, and his clothes were stripped from him, while groans were given at frequent intervals, The crowd increased as the party proceeded and he became more and more excited. On reaching the residence of Mr. WM. O. COOLIDGE, that gentleman was aroused by the clamor of the rioters, and came out to see what the matter was, Mr. HARRIS fell from the rail at this point, and Mr. COOLIDGE picked him up, and discovering who he was, thrust him inside his gate, and bidding him flee for his life, closed the gate and forbade the crowd to enter his premises. HARRIT gladly took took to his heels, and reached his home by a rapid run across lots. No attempt was made to follow him by the crowd, which quietly dispersed after being addressed by Mr. COOLIDGE. The perpetrators of this ontrage were disguised. But for the timely interference of Mr. COOLIDGE, HARRIS would probably have met with more serious bodily injury. The proceedings were entirely unjustifiable, for Mr. HARRIS was in the grasp of the law, and were disgraceful to the perpetrators. Mr. HARRIS has been surrendered by his bondsmen, and is now In jail. -- Boston Traveler,May 27.

abstract: CONCERT IN AID OF THE IMPERIAL ZOUAVE REGIMENT. -- HORACE WATERS and his inimitable troops of young vocalists will be special request, repeat the Concert given last week, for the benefits of the above-named regiment, in the Church of the Paritan, (DECREEVER'S,) on Thursday night of this week. In addition to the singing of it the MARTHA DAVIS, MARTHA CORWIN, HENRY HAYDEN, and the other singers, G.C. Bingham, Esq., the Quartermaster of the regiment, will sing old fantastic song, entitled "Union and Liberty," composed in the year 1798. Prof. ABBOTT will preside at the organ. Admission, 25 cents.

abstract: Sergeant F.B. MARSHALL, of Company A, First Regiment New-York Zouaves, who has just come from Washington, gives the most positive assurances that there is no truth whatever in the rumor that two of the regiment had been condemned to be shot. The report originated in the re-arrest of four members of the regiment who had been dismissed from the ranks and their uniforms taken from them.

abstract: In obedience to the fourteenth resolution of the Convention which met in this city, on the 13th inst., we earnestly conjure you to enter actively and immediately upon the great work of preparing your neighbors and friends, as well as yourselves, for the firm, stern and decided stand necessary to be taken and adhered to at all hazards, and maintained at any and every cost, if we would preserve to ourselves and transmit to our posterity, that unity of government which constitutes us one people, which we justly regard as a palladium of our liberties and the main pillar in the edifice of our independence. In this way and this way alone, we can save ourselves from the innumerable evils consequent upon secession and all the horrors of civil war.

In this way and this way alone, we can save ourselves from the innumerable evils consequent upon secession and all the horrors of civil war.

abstract: A YOUNG SPORT. -- A lad, 14 years of age, named ZACARIAN. was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, on Wednesday morning, charged with having stolen $25 from his mother, Mrs. LETITIA MALONE, of No. 120 Coles-street, on the day previous. Mrs. MALONE is the woman arrested a few days since, charged with keeping a disorderly house for the resort of vile persons. ZAC, who was born in Vera Cruz, while his mother was a camp follower in the Mexican war, after getting the money went to Elizabeth, taking with him a companion. At that place ZAC attracted considerable attention from the lavish manner of expenditures for refreshments, and he was accordingly taken into custody and brought to Jersey City, On his person was found about $3 and a pistol and ammunition. The boy claimed that the money was his own, it being interest of money left to him by his father. A few years since ZAC was kidnapped from Philadelphia, and was held as a slave in Maryland for six years, when be was finally traced out and released by his mother. He will be provided for.

abstract: The question raised in the Sunday theatre cases, as to the constitutionality of the act of 1860, "To promote the public peace and order on Sunday," was argued in February, and decided yesterday, at the General Term of the Supreme Court, Judge ALLEN presiding, all the Judges concurring. The opinion is understood to be very elaborate, and will add to the well-earned reputation of the able Jurist whose attention has been given to this important subject. It is not known whether the counsel for the theatres will carry the case to the Court of Appeals. There would not seem to be much encouragement to contest further a statute uniformly sustained by the lower courts; but the friends of law and morals would not be reluctant to have that last step taken and thus settle the question for generations. Meanwhile it is certainly desirable that this and kindred statutes for the preservation of valued civil rights should be faithfully enforced, as is the evident purpose of our Police authorities.
lead_paragraph: The question raised in the Sunday theatre cases, as to the constitutionality of the act of 1860, "To promote the public peace and order on Sunday," was argued in February, and decided yesterday, at the General Term of the Supreme Court, Judge ALLEN presiding, all the Judges concurring. abstract: The United States transport Empire City, Capt. BROWN, arrived yesterday afternoon from Fortress Monroe, where she landed the Seventh Regiment New-York State Volunteers. The Empire City left her dock foot of Warren street, an Saturday, 24th inst., at 6:30 P.M., bound to Fortress Monroe, having on board the Steuben Regiment (Seventh) New-York State Volunteers, 800 rank and file, Col. BONDIX.
lead_paragraph: The United States transport Empire City, Capt. BROWN, arrived yesterday afternoon from Fortress Monroe, where she landed the Seventh Regiment New-York State Volunteers. The Empire City left her dock foot of Warren street, an Saturday, 24th inst., at 6:30 P.M., bound to Fortress Monroe, having on board the Steuben Regiment (Seventh) New-York State Volunteers, 800 rank and file, Col. BONDIX. Nothing of moment transpired on the passage, except some severe squalls of rain which wet some of the troops through and through, which they bore without a murmur. Capt. BROWN asserts that a finer body of men he never carried in his vessel, their discipline being equal if not superior to any he ever saw. Many of the officers have seen service in the battle-fields of Europe.

abstract: The most important intelligence from Washington, which we publish, this morning, is in reference to the position Great Britain is likely to oc. cupy towards the Jeff. Davis Government in the pending contest.
lead_paragraph: The most important intelligence from Washington, which we publish, this morning, is in reference to the position Great Britain is likely to oc. cupy towards the Jeff. Davis Government in the pending contest. No official dispatches were received by the last steamer from the new American Ministers at London and Paris, Messrs. ADAMS and DAYTON, but from the nature of the private advices received by the Administration, there is reason to believe that the views of the British Government have become considerably modified, and that it is rapidly becoming cured of its apparent penchant for rebellion, even when Cotton stands behind it, or is supposed to do so. It is likely that official advices will be received, both from London and Paris, by the next steamer. The Federal troops in Virginia are still engaged in intrenching themselves, and the works are proceeding with remarkable rapidity.

abstract: The farm mortgages, in aid of the Wisconsin Railroads, amount to an immense aggregate, and the stocks, which the farmers took in exchange, have turned out worthless. Resistance in the payment of the mortgages has become almost general; and the State has interposed stay laws to delay the foreclosure. An action was recently brought to foreclose one of the mortgages, and this stay law was appealed to. Judge MCARTHUR, of the Milwaukee Circuit Court pronounced the law unconstitutional, as clearly tending to impair the "obligation of contracts." This is in conformity with previous decisions in other States. As Wisconsin proposes to borrow money for war purposes, the decision is necessary to her credit.
