abstract: There is occasion no longer for exhortations to action. The advices, which one day adds to another, show how cautiously, but steadily and certainly our Government is moving toward the results for which the people have been clamorous; and that it omits from its plans, no element of strength, or assurance of success, which patriotism or talent throws within its reach.
lead_paragraph: There is occasion no longer for exhortations to action. The advices, which one day adds to another, show how cautiously, but steadily and certainly our Government is moving toward the results for which the people have been clamorous; and that it omits from its plans, no element of strength, or assurance of success, which patriotism or talent throws within its reach. The movement is rapid, systematic and safe. Maryland having been manacled and placed aside, not only Washington, but all the various communications between Washington and the loyal States have been secured. Fortress Monroe has not only been, armed and garrisoned to the full extent of its vast capacity, but it has been made the point d'appui of the left wing of the army, which is to Marylandize Virginia. Already Gen. BUTLER has advanced far enough on the road to Richmond to command at Newport News the passage of James River, thus cutting off water communication between the rebels at Norfolk and the head-quarters at the State Capital. His movements up the peninsula will only be delayed by the necessity of waiting for those large reinforcements which are on their way to join his division, or by the opposition of the enemy in superior numbers.

abstract: The commissariat of an army has never yet been complete in the organized military power of any nation. It is the last one that is provided for, and the first one that should be thought of. No nation in history ever lacked fighting men.
lead_paragraph: The commissariat of an army has never yet been complete in the organized military power of any nation. It is the last one that is provided for, and the first one that should be thought of. No nation in history ever lacked fighting men. No nation ever has sent a perfectly equipped army into a campaign -- equipment meaning everything needed to eat, and drink, and wear, and sleep with, and fight in any emergency. Starvation has reduced the strongest garrisons. Men cannot fight on empty stomachs. Demoralization in armies grows up, in most instances, from incompleteness in the Commissariat. Men cannot fight in a campaign without the means of fighting, any better than a mechanic can work without tools and materials.

abstract: By the Politeness of Dr. GARRISH, a large number of medical men were convened at his residence, No.40 West Twenty-first-street, on Monday evening, for the purpose of observing the sanitary arrangements of the Fifty-fifth French Regiment, of this City, Col. Ln. GAL and several of his staff being present to demonstrate it.
lead_paragraph: By the Politeness of Dr. GARRISH, a large number of medical men were convened at his residence, No.40 West Twenty-first-street, on Monday evening, for the purpose of observing the sanitary arrangements of the Fifty-fifth French Regiment, of this City, Col. Ln. GAL and several of his staff being present to demonstrate it. The first object of note was the ambulance, made after the latent pattern used in the French Army in Algeria and the Crimea. This ambulance is an omnibus chaped vehicle, to be drawn by two or more horses, weighing some twelve hundred pounds, but constructed in such a manner that it it may be easily detached, separated in several pieces in the interior, the most important portion easily carried by several man, The interior is, when fully standing, a row of beds, carrying six or eight men with great ease, but when crowded, may be forced to transport three times that number. Each bed is a " field-astretcher," or portable cot, which takes the wounded man from the field, and without any fatiguing change, places him in this portable hospital. An india-rubber ball is also attached.

abstract: JOHN MERRIMAN, a citizen of Baltimore, was made prisoner the other day by the military authorities and confined at Fort McHenry. He had held a commission as Lieutenant in the rebel forces, and the company in which he served was armed with guns stolen from the Government arsenals.
lead_paragraph: JOHN MERRIMAN, a citizen of Baltimore, was made prisoner the other day by the military authorities and confined at Fort McHenry. He had held a commission as Lieutenant in the rebel forces, and the company in which he served was armed with guns stolen from the Government arsenals. He was active in inciting the revolt which resulted in the murder of the Massachusetts soldiers in the streets of Baltimore, and he was taken while his hands were scarcely washed of the blood of those brave men to whose massacre he was accessory. He was the principal agent in the destruction of the bridges between Baltimore and Washington, which cut off the communication between those two cities. He was busy in attempting to organize the military of Baltimore against the Federal forces, -- and for these offences he was arrested.

abstract: However much we have felt aggrieved by the tone adopted toward us by foreign nations and their public journals, we may calculate with almost entire certainty, if not upon their friendly offices, at least upon more decided expressions of their good-will in our contest with the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: However much we have felt aggrieved by the tone adopted toward us by foreign nations and their public journals, we may calculate with almost entire certainty, if not upon their friendly offices, at least upon more decided expressions of their good-will in our contest with the rebellion. Commercial nations cannot afford to have this contest continue; and they must soon discover there is no way of speedily ending it but by siding with our Government. Till we triumph, and order is restored, a first-class nation is a blank in commercial circles. Our gross foreign trade the past year equaled very nearly $800,000,000. This is no inconsiderable fraction of the international commerce of the world. To blot out from the system the United States, would hurl the others from their spheres. In less than a month's time all foreign nations will see that resistance to the power of our Government is hopeless; that the submission or subjection of the rebels is simply a question of time; and that the only way in which they can save themselves from excessive losses and embarrassment, is to aid us in putting an immediate end to the struggle, Every echo we get of news from this side must have a more friendly tone. We have already decided indications of such change. Even the London Times has adopted towards us the language characteristic of gentlemen, and no longer sees us glistening in paint, nor displaying the tomahawk and scalping-knife as symbols of our mode of warfare. A week ago it told us that our Confederacy was hopelessly dissolved; the latest arrival predicts an arduous struggle, and implicitly admits the overwhelming power of the Government, which a short time previously it thought probable would be chased from its Capital!
headline: {'main': 'The Better Tone of Foreign Sentiment.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Better Tone of Foreign Sentiment.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge ALLEN, the District-Attorney moved on the trials of Harbor-masters Marsten and Van Ness, indicted for taking illegal fees. abstract: The organization of the Eleventh and Twelfth Infantry, and their enrollment on the books of the Regular Army of the United States, makes it consist of twenty-one full regiments, instead of nineteen, as heretofore. The military force of regulars is, therefore, at present, as follows: Twelve regiments of Infantry; four of Artillery; one of Mounted Riflemen, and two of Dragoons. The commissions of the officers transferred with the volunteers have been made out, given to them, and registered.

abstract: Letters to the Southern papers do not agree regarding the transferral of the Capital to Richmond. The correspondent of the Picayune says that JEFF. DAVIS vetoed the project, while that of the Mobile Advertiser, writing later, says nothing of this but states that the vote of Arkansas carried it. There seems to be a serious disagreement in the Cabinet of JEFF. DAVIS, for some reason or other, and it was rumored that all the members intended to resign. abstract: The experience of nearly a century of domestic quiet, the apparent absence of causes of internal disturbance, and the traditional foreign policy of our Government "peace with all nations; entangling alliances with none" had led our people to the belief that we were an exception to the rule which requires other nations to maintain a large standing army to act either as local police, or to resist foreign aggression.
lead_paragraph: The experience of nearly a century of domestic quiet, the apparent absence of causes of internal disturbance, and the traditional foreign policy of our Government "peace with all nations; entangling alliances with none" -- had led our people to the belief that we were an exception to the rule which requires other nations to maintain a large standing army to act either as local police, or to resist foreign aggression. We are suddenly awakened from this dream. At the very moment our faith was the strongest in the permanence of our happy condition, we were nursing in our very bosom a treason which, for a time, threatened to blot us out from the list of nations. We recovered from the stunning blow, and, with unexampled celerity, placed a hundred thousand men in the field, to be immediately followed by another hundred thousand. Our first task is to subdue; next to preserve order. This for a time must be an enforced one. The great element of discord still remains, and must be watched by a powerful force. Confidence is a sentiment of slow growth, and it takes an equally long time for a subdued party to forget its defeats and heartily fraternize with the conquerors. We shall gladly extend amnesty to all who lay down their arms; but we can never again allow ourselves to be surprised and nearly overthrown. If Slavery remains undisturbed, we must not forget that it has been the sole cause of the rebellion, and may breed further disturbance. Men brought up under its influence differ radically from those nurtured in freedom. This natural divergence must be counteracted, as far as necessary, by force. Should the slave be partially freed, we must remember that he is of different race from ourselves; that there will soon be 5,000,000 of them within our borders, rendering necessary, by way of precaution, a strong arm to meet our anomalous condition which unites the totally different races under one Government.

abstract: We have already intimated that the insurgent army is distributed among so many isolated points, so far removed, each from the other, that their communications will be at the mercy of our own commander, and that, consequently, these remote and isolated positions cannot be successfully held.
lead_paragraph: We have already intimated that the insurgent army is distributed among so many isolated points, so far removed, each from the other, that their communications will be at the mercy of our own commander, and that, consequently, these remote and isolated positions cannot be successfully held. We shall not attempt to speculate on the particular moves which the experience of Gen. SCOTT, and able officers associated under his command, may intend first to make from the plains of Alexandria, where a part of his army of volunteers is now encamped. It is sufficient to say, on this point, that whether the next advance is to be directed towards the Valley of Virginia, with a view to take the force at Harper's Ferry in the rear, or towards Fredericksburgh, with the intention of crossing the Rappahannock, where it is fordable, and cutting off the isolated encampments at Fredericksburgh and Aquia Creek; or directly upon Richmond or Lynchburgh -- the move made during the night of the 23d would be the necessary incipient step. We shall assume, therefore, as the prevailing supposition, that the first object of this formidable demonstration will be to "repossess" the Government's property at Harper's Ferry, and capture the army of rebels and outlaws which now holds it -- an object which will most assuredly come in its turn, if that army long continues to occupy its present position, whether that be the first or the succeeding effort of the Administration.

abstract: A telegram at Halifax, N.S., from St Johns N.F., on Monday, states that the roughs had fired the dwelling house and out buildings of the Hon., H.W. [???] Attorney General and leader of the Government which were burned to the ground. Troops had been sent from Halifax to St Johns, is the mall steamer Delta, but a rumor prevailed that their debarkation has been prevented by the mob, armed with sealing guns, a formidable weapon with the use of which they are, from their occupation, very familiar. There is reliance to be pleased upon this rumor, and prevailed too soon to be authentic, for the Delta would not reach St. Johns before Monday afternoon, and judging from the time latterly taken to forward messages, the news would not be received in Halifax before Tuesday night. Besides, the presence of a [???] of regulars, in forts commanding the town would render a proceeding of this kind absolution insanity on the part of the mob. Her Majesty's steamer Hyora left Halifax on Saturday last with a second attachment of troops for St. Johns. We are assured that no more competent person that the present Executive officer of the island, Sir A. [???], could be in authority at this juncture, and that everything that can be done to restore order will be accomplished by him, and the Government lately lately indorsed by the people. -- Boston Traveler, May 25.

abstract: SALE OF PICTURES FOR THE PATRIOTIC FUND. The large and handsome collection of paintings contributed by the artists of New-York to the General "Patriotic Fund," was brought under the hammer yesterday, by HENRY H. LEEDS CO., in the Rotunda of the Merchants' Exchange.
lead_paragraph: SALE OF PICTURES FOR THE PATRIOTIC FUND. -- The large and handsome collection of paintings contributed by the artists of New-York to the General "Patriotic Fund," was brought under the hammer yesterday, by HENRY H. LEEDS & CO., in the Rotunda of the Merchants' Exchange. There was a very good attendance, and contrary to general expectation the prices realized were excellent, considering the stringency of the times. Towards the close there was a little flagging, but the sale most be regarded as a complete success, and can hardly fail to give satisfaction to the liberal artists who have so cheerfully contributed their labor and talent to the cause. Upwards of four thousand dollars will be added to the fund by this sale. The first blood was drawn by Wm. Hart's picture called "Moonlight on the Grand Menau," which reached $100, and was knocked down amidst much applause. Inman's "Black your Boots, Sir" brought $45; Casilear's "Swiss Mountains," $85; Gignoux's "Niagara," after a brisk competition in ten-dollar bids, was sold for $160; Beard's "Reflection". only brought $60, and his caricature, "Beef for the Southern Army," $37 50; "Cumaeir Sibyl," by Louis Lang, $100, (there was only one bid for it;) "Homeward through the Stream," by A.F. Bellows, $140; "A Foxy Morning," by Eastman Johnson, $105; two landscapes, by Keneett, brought respectively $100 and $105; "Paolina," by H.P. Gray, $80; "Happy Summer-time," by G.A. Baker. $150; "Alps." by, Casilear, $77 50; "Study." by Durand, $110; "Beatrice." by Hunting-don, $115; "The Life-Boat," by Warren, $00; "Death of Scipio," original drawing, by Darley, $73 These were the principal items; the others ranged from $45 down to $5. One hundred and thirteen pictures were disposed of Mr. JOHN H. GOURLEY was called to the chair, in the absence of Gen. Div., who was "expected to be present. He made a few remarks appropriate to the occasion and complimentary to the artists, concluding with an acceptable proposition for three cheers, which were given with great good will.

abstract: The sales of Cotton for the week foot up 47,000 bales, of which speculators took 9,500 bales, and exporters 10,000 bales. The market closed dull, at a decline of 1/4d. on the lower qualities, and of 1/8d. on middling. There was no pressure to sell at the decline. The sales yesterday (Friday) reached 10,000 bales, of which 3,000 bales were taken on speculation and for export. The market closed quiet and steadler at the following authorized quotations: Orleans fair, 8 3/8d.; do. middling, 7 3/4d.; Mobile fair, 8 1/8d.; do. middling, 7 9-16d.; Upland fair, 8 1/8d.; do. middling, 7 9-16d.

abstract: It is doubtful whether the annals of any nation, however uncivilized, can furnish a system of warfare so illicit as that which defaces the infant record of the Southern Confederacy. We find renegades from our Government furnishing to the Commissariat of the Southern forces stolen arms, "appropriated" funds and "attached" artillery.
lead_paragraph: It is doubtful whether the annals of any nation, however uncivilized, can furnish a system of warfare so illicit as that which defaces the infant record of the Southern Confederacy. We find renegades from our Government furnishing to the Commissariat of the Southern forces stolen arms, "appropriated" funds and "attached" artillery. Timid tradesmen are compelled to abuse the confidence of trusting creditors at the North, while the moneys honestly due here are placed to the credit of the enemies of the country. Officers, who for years have in time of peace been generously supported from the treasury of the nation, are seduced from honor and the sacredness of their oath by the promise of promotion and an increase of compensation.

abstract: It is now only six weeks since Mr. LINCOLN issued his proclamation calling for volunteers for the defence of the Capital. The same act that led to this step precipitated Virginia into secession. This was effected for the purpose of adding a strength to the movement which would, as it was believed, render it invincible, and to transfer the seat of the war from the cotton to the food-producing districts. The rebels elected to make this State their battle-ground. The Government accepted the challenge, and, to-day, has one hundred thousand men either upon, or who are swiftly advancing towards the soil of this State, and directed by the ablest commander of his time. This force is well equipped, abundantly supplied with munitions of war, and sustained by the entire financial strength of the North. If it is not so thoroughly trained as the veterans that compose European armies, it will be opposed to troops, who, whatever may be their personal courage or endurance, are vastly inferior in soldierly qualities to those of the North. With equal numbers it is discipline that wins, and this is the last quality of which Southern soldiers are capable. In the Slave States the whites, no matter how poor, must have something to mark the wide difference between them and an inferior and degraded caste. This is personal equality among themselves. It is the negro's business to obey, to take a subordinate position -- not the white man's. Hence their incapacity for that high degree of discipline to which Northern soldiers readily submit, because to them it implies nothing unmanly or degrading.

abstract: The case of America has again been considered in the House of Lords, and with pretty much the same degree of intelligence as characterized previous discussions of the same problem. The subject is clearly beyond the reach of their Lordships. The disposition of all the debaters, is evidently to so interpret the neutrality of England, as to make it most efficacious in aid of the Confederate rebels;
lead_paragraph: The case of America has again been considered in the House of Lords, and with pretty much the same degree of intelligence as characterized previous discussions of the same problem. The subject is clearly beyond the reach of their Lordships. The disposition of all the debaters, is evidently to so interpret the neutrality of England, as to make it most efficacious in aid of the Confederate rebels; and we accordingly find Lord Chancellors and Ex-Chancellors declaring the doctrine of this Government, that privateering is piracy, to be inadmissible; and Law Lords announcing that the execution of a British subject under such an interpretation, would be a ground of war. A similar willingness to weaken the power of the Federal Government, by demonstrating that a blockade which foreign Powers are bound to respect cannot be established, is also sufficiently discernible in the meagre abstract of the debate supplied by our telegrams, and will no doubt appear in broader light when we receive the extended report.

abstract: It is evident from the tenor of our advices from Washington this morning, that the Government is about to make another important forward movement into Virginia, but in what direction, is of course, known only to those who direct.
lead_paragraph: It is evident from the tenor of our advices from Washington this morning, that the Government is about to make another important forward movement into Virginia, but in what direction, is of course, known only to those who direct. The New-York Regiments which have recently reached the Capital, including the Ninth, which has a splendid engineer corps attached, and the Garibaldi Guard, which is composed in great part of veterans of several of the European wars, have received intimations that their services will be immediately required on important duty, and the regiments of the District volunteers last night were ordered under arms, with directions to make preparations for a long march. It is stated, also, that eleven steamers are at the Washington Navy-yard, laying in stores and munitions of all kinds, the destination of which is at present a mystery. It is probable able that a demonstration will be made upon Centreville, where about four thousand rebel troops are stationed, and which is a point of considerable importance. Meantime our troops at Alexandria have commenced throwing up entrenchments about a mile to the west of that city, to command the approaches, in anticipation of a possible demonstration from the rebels of Manassas Gap Junction, which has been threatened.

abstract: The volunteers, as already announced, have been placed on the same footing as regards the regulars, relative to clothing. The following information is therefore published for their instruction. Private
lead_paragraph: The volunteers, as already announced, have been placed on the same footing as regards the regulars, relative to clothing. The following information is therefore published for their instruction. Private army soldiers are allowed one uniform hat each year, price $1; 1 forage cap each year, price 57 cents; 1 uniform coat each year, price $6 56; 3 pair of trowsers the first year; 2 the second, and 3 the third, price $2 82 per pair; 2 sack coats each year, price each $2 10; 3 flannel shirts each year, price 90 cents each; 1 overcoat in 5 years, price $6 40; 3 pairs of drawers the first year, two every other year, price 71 cents each; 4 pair of brogans each year, price $2 20 per pair; 2 blankets in five years, price $2 44 each. These are a variety of other articles supplied, but there are the chief ones. In order to encourage economy, and cleanliness among the troops, every article not drawn according to the allowance, will be paid for to the soldier. So every man now in the ranks will probably receive pay for the clothes he wears, as they were not furnished by the Bureau of Clothing.

abstract: That indomitable patriot, President JACKSON, had, in his day, to deal with secession. It was then called Nullification; but it was in its elements secession pure and simple. He designated it by its right name when he denounced it as treason, and he appreciated its nature when he dealt with it as such. Had he been made of different stuff; had he been less imbued with patriotism; had he lacked courage; had he been weak of purpose, or imbecile from age; had he sympathized with their objects, or for years associated with the conspirators, taken them to his counsels, or yielded to their influences; had he been content with entreaty where he had the right to command; there would have been rebellion in his time under the auspices of CALHOUN and his followers, as we have it now under the guidance of FEFF DAVIS and his associates. But a Jackson, and not a Buchanan, was at the head of the State, and he waited not an hour for treason to gather strength. He throttled it at once. The sword and the gallows were waiting the conspirators, and sharp justice was ready with its-retribution. Treason shrunk dismayed at these preparations, and the repose of the country was secured by the man who saved it at New-Orleans.
lead_paragraph: That indomitable patriot, President JACKSON, had, in his day, to deal with secession. It was then called Nullification; but it was in its elements secession pure and simple. abstract: -- The law of contraband threatens to work one piece of justice not wholly unpoetical. It is said that the export of paper to the seceded States has, under order of Government, been entirely stopped! Not a team, as we are credibly informed, is now permitted to cross the Ohio. And as it is well known that the greater part of the paper consumed in the South hitherto has been of Northern manufacture, it is easy to see what the result must be. There are, indeed, a few paper mills in the seceded States; but these, for the want of necessary materials, are on the point of ceasing operations. The chemicals, which are indispensable for the bleaching process, as soda-ash and sulphuric acid, are only produced in the North and in Europe, and the same is true of wire, gauze and feltings, all of which are absolute necessities. There is, indeed, but one article requisite in paper manufacture which they are likely soon to have in quite unwelcome abundance -- rags.

abstract: All persons are respectfully and earnestly requested not to send to army quarters, or moving stations, women of any age in search of employment, unless the want of these is announced by either letter or advertisement, there being no provision made by Government, or otherwise, for such persons. There are many who are anxious to join their friends, who believe that they will find readily remunerative employments. They arrive without means, either of support or for defraying return expenses; and so far from meeting fathers, brothers or husbands, may learn that their regiments are on the march to distant stations. The expense of providing for these ill-counseled, but well-intentioned and helpless persons in Washington falls inconveniently on individuals who are not willing to witness needless exposure or suffering. D.L. DIX.

abstract: Fortune has smiled upon Col. DURYEA'S Advance Guard thus far. Under sunny skies and over a smooth sea, the vessel that carries the Regiment and its fortunes has proceeded, until we are within an hours' sail of Fortress Monroe. If our Virginia experiences are as pleasant as those of our Alabama trip, we shall have nothing to complain of.

abstract: DODWORTH'S SALOON.--In the present paucity of amusements and, we may add, disinclination for them, a first rate concert is as unexpected as it is agreeable. The drum for the moment supplies all our musical need, and managers who hate its imperative roll generally avoid a direct competition with it.
lead_paragraph: DODWORTH's SALOON. -- In the present paucity of amusements and, we may add, disinclination for them, a first rate concert is as unexpected as it is agreeable. The drum for the moment supplies all our musical need, and managers who hate its imperative roll generally avoid a direct competition with it. Mr. MAX STRAKOSCH, who has just entered into the business of management, and already displays that admirable quality of success, called enterprise, determined, it seems, to fight the drum on its own grounds. He announced a concert which was excellent in quality. It attracted an overflowing audience, and he may now retire to the Provinces in triumph. This great and unexpected event came off last evening at Dodworth's Saloon. Miss CARLOTTA PATTI was the principal attraction. She is a charming vocalist; posseses great facility of execution, and a thoroughly delicious quality of voice for the concert room. It would be difficult to mention another artiste who could give so much general satisfaction. In addition to this trump card, Mr. MAX STRAKOSCH boasts of the services of Signor BRIGNOLE, the favorite tenor of New-York; Madame AMALIA STRAKOSCH, Signor ETTORE BARILI and Mr. GEORGE W. WARREN. With such first class artists, it is his intention to make a Provincial tour in the West and Canada. If the times are not altogether too bad for such an enterprise, it will surely meet with much success.

abstract: All persons are respectfully and earnestly requested not to send to army quarters, or moving stations, women of any age in search of employment, unless the want of these is announced by either letter or advertisement, there being no provision made by Government, or otherwise, for such persons. There are many who are anxious to join their friends, who believe that they will find readily remunerative employments. They arrive without means, either of support or for defraying return expenses; and so far from meeting fathers, brothers or husbands, may learn that their regiments are on the march to distant stations. The expense of providing for these ill-counseled, but well-intentioned and helpless persons in Washington falls inconveniently on individuals who are not willing to witness needless exposure or suffering. D.L. DIX.

abstract: The Second Maine Regiment, Col. JAMISON, which has been temporarily quartered at Willett's Point, on the Sound, took their departure, yesterday afternoon. The promulgation of the order produced
lead_paragraph: The Second Maine Regiment, Col. JAMISON, which has been temporarily quartered at Willett's Point, on the Sound, took their departure, yesterday afternoon. The promulgation of the order produced intense delight among the men, some of whom were getting almost homesick, on account of their delay. At yesterday noon, the camp equippage had been packed, and soon after the troops had dined, every, thing was in readiness to move. The steamer Thomas Hunt, which was chartered for the purpose, arrived at the Point in time to receive the regiment on board at 3 o'clock P.M. They were conveyed directly to Jersey City, where they landed, and took the 6 P.M. train for Washington. The men had evidently improved in health and general appearance by their sojourn at Willett's Point. A large crowd assembled to meet them when they landed. A number of the citizens of Maine, who heard of their movement, went over to bid their friends good-bye. They went off in the best spirits. They will arrive in Washington this forenoon. The names of the officers have already been published.

abstract: The sales of Cotton for the week foot up 47,000 bales, of which speculators took 9,500 bales, and exporters 10,000 bales. The market closed dull, at a decline of 1/4d. on the lower qualities, and of 1/8d. on middling. There was no pressure to sell at the decline. The sales yesterday (Friday) reached 10,000 bales, of which 3,000 bales were taken on speculation and for export. The market closed quiet and steadier at the following authorized quotations: Orleans fair, 8 3/4d.; do. middling, 7 3/4d.; Mobile fair, 8 1/8d.; do. middling, 7 9-16d.; Upland fair, 8 1/8d.; do. middling, 7 9-16d.

abstract: The Louisville Journal, of May 27, publishes a summary of the testimony which Hon. GARRETT DAVIS was prevented from presenting to the Legislative Committee, appointed to investigate the statement that arms had been sent into the State for the use of the Union men. The Committee, it seems, knew the general purport of what Mr. DAVIS wished to tell them, and would not get together a quorum.
lead_paragraph: The Louisville Journal, of May 27, publishes a summary of the testimony which Hon. GARRETT DAVIS was prevented from presenting to the Legislative Committee, appointed to investigate the statement that arms had been sent into the State for the use of the Union men. The Committee, it seems, knew the general purport of what Mr. DAVIS wished to tell them, and would not get together a quorum. The Journal states that he had no information of any arms or ammunition having been "brought into the State without authority, of the laws thereof," as the inquiry suggested, or for any unlawful purpose whatever. While he considered that the Legislature had no light to institute such an inquiry as it proposed, he waived all these objections, and prepared his statement, with the intention of telling all that he knew. In his County, Bourbon, at appears that the Secessionists were very active. They sent an agent to New-Orleans who procured fifty stand of arms which were found to be to heavy for cavalry on their arrival at Paris, and which were consequently transferred to a foot company. The secession party had sent two other agents to JEFF, DAVIS to procure arms, who had returned without obtaining them. These facts were public and notorious, but no person ever objected to such efforts of the Secessionists of Bourbon to obtain arms for themselves, or to their perfect right to get them whenever and wherever they chose. There were two companies of the State Guard at Bourbon County; one of them, with its officers, were Secessionists, and had repudiated the Stars and Stripes, and for some week? had been drilling under the secession flag. Its Captain had posted up printed notices to the members to hold themselves in readiness for active-service; public recruiting was also going on in the neighboring counties for the Order of the Knights of the Golden Circle, and leaders of the party were openly declaring that when they got arms they would show whether Kentucky would secede or not -- that she would go out of the Union in sixty days, and that they would assist in hanging any man who would go to join the Army of the United States -- in chorus with the Louisville Courier, mark yon. They were warning good citizens, who were Union men, that they were "spotted," and the time would so on come when they would have to leave the country. Some Union men had already been notified to leave, and, for fear of violence, had gone, and some had been threatened with hanging, Mr. DAVIS was informed that threats in all these forms had been made against himself.

abstract: DEDICATION OF A MONUMENT BY THE SONS OF TEMPERANCE The Sons of Temperance, on Wednesday, the 29th inst., dedicated a large and very handsome monument, which has been recently erected at Cypress Hills Cemetery, to the memory of DANIEL H. SANDS, one of the founders of the Order. This monument enterprise has been the subject of active effort in the Order for the past two years, and has now reached a very successful consummation.
lead_paragraph: DEDICATION OF A MONUMENT BY THE SONS OF TEMPERANCE -- The Sons of Temperance, on Wednesday, the 29th inst., dedicated a large and very handsome monument, which has been recently erected at Cypress Hills Cemetery, to the memory of DANIEL H. SANDS, one of the founders of the Order. This monument enterprise has been the subject of active effort in the Order for the past two years, and has now reached a very successful consummation. Nearly $1,300 have been contributed by the Order of Sons of Temperance in the following States: New-York, New-Jersey, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Virginia, Maine, Ohio, North Carolina, Illinois, Rhode Island, Tennessee, Louisiana, Vermont, South Carolina, Missouri, Mississippi and California; also, by the British Provinces of New-Brunswick, the two Canadas. Nova Scotia, Prince Edward's Island and Newfoundland, and a small contribution all the way from England. This sum, through the liberality of Mr. HALL, the constructor of the monument, has produced a very large and really beautiful structure. It is of Italian marble, is of the obelisk style, 25 feet 3 inches in height, with a granite base of 5 feet 3 inches in breadth. The shaft itself is 17 feet in height. The only ornamental work on the monument, if we except the slab of California marble sent specially from Sands Division of Sacramento, are from raised triangles on the four sides of the shaft, and five feet from the shaft's base. Each triangle contains a raised star in its centre, and on the rim of each triangle is cut in raised letters, the motto of the Order -- "Love, Purity, Fidelity," respectively in English, Latin, French and German, the German, "Liebe, Lanterkeit, Treur," and beautifully executed in German text. The Committee of the Grand Division of Eastern New-York, through whom the Monument Fund was raised, and under whose direction the Monument was erected, are P.G.W.P. Wm. H. Armstrong of N.Y., and P.G.W.A. Alex. Campbell, of Brooklyn, and Wm. E. Macdonough, of New-York. A large concourse of the Divisions and members of the Order, with regalta and banners, was on the ground, and the special dedication service prepared for the occasion was duly performed. Prominent in the exercises were M.W.P. Dr. S.L. Condict and P.M.W.P. John W. Oliver, himself one of the sixteen founders of the Order, and P.G.W.P. Theo. L. Cuyler. Rev. J.B. Wakeley, Pastor of D.H. Sands, and who, seven years ago, preached his funeral sermon, also assisted. In the evening there was a public meeting in the Forsyth-street M.E. Church, of which Mr. Sands was a member when he died, and at which his funeral exercises took place. The M.W.P., Head of the Order in North America, presided. Addresses were delivered by Rev. J.B. Wakeley, A.C. Flanagan, John N. Steams, Mr. Cutter, of Poughkeepsie, and others, and excellent and appropriate singing by the Marshall Family and Mr. Macdonough's Glee Club. Altogether, Dedication Day will long be remembered by the Sons of Temperance hereabouts.

abstract: We have been so unused to war in this country, that it is with the greatest difficulty we can address ourselves to it in earnest. We forget that the more vigorous the more humane the blow. The moment we touch the soil of a seceding State, we should make clean work. Every rebel should be taken prisoner and instantly marched out of the State; the idea of letting him off on a parole of honor is a delusion which we should no longer practice upon ourselves. There is no honor in a rebel. Where was the honor of JEFF. DAVIS, FLOYD and THOMPSON, and the whole tribe of conspirators in Congress and the Army and Navy, who were plotting to overthrow the Constitution they had sworn to support? To treat such persons leniently only adds to their malignity. It is the nature of such men. If we let them off we shall, on the morrow, be always doing the work of the day before, and the war will never be ended. The moment a rebel is captured, particularly if in arms, he should be instantly packed off to the interior of Massachusetts, or New-York or Ohio, where extensive barracks should be immediately erected for his accommodation. We should clear the soil as we go, leaving no enemy among us, or in our rear, to take advantage of the least reverse. The moment this course is taken, traitors would be very scarce, even upon the soil of Virginia. We should hope to make a pretty good haul, for we could perform no more useful service than to take 20,000 Virginians and give them six months' schooling in the interior of Massachusetts. They would see things there they never dreamed of, and go home, when the time come for their discharge, wiser men, and fitted to introduce in their own State the industries and habits which have made in Massachusetts a garden out of a desert, and for the want of which Virginia, though a garden by nature, is still a desert, as far as art and industry are concerned.

We should clear the soil as we go, leaving no enemy among us, or in our rear, to take advantage of the least reverse. The moment this course is taken, traitors would be very scarce, even upon the soil of Virginia. We should hope to make a pretty good haul, for we could perform no more useful service than to take 20,000 Virginians and give them six months' schooling in the interior of Massachusetts. They would see things there they never dreamed of, and go home, when the time come for their discharge, wiser men, and fitted to introduce in their own State the industries and habits which have made in Massachusetts a garden out of a desert, and for the want of which Virginia, though a garden by nature, is still a desert, as far as art and industry are concerned.

abstract: The Second Maine Regiment, Col. JAMISON, which has been temporarily quartered at Willett's Point, on the Sound, took their departure, yesterday afternoon. The promulgation of the order produced intense delight among the men, some of whom were getting almost homesick, on account of their delay. At yesterday noon, the camp equippage had been packed, and soon after the troops had dined, every, thing was in readiness to move. The steamer Thomas Hunt, which was chartered for the purpose, arrived at the Point in time to receive the regiment on board at 3 o'clock P. M. They were conveyed directly to Jersey City, where they landed, and took the 6 P. M. train for Washington. The men had evidently improved in health and general appearance by their sojourn at Willett's Point. A large crowd assembled to meet them when they landed. A number of the citizens of Maine, who heard of their movement, went over to bid their friends good-bye. They went off in the best spirits. They will arrive in Washington this forenoon. The names of the officers have already been published.

abstract: The steamer Adelaine, from Old Point Comfort, arrived here this morning, and reports all quiet-there.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Thursday, May 30.

abstract: NEWSPORT. May 30. -- The brig Alpine, Killman, from New-Orleans, bound to Bordeaux, has put in here with loss of suits. Will repair immediately, and proceed. -- (By telegraph)
lead_paragraph: NEWSPORT. May 30. -- The brig Alpine, Killman, from New-Orleans, bound to Bordeaux, has put in here with loss of suits. Will repair immediately, and proceed. -- (By telegraph)
